DOC.HEAD: Five Dead, 54 Wounded after Blackout Following Haiti Rally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with toll of wounded to 54 sted 43, details, editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Gunmen killed at least five people and wounded 54 Wednesday night following a campaign rally by a radical priest who is front-runner in the Dec. 16 presidential elections, radio reports and witnesses said. The violence by unknown assailants in Petionville, seven miles outside the capital of Port-au-Prince, occurred during a 10-minute blackout at about 7:30 p.m., after the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide spoke to about 10,000 people. Aristide is considered a hero of the young and poor in this violence-prone Caribbean island nation of 6 million people. Haiti is the poorest country in the Western hemisphere. Aristide, 37, was reported unharmed. He has survived at least three assassination attempts since 1987. Witnesses said men in a jeep drove moments after the blackout and that a big explosion was followed by gunfire. ``It happened during the blackout. There was a big boom. We ran, and while we were running there was shooting. The lights went on after,'' said one witness, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Hundreds of people ran screaming down the streets after the explosion rocked the affluent suburb. Scores of people fell to the ground. Witnesses and Radio Metropole said five people died and 54 were wounded. What caused the blast was not known, nor was it known if the violence was directly aimed at Aristide or meant to cow supporters into not voting for him. Minister of Interior Joseph Maxi said, ``All necessary steps have been taken, and an investigation has been opened.'' Dr. Robert Jean Louis, a physician treating wounded at the scene, said all the victims appeared to have been shot. He said one woman he hoisted into an ambulance died of bullet wounds. In nearby Delmas, the party headquarters of the Movement to Organize the Country also was broken into by three men, the offices ransacked and its guard severely beaten, witnesses said. The Movement supports Aristide's candidacy. This was the first election-related violence since the presidential campaign began in October. In November 1987 elections, at least 34 people were killed by thugs at the polling stations. Hundreds had died during the campaign in political violence. Wednesday's violence darkened hopes Haiti could at last have democratic elections, the first in the country's 186-year-old history. More than 400 observers, including former President Jimmy Carter and about 60 unarmed U.N. military advisers, were to monitor the balloting. Haiti is the first U.N. member to ask the world body to observe balloting. The country has been rocked by violence and political turmoil since the fall of President-for-life Jean-Claude Duvalier. His flight into exile in France in 1986 ended 29 years of Duvalier family dictatorship that began with his late father Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier in 1957. The interim government of President Ertha Pascal Trouillot, appointed in March, is the fifth since Duvalier's fall. An ardent critic of Duvalier while he was in power, Aristide has many enemies in hard-line Duvalierist circles. He reluctantly became a candidate at the prompting of a center-left organization which sought to offset the candidacy of Roger Lafontant, reputed head of the Tonton Macoutes, the feared secret militia of the Duvaliers. Lafontant came back from exile in July to run for president. The Electoral Council disqualified him for technical reasons but he vowed at the time to fight the decision. A former Salesian priest, Aristide was expelled from the conservative Roman Catholic order in December 1988 for allegedly fomenting revolution. Three months earlier, hoodlums backed by the army stormed into his Saint Jean Bosco Church and killed at least 12 parishioners. Aristide was shielded by his flock and unharmed. His critics accuse Aristide of demagoguery. They say his presidency is based on emotional appeal and would pose the threat of a theocratic dictatorship. Many Haitiians had feared Aristide's candidacy would provoke new violence.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Urges Security Council to Send Staff to Protest Palestinians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 9 grafs to UPDATE with reports that the United States is urging consideration of regional peace conference; pickup graf 17 pvs `He told...'
DOC.TEXT: The Palestine Liberation Organization on Wednesday urged the Security Council to send U.N. staff to the Israel-occupied territories to help protect Palestinians. The United States, however, could veto any resolution calling for deployment of U.N. personnel, appointment of an ombudsman or convening of an international human rights convention to help the Palestinians. Negotiations were continuing in efforts to devise a draft resolution that could be adopted by consensus, or avert a U.S. veto in defense of its Israeli ally. The British Broadcasting Corp. reported the United States has proposed that the Security Council consider convening a broad Middle East peace conference. The idea was discussed at a meeting of the five permanent members of the council, who agreed to it, said the BBC, attributing its report to unidentified diplomatic sources. The New York Times reported in Thursday's editions th United States would not oppose a call for an international Middle East peace conference to settle the Palestinian question in a resolution criticizing Israel's treatment of Arabs in the territories. U.S. representative Thomas Pickering denied at midday Wednesday that Washington was making any proposal on the Palestinian issue. State Dept. spokesman David Denny said later he was aware of the BBC report but had no comment. Soviet Ambassador Yuli Vorontsov told reporters he did not expect a U.S. veto but declined to discuss details of a possible consensus resolution. The council was to meet against Thursday and could vote on a resolution on protecting Palestinians. ``I don't think there should be any question of a veto because we are working differently now ... on a consensus basis and that's a sign of the times.'' After more than three months of close cooperation and consensus, he said, ``the council now is not interested in scoring points or in passing resolutions that will be vetoed by the other members.'' The Soviet envoy commented after informal consultations among the five permanent members, including the United States, Britain, China and France. He said the council was ``not interested in the resolutions, we are interested in solutions.'' Earlier Farouk Kaddoumi, the PLO foreign affairs spokesman, told the Security Council that it had a moral obligation to protect Palestinians from what he called Israeli crimes, like the shooting deaths of at least 19 Palestinians on Temple Mount on Oct. 8. He told the 15-member council that the United Nations should do no less for Palestinians under Israeli occupation than it has done for Kuwaitis under Iraqi occupation. ``We call upon your august council to establish a permanent presence of the United Nations and its personnel in the occupied Palestinian territories, in the context of an established mechanism, based on monitoring the situation and submitting periodic reports.'' His speech was delivered as the council continued an intermittent monthlong debate about how to help safeguard the rights of Palestinians in the Israeli- held territories. He also blamed the United States for protecting Israel ``and its criminal practices.'' He said that the contradiction between council actions in the case of Kuwaitis under occupation and its inaction in the case of Palestinians ``has come to jeopardize its credibility and prestige and to cast doubt on its potential to play its required role in our new world.'' Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar told reporters Wednesday that he intends to send his special envoy, Jean-Claude Aime, to Israel to discuss the Palestinian problem after the council concludes its debate this week. Several draft resolutions currently are in circulation and United States is meeting with various council members in an effort to find an acceptable resolution. PLO officials said if there is no agreement, then they will push for a vote Thursday on a tough resolution sponsored by Colombia, Cuba, Malaysia and Yemen. That resolution calls for the council to appoint an ombudsman to the territories ``to monitor and observe the situation, with the help of the U.N. personnel stationed there, and to report on it to the secretary-general and the Security Council.''

DOC.HEAD: Ozal Increasingly Isolated as Opposition to His Policies Mounts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: President Turgut Ozal, often praised by President Bush as a loyal ally for his strong support in the Persian Gulf crisis, is on slippery ground at home. The 63-year-old president is increasingly isolated, has little public support and often faces criticism from establishment groups and members of his own Motherland Party. The resignation of the chief of staff on Monday indicated Ozal also had alienated the military as well - the most powerful establishment group in Turkey. Gen. Necip Torumtay, who was succeeded Tuesday by Gen. Dogan Gures, stepped down not so much over a specific issue but to protest a style of government, sources close to the military said. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, Ozal has run a one-man show concerning Turkey's gulf policy, often bypassing Cabinet members and the Foreign Ministry. A few days after the invasion, for example, reporters told the foreign minister that pipelines carrying Iraqi crude oil through Turkey were being closed to comply with a U.N. trade embargo. In October, Foreign Minister Ali Bozer resigned. Defense Minister Safa Giray quit the next month. Some observers fear Ozal may lead Turkey into a Middle East war. ``Who else but Bush still supports Ozal's style of government?'' asked columnist Turker Alkan in the daily Gunes. ``Could a nation of 50 million be pushed into war behind the United States just because Ozal wants it when everyone, from 15-year-olds to the chief of staff, is opposed to war?'' Ozal was elected prime minister in 1983 when the military turned over power to civilians in general elections. He won re-election in 1987 but his party was badly beaten two years later. The parliament, where the Motherland Party enjoys a large majority, elected him president - his term runs until 1995 - that year. Ozal moved to Cankaya Palace, turning over the prime minister's job to a loyal follower, Yildirim Akbulut. Opposition politicians say Ozal is running the government even though the presidency is supposed to be a mainly ceremonial post. They hope to win enough votes in the next elections to change the constitution and unseat him. Ozal is also opposed by organized labor. At a meeting Tuesday to discuss productivity, labor representatives marched out in protest when Ozal entered the hall. Nationwide, 48,000 miners are on strike to protest the government's insistence on low wages. Businessmen, once Ozal's allies and supporters of his free market policies, now grumble about what they say is widespread corruption in government and the lack of a coordinated economic policy. The educated elite and other secularist Turks, meanwhile, are demanding an end to government policies and hiring practices deemed favorable to Islamic fundamentalists. Their discontent is shared by the traditionally secular military. In a farewell message to Turkey's 800,000-strong armed forces, Torumtay said ``the road shown by Ataturk'' was ``the goal which cannot be deviated from.'' He referred to Kemal Ataturk, founder of modern Turkey in 1923 and proponent of a Western-allied, secular state. The military has toppled civilian governments three times since 1960. The latest takeover was in 1980, following a period of political violence that claimed 5,000 lives.

DOC.HEAD: Dopoulos Named Athens Bureau Chief
DOC.TEXT: Philemon Dopoulos, correspondent for The Associated Press in Athens, has been designated chief of bureau for Greece. The appointment to the new position was announced Tuesday by AP President Louis D. Boccardi. Dopoulos, 58, will continue to report to the Rome bureau chief, Dennis Redmont. Dopoulos joined the AP in 1960 as a newsman in Athens. He was named correspondent there two years later. In 1980, Dopoulos was appointed business manager for the Middle East, based in Greece. He returned to the position of Athens correspondent in 1989. Before joining the AP, Dopoulos was a reporter in Athens for Fairchild Publications. He also worked for Pacific Stars and Stripes in Tokyo. He is a native of New York City and graduate of Boston University.

DOC.HEAD: NBC: Transcripts Show DC-9 Crew Was Lost in Fog
With PM-Planes Collide, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a partial transcript reported by NBC News of an exchange between an air traffic controller and the cockpit of a DC-9 that collided in fog with a Boeing 727 at Detroit Metropolitan Airport on Monday.

Controller: Verify position. Pilot: Uh, we're not sure. It's so foggy out here, we're completely stuck here. Look's like we're on 21-Center here. Controller: You say you're on runway 21-Center? Pilot: We believe we are, we're not sure. Controller: If you're on 21-Center, exit that runway immediately, sir.
Moments later, the planes collided.

DOC.HEAD: The Ethics Committee's Blunt Special Investigator
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Keating-Senators, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A United States senator was shouting accusations at Robert S. Bennett when the special ethics counsel began to fidget in his black swivel chair. Sen. Dennis DeConcini was good and mad, gesturing vividly while he complained that Bennett was out to get him and the other so-called Keating Five. Bennett squirmed in his seat while DeConcini hurled accusations: Bennett was personally trying to write new standards of conduct for the Senate. Bennett was no longer a independent investigator, but a prosecutor who wanted the five senators as a trophy. Finally, the senator sat down. The Senate Ethics Committee hearing room was quiet as the stocky attorney rose to speak in rebuttal. ``These are not my standards,'' Bennett said, speaking directly to the committee with a forceful voice but not hurrying his words. ``And just because you can't go to the Government Printing Office and say, `Hey, give me the ethical standard that covers all situations' doesn't mean they don't exist. Gentlemen, you're a lot better than that.'' While many lawyers hired by Congress to conduct a highly visible investigation may show great reverence to U.S. senators, Bennett is not one of them. He is not intimidated by the committee members who hired him or the lawmakers he was brought in to investigate. Bennett, 51, is known for his straightforward - even blunt - speech. ``He is a no-nonsense litigator who has a way of getting across to a whole spectrum of different people,'' said Peter P. Mullen, executive partner of the 1,100-lawyer, New York-based firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher and Flom - which hired Bennett this year. ``He can talk to princes and paupers, kings and the homeless.'' Bennett's expertise is in defending businessmen accused of white collar crimes. Mullen said his firm scoured the country before hiring him to head its white collar practice. By the time the deal was completed, Bennett had brought along, from his former firm, 14 other lawyers, three legal assistants and four secretaries. The Ethics Committee also could point to Bennett's experience when he was hired a year ago to investigate Sens. DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.; John Glenn, D-Ohio and Alan Cranston, D-Calif. The five intervened with thrift regulators on behalf of former S&L owner Charles H. Keating Jr., a political contributor. Bennett was special counsel in the investigation of Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn., who the Senate denounced earlier this year for financial misconduct. And he performed the same role in the case of former Sen. Harrison A. Williams Jr., D-N.J., who quit the Senate in 1982 just as the chamber was about to expel him for bribery. Bennett's response to DeConcini in the opening days of the ongoing ethics committee hearing told a lot about himself. He told the committee the only trophy he wanted was the one he already had in the wall of his office, which also has a panoramic view of the Washington Monument and environs. The trophy is a stuffed, 5-pound, 2-ounce brown trout he caught in 1985. Underneath the fish is a saying that Bennett shows clients in hopes they'll heed the advice: ``If I had kept my mouth shut, I wouldn't be here.'' And he reminded the committee that many Senate standards of conduct were not written by him but by former Sen. Paul Douglas of Illinois in 1951 - when Bennett was growing up in Brooklyn and only interested in the Dodgers. Bennett's rebuttal also mentioned his three teenage daughters, to make the point that even the school they attended has standards of conduct. ``Whenever I have a case I feel is important, I always work my daughters in,'' Bennett said later. ``It's just something to make them feel good, to let them know I'm thinking about them.'' Sitting in his office for an interview, Bennett - remembered that he may be focused on his work now, but once was more interested in cutting school to watch games at old Ebbitts Field. ``One day I was yelling `Come on Pee Wee (Reese) and I felt a hand on my shoulder. It was my father,'' Bennett said, who had been tipped off by a friend that his son was at the ballpark. Bennett's father, a banker officer, expressed his displeasure that day. But now, Bennett says, ``I have one request for this story. Mention my father. F. Robert Bennett.'' Bennett is not the only high-profile member of his family. Younger brother William is incoming chairman of the Republican National Committee, formerly the national drug czar and a secretary of education. Robert Bennett, though, says he's strictly non-political. A favorite hoby is fishing for brown trout in Montana and a year ago, Bennett bought a home near Livingston, along the Yellowstone River. ``Bob is a good spin fisherman, but now he's trying to become a good fly fisherman,'' said Bennett's pal Lenny Gregrey, of Livingston, a retired New York City police lieutenant. ``His only frustration is he can't tie knots. His fingers won't work. I gave him a written test and he got all flustered,'' Gregrey said of his usually unflappable friend. ``He was sweating over the questions.''

DOC.HEAD: A Mattress, a Dentist, a Meal - Just Call
DOC.TEXT: Need a new mattress, but don't feel like getting out of bed? Slumber comfort is just a phone call away - as are dream dates, decorators, teachers and T-shirts, all via the city's assorted Dial-A lines. Dial-A-Floor. Dial-A-Chef. Dial-A-Hearing Test. In New York, where time is always tight, you can get everything from soup to nuts - and a redecorated kitchen to eat them in - with nothing more than a touch-tone phone. ``You can call us from your office, from your home, from your car - doesn't matter. And within two hours, we can deliver you a mattress,'' said Joe Vicens, vice president of sales and marketing at Dial-A-Mattress. ``We get close to 1,000 calls a day,'' he said. ``On a top day, we get 1,500 calls.'' It wasn't always so. For seven years, Vicens answered the phones alone. But times have changed; there are more two-job families, less time to shop. And it's so easy to punch in 1-800-MATTRES (nobody said spelling was a requirement for sales). Dial-A-Mattress was born 12 years ago when a small furniture company owner, Napoleon Barrigan, spotted a ``dial-a-steak promotion in one of the papers,'' Vicens recalled. ``This gave him the idea for Dial-A-Mattress. Surprisingly, a lot of people started calling.'' The steak idea is still hot. Dial-A-Chef will dispatch a genuine, trained cook to your residence to prepare the repast of your choice. ``We are not a catering service. If you're planning a dinner party, you call us up. We send over a chef who prepares an entire meal right in your home,'' said manager Charles Dean, whose company opened last year. He has about two dozen chefs, who handle everything from vegetarian delights to fine French cuisine. The chefs get $20 to $50 an hour; they work a minimum of four hours, and raw materials cost extra, said Dean. Since man does not live by bed alone - or by pheasant under glass - there are Dial-A-Prayer and Dial-An-Atheist. ``I give thanks, O God, that because I believe in thee, I can be positive about life. ... Remove the fears from my heart, I pray, for fears draw negative feelings. Prune my thoughts of defeat,'' intoned Tuesday's Dial-A-Prayer. Thus inspired, it's on to the secular, like Dial-A-Hearing Test. There was no answer there, leading a caller to believe it apparently works this way: If you can hear the phone ringing, your ears are OK. Obviously in demand: secretaries. There are three Dial-A-Secretary numbers for people seeking temporary office assistance, a figure outdone only by Penthouse magazine's risque Dial-A-Forum Letter and its five exchanges. Overall, Manhattan offers 40 Dial-A services - uh, make that 39. Out of business: Dial-A-Dentist. ``I'm sure you've got the wrong number. This is a shoe store,'' advised the worker answering the phone at the line once used for oral aid. The services are not only for adults. Students stumped by homework can Dial-A-Teacher from Monday through Thursday, 4-7 p.m. Instructors take phone calls and provide instant assistance in both English and Spanish. People looking to get dressed but not dressed up can ring Dial A T-Shirt, where custom print jobs are a specialty. These guys will put anything you want on a hat, T-shirt or sweatshirt, said manager Dean Artenberg. Unfortunately, people still must come down to the store to pick up their orders, although Artenberg said he can understand why they'd rather do their business by phone only. ``It's getting to where you go out on the street around here, you might not ever be coming back,'' he observed.

DOC.HEAD: Some Democrats Discuss Surtax if War Breaks Out
DOC.TEXT: Some top congressional Democrats say that if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf, lawmakers should consider an income tax surcharge to raise the tens of billions of dollars the fighting likely would cost. The idea - similar to the surtax that helped finance the Vietnam war - drew a negative response from one White House official and a mostly skeptical reaction from several Republican congressional leaders Tuesday. Nonetheless, some Democrats say a war against Iraq would be so expensive that it would be a blow to the weakening economy if the government was forced to borrow the money. ``War is a very expensive proposition,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., who was among the first to publicly discuss the idea. ``If we go into a war, we have to find some way to pay for it, not to shove these costs onto future generations by borrowing.'' The proposal has yet to be embraced by House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., or Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. But for Democrats skeptical of attacking Iraq soon, calling for a surtax underscores the domestic price of going to war. Sasser said he envisions a surtax of about 5 percent to 10 percent. During the height of U.S. involvement in Southeast Asia, President Johnson persuaded Congress to approve a 10 percent income tax surcharge to pay for the war. Taxpayers would calculate the amount of money they owed the government, and simply increase it by 10 percent. The surtax was in effect from April 1968 through December 1969. Because of it, fiscal 1969 was the last time the federal budget ran a surplus, finishing $3.2 billion in the black. Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee, agreed that a surtax should be weighed if fighting breaks out in the Persian Gulf. ``The prevalent view is if we sustain our current level of operations, we'd be able to handle that,'' Panetta said. ``When you go beyond that into a full-scale war, that's when the question marks start coming.'' ``If war occurs and we incur substantial costs, do we need to come up with a way to pay for it? Absolutely yes,'' said Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Md., a member of the House Democratic leadership. One White House official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it would be premature to talk about using a surtax to pay for a war against Iraq. ``And it's not clear that that's the way to go,'' the official said. Republican lawmakers seemed mostly opposed to the idea, although House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., said, ``I'm not going to prejudge anything.'' ``We may have to consider cutting spending to pay for those costs,'' said No. 2 House Republican Newt Gingrich of Georgia, who led the anti-tax faction of the House GOP during this year's budget negotiations. ``I know that's an unthinkable alternative for Sasser and Panetta.'' The administration has not released an estimate of what a war in the gulf would cost. In September, when the United States was building a force of 240,000 troops, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the price of maintaining it would be $15 billion this fiscal year. Last month, President Bush said he would add 200,000 troops to the total, but the administration has provided no new cost estimate. Democrats, citing studies by private defense analysts, say fighting could cost $1 billion to $2 billion per day. Republicans, using experts of their own, say a three-month war could cost $15 billion to $30 billion. Under new budget procedures, the costs of U.S. operations in the Middle East will not be counted as part of the official federal deficit. But to pay its military expenses in the gulf, the government will have to either raise taxes, cut spending or borrow money.

DOC.HEAD: 13-Year Old Detained After Driving Across Moravia
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old boy was detained after he drove his uncle's car across Moravia and tried to sell it for nearly $4,200 to a man on the street, the state news agency CTK reported. The boy stole the car, which was recently purchased and without license plates, from his uncle and drove it about 80 miles from Hodonin to Ostrova, the news agency said in Tuesday's report. In Ostrova, the boy tried to sell the car for 100,000 crowns (nearly $4,200) to a man on the street, then lowered his asking price to 20,000 crowns, the agency said. When asked by the police how he managed to drive the distance on icy roads, the boy said: ``I have some experience from the years when I was younger.''

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 11 a.m. EST; time set by source
Nation Seen Vulnerable to Computer Criminals
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Should stand
DOC.TEXT: A thief can steal more money with a computer than with a gun and a terrorist can spread more chaos with a keyboard than with a bomb, experts said today. ``We are at risk,'' the National Research Council said in a 300-page report. ``Increasingly, America depends on computers. They control power delivery, communications, aviation and financial services. ``They are used to store vital information, from medical records to business plans to criminal records. Although we trust them, they are vulnerable.'' The report, titled ``Computers at Risk,'' calls for a coherent national effort to develop security systems and increase public awareness of the dangers posed by vulnerable computers to accidents and deliberate attack. ``To date, we have been remarkably lucky,'' the council said. It pointed out that although money and information have been stolen, lives have been lost because of computer errors and communications and financial systems have been disrupted, there has been no systematic attempt to subvert critical computing systems. ``Unfortunately, there is reason to believe that our luck will soon run out,'' the report said. ``Thus far we have relied on the absence of malicious people who are both capable and motivated. We can no longer do so. We must instead attempt to build computer systems that are secure and trustworthy.'' As evidence of how untrustworthy computers are, the report listed these examples: -A nearly successful attempt to use thousands of phony Bank of America automatic teller machine cards fabricated with personal identification numbers stolen from an on-line data base. -Thousands of reported virus attacks and hundreds of different viruses identified, such as Stoned, Devil's Dance, 1260, Jerusalem, Yankee Doodle, Pakistani Brain, Icelandic-2, Ping Pong and December 24. -A software design error that froze much of American Telephone & Telegraph's long distance network. -The German Chaos Computer Club break-ins to the NASA Space Physics Analysis Network. -The 1988 Internet ``worm'' incident. Robert Morris of Arnold, Md., is appealing his conviction in federal court for unleashing a program that paralyzed thousands of computers linked to the nationwide program. -An error in computer software controlling a radiation therapy machine, a Therac 25 linear accelerator, resulted in at least three patient deaths. -A Cleveland man allegedly mailed more than 26,000 virus-infected diskettes with AIDS prevention information to hospitals, businesses and government agencies worldwide. ``Whatever trust was justified in the past will not be justified in the future unless action is taken now,'' the report said. It recommended that an institution be created to accelerate the commercialization and adoption of safer and more secure computer and communications systems. A major activity of the group would be to evaluate products with respect to security. ``The organization must not be ... a captive of government, system vendors or individual segments of the user community,'' the report said. But it would need the highest level of government support, even a congressional charter, the report said, adding, ``The committee sees this proposal as a test of commitment for industry.'' The National Research Council is an arm of the National Academy of Sciences, a private organization chartered by Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators: Unclear Who at Controls of DC-9 in Runway Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CLARIFY that pilot returning from medical leave was at controls of plane; INSERTS 2 grafs after 14th graf pvs, `NTSB spokesman...,' to UPDATE with pilot's report of hearing radio call from flight crew mistakenly on runway. Pick up 15th graf pvs, `Among those...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Planes Collide-Scene
LaserPhotos DTX1, 2, 3 and LaserColor DT108
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of a DC-9 that collided in fog with another jetliner on an airport runway, killing eight people, returned to the cockpit only last week from a five-year medical leave, officials said Tuesday. The National Transportation Safety Board said Tuesday night that Northwest Airlines Capt. William Lovelace was at the controls Monday when the plane ran into a Boeing 727 racing for takeoff at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. Investigators said earlier Tuesday it was unclear whether Lovelace, of Phoenix, or his first officer, James F. Schifferns of Spokane, Wash., was piloting the plane. Schifferns, who spent 20 years in the Air Force, was hired by Northwest in March, his first job in commercial aviation. NTSB investigators said they were looking at such factors as human error, weather and equipment as possible causes of the accident. A fireball fed by fuel burned away the top of the Pittsburgh-bound DC-9 after the right wingtip of the Northwest 727 tore open the DC-9's fuselage and dislodged an engine. Noxious fumes killed six men and two women among the 43 people aboard the DC-9, said Wayne County Chief Medical Examiner Bader Cassin. Seven people remained hospitalized, two of them in critical condition. I.C. Payne, a passenger on the DC-9, said he couldn't see much out his window and just remembers a piece of shrapnel striking him on the head. ``It nearly knocked me out of my seat,'' said Payne, a quality inspector for General Electric based in Fort Wayne, Ind. ``The first thing I did was reach up to see if all my head was still on. Then I heard someone in the front of the plane yell out that the engine just blew.'' NBC news reported Tuesday night that it had obtained partial transcripts of an exchange between an air traffic controller and the DC-9 cockpit. That exchange showed the controller asking the pilot to verify his position. ``Uh, we're not sure. It's so foggy out here, we're completely stuck here. Looks like we're on 21-Center here,'' NBC quoted the transcripts as saying. The collision occurred near the end of runway 3C, which leads directly into runway 21C. The DC-9 turned off a taxiway into runway 3C and into the path of the 727, officials said. The Federal Aviation Administration said it had not reviewed the control tower transcripts and could not comment on the NBC report. NTSB spokesman Alan Pollock said ``we obviously had interviews with people in the tower and we have determined the DC-9 was having visibility problems. As far as exact wording, I cannot comment on that.'' The crew of another Northwest flight reported overhearing a flight crew say they were unsure of their location, but that they thought they were on runway 3C, said NTSB spokesman John Lauber. He said it hadn't been determined whether the transmission came from the DC-9 or another plane that may have been on the wrong runway. Among those killed was Heidi Joost, 43, of Dearborn, a flight attendant who worked for Northwest since 1968. Five other victims were identified Tuesday night as Kingsley A. Brown, 30, of Pittsburgh, Pa., Mary Blankenship, 37, of Colorado Springs, Colo., Thomas Kopriva, 50, Daniel Loughnane, 44, and Fred Zitto, 59, all of Memphis. The names of the others were unavailable from the medical examiner because their bodies were so badly charred. Cassin said dental records were being sought to make positive identification, which Northwest spokesman Kevin Whalen said could come Wednesday. Another Northwest spokesman, Bob Gibbons, said the flight was Lovelace's first without another pilot observing since he returned to flying Nov. 25. He spent five years on medical leave for kidney stones, Gibbons said. Airline officials refused to provide further details on Lovelace's leave. Lovelace, 52, of Phoenix, had two weeks of ground school and 13 hours of simulator flying after he was medically cleared Oct. 10 to return to work. Five of Lovelace's 12 flights between Nov. 25 and Nov. 30 had been into or out of Detroit. Schifferns, 37, of Spokane, Wash., was hired by Northwest after a military career in which he flew a variety of planes, including B-52 bombers. It was unknown how many of Schifferns' previous flights began r ended at Detroit. He had 150 hours flying with the airline. At the time of the crash, visibility was estimated by the air traffic controllers' union at a quarter-mile. The ground was wet from a snow and sleet storm that delayed flights at the airport. It was closed at the time to inbound flights. Gibbons, the Northwest spokesman, said if visibility was less than a quarter-mile, FAA rules require the tower should to ground all departing flights. The National Air Traffic Controllers Association said it appeared Lovelace or Schifferns taxied the plane onto the runway without clearance from the tower. The Federal Aviation Administration, which is responsible for air traffic controllers, did not respond to the union's statement. Recordings of cockpit conversations were being analyzed Tuesday in Washington. The Memphis-bound 727 had 153 people aboard. Some suffered minor scrapes and bruises when sliding down emergency slides. Romulus, 10 miles from Detroit, was the site of the second worst air crash in U.S. history, the Aug. 16, 1987, crash of a Northwest MD-80 on takeoff. That crash killed 156.

DOC.HEAD: Cards Keep Out Palestinians Deemed Potential Troublemakers
DOC.TEXT: After Nasser was released from a six-year prison term for attacking Israeli soldiers, he was hoping to find a job and settle down to a normal life. That didn't happen. Instead, Nasser, 27, was ordered to turn in his orange, Israeli-issued identification card. It was replaced by a green one that says in Hebrew and Arabic: ``The holder of this card is not allowed to enter Israel.'' Nasser is one of at least 2,400 Palestinians in the West Bank getting green cards under new strictures following more than a dozen stabbing attacks by Palestinians on Israelis in the past two months. Having a green card prevents the holders from working in Israel, where Palestinians have provided much of the cheap labor as restaurant workers, garbage men or - as in Nasser's case - construction workers. ``I thought my punishment ended, but I guess it is just beginning,'' said Nasser, who was interviewed at his father's home in this refugee camp near Bethlehem. He asked that the family name not be used for fear of reprisal. Nasser was jailed for fire-bombings aimed at Israel patrols and attacks on Palestinians suspected of collaborating with Israel. He says no one was killed or injured in the incidents. He feels he paid his dues in prison and worries that he will have trouble supporting himself and won't be able to help his retired parents. ``It's like being back in prison,'' he said. Nasser was in jail while tensions grew enormously between Arabs and Israelis during the last three years of the Palestinian uprising. In the past two months, stabbing attacks by Arabs seeking revenge for the deaths of 17 Palestinians in Jerusalem's Temple Mount riots have brought counterattacks by Israelis and increased calls for blocking Palestinians from entering Israel. Following a fatal stabbing attack Sunday in Greater Tel Aviv - the coastal area that is Israel's main population center - hundreds of police on Tuesday set up checkpoints on roads leading to the Jewish state. Police not only checked for green cards but frisked any Palestinian trying to cross the Green Line, Israel's boundary with the West Bank and Gaza Strip before it seized the territories in the 1967 Middle East war. Green cards were first issued to Palestinians in February 1989, but the program has been stepped up in the past month. Shmuel Ozenboy, a spokesman for the military government of the occupied territories, said the 2,400 new green cards issued brings to 10,800 the number of Palestinians barred from entering Israel because of crimes or anti-Israeli activities. News reports said that following Sunday's Tel Aviv attack officials were considering raising the total of banned Palestinians to about 15,000. The number could potentially include any of the 60,000 people jailed during the Palestinian uprising, including thousands held without ever being formally charged or tried. Economics Minister David Magen already has suggested that the 110,000 Palestinians who work in Israel be cut to 50,000 to create jobs for the thousands of Soviet Jews being resettled in Israel. Similar calls for banning Palestinians in the past have been thwarted by employers' dependence on cheap Palestinian labor and Israelis' distaste for menial jobs. Defense Minister Moshe Arens argued at a Parliament committee this wee that it would be naive to expect to instantly end Israel's dependence on cheap Arab labor. ``We should change the state of affairs but it would only be possible in gradual stages and with planning,'' he said. Both Palestinians and Israelis have warned that cutting off Palestinians from jobs - when they are frustrated at the uprising's failure to produce political gains - could further increase violence. Job openings in the territories are almost nonexistent because Israel routinely refuses permits for factories, keeping the West Bank and Gaza a captive market. The uprising has further reduced jobs for the 1.7 million Palestinians in the territories. Abdul Fatah Abu Shukur, dean of the economics department at An-Najah University in the West Bank city of Nablus, said the territories' unemployment rate of more than 25 percent would be driven up by the green cards.

DOC.HEAD: Dockside Gambling Approved in One County; Rejected in Two Others
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with gambling approved in one county, rejected in two others. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Voters in one of Mississippi's three coastal counties narrowly approved dockside gambling Tuesday. The other counties turned it down. Hancock County became the third Mississippi county to approve casino-type, cruise vessel gambling. The Hancock vote was 4,246 in favor and 4,004 against, according to unofficial returns. The referendum failed in Harrison County 18,490 to 17,463, and lost 15,351 to 9,508 in Jackson County. Opponents of legalized gambling in the Gulf of Mexico charged passage would change a community's way of life by encouraging crime and weakening morality; proponents said tax dollars and new jobs would bring an economic windfall. Charles Phillips, a consultant hired by the anti-gambling Citizens for Quality of Life, said the group researched the effects of gambling on the economies of Deadwood, S.D., and Atlantic City, N.J., and found that the communities weren't revitalized at all. There are no restrictions on the casinos' size or operations except that they have to be aboard a ship or riverboat. The kind of gambling, either high stakes or small amounts, would be determined by each individual ship. Applicants to operate casino vessels in Hancock County still face the screening process before the Mississippi Tax Commission. Lawmakers expect it will take about a year for such a gaming operation to open up. The gambling issue has been debated as economic boons to depressed economies. Civic leaders on the coast and the Mississippi river counties have pushed for greater tourism revenue, which is off after several conventions normally reserved for the coast moved to Florida or Louisiana. Casino ships are not allowed to open their casinos once they get into international waters.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Germans Asked to Invite Soviet Soldiers to Homes at Christmas
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Germans are being asked to invite Soviet soldiers into their homes for Christmas. A group called the German Society has appealed to local Germans to share their holidays ``to show a bit of human politics from people to people,'' the ADN news agency said Tuesday. About 360,000 Soviet soldiers are stationed in the lands that once were East Germany. The German government has promised massive aid in the next four years to help return them to the Soviet Union, where housing is in short supply. The German Society was founded in January with the goal of bettering cultural and economic relations between then-East and West Germany. Among the group's curators are former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt, and Eberhard Diepgen, who won Sunday's election for the first mayor of united Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Sends Melons, Tomatoes and Powdered Milk to Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Israel is flying tons of emergency food supplies to the Soviet Union to help alleviate winter shortages. A Boeing 767 of the national air carrier El Al left for Moscow on Tuesday carrying melons, tomatoes, cucumbers and oranges. Another planeload carrying 15 tons of powdered milk will be shipped on an Israeli jet Thursday to Moscow, Israeli reports said. Jewish Agency chairman Simcha Dinitz says the shipments are a humanitarian gesture and an expression of gratitude for the tens of thousands of Soviet Jews allowed to emigrate this year.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Rights Advocates Question GOP Commitment to Blacks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's selection of conservative William Bennett to head the Republican National Committee is prompting ``I told you so's'' from critics who doubt the party's commitment to minority concerns. Civil rights advocates see the choice of Bennett - an ardent foe of racial quotas - as a departure from RNC Chairman Lee Atwater's high-profile effort to woo black voters over the last two years. Bush's decision ``sends the wrong signal'' to blacks, especially following his veto of sweeping civil rights legislation that blacks considered a litmus test, said Howard University political science professor Ron Walters. ``It lends credence to my opinion that the Republican Party was never really serious about this,'' Walters said, voicing the opinion of many who have been suspicious of the GOP's intentions. However, RNC officials insist that Bennett will continue the minority outreach program, and that his staunch opposition to minority hiring quotas should not affect that. Atwater, who is battling a brain tumor and will remain as the party's general chairman, often said his long-range goal was to bring more minorities to the party. It also was his short-term goal for the 1990 election in which 22 percent of the blacks voted for Republicans in congressional races, according to a New York Times-CBS News poll. That was up 7 percentage points from 1988, and double the percentage found in 1982. Sources said Atwater urged Bush to sign the civil rights legislation that came to the president's desk shortly before the Nov. 6 election. Bush vetoed the bill after a fight within his administration. The president contended it would lead to racial hiring quotas, although language in the measure said it was not intended to encourage quotas. The selection of Bennett was like salt in the wound after the veto, said Ralph Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights. ``It appears that once again President Bush has cast his lot with the right wing, his core constituency, with the wealthy and the privileged,'' Neas charged. Bennett has several strikes against him as far as minority groups are concerned, including his recent help in the racially tinged re-election bid of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. Bennett defended Helms' campaign advertisements that were widely criticized for racial overtones, and said North Carolina was ``the most harmonious place I've been for race relations.'' Helms beat back a strong challenge by Harvey Gantt, a black Democrat. Bennett later said he was eager to do battle with Democrats over racial quotas and affirmative action. When he was President Reagan's chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities in the mid-1980s, Bennett refused to set numerical goals directed by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission for hiring women and minorities. Critics said he steered the endowment's funds away from research on black and women's studies. Then as Reagan's education secretary, Bennett blasted colleges and universities that he said were imposing unofficial quotas. He wrote a book, ``Counting By Race,'' in 1979 that lays out a historical argument against using quotas for hiring or college admissions. Republican civil rights advocates are trying to put the best face on Bennett's pending chairmanship. Most recently Bush's anti-drug czar, he still must be approved by a vote of the Republican National Committee members. RNC spokesman B.J. Cooper said Bennett's ``statements on quotas mirror exactly the administration's policy'' and that the party is committed ``more than ever'' to recruiting minority voters and candidates. ``Give the man a chance,'' said Thaddeus Garrett Jr., an informal adviser to Bush on minority issues and a backer of the civil rights bill. Garrett said he hopes that ``the die is cast, and that Bill Bennett will have no other desire than to make sure this outreach program continues.'' ``It doesn't do me any good not to be hopeful,'' said Garrett. Arthur Fletcher, chairman of the Civil Rights Commission, who also disagreed with Bush on whether the civil rights legislation was a ``quota bill,'' said he hopes Bennett's appointment will force a needed debate on civil rights. ``Since they made the move and appointed the guy, let's have the debate. The assumption is that because he's there he's uust going to turn everybody off ... I'm saying let Bennett express himself,'' said Fletcher. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Rita Beamish covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Clean-Up After Soviets to Cost Millions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Language in 5th graf may be offensive to some
DOC.TEXT: Cleaning up the mess left behind by departing Soviet troops is likely to cost tens of millions of dollars, the state CTK news agency reports. The Ministry of Control estimates that damages to the environment and to buildings occupied by Soviet troops in Czech lands for the past 22 years will run as high as $28.5 million, CTK said Tuesday. The estimate did not include the damage caused by Soviet soldiers in the country's eastern republic, Slovakia. According to the report, most historical buildings in northern Bohemia have been damaged. The area around Ceska Lipa, near the borders with Poland and what was formerly East Germany are the most severely damaged, CTK said. ``Soviet soldiers vandalized the interior of the castle of Decin (50 miles north of Prague) and turned the castle's basement into a reservoir of feces,'' CTK said. The pullout of Soviet troops from Czechoslovakia began in February, but differences over financial compensation for damages they have caused during their 22-year stay have yet to be resolved. Moscow has agreed to withdraw all the troops stationed on Czechoslovak territory by July 1991. The agreement was reached after the peaceful revolution last year that ousted the Communist leaders put in place after a Soviet-led invasion in 1968 crushed reform. The Soviet Union has a similar agreement with Hungary and that country is also seeking financial compensation for damages resulting from the Soviet soldiers' decades-long stay.

DOC.HEAD: European Farmers Usually Prevail in Fights Over Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: An Agriculture Department report says there's a good reason why farmers in the European Community take to the streets when their subsidies are threatened: the protests have usually worked. In late August, for example, French farmers protested low prices they had been getting for beef and lamb, blaming cheaper imports from Britain, Ireland and Eastern Europe. Groups of angry French farmers hijacked imported shipments, destroyed beef and lamb carcasses, and set live animals loose in town squares. Other acts included killing sheep or lambs in public, and British trucks carrying live sheep twice were set on fire. ``Farmers in the EC stage such protests largely because the demonstrations are successful,'' the report said. ``The French agriculture minister, while condemning the demonstrators' violence, announced measures designed to relieve some of the profit squeeze.'' The tradition of protests continued this week as negotiators met in Brussels in a last-ditch attempt to revamp the world's trading system. Police used tear gas and water cannons on Monday to disperse 30,000 farmers protesting the talks being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The so-called Uruguay Round of talks for the liberalization of world trade has been clouded by persistent snarls over agricultural issues, primarily the refusal of the 12-nation EC to go along with substantive reductions in farm subsidies favored by the United States and most other GATT members. European farmers, typically small and heavily dependent on EC subsidies and protection from outside imports, fear they would be swamped by the market-oriented policies sought by the others. The report, by economist Mary Lisa Madell of USDA's Economic Research Service, was published in the December issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. ``Farmers may have a lot to protest, but they face some economic realities that politicians in Brussels and the national capitals cannot change,'' the report said. For instance, the average size of the EC's 9 million farmers is only 33 acres, it added. Those averages range from 161 acres in the United Kingdom to less than 10 acres in Greece. The larger, more efficient farms ``can flourish under the high level of support'' provided by the bloc's Common Agricultural Policy, or CAP, but many smaller operations still struggle to survive. Until the mid-1980s, the community adjusted prices under the CAP to ensure that farmers could earn a good living from the land. But costs grew burdensome and chronic surpluses developed. Thus, price supports, or ``intervention'' prices, have remained stable or have been shaved somewhat since then. Even so, the CAP price levels are still high compared with world prices, and overproduction remains a problem, the report said. Current attempts in the Uruguay Round to reduce trade-distorting price supports and phase out longstanding EC export subsidies have helped stir the conflict further. Health scares such as the mysterious new cattle disease - bovine spongiform encephalopathy or ``mad cow disease'' - in the United Kingdom and Ireland have taken a toll. So have concerns over food poisoning outbreaks and local scandals over hormones in meat supplies. Animal rights issues are also worrying livestock producers, the report said. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Agriculture Department has plugged a loophole that allowed about 5 percent of the peanuts sold for human consumption to be marketed without federal inspection. Officials said the new regulation, which took effect Tuesday, was required by Congress in legislation a year ago. Daniel D. Haley, administrator of the department's Agricultural Marketing Service, said approximately 95 percent of the peanuts marketed for human consumption are sold under marketing orders and are inspected and certified for size, quality and condition. The new rule covers those peanuts not covered by the marketing orders. Haley said the agency conducts the program on a fee basis for peanut handlers. Most handlers operate under a peanut marketing agreement authorized by federal law. An 18-member comittee of peanut producers and handlers administers the program, which is financed by assessments on handlers. Haley said that under the agreement, peanut handlers are indemnified for peanuts tested and found unsuitable for human consumption because of aflatoxin contamination. Aflatoxin, a naturally occurring chemical that can cause cancer, can result from a certain kind of crop mold or fungus. Only handlers who have signed the agreement are eligible for indemnification, he said. Handlers whose peanuts until now have not been tested - but will be now, under the new law - may wish to sign the agreement to take advantage of the indemnification, Haley said. Those interested should contact: Peanut Administrative Committee, P.O. Box 18856, Lenox Square Station, Atlanta, Ga. 30326. Telephone 404-261-7800. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Last year the United States sold $17 million worth of crayfish to Sweden, up from $6 million in 1988, says the Agriculture Department. Swedes turned to U.S. crayfish providers after their own domestic supply was jeopardized by a fungus and pollution, the department's Foreign Agricultural Service said in this month's AgExporter magazine. The small, lobster-like crustaceans are known by many names, depending on where you buy them. They're crayfish in Sweden. But in Louisiana, the main source for U.S. exports, the creatures are crawfish. And in Tennessee and many other places, they're crawdads or something else. Don't ask for crayfish in Australia, the report said, because the name there is yabbie or marron.

DOC.HEAD: DEA Pleased With Dismissal of Allegations in Plane Bombing
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Drug Enforcement Administration says he is pleased that the Justice Department found no support for news reports his agency was involved in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. However, DEA Administrator Robert C. Bonner added Tuesday: ``I'm concerned that there may be some subliminal impact'' on the agency's reputation. ``This would be unfortunate, as it is clear there was no connection between DEA activity of any kind and the Pan Am 103 tragedy.'' The Dec. 21, 1988 explosion over Lockerbie, Scotland, killed 259 people aboard the plane and 11 on the ground. The New York-bound flight originated in Frankfurt with a stop in London, where passengers and luggage were transferred to another aircraft. News reports in late October alleged that terrorists took advantage of an undercover DEA operation to smuggle explosives aboard the plane. The DEA quickly rebutted the reports, but the parent Justice Department ordered further inquiries by the DEA and especially the FBI, the lead U.S. agency investigating the bombing. In a statement Tuesday, Deputy Attorney General William P. Barr said: ``While the investigation is continuing, the FBI has found no evidence to substantiate recent allegations of a connection between operations of the DEA and the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103.'' Bonner said in an interview that he understood the delay. ``I think it was appropriate to have the bureau (FBI) take a look at this,'' he said. ``To totally rule out even a scintilla of concern has taken several weeks.'' NBC and ABC had reported, among other things, that the Frankfurt airport security had been relaxed to accommodate DEA agents tracking U.S.-bound drug shipments from the Middle East. But Bonner said evasion of airport security measures, even to ensure the success of a sting operation, ``is not something we do.'' The DEA inquiry found specifically that the agency never circumvented security measures at the Frankfurt airport. The DEA's inquiry also found that it ``had no investigative or operational activity in effect on Dec. 21, 1988 that involved the use of Pan Am Flight 103 or Frankfurt International Airport,'' Barr said. In addition, the DEA probe rejected contentions that Flight 103 passenger Khalid Nazir Jaafar of Detroit was part of an undercover DEA operation. Lew Kreindler, a lawyer for U.S. relatives of Flight 103 victims, said last month that the allegation of an undercover drug operation was an ``old story'' that had surfaced last year in a British newspaper. He contended it was an attempt to distract attention from Pan Am, which is being sued by the relatives. Pan Am has maintained its security procedures are second only to those of El Al, the Israeli airline. Investigators believe members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine conducted the bombing, but the FBI has not produced enough evidence to bring criminal charges, law enforcement sources say. British and German authorities also are investigating the bombing.

DOC.HEAD: `Ground Zero' for Dinosaur-Killing Asteroid May Be in Mexico
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Scientists think they found the smoking gun to show that asteroids wiped out the dinosaurs: a 110-mile-wide crater in Mexico possibly gouged by a mountain-size rock smashing to Earth. The crater near the Yucatan Peninsula town of Chicxulub may have been ``ground zero'' for the collision that some scientists believe killed dinosaurs 65 million years ago, University of Arizona scientist Bill Boynton said Tuesday. The collision, with the estimated power of 70 million one-megaton bombs, could have kicked up 3-mile-high tidal waves and a sparked a worldwide firestorm. ``We think we have found the smoking gun, but there may be other guns and maybe a firing squad,'' Boynton said during a meeting of the American Geophysical Union. Boynton and other researchers said another impact crater 22 miles wide near Manson, Iowa, and possible craters under the Caribbean near Colombia and Cuba point to the possibility a shower of asteroids or comets caused the extinction. The Yucatan crater Boynton and his colleagues theorize was caused by an asteroid striking shallow Mexican waters is now on dry land, buried by 65 million years of sediment. The study by Alan Hildebrand, Boynton and others was the latest of more than 2,000 in the past 12 years that examined whether asteroids, huge volcanic eruptions or slow climate change sent the dinosaurs to oblivion. In 1978, scientists found deposits of iridium metal in 65-million-year-old rocks around the world. Iridium is rare on Earth but less rare in asteroids and comets. The killer-asteroid theory was born because an impact would have spread iridium dust around the globe. The theory is that a 6-mile-wide asteroid or comet - or a comet shower - smacked into the Earth, kicking debris into the atmosphere and causing radical environmental damage that wiped out the dinosaurs and up to 75 percent of all species. ``We wouldn't be here if it hadn't been for the extinction of the dinosaurs,'' said geologist Walter Alvarez of the University of California at Berkeley. ``They were ruling the place. Mammals were just running around underfoot until the impact killed the dinosaurs and let us evolve.'' Some researchers think the impact or impacts clouded the sky with smoke, dust or debris that blocked out sunlight and wiped out food supplies. Others have theorized, somewhat in jest, that changes in vegetation upset the dinosaurs' diet, leaving them fatally constipated. Other possible deadly effects of asteroids hitting Earth include acid rain, giant tidal waves, dark freezing weather, global warming by the greenhouse effect and a worldwide firestorm that broiled creatures in their tracks.

DOC.HEAD: White House Ornaments Offer a Presidential Twist to the Holidays
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: With Christmas around the corner, the White House Historical Association's souvenir shop is doing a booming business once again in Christmas ornaments with a presidential twist. It was almost a decade ago that the non-profit group came up with the idea of selling tourists the special Christmas keepsakes alongside its standard postcards and guidebooks about presidents and first ladies. The shiny ornaments proved a hit with tourists and natives alike. Each year's ornament has outsold the last, and the association's executive director, Bernard F. Meyer, confidently predicts ``we'll sell in the neighborhood of 150,000 to 200,000'' of the newest one. The 1990 White House ornament is a colorful miniature of the Blue Room as it looked at Yuletime when Martin Van Buren was president 150 years ago. The association, which operates out of a townhouse on Jackson Place across from the White House, sells the 24 karat gold-finished ornaments for $11 - or $13 by mail. Meyer said he has heard reports of stores reselling the ornaments for as much as $18. He shrugged off the black market markup, saying, ``There's nothing we can do about it.'' The association, which raises funds for acquiring art and furnishings for the presidential mansion, now counts on the Christmas ornament sales for two-thirds of its $2.5 million annual operating budget. Not all of that is profit, but Meyer says the group clears several hundred thousand dollars from the ornament sales to subsidize other projects, including a forthcoming new book on White House art and paintings. The association still sells the earlier ornaments from each Christmas going back to 1981. In keeping with its mission, it packages them with pamphlets recalling the history of early U.S. presidents. Last year's ornament was a colorful presidential seal. Its popularity was heightened by a production glitch that led to temporary shortages and long lines outside the association's townhouse. The ornaments also are sold at a booth inside the White House along the route that more than 1 million visitors follow each year. Meyer said the association's volunteer board of directors has turned down proposals for wider marketing of the Christmas ornaments. ``Our organization is conservative,'' he said. ``We are not connected with the White House, but we have the name. We don't want to do anything that could create an embarrassment.'' Word of mouth has proven sufficient to propel ornament sales upward each year. And people who give a White House ornament once to friends or relatives often find they are expected to produce the new one the next Christmas. Meyer knows how that works. He says he has to buy 22 himself to keep everyone on his gift list happy. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Ornaments can be ordered by mail at $13 each with checks payable to: The White House Historical Association, P.O. Box 96586, Washington, D.C. 20090-6586. The association's telephone is: (202) 737-8292.

DOC.HEAD: Government Working to Develop Anti-Fire Systems
With PM-Planes Collide
DOC.TEXT: The government has been trying for years, with one spectacular failure along the way, to develop systems to retard aircraft fires such as the one that swept a Northwest Airlines jetliner this week. The hope at one time was that an anti-misting fuel additive would prevent the vapors in jet fuel from igniting and exploding in a crash. In on-the-ground stationary tests the additive appeared to work and the Federal Aviation Administration was close to requiring airlines to add it to jet fuel. But when the FAA deliberately crashed a remote-controlled Boeing 720 in the California desert six years ago to test the idea under realistic conditions, the jetliner exploded in flame. Eleven months later, the FAA acknowledged: ``The concept is not practical for day-to-day airline operation in the foreseeable future.'' The experiment was not repeated, and as Monday's runway collision at Detroit's Metropolitan Airport shows, fire remains a constant hazard in aviation accidents. The collision of two Northwest jetliners, a DC-9 and a Boeing 727, killed eight people aboard the DC-9 and left it a shredded and fire-chared hulk. The eight apparently died from inhaling noxious fumes before their bodies were burned beyond recognition, officials said. At least 20 other people were hospitalized with burns, broken bones and smoke inhalation. Concern over aircraft fires was dramatized in 1977 when two Boeing 747 jumbo jets collided on a foggy runway at Tenerife in the Canary Islands, killing 581 people. In the years since the failure of the fuel-additive experiment in 1984, the FAA and the Department of Transportation have concentrated on trying to make the immediate surroundings of air passengers more flame-resistant. FAA officials say the aim is to delay for an additional 60 seconds the spread of fire inside an aircraft cabin, thus providing additional time to evacuate. A year after 23 people were killed in a 1983 smoky fire aboard an Air Canada jetliner, the DOT ordered all aircraft with 30 or more seats to install fire-blocking material in all passenger seats. Floor-level lights were required to facilitate escape from an aircraft cabin choked with smoke. In 1988, additional safety rules were imposed after an agreement between the FAA and the aviation industry on more stringent flammability standards for aircraft cabin walls, ceilings and storage bins. Northwest said it could not immediately determine whether the destroyed plane, the oldest version of the McDonnell Douglas DC-9, was in full compliance with the FAA's fire safety rules.

DOC.HEAD: Relaxation of Reserve Requirements Seen Aiding Banks, Not Economy
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve's relaxation of reserve requirements should help fatten the thin profits of large banks at taxpayers' expense, but likely will not greatly stimulate the economy in general, analysts say. The central bank said its unusual action, announced Tuesday, was aimed in part at encouraging banks to lend to creditworthy borrowers, easing a shortage of credit. But private economists said the most visible result of the first change in reserve requirements since 1983 likely will be a modest increase in bank earnings at a time of increasing strain on the industry. ``This increases the profit margin to banks but does not guarantee more loans,'' said economist Allen Sinai of The Boston Co. ``It may or may not reduce interest rates. ``This is a surgical move to shore up the banking system because there is a risk that the banking system could bring the economy down more,'' Sinai said. Because of the types of reserves reduced, large banks likely will benefit more than smaller banks, he said. Reserve requirements ensure that banks have the cash on hand to meet depositor demands. Institutions must maintain the reserves either as cash in the vault or in non-interest-bearing accounts with the Fed. When the central bank requires fewer reserves, banks then have more money to make profit-earning loans or other investments. Consequently, the Fed's revenue is reduced because it has less money to invest in government securities. ``As I understand it, this is a transfer of profits from the Treasury to the banking sector,'' said economist Paul Getman of Regional Financial Associates of West Chester, Pa. ``All of the Fed's profits at the end of the year go to the Treasury.'' The central bank turned over $21.6 billion in 1989, according to a Fed official. The net effect of Tuesday's change, depending on interest rates, will be to deprive taxpayers of roughly $600 million a year and to bolster bank profits by about the same amount. ``That's a nice piece of change for the banking sector, but I don't think it's going to do squat to get them to make more loans,'' Getman said. He said banks aren't tightening credit because they lack money to lend, but rather because of concerns about the ability of borrowers to repay the loans during an economic downturn. Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va., said the reduced reserve requirement will only partly offset a more than 60 percent increase next year in banks' deposit insurance premiums. ``What the government taketh with one hand, it giveth back partially with the other,'' he said. During the two weeks ending Nov. 28, institutions maintained $59 billion in reserves. Tuesday's change would reduce reserves by about $13.6 billion, according to the Fed. The move Tuesday affects two types of reserves: those held against non-personal time deposits with maturities of less than 18 months and net Eurocurrency liabilities. Non-personal time deposits primarily are certificates of deposit purchased by businesses. Net Eurocurrency liabilities are the net amounts that banks borrow from their overseas branches. The reserve requirement on those two types will drop from 3 percent to 1.5 percent beginning Dec. 13 and to zero beginning Dec. 27. No change was made in the requirement of a 12 percent reserve for transaction accounts, primarily checking accounts. A change in the reserve requirements is the most rarely used of the Fed's three monetary policy tools. The most common is the purchase or sale of government securities to expand or contract the amount of cash available to banks. Those sales directly affect the federal funds rate, the interest charged among banks for overnight loans. The Fed has cut the funds rate - now at 7{ percent - three times since July, each time by a quarter-point. The next most common is a change in the discount rate - the interest the Fed charges on direct loans to member banks. That was last changed in February 1989, when it was raised from 6{ percent to 7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Task Force to Probe Pipeline Problems
DOC.TEXT: A federal-state task force will review corrosion and maintenance problems on the Alaska oil pipeline in an effort to deter what one official calls a ``potential disaster.'' The Transportation Department said Tuesday the task force will assess operation, maintenance and safety of the 800-mile-long, 48-inch steel pipeline, which snakes from Prudhoe Bay to the marine terminal at Valdez and carries a quarter of the nation's domestically produced crude oil. The panel also will review environmental protection and emergency response procedures. The formation of the task force was announced by Travis P. Dugan, head of the department's Research and Special Programs Administration. ``Twenty-five percent of this nation's domestic oil production is transported through this pipeline,'' Dugan said. ``It's vital that the safety and operational procedures used in this system are of the highest caliber. ``We formed this task force to avoid potential disaster, which could easily occur if the pipeline is neglected,'' he said. ``It is our way of locking the barn door before the horse runs away.'' The task force will include representatives of the Transportation Department's Office of Pipeline Safety; the Pipeline Monitoring Branch of the Bureau of Land Management, part of the Interior Department; and the state of Alaska's Department of Natural Resources and Office of Pipeline Monitoring. A report by the congressional General Accounting Office in May said there has been no proper watch over the maintenance of the 13-year-old pipeline, leading to the possibility of an oil spill on land equally as disastrous as the March 1989 ocean spill in Prince William Sound. ``The pipeline has not received the systematic, comprehensive oversight needed to ensure compliance with operational safety, emergency response and environmental requirements,'' the report concluded. GAO officials said at the time the situation was worrisome because of reports of corrosion in the pipeline. They did note recent improvement in federal and state checkups on pipeline operations and said new efforts at coordination showed promise ``if organized and staffed appropriately.'' The pipeline is operated by Alyeska Pipeline Service Co., which said last month it expects to spend $600 million to $800 million by 1993 on corrosion detection and repair. Alyeska said then it had already repaired 138 corroded sections with steel sleeves. Alyeska is a consortium of subsidiaries of the Exxon, BP, ARCO, Mobil, Unocal, Phillips and Amerada Hess oil companies. The pipeline carries nearly 2 million barrels of crude oil per day. That is about one-eighth of all U.S. crude consumption because the nation imports half its crude.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Hearings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``Who can doubt that a year of blockade will be cheaper than a week of war?'' - Former defense secretary Robert S. McNamara urging the administration to continue to rely on economic sanctions as the main weapon against Iraq. --- ``We have time. I don't see any hurry. I don't see any doubt that he (Saddam Hussein) either gets out, or he gets thrown out, blown out.'' - Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., suggesting economic sanctions be given more time. --- ``Action that isn't backed by consensus will mean disaster. Whatever we do, the country, the Congress and the president must do it standing on common ground.'' - Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., opening three weeks of hearings by his House Armed Services Committee on U.S. options in the gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: In Break With the Past, France Lets African Rebels Take Over
DOC.TEXT: France signaled a dramatic shift in dealings with its former African colonies by ordering French troops in Chad to stand aside while rebels toppled a regime that Paris had backed with guns and money since 1982. ``The time has passed when France could pick and choose the governments in these countries, change them or maintain them as it wished,'' said Foreign Minister Roland Dumas. Foreign Legionnaires had grandstand seats when Idriss Deby's insurgents marched into Chad's capital, N'Djamena, on Sunday, having chased President Hissene Habre across the Chari river to Cameroon. In other African capitals, amidst other upheavals in the past, French troops have helped prop up friendly regimes. Habre himself received extensive French military support in countering Libyan incursions in 1986-87. But this time, Habre got no help. ``We didn't aid Idriss Deby. We simply left him alone,'' said the French development minister, Jacques Pelletier. As recently as June, France helped finance Habre's re-election to the presidency. Billed as Chad's first free elections, only the official party and independent candidates were allowed to run. But during that same month, President Francois Mitterrand spelled out France's new attitude at a Franco-African summit. He linked French aid to efforts at democratization and stressed that his country's military muscle was not at the disposal of dictators seeking to settle scores with domestic rivals. Habre was notably hostile to Mitterrand's pronouncements, saying France must not impose Western ideological systems on nations unable to sustain them. Some skeptics question whether France is prepared to exchange its role of gendarme for spectator in all cases, arguing that expediency dictates the African policies made in Paris. Jean-Pierre Magnant, a Chad specialist at Bordeaux University's Institute for Political Studies, is among those unconvinced that France will remain faithful to a new policy. ``It doesn't change the foundation of things, it changes the form,'' Magnant said of Mitterrand's pronouncements. ``We support the good dictators, and those that bother us, we let them go.'' France acknowledges that Libya supplied Deby with 40 percent of his arms but, in a departure from past policy, said this was not grounds to contain his advances on Habre. Some French media have referred to massive Libyan arms shipments, saying Paris conveniently chose to ignore what in the past would have constituted an aggression by a foreign power. France, which currently has 1,800 troops in Chad, one of the world's poorest nations, had backed Habre after he took power in a 1982 coup d'etat. Deby, 38, a master tactician trained at France's war college, became Habre's military adviser. But he fled last year amid allegations of a coup, taking refuge in Sudan. Deby, who began his final offensive Nov. 10, had implored the French to remain neutral and, victory in hand, thanked them. France has expressed satisfaction with Deby's stated wish for multiparty democracy in Chad. Like most former French colonies in Africa, Chad has had only dictators of various types since gaining independence three decades ago. Habre has slowly fallen from grace in Paris. Since the fall of Communist dictatorships in Eastern Europe, several of Africa's strongmen have been forced to move to multiparty systems. ``The shock of 1989 had lots of repercussions in Africa and, especially, Francophone Africa, where bloody dictatorships were everywhere,'' said Magnant. ``It is France which made the one-party regimes.'' Chad is the most dramatic, but not the first, example of recent French neutrality in a conflict in Francophone Africa. In May, France reinforced its military presence in Gabon, where demonstrations hostile to President Omar Bongo threatened the security of French oil operations. But the French troops, there to protect French citizens, avoided intervening in the violence. The same scenario was played out recently in Rwanda, where French soldiers helped evacuate foreigners and guard the airport, but engaged in no major fighting against a rebel army. Besides Chad and Gabon, France maintains troops in the Ivory Coast, Senegal, the Central African Republic and Djibouti, an important French naval base. The Paris newspaper Liberation said Africa is no longer a top priority for France. With the ongoing changes in Europe and the Persian Gulf crisis, Chad is but a poor man's war, the paper said. Other African despots must now take note that France is no longer their ``life insurance policy,'' Liberation wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Nonsmokers Regularly Exposed to High Levels of Cigarette Smoke
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Should stand
DOC.TEXT: A new study found 91 percent of nonsmokers were regularly exposed to high levels of cigarette smoke, suggesting that the Environmental Protection Agency has underestimated the risk of passive smoking, a researcher says. Dr. Michael Cummings of the Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, N.Y., also said childhood exposure to parents' cigarette smoke could be a greater risk than an adult nonsmoker's exposure to a spouse's or colleague's smoke.
