If that is correct, lung cancer could be about to increase among nonsmokers of the baby boom generation, a result of their parents' widespread adoption of smoking after World War II, Cummings said. He presented his findings Tuesday at a meeting of an EPA panel considering the merits of the agency's draft passive smoking study that concludes that cigarette smoke is a known cause of cancer in nonsmokers. The panel has been criticized by anti-smoking groups after news reports disclosed that six of its 16 members had ties to a tobacco industry research organization. Questions of potential conflict of interest arose again Tuesday. During a voluntary disclosure of possible conflicts, three panel members did not disclose that their institutions had received tobacco industry grants. Morton Lippmann, the panel's chairman, did not mention that three researchers in his department at New York University were receiving a total of $578,000 from the Center for Indoor Air Research of Linthicum, Md., which is financed and operated by the tobacco industry. Lippmann declined to be interviewed Tuesday. Two other panel members failed to disclose tobacco industry research grants to their institutions. Geoffrey Kabat did not mention that his employer, the American Health Foundation of New York, is receiving a $109,000 grant this year from the Center for Indoor Air Research. Kabat also declined comment. A third panel member, Jan Stolwijk of Yale University, said his department several years ago received a grant of $250,000 from the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. ``I had nothing to do with it,'' he said. ``As a matter of fact, I was not happy about it.'' The EPA panel, which was meeting again today at an Arlington hotel, is considering two draft EPA reports. One concludes that cigarette smoke causes 3,700 lung cancer cases per year in nonsmokers and should be designated a class A carcinogen - a known cause of human cancer. The other report is a guide to aid the development of workplace smoking policies. As the meeting opened Tuesday, Rep. Chet Atkins, D-Mass., and 10 other congressmen wrote a letter to EPA Administrator William Reilly asking that panel members be required ``to sever their ties to the tobacco industry.'' They said EPA's rule ``prohibits officials from participating in decisions that `directly and predictably affect the financial interest' of an industry in which they have an employment or financial stake.'' David Ryan, an EPA spokesman, said the agency had no comment on the letter. The Cummings study measured levels of cotinine, a nicotine breakdown product, in the urine of 669 nonsmokers. He found that 91 percent had detectable levels. ``That means they had been exposed, probably in the past week, to tobacco smoke,'' he said. When this hitherto unsuspected high background exposure to smoke is taken into account, studies suggest that women married to smokers may have more than double the risk of lung cancer than do women married to nonsmokers. The EPA, which did not take the background exposure into account, concluded that wives of smokers have a 28 percent increase in lung cancer risk, compared to wives of nonsmokers. J. Donald deBethizy of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco said small amounts of nicotine found in some foods could be producing some of the cotinine Cummings measured, but others disagreed. ``We don't find any evidence that dietary intake is related to cotinine,'' said Joellen Lewtas, manager of the EPA's environmental tobacco smoke research program. Robert Flaak, the EPA official conducting the panel meeting, said he was not concerned that the panel members had failed to disclose the tobacco grants to their institutions. ``The fact that they left something out is not malicious, I don't think,'' he said. ``The disclosure process is a voluntary one.'' In materials sent to the panel, Flaak had written that the issues that might be perceived as conflicts of interest include ``the extent to which you or your organization have received ... professional or personal benefits from any individuals, organizations or groups representing any viewpoint concerning the issues under consideration at this meeting.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Rebuffs Symington Supporters; Upholds Runoff
DOC.TEXT: Backers of Republican Fife Symington were rebuffed by the Arizona Supreme Court in their bid to have him declared governor outright without having to compete in a runoff Feb. 26. Symington and his Democratic opponent, Terry Goddard, praised the court's decision Tuesday and said they looked forward to the runoff. The legal tangle began when Symington outpolled Goddard by about 4,000 votes in November's election but did not get the required majority to succeed Democratic Gov. Rose Mofford, who did not run this year. Symington supporters, acting without his approval, went to court to argue that the constitutional amendment requiring the runoff was invalid because rules on how to implement it had not been passed by lawmakers before the election. The court ruled against the Symington supporters three hours after hearing arguments. ``The Legislature does not have the power to eliminate by inaction this constitutional requirement,'' Chief Justice Frank Gordon Jr. wrote. Symington supporters said they would decide in a day or two whether to go to federal court. Symington, after initial hesitation, had come out against the lawsuit, saying he didn't think avoiding a runoff would sit well with voters.

DOC.HEAD: Younger Brother of Len Bias Shot To Death in Parking Lot Altercation
DOC.TEXT: A 24-year-old Maryland man has been arrested in connection with the shooting death of the younger brother of Len Bias, a University of Maryland basketball star who died of a cocaine overdose. Prince George's County police have charged Jerry Samuel Tyler of Temple Hills with first-degree murder in the death of James Stanley Bias III, 20, also known as Jay. Tyler turned himself in Tuesday night, said Lt. Alphonso Hawkins. A second suspect remained at large. Bias was shot about 1:10 p.m. Tuesday in the parking lot of the Prince George's Plaza Shopping Center in the Washington suburb of Hyattsville, Md., police said. The cocaine overdose death of Len Bias shocked the sports world through its illustration of the extent of drug use among athletes. Len Bias died just two days after his first-round selection by the Boston Celtics in the National Basketball Association draft. Tuesday's shooting apparently resulted from an argument that began in a jewelry store, Cpl. Mark Polk said. Jay Bias and two friends were shopping when they were confronted by a man who accused Bias of flirting with his girlfriend, the store's clerk, police said. ``He was confronted by a black male suspect. They got into an argument. There was an exchange of words,'' Polk said. ``The suspect asked Mr. Bias to come out to the parking lot and they would take care of business there. Mr. Bias declined.'' The man left, but Bias remained inside for a short time. He left after making a purchase, police said. He was shot as he and his friends were driving away from the shopping center, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Urges Court to Duck Iraq War Powers Issue
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department says the courts have no role in political discussions between President Bush and Congress over whether to go to war in the Mideast. Arguing that it was a matter for the ``political branches'' of government, Congress and the White House, Assistant Attorney General Stuart M. Gerson asked Tuesday for dismissal of a lawsuit by 54 Democratic members of Congress that seeks an injunction requiring Bush to seek congressional approval before attacking Iraqi forces. Lawyers for the plaintiffs argued that the court should tell the president not be ``snubbing his nose'' at Congress. Gerson told U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene that an injunction is unnecessary because ``there has been no decision, one way or another, to deploy forces'' against Iraq. ``It may well be that Iraq will come to its senses, it may very well be for the Congress to endorse the United Nations resolution'' passed last week by the Security Council authorizing force to expel Iraqi troops from Kuwait after Jan. 15, Gerson said. ``At this point, it's a matter to be worked out by the political branches.'' Gerson argued that granting the injunction ``would put this court directly in the way of defining what a war is - itself becoming commander-in-chief,'' Gerson said. The plaintiffs contend that the war-powers clause of the Constitution requires a declaration of war or some other authorization by Congress before the president may launch U.S. forces. ``I think the president is snubbing his nose at Congress and I think the court should say he cannot continue to do so,'' University of Pittsburgh law professor Jules Lobel argued for the lawmakers. ``This suit is not about whether we ought to go to war, but who ought to make that decision.'' But Greene expressed skepticism about Lobel's argument, noting that the Bush administration views the war powers clause as a process for ``the two political branches to agree when there is a war. ``It doesn't have to involve the judiciary,'' Greene said. ``You also have a problem to overcome in that no court has ever issued an injunction you are asking for.'' Presidents have ordered armed forces to engage in hostilities more than 200 times since the founding of the republic. Congress has issued only five declarations of war, though it sometimes has approved of presidential action through other resolutions. The Constitution says ``The Congress shall have power ... to declare war'' and also ``The president shall be commander in chief'' of the armed forces.

DOC.HEAD: Hostages Desperate as More Kuwaitis Flee
DOC.TEXT: Westerners hiding from the Iraqi army in Kuwait, growing desperate, are thinking of surrendering before Christmas just to have contact with their families, a recently arrived Kuwaiti refugee says. Dr. Abdullah Al-Shayeji, a 32-year-old economics professor at Kuwait University, said Tuesday that Kuwaitis were still risking their lives to get food, water and medicine to mostly British and American men hiding from the Iraqis. He said Iraq was not mounting active patrols to look for them, but moved quickly when informants told them where Westerners might be hiding. Iraq has promised to execute anyone hiding a Westerner in Kuwait. Foreigners who are caught are transported to Iraq, where they are deployed as human shields at strategic targets around the country to try to deter an attack by Western forces. About 600 Americans, British and Japanese are held at such sites. Up to 2,000 British and American men are still believed hiding in Kuwait. Americans and Britons told Al-Shayeji that many are considering giving themselves up just to talk to their wives and other loved ones at Christmas, said the professor. He said he had been in regular contact with four Americans and also spoke to the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. Al-Shayeji said that before he drove to Saudi Arabia on Nov. 29, two hostages told him to contact their families and tell them they were on the verge of turning themselves in. He said they want the U.S. government to take action against Iraq: ``They are wiped out mentally, physically, morale is down. They are basket cases, every one of them.'' Since the Kuwaitis help the Westerners avoid Iraqi patrols, find them empty houses to live in and get them food, the foreigners are in increasing danger as more Kuwaitis flee the country. The Kuwait information office in Saudi Arabia says 200 Kuwaitis have crossed the border into Saudi Arabia daily since early October, and just 200,000 of the original population of 570,000 native Kuwaitis remain behind. Al-Shayeji said the Iraqi forces had been especially vigilant at the university while they systematically stripped Kuwait of everything of value. ``It has been wiped out. Period. Everything that could be moved was moved,'' said the professor, who was an undergraduate at Oklahoma State University and received his doctorate at the University of Texas. The five campuses of Kuwait University, which once held 18,000 students, are no longer functioning, and neither are the country's 600 schools, meaning there will be no 1990-91 academic year for any students who stay in Kuwait, the professor said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Navy Submarine Has Financial, Technical Problems
DOC.TEXT:
Development of the Navy's $48.7 billion Seawolf attack submarine should be slowed until technical and financial problems are solved, says a House committee report released today. The vessel is ``perhaps the most conspicuous and potentially most costly example of a program struggling with the problems of adapting state-of-the-art computer technology into a multi-billion-dollar weapons platform,'' says the Government Operations Committee report. It recommends that Congress limit funding for construction of additional Seawolf submarines until the Pentagon clarifies the program's mission and provides assurances that the computer problems will be fixed. Spokesman Lt. Greg Smith said the Navy would have no immediate comment. Pentagon plans call for building 29 of the ships for $48.7 billion, with the first scheduled for completion in 1995 at an estimated cost of $1.9 billion. It is billed as the largest, quietest and most heavily armed nuclear attack submarines.
---
DOC.HEAD: Mammograms Improving, FDA Says
DOC.TEXT:
The ability of mammograms to detect breast cancer early has improved significantly since 1985, says the Food and Drug Administration. The agency said Tuesday that greater radiation now being used is justified by the improved quality of images, is still within FDA safety guidelines and is about two-thirds lower than 1979 levels. FDA surveys of mammography equipment in 1985 showed that 36 produced substandard images. A survey by the agency in 1988 found the rate had declined to 13 percent. ``I hope the surveys will encourage women to make greater use of mammography,'' said Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary for health at the Department of Health and Human Services. ``Early detection and treatment offer women their best chance of surviving breast cancer.'' The National Cancer Institute recommends that women over 40 have regular mammograms. A report on the FDA's surveys was published in the November issue of the journal Radiology, the agency said.
---
DOC.HEAD: INS Releases 75; Many in California
DOC.TEXT: The Immigration and Naturalization Service says it has released 75 Salvadorans from custody in anticipation of a new form of legal residence for them. The 75 were those who may qualify for so-called ``Temporary Protected Status'' under the new immigration law signed last week by President Bush. This provision was established for Salvadorans illegally in this country who fear returning to their war-torn homeland but nonetheless do not qualify for regular refugee status. To be admitted to legal residence as a refugee, an immigrant must demonstrate a ``well-founded fear of persecution'' at home. The Immigration and Naturalization Service in the past has contended that most Salvadorans who enter the United States illegally could not qualify as refugees. The new law permits those Salvadorans in the United States before Sept. 19 and here continuously since then to apply for ``Temporary Protected Status'' as of Jan. 2, permitting them to work legally and banning their deportation. The law contains provision for eventual extension to citizens of other nations. ``Temporary Protected Status'' is to last only 18 months from Jan. 1. An INS statement Tuesday quoted the head of the service, Gene McNary, as saying, ``In keeping with the humanitarian spirit of the Temporary Protected Status program,'' the service was releasing Salvadorans in custody who could qualify.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Stocks Bounce Back
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the Japanese yen Wednesday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange bounced back moderately. The dollar closed at 133.42 yen, down 0.93 yen from Tuesday's close of 134.35 yen. It opened at 133.35 yen, and ranged between 133.02 and 133.67 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 331.11 points, or 1.51 percent, closing at 22,193.72. The index had shed 863.38 points on Tuesday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.22 points, up from Tuesday's 86.65 point finish. Their yield fell to 7.225 percent from 7.350 percent. Currency traders said the dollar's slide followed its drop in New York on Tuesday, triggered by the U.S. Federal Reserve's decision to ease its grip on interest rates and a news report that Iraq may be ready to withdraw from most of Kuwait. Lower interest rates tend to erode the value of a currency. Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, said weak sentiment for the dollar was carried over in early Tokyo trading, but the currency traded in a narrow range after news about Iraq was considered. Sky television, a British television station, reported Tuesday that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was considering a possible withdrawal from Kuwait provided it be allowed to keep the disputed Kuwaiti portion of the border-straddling Rumailah oil field. U.S. and British officials could not confirm the report. On the stock exchange, the Nikkei index started higher almost across the board with an expectation that the Persian Gulf situation may make a favorable turn with the reported Iraqi move, securities dealers said. Dealers said the yen's appreciation and higher bond prices also helped trading, though the index lost as many as 235 points at one point following a round of buying.

DOC.HEAD: Contra Backer John Hull Said to Be Living in Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: American John Hull, sought in neighboring Costa Rica in connection with a 1984 news conference bombing that killed three journalists, has been living in Nicaragua since October, a newspaper reports. Barricada, the official daily of the leftist Sandinista National Liberation Front, said in Tuesday's editions that Hull is living with his daughter in the southeastern town of Juigalpa. The paper said Hull was reported to be trying to set up a business with former Contra rebel leaders. Nicaraguan presidential spokesman Daniel Lacayo said he was unaware of Hull's whereabouts, but said he would look into the reports that the American has allegedly been living in the country. Hull, 71, who arrived in Costa Rica in the 1960s, owned a farm and landing strip near the Nicaraguan border that was used to supply American-backed Contra rebels fighting the Sandinistas in Nicaragua. Hull, who holds dual citizenship in the United States and Costa Rica, was an enthusiastic supporter of the Contra cause. He was arrested in Costa Rica, but skipped bond in July and fled to the United States. In Costa Rica, Hull has been implicated in the May 1984 assassination attempt on Nicaraguan rebel leader Eden Pastora during a news conference. In the incident, a bomb carried into Pastora's jungle headquarters at La Penca wounded Pastora and about a dozen reporters and killed American reporter Linda Frazier and two Costa Rican journalists. Hull is one of 29 people named in a civil suit filed in the United States in relation to the bombing.

DOC.HEAD: Powerful Hawaii Telescope Produces First Photo
LaserPhoto LA4 of Dec. 4
DOC.TEXT: The picture had no particular scientific value, but astronomers were still ``hopping up and down'' with excitement over the first photo taken by whtt will soon be the world's most powerful optical telescope. Scientists said the $94.2 million Keck Telescope at Mauna Kea, Hawaii, will peer deeper into space than ever before and yield clues to the creation of the universe. Astronomers on Tuesday displayed Keck's first picture, which was taken with only a quarter of the telescope's 36 mirror segments in place. When completed it will be the world's largest telescope with a mirror 10 meters in diameter. The photo of a galaxy 65 million light years from Earth more than matched the quality of images from the world's largest effective telescope, the 5-meter Hale Telescope at Mount Palomar Observatory. It was taken Nov. 24. ``When we first saw the picture we were really thrilled,'' said mirror designer Jerry Nelson, an astronomer at the University of California, Berkeley. ``We were all hopping up and down.'' The photograph had no particular scientific value, Nelson said. He said the galaxy NGC 1232 was selected simply to demonstrate the quality of the telescope, which will be fully functioning late next year. Astronomers said the Keck will allow them to gaze back 12 billion years in time by revealing light images still traveling toward Earth. They will be able to see stars as they appeared some 3 billion years after the birth of the universe. Palomar, by contrast, reaches back 8 billion years. ``How did the Big Bang lead to the structure of the universe?'' asked William Frazer, vice chairman of the California Association of Research in Astronomy. ``To understand that we've got to look closer to when the galaxies first formed. This will enable us to get closer.'' The Keck telescope is the first to be built of automated mirror segments. It differs from other large telescopes in that its mirror is composed of separate hexagonal segments 6 feet in diameter. The aluminum-coated mirrors are kept in alignment within one-millionth of an inch by computer-controlled sensors. The Keck will offer research opportunities not possible with the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, which was supposed to see farther into the universe than the Keck but has a mirror flaw that renders it less powerful. NASA won't be able to fix the orbiting Hubble until 1993. The California Institute of Technology and the University of California are sharing the cost of the Keck.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Loses Exclusive on Noriega Tapes
DOC.TEXT: CNN got the scoop on Manuel Noriega's taped phone calls but no longer has an exclusive on the story. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler ruled Tuesday that transcripts of the tapes will be made public Thursday unless CNN appeals. He ruled in favor of four news organizations that had argued the transcripts were part of the public record and that the public had a right to know the facts behind a case that had tested the limits of freedom of the press. CNN had sought to retain exclusive use of the tapes, accusing the other news organizations of trying to steal their story. ``The content never was and never will be CNN's,'' said Sanford Bohrer, an attorney for the four news organizations: The Miami Herald, The Associated Press, Post-Newsweek station WPLG-TV of Miami and Gannett Co. and its USA Today. CNN attorney Terry Bienstock said the network had not decided whether to appeal. He said the judge broke new ground by deciding that material used in closed court hearings could be made public. ``To the extent it benefits all media, CNN's pleased about that,'' Bienstock said. ``But we still see this as a continued breach of the news-gathering process, by allowing access to information gathered under a promise of confidentiality.'' CNN has broadcast some of the seven tapes and argued that the recordings, and therefore the transcripts, were its property. The network said the transcripts should be burned or returned to CNN. Hoeveler disagreed, saying CNN ``did not interview Noriega to obtain the conversations, nor did it record the conversations.'' The tapes contain conversations between the deposed Panamanian dictator, who awaits trial on drug-trafficking charges, and his defense team. His lawyers accuse the government of leaking the recordings made by prison authorities. After CNN aired one of the tapes last month, Noriega attorney Frank Rubino argued that the recordings violate Noriega's attorney-client privilege, and Hoeveler on Nov. 8 barred the network from further such broadcasts. But CNN aired a tape anyway the next day, saying the First Amendment forbids prior restraint of the media. CNN stopped the telecasts after a federal appeals court upheld the judge's ruling. The U.S. Supreme Court, on a 7-2 vote, refused to intervene. CNN then submitted the tapes to Hoeveler, who had the transcripts made. After all sides examined them in secret, the judge found the tapes did not prejudice Noriega's defense and said the network could air them. Noriega is awaiting trial on charges of taking $4.6 million in payoffs to protect the cocaine trade.

DOC.HEAD: `Canned' Quake Forecasts to Help Warn When the `Big One' May Be Imminent
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have computed a table of quake odds that will help emergency officials in Southern California warn the public quickly that the Big One may be imminent. The U.S. Geological Survey scientists figured out the chances that a moderate jolt along the San Andreas Fault will be followed by a catastrophic quake. It computed those odds for jolts of different sizes and locations. When a moderate jolt does occur, the scientists will consult their canned forecasts and will warn state officials if the odds of a catastrophic quake striking within the following three days fall between 5 percent and 25 percent. Armed with such a warning, state officials can tell the public and get emergency equipment in place, said scientists who unveiled the quake-prediction system Tuesday at a meeting of the American Geophysical Union. ``The idea is to let people know when the possibility exists of a larger earthquake on the next several days,'' said Jim Davis, California's state geologist. Last month, the state announced the nation's first detailed plan for issuing warnings that there is a strong chance an earthquake will strike within days. Under that plan, state officials can close schools, prepare emergency equipment and urge people to stay at home until the danger has passed. A 1988 Geological Survey report said the Big One is at least 60 percent likely within 30 years somewhere along the southern San Andreas Fault, which runs past Los Angeles. A 1980 Federal Emergency Management Agency report said such a quake could kill up to 14,000 people, hospitalize 55,000 and cause up to $17 billion in damage.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Stocks Rebount
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell back against the yen today after rising for four consecutive trading days, while share prices rebounded moderately. The dollar closed at 133.42 yen, down 0.93 yen from Tuesday's close of 134.35 yen. It opened at 133.35 yen and ranged between 133.02 and 133.67 yen. It had gained 5.45 yen in the previous four trading days. About $9.94 billion changed hands in today's spot trading, compared with $12.73 billion Tuesday. Traders said the dollar recovered somewhat from its low start after U.S. and British officials said they could not confirm a news report that Iraq might be ready to withdraw from most of Kuwait. War fears tend to encourage buying of the dollar, seen as a safe haven in times of trouble. Sky Television, a British station, reported Tuesday that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was considering a possible withdrawal from Kuwait provided Iraq were allowed to keep the Rumailah oil field. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which had shed 863.38 points on Tuesday, climbed 331.11 points, or 1.51 percent, closing at 22,193.72. A total of 350 million shares were traded on the first section, up from 250 million the previous day. Shares first rose broadly after the report on Iraq indicated the Persian Gulf situation might take a favorable turn, securities dealers said. The yen's rise and higher bond prices also encouraged stock purchases, although the index lost as many as 235 points at one point following a round of buying, they said. ``But a wait-and-see mood basically remains in the market,'' partly because of uncertainties about the gulf crisis, said Takashi Morinaga of Okasan Securities. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.22 as of 5 p.m. (3 a.m. EST) from Tuesday's close of 86.65. Their yield fell to 7.225 percent from 7.350 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RESTORES dropped `was' in lead of first item.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: The 1989 best new artist Grammy that was taken away from the lip-syncing front men of Milli Vanilli will not be given to another act. The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences decided than when an award is withdrawn, ``the category will remain vacant,'' academy president Michael Greene said Tuesday. ``There is one winner. There is no first runner-up. We either have a winner or we give no award,'' Greene said in a statement. In addition, Milli Vanilli's three entries in the 1990 awards were declared ineligible. However, their single ``Blame It On The Rain,'' written by Diane Warren, remains eligible in the 1990 Song of the Year category because the award is for songwriting. The academy stripped Rob Pilatus and Fabrice Morvan of their Grammy on Nov. 19 after it was learned that they hadn't sung a note on their album. The group's first and only album, ``Girl You Know It's True,'' sold 7 million copies and made the two unknowns international stars.

DOC.HEAD: Afternoon Edition Hits Streets
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News, fighting to bring back advertisers and regain circulation lost in a 6-week-old strike, has launched its first afternoon edition in nine years. Street hawkers Tuesday distributed 30,000 copies of the initial press run. The tabloid had blue ink printed across the top and bottom of the front page to distinguish it from morning editions. ``We have been champing at the bit to be innovative and try to do things when we think it's practical to do so,'' said News Publisher James Hoge. Theodore Kheel, an adviser to the unions, called the new edition ``an act of desperation ... doomed to failure.'' Using management, replacement workers and employees who crossed the picket line, the News has published every day during the strike. But its pre-strike circulation - the nation's third highest at 1.09 million - has dropped by more than half. The circulation drop has cost the paper many major advertisers. The News said it expects to lose up to $35 million this quarter and about $85 million for the year. That's on top of losses of $115 million from 1979 through 1989. In 1981, the Daily News ceased publication of an afternoon edition called Daily News Tonight. That paper lasted a year. The News' parent, the Tribune Co. of Chicago, committed $20 million to that venture, but Daily News Tonight attracted only about 70,000 readers compared with a hoped-for 200,000. The New York Post was New York's last afternoon paper when it closed down its afternoon edition in 1988. It started a morning edition in 1980 in an attempt to boost circulation and cut costs.

DOC.HEAD: Puerto Rican Leaders Fault Police Handling of Riot
DOC.TEXT: Puerto Rican leaders say it took a riot to draw attention to their impoverished community's problems. ``My community has the same problems, especially in the poorer neighborhoods, as the black community. We've been completely ignored,'' Emilio Lopez said one day after hundreds rampaged in the city's Wynwood section. The five-hour riot erupted Monday after six police officers were acquitted of conspiracy in the beating death of a reputed drug dealer from the neighborhood. Stores were looted and burned. Fire damage alone was put at $2.9 million. Business owners Tuesday said police were too slow to move in and save their shops. ``The Miami police sacrificed us,'' said Patrick Gerrits, owner of a contracting firm that fell victim to the looting and vandalism. Only three mismatched shoes remained at a shoe store operated by Ricardo Perez's family. ``I saw people on television running with boxes and boxes of our shoes,'' he said. ``The police stood half a block away and didn't lift a finger.'' Police Chief Perry Anderson admitted that the riot squad, which waited two hours before moving in, was slow to react. Nevertheless, he defended their caution, pointing out that there were no deaths or serious injuries. ``We live in a very volatile city, a powder-keg city,'' he said. ``You're damned if you do and you're damned if you don't.'' About 15 arrests were made. It was the fifth major racial uprising in Miami in little more than a decade. Previously, the riots affected primarily black neighborhoods. ``There seems to be an invisible government, where the voices of minorities, unless they peak in violence, are not heard,'' said Betzaida Ferrer, state director of the national Puerto Rican Foundation. Emilio Lopez said inadequate education, health care and social services, a lack of jobs and tense relations with police plague the community and make disturbances more likely. The jury on Monday cleared the officers of conspiracy in the beating death of Leonardo Mercado two years ago and deadlocked on more serious civil rights charges. The judge declared a mistrial on those charges. Community leaders met Tuesday night and called for a renewed investigation of the slaying. They also demanded a retrial on the deadlocked charges and better communication with local government. ``We are getting a lot of attention now, but I don't want within 48 hours everything to be forgotten,'' said Ivette Morgan, a Puerto Rican member of the Community Relations Board.

DOC.HEAD: Social Democrats In Crisis, Lafontaine Declines Party Leadership
DOC.TEXT: The main opposition Social Democrats are in the throes of their worst crisis in years after standard-bearer Oskar Lafontaine failed to unseat Chancellor Helmut Kohl, then turned down the party chairmanship. The left-leaning Social Democrats are a party without a platform. They are crippled by internal divisions and desperately seeking a new leader of the caliber of senior party member Willy Brandt, the former chancellor. Lafontaine said Tuesday that he is too busy as governor of Saarland state to assume the chairmanship. But he also complained about the half-hearted support his campaign received among some Social Democrats before Sunday's election. ``It is impossible to conduct an election campaign without solidarity,'' Lafontaine said Tuesday.. Lafontaine refused to fully embrace German unity during the campaign. The resulting damage was especially severe in what had been East Germany, where the party captured just 25 percent of the vote. Social Democrats are now viewed by many there as political pariahs. Lafontaine, 47, spent most of his campaign warning against the pitfalls of unification, rather than proposing how unity's problems - like high unemployment in the eastern lands - can be solved. ``The SPD should wholeheartedly say that unification is a positive development,'' said Renate Koecher, a researcher at the Allensbach polling institute. ``Secondly, they should see the new German states (East Germany) as new turf where they have to be intensively engaged.'' The party lost a half-million votes to Kohl's Christian Democrats in the opposition party's worst electoral showing since 1957. It was the Social Democrats' third defeat by Kohl since he came to power eight years ago. Kohl's grasp on Germany's leadership is already being compared to that of Konrad Adenauer, West Germany's first chancellor, who held office for 14 years. ``It really is now a fairly unbalanced political system, with a very strong predominance of the government parties,'' said Peter Pulzer, an Oxford University Germany specialist who observed the elections. The governing parties, led by the Christian Democrats, also include the Christian Social Union and Free Democrats. It took Brandt finally to dislodge Adenauer's Christian Democrats in 1969. The Social Democrats are now hunting for a leader who can do the same to Kohl. Brandt, 76, is the Social Democrats' most popular member and is respected throughout the party. ``The party leadership needs rejuvenation,'' said national chairman Hans-Jochen Vogel, who on Tuesday announced plans to step down. Possible candidates for the top party job include Johannes Rau, Walter Momper and Bjoern Engholm. Rau, 59, is the popular governor of North Rhine-Westphalia, but he lost heavily to Kohl in the 1987 chancellor race. Momper, the 45-year-old former mayor of Berlin, had been seen as a rising star within the Social Democrats' ranks, but he lost in Berlin city elections on Sunday. Engholm, the 51-year-old governor of Schleswig-Holstein state, is a dapper, pipe-smoking intellectual popular in his home state. One of the Social Democrats' best orators - 47-year-old Herta Daeubler-Gmelin - has also been mentioned for the job.

DOC.HEAD: Two White Men Found Innocent in Racial Murder of Black New York Youth
DOC.TEXT: Two white men were acquitted of murdering a black teen-ager in a mob attack in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst section that heightened racial tension in the city. A jury took four hours Tuesday to find Joseph Serrano and James Patino innocent in the 1989 slaying of Yusuf Hawkins, a 16-year-old shot to death after he and three friends went to the white neighborhood to look at a used car. The blacks were set upon by a mob of up to 30 people wielding baseball bats. Another defendant, Joseph Fama, has been convicted of murder in the slaying. John Vento, whose first murder trial ended in a hung jury, went on trial again Tuesday. Several other defendants face trial next year. The attack heightened racial tensions during the mayoral contest between David Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani. Dinkins went on to become New York's first black mayor. Serrano, 21, and Patino, 25, smiled broadly and embraced as the verdict clearing them of murder, riot and other charges was announced. ``I'm sorry for what happened to Yusuf Hawkins, but I had nothing to with it. I was confident, I was secure in my innocence,'' Serrano said. Serrano was convicted of a weapons offense punishable by up to a year in prison. Sentencing was set for Jan. 11. None of Hawkins' family was in court for the verdict, but the Rev. Al Sharpton, a family adviser, complained about the verdict. ``The first defendants are convicted, but when they get to the bottom of the list, the community pressure is no longer there,'' he said. ``Maybe we just have to stay on the system all the time.'' Fama, who shot Hawkins, is serving 32 and two-thirds years to life in prison. Keith Mondello, the mob's alleged ringleader, was acquitted of murder but convicted of lesser crimes and drew five and one-third years to 16 years.

DOC.HEAD: Members of Maryland's Founding Family Believed Unearthed
DOC.TEXT: Archaeologists have unearthed what they believe is the crypt of members of Maryland's founding family, the Calverts, from beneath the ruins of a 323-year-old Catholic chapel. The find was described as one of the most significant discoveries in Maryland history. Wielding a gold-colored trowel, Gov. William Donald Schaefer ceremoniously scrapped the last bit of earth Tuesday from the largest of three coffins hoisted from the ground. The casket is believed to be the final resting place of Philip Calvert, the former British colony's first chancellor, who died in 1682. ``He is the one man who died in Maryland, of sufficient wealth and stature and a Catholic, to be buried in the church, and in a lead coffin,'' said Henry Miller, chief archaeologist on the dig. The two smaller caskets may contain the remains of two grandsons of Cecil Calvert, who was Philip's half-brother and the first Lord Baltimore, archaeologists said. ``In terms of religious and political significance, it ranks extremely high,'' state archivist Edward Papenfuse said of the find. ``It's probably as important as any Maryland site so far.'' Miller said experts will be consulted on whether to open the caskets. Maryland was founded in 1634 in St. Mary's City, at the state's southern tip.

DOC.HEAD: First Missile Test-Fired from Prototype Advanced Fighter Jet
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. says its YF-22 advanced tactical fighter successfully fired a Sidewinder missile in the first such launch in the high-stakes competition for the Pentagon contract to build the plane. The plane passed the test of whether the missile would scorch the fuselage or affect the jet's handling, Lockheed spokesman Richard Stadler said Tuesday. A team led by Lockheed and one by Northrop Corp. are in a winner-take-all competition for the $63 billion contract for the ATF, the replacement for the F-15 and the first U.S. fighter to carry missiles entirely inside its fuselage. The Pentagon has said it hopes to buy the first of 750 planes for the Air Force in 1996. The Navy has indicated it may want about 500 similar planes. Lockheed's version is more compact than Northrop's, the YF-23. The launch at the remote China Lake Naval Weapons Station last week had ``zero effect'' in the two critical areas, Stadler said. Like Lockheed, Northrop has produced two prototypes, which are being tested in a variety of areas such as wind drag, handling and engine performance. So far, the government has given each team about $750 million to develop their versions of the ATF, and each team has invested more than that in its own money since the program began in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: PANAMA CITY, Panama: a coup.
DOC.TEXT: Herrera told reporters at police headquarters that he was seeking greater respect for police: ``This is a movement that is not a military coup.'' He said members of the police ``felt humiliated and wanted me to be their spokesman. I came to cooperate in the reconciliation of this country. No one has been kidnapped. No shot has been fired.'' He did not elaborate on the alleged discontent among members of the country's police force, which was rebuilt after the December U.S. invasion that toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. There were no reports of injuries in Hererra's escape Tuesday afternoon from prison on the Pacific island of Nao aboard a private helicopter. A U.S. Army officer met with Hererra early today, but there was no indication as to what they discussed. Hererra said he also met with Panamanian officials to present them with complaints of officers.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: PANAMA CITY: of officers.
DOC.TEXT: Endara said Tuesday night that Herrera had tried unsuccessfully to seize a police station in the Panama City neighborhood of San Miguelito. ``He called several provinces and we know he failed absolutely. He called over the National Police radio network and he got no response,'' Endara told a news conference. Reporters saw a heavy deployment of security men at the presidential palace Tuesday afternoon and evening. Herrera, exiled by Noriega before the U.S. invasion, was fired as Panama's deputy police chief in August and was awaiting trial when he escaped. The government has not made public the details of the conspiracy it alleges he was involved in. Herrera had served in the country's Defense Forces until towards the end of Noriega's decade-old regime, when the dictator accused him of conspiring to overthrow him and expelled him from Panama. After the U.S. invasion, Noriega was taken to Miami, where he is awaiting trial on drug trafficking and money-laundering charges. Endara allowed Herrera to return home and made him deputy chief of the National Police which replaced the Defense Forces that Noriega headed. Herrera's escape Tuesday coincided with an afternoon march by an estimated 40,000 public workers to protest government economic austerity measures, and to demand pay raises and fringe benefits. The march, organized by an umbrella group called the Coordinator of Unions which includes some pro-Noriega leaders, also called for a 24-hour general strike to pressure the government into accepting the demands. Coordinator leaders said they will call longer general strikes if their demands are not heeded. Endara's government has been laying off hundreds of public workers under a new labor code it adopted earlier this year, and has been selling off government-owned companies in an effort to reduce the budget deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were also lower. Dealers said the dollar fell on an unconfirmed report that Iraq might be willing to retreat from Kuwait if it were allowed to keep the disputed Rumailah oil field. The dollar is considered a safe haven currency at times of unrest and chances of a peaceful settlement in the Persian Gulf pulled the dollar lower. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.93 yen to close at 133.42 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 133.95 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: -1.4942 German marks, down from 1.5030 -1.2750 Swiss francs, down from 1.2840 -5.0570 French francs, down from 5.0835 -1.6933 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6955 -1,124.00 Italian lire, down from 1,130.00 -1.1632 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1638 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9370, compared with $1.9350 dollars late Tuesday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $377.30 per ounce at midmorning, down from $378.20 bid per ounce late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $376.90, down from $377.40 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 95 cents to close at a bid $377.04. DOC.HEAD: Rainy Hilo Sets Record for November
DOC.TEXT: Notoriously rainy Hilo outdid itself in November, setting a soggy new record that broke an 89-year-old mark. Rainfall for the month was 45.75 inches, breaking the old record of 38.80 inches set in 1901, the National Weather Service said Tuesday. The wettest period was between Nov. 14 and Nov. 20 when 29.30 inches fell. Hilo also is having its wettest year since 1938, but forecasters don't expect a new record. Through Monday, 181.45 inches of rain had fallen this year, the most since 188.52 inches fell in 1938. The annual rainfall record at Hilo since records have been kept was 207.40 inches in 1923. Hilo lies below two 13,000-foot mountains that funnel ocean storms toward the coastal city and often causes them to linger.

DOC.HEAD: FBI, NYC Police Take Kahane Revenge Hit List Seriously
DOC.TEXT: A hit list targeting 10 people for revenge following the killing of anti-Arab Rabbi Meir Kahane worried police enough for them to offer protection to those threatened. Officers and FBI agents have notified all 10 people on the list thought to have been mailed last month by Kahane supporters, city Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli said Tuesday. The letter sent to a New York television news reporter on Nov. 14 contained symbols commonly used by members of the Jewish Defense League, a militant group founded by Kahane, Borrelli said. ``Time is on our side. We will make sure Rabbi Kahane's death was not in vain,'' the note said. It warned that ``things will go boom in the night.'' ``I think it's wise to treat any threats as legitimate,'' Borrelli said, adding that his officers and the FBI were investigating. Arab-American leader M.T. Mehdi and attorney Rita Hauser, U.S. chair of the International Center for Peace in the Middle East, were among those named. They said Tuesday that police warned them about it two weeks ago. ``I'm really concerned about it,'' said Hauser, adding that she was more worried because the list become public. Mehdi, secretary general of the National Council on Islamic Affairs and president of the American-Arab Relations Committee, said Tuesday he's had private protection ``for some time'' after 1974 attacks left him with a broken back and torched office. ``I ignore it,'' Mehdi said of the list. ``I believe 100 percent in the beloved First Amendment. I shall not succumb to any threat.'' The list also included Louis Farrakhan, head of the Nation of Islam; Clovis Maksoud, former UN ambassador from the Arab League; University of Chicago history professor Rashid Khalid; Columbia University professor Edward Said; New York Times columnist Anthony Lewis and Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, a Dartmouth University professor. The identities of the two others named could not be confirmed immediately. Borrelli did not say how many of those on the list accepted police protection. The Jews on the list are considered liberal in their views, contrasting Kahane's strident calls for the deportation of all Palestinians from Israel and the occupied territories. Hertzberg ``feels personally at risk,'' Dartmouth spokesman Alex Huppe said. ``Discussion about issues should not be conducted under threat of violence,'' Hertzberg said in a statement. He plans to continue teaching and speaking out, with extra protection from police and campus security. Said could not be located for comment, Columbia spokesman Fred Knubel said. Farrakhan, Khalid, Lewis and Maksoud had no immediate comment. Kahane was shot Nov. 5 at a Zionist meeting in New York City. Arab-born El Sayyid Nosair has been charged with the killing. Police say they have no evidence linking him to any anti-Israel organizations. Police found another list, this one with the names of six prominent Jews - including a congressman, two federal judges and a federal prosecutor - at Nosair's home in Cliffside Park, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Ohio Valley, Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell in the Ohio Valley and the Northeast today, and the weather was dry across much of the remainder of the nation. Light snow and flurries fell over New York and Vermont early today, and snow was expected to filter off Lake Erie and Lake Ontario during the day. The temperature was not likely to climb above 30 degrees in the region. Snow and flurries were expected in the mountains of Idaho, Montana, Colorado, Wyoming and Utah. Snow also was expected in northern Wisconsin. Sub-freezing temperatures were expected in the Carolinas and Tennessee Valley today. Some rain was likely in the Northwest. High winds were expected today in northern Colorado. The nation's high on Tuesday was 82 degrees at Fallbrook and Montebello in California, and West Palm Beach, Fla. DOC.HEAD: High Tides Cause Flooding, Evacuations in New England
DOC.TEXT: Wind-whipped rain and a rare high tide battered the New England coastline, forcing evacautions and closing roads. A change in wind direction eased the chance of more flooding today. Hundreds of coastal residents returned to flooded homes after Tuesday's storm dumped up to 3 inches of rain in parts of northern New England and gave Portland, Maine, its fourth-highest tide on record. Weather officials said an unusual alignment of the moon, sun and Earth caused tides to rise 2 to 3 feet above normal. Strong winds and heavy rain whipped the waves even higher. State and local officials had been on alert for the high tide, and no injuries were reported. Many feared a repeat of the January 1987 storm that flooded New England coastal areas. The tide was expected to crest around noon today. Forecasters said a change in wind direction from southeast to west lessened the risk of more flooding. ``We shouldn't have any problems,'' said John Cannon of the National Weather Service in Portland, Maine. ``The seas should be quite a bit lower.'' The storm moved out of the Midwest, where a deadly blizzard dumped up to 2 feet of snow on Monday. In Providence, R.I., Civil Defense officials closed the city's massive hurricane gates for the first time since Hurricane Gloria brushed the East Coast in September 1985. Hurricane gates in New Bedford, Mass., also were closed for about four hours because of high tide coming over the seawalls. On Cape Cod, Yarmouth firefighters evacuated about 50 coastal residents. In Eastham, Mass., volunteers waited for high tide to recede to see what remained of a 6,000-year-old archaeological find an amateur archaeologist discovered last week. The volunteers tried to save the remains of a campsite, hearth and dwelling but had to retreat to higher ground as water rose. Authorities in Maine said about 100 people were evacuated from offices on the Portland Pier, sections of which were under 3 feet of water. Winds of 40 mph to 50 mph hit the Maine coast. The high tide in Portland was 13.65 feet, nearly 4 feet above its norm but below the city's all-time high of 14.7 feet.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Explode Bomb Near U.S. Consulate to Protest Bush Visit
With PM-Bush-South America
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas exploded a bomb early today near the U.S. Consulate to protest President Bush's visit here Thursday, police said. The blast caused minor damage but no injuries. The bomb was planted under a bridge across the Mapocho river, 100 yards from the consulate in front of park near the city center. Witnesses told police the bomb was planted by three people wearing ski masks. They fled in a car. Hours later, an anonymous caller told a local news agency that the bomb was planted by the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, a pro-Communist urban guerrilla gang, to protest Bush's visit. He is scheduled to arrive Thursday morning on the fourth leg of a five-country South American tour. Police said they also found a mock bomb outside the consulate. Late Sunday, three bombs went off in Santiago, causing minor damage but no injuries. The targets were the offices of two right-wing political parties and a Mormon chapel. Another leftist guerrilla group, the Lautaro Front, claimed responsibility for those bombs, saying they were ``an offensive'' against Bush's visit.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Lawmaker: Chinese Human Rights Issues Cloud Relations
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. congressman today expressed disappointment in human rights discussions with Chinese officials and said Beijing's prosecution of people involved in the pro-democracy movement raises serious rights concerns. Trials of pro-democracy advocates raise questions that will not be overshadowed by the Persian Gulf crisis, said Robert Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat. Torricelli also criticized China's abstention on a U.N. measure authorizing the use of military force to dislodge Iraqi troops from Kuwait. He said he told Chinese officials this week that they ``missed an important and dramatic opportunity'' to improve China's international standing. Torricelli, a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said he was disappointed by human rights discussions with Vice Foreign Minister Liu Huaqiu and other Foreign Ministry officials. Human rights will be the focus of U.S. discussions on China's most-favored nation trade status and lifting sanctions imposed after the bloody crackdown last year on protesters demanding democratic reforms, he said. ``There seems to be a general judgment here that the worst in their relationship with the United States has passed, that the world is looking at other problems, that what might happen here with further prosecutions will be little noticed,'' he said. ``It is my view that that is a tragic mistake if that is their judgment.'' Torricelli said Chinese officials voiced regret over the army's June 1989 suppression of the pro-democracy movement but seemed most concerned with the international condemnation that followed. Soldiers killed hundreds, perhaps thousands, of protesters. Thousands were arrested in a nationwide crackdown against dissent that followed. According to court officials and Chinese sources, about a dozen major figures in the pro-democracy movement have been charged with counterrevolutionary crimes. At least two have been charged with plotting to overthrow the government, a crime punishable by death. Torricelli said China should grant amnesty to people jailed because of their political activities linked to the movement. Torricelli also said he told officials China acted irresponsibly by abstaining on a Security Council resolution Thursday that authorized force against Iraq if it refuses to withdraw troops from Kuwait. China was the only permanent member of the council that did not support it.

DOC.HEAD: Wing Fire on Northwest Jet; No One Injured
With PM-Planes Collide, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fire was spotted on the wing of a Northwest jetliner after it landed at Detroit Metropolitan Airport today. The fire was put out and passengers safely left the aircraft, officials said. Northwest Airlines spokeswoman Christy Clapp said residual fuel in an auxilary power unit ignited on the right wing. She said the fire was spotted by ground crews as the Boeing 727 was taxiing to the terminal. A ground agent put out the fire at the gate, and firefighters doused the plane with chemical foam to prevent another flareup. Flight 582, with 69 passengers and six crew members aboard, landed at the airport about 6 a.m. after a flight from Seattle. The passengers left the plane at the terminal gate, Clapp said from Northwest headquarters in Eagan, Minn. An unidentified passenger told television station WXYZ that there was no panic among the passengers. The wing unit runs the plane's air conditioning on the ground, Clapp said. Flight 582 was scheduled to continue to Newark, N.J., Clapp said. The passengers were put on other flights. National Transportation Safety Board spokesman Alan Pollock said the agency would decide whether to investigate after it receives reports on the fire. On Monday, two Northwest Airlines jets collided on a runway at the airport west of Detroit. A fireball swept one of the planes, killing eight people.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Says New Ground Radar System Could Have Helped Prevent Detroit Collision
With PM-Planes Collide, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A new ground radar system to be installed at airports in Detroit and 29 other cities will help air traffic controllers prevent accidents like the one in Detroit, a federal official said. The new system is designed to track vehicle and aircraft movement on runways, Robert Bartanowicz, supervisor of the Federal Aviation Administration Academy in Oklahoma City, said Tuesday. ``It gives us a video map of the airport on the radar screen,'' Bartanowicz said. ``It can paint runways, ramp areas and pickup targets such as trucks and aircraft. ``It will especially be useful during periods of low visibility,'' he said. Detroit, which doesn't have ground radar, is among the first 10 cities scheduled to receive the Airport Surface Detection Equipment 3 sometime after March, he said. A collision between two jetliners on a Detroit runway Monday killed eight people and injured 24 others. A transcript obtained by NBC indicated the pilot of one plane told an air traffic controller moments before the accident that he was lost in the fog. Bartanowicz said the FAA currently is testing the system in Pittsburgh. ``These are highly reliable and much better, much improved,'' Bartanowicz said. ``It's a good way of directing surface traffic.'' He said tests on the model in Pittsburgh are not complete. But the FAA academy is set to receive one for training in March 1991. He said other models will be installed in airports sometime after that.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney to Ask Allies for More Help for Gulf Buildup
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney will ask NATO allies for more help in transporting American troops to the Persian Gulf region, a U.S. official said today. The official said the appeal would be made at a two-day defense ministers meeting starting Thursday. The official cited a need for planes and ships to bring more American troops and their gear to the gulf, for help in transporting U.S. troops through European ports, and also for more chemical-warfare protective gear. ``All of them (the allies) have made some contributions to the effort in the gulf,'' said the official. But he said more help is needed for ``this massive undertaking.'' ``We have some requirements that have already been presented and not all have been met,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We need (chemical warfare) suits. We have received some, notably from the Germans. The British and some of the Arab forces need them as well,'' said the official. There are now about 300,000 U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf region, a number that is to increase to more than 400,000 in the next weeks. About 100,000 American troops are being transported from Europe. Today, NATO's European defense ministers met to discuss the prospect of war in the gulf and a new conventional and nuclear defense strategy for the allies to reflect a new East-West relationship. Cheney and Canadian Defense Minister Bill McKnight join them Thursday for two more days of talks on the same issues. The meeting comes one week after the adoption of the U.N. resolution authorizing military action against Iraq unless it leaves Kuwait by Jan. 15, almost six months after it invaded and annexed its small neighbor. In all, forces from 27 nations are lined up against Iraq. All 16 NATO allies, except Turkey, Luxembourg, Iceland and Germany have sent forces to the gulf region. In recent weeks, Washington issued two separate appeals to its allies for help in flying and shipping American forces to the gulf. While the response has been generally good, officials said more help was needed in view of the scope of the U.S. military buildup. NATO will not specify the contribution each of the allies has made to date for fear that providing such a breakdown would generate friction within the alliance.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Nominates Chief Justice to Lead Caretaker Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with opposition nominating chief justice to leader caretaker government, new quotes, student leader killed. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The opposition today selected the chief justice of the Supreme Court to head a caretaker government, meeting President Hussain Muhammad Ershad's condition for resigning. Thousands of people poured into the streets to celebrate Ershad's dramatic resignation announcement Tuesday night. Several thousand people assembled at Dhaka airport demanding that authorities prevent Ershad or other government officials from fleeing. In the northern town of Rajshahi, a student leader was killed and two other people were wounded by security guards when they marched on the home of a high-ranking state official. Ershad, a 60-year-old former army general, capitulated to the opposition's intense, seven-week campaign to oust him and said he would step down as soon as the opposition agreed on a candidate to replace him. Chief Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed's candidacy was expected to sail through Parliament on Saturday with Ershad's support, said opposition leader Khaleda Zia. Sheik Hasina, another top opposition leader, confirmed the choice. Jubilant opposition leaders appealed for calm today. For the first time, speeches by the two women who had led the long struggle to unseat Ershad were broadcast on state-controlled media. ``We have initiated the path of victory for democracy. We must take the movement to its final victory,'' Ms. Hasina, leader of the opposition Awami League, said in a recorded speech. ``The autocratic regime has fallen. Now is the time to display restraint and maintain peace to take our movement for democracy to a total victory,'' said Mrs. Zia, head of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party. Mrs. Zia and Ms. Hasina also warned the president of ``the people's wrath'' if he reneges on his promise to quit. Addressing a rally of 50,000 cheering and chanting followers, Ms. Hasina warned that the effort to unseat Ershad was not over. ``Although Ershad announced that he had resigned, in fact he is still in power,'' she said. She called for immediate dissolution of the Cabinet and handing over power to a neutral caretaker government. ``Ershad is conspiring to stay in power,'' Mrs. Zia said. ``Let there be no doubt that people will fight until they have achieved the victory and ousted the autocratic government.'' Seizing power in a bloodless coup in 1982, Ershad governed under martial law for four years, then quit the army and staged an election in 1986 which observers agreed was rigged. The drive to force Ershad's resignation began after he said he would seek re-election in June. The opposition insisted that a fair vote would be impossible unless he handed over power to a neutral administrator. Shahabuddin's confirmation as vice president would clear the way for him to succeed Ershad in compliance with Bangladesh's constitution. Once in office, the caretaker government would likely dissolve Parliament, making new elections possible. The opposition parties boycotted previous elections, saying Ershad would have rigged the voting against them. If Ershad's replacement is chosen by the opposition and approved by Parliament, it will be the first peaceful transition of power in Bangladesh. The campaign for Ershad's ouster had mushroomed in recent weeks, with doctors, university professors, some of Ershad's parliamentarians and civil servants resigning in solidarity with the opposition. Last week, Ershad imposed a state of emergency in an attempt to crush the movement. The army was called out to counter street protests, and the opposition claimed at least 100 political activists were shot and killed. This morning, scores of victory processions paraded through the streets of Dhaka, unhindered by police. The houses of Ershad's ministers were under extra guard by troops. Mobs attacked four ministers' residences and the offices of Ershad's Jatiya Party after his announcement. Ershad canceled all appointments and remained at his home deep inside Dhaka's well-guarded military cantonment, according to an aide who spoke on condition of anomymity. ``He is still in charge of the government,'' the senior minister in his Cabinet said. Other sources said the armed forces were still taking orders from Ershad. Ms. Hasina combined forces with Mrs. Zia in October to renew the pressure on Ershad to quit. Previous efforts to unseat him were undermined by the rivalry between the two women. Ms. Hasina is the daughter of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, Bangladesh's first president. Mrs. Zia is the widow of Ziaur Rehman, another former president. Both men were assassinated. Bangladesh has had nine presidents since it gained independence in 1971, and all have taken over after assassinations or military coups. Though Ershad gave Bangladesh a measure of political stability, he made little headway in alleviating the misery of his people. Bangladesh, one of the poorest nations in the world, has more than 107 million people. It is bordered by India, Burma and the Bay of Bengal.

DOC.HEAD: Telescope Targeting Problems Make Astronauts Miss Celestial Targets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with percentage of observing time achieved; picks up 2nd graf, `Ten percent ...'; SUBS 7th graf ```Except that ...' to delete now redundant first name of astronaut Parise.
DOC.TEXT: NASA tried to get its troublesome $150 million observatory working right today as more and more star-gazing time evaporated on Columbia's scientific mission, already set back by four years of delays. Astronaut-astronomers Ron Parise and Robert Parker got in 36 percent of the observation time planned for their 12-hour shift that ended this morning, NASA said. That compares to 17 percent in the crew's previous work period and none before that. Among the targets viewed today was a galaxy 41 million light years away that is believed to contain a black hole and Crab Nebula, a remnant of a supernova that occurred more than 900 years ago. ``We're trying as hard as we can,'' Parise told ground controllers. Ten percent of the Astro observatory's 230 planned celestial targets could have to be scrapped because of the trouble with its automatic aiming systems, NASA scientist Ted Gull said Tuesday. It could be several days before the observatory aboard the shuttle is working at peak efficiency, Gull said. After a day of problems Monday, Columbia's astronauts reported early Tuesday that the observatory's instrument pointing system appeared to be working properly. The system, which automatically aims Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes, developed glitches later in the day before it was coaxed back into operation early today. Problems persisted, however, through the morning. Spacelab Mission Operations Control's John David Bartoe at one point informed the astronauts that ``this is by far the most stable pointing we've seen so far.'' ``Except that the target isn't in the (telescope),'' replied Parise. New software later was transmitted to correct the sensitivity of one of the instrument pointing system's three star trackers. Fine-tuning of the system was expected to continue through the day. The observatory also has an X-ray telescope, which has its own pointing system and is controlled by computer commands from the ground. The telescope unexpectedly fell out of alignment Tuesday night, but ground controllers corrected the problem today and got the instrument operating again. Clusters of galaxies were observed. ``It's sort of a continuing story - nothing's quite right yet,'' said Arthur Davidsen of Johns Hopkins University, principal investigator for one of the ultraviolet telescopes. The astronauts used the ultraviolet telescopes' pointing system to spot a few targets Tuesday, but they sometimes had to aim the telescopes manually, a less precise and more time-consuming operation. The manual operation was not always successful, either. Trouble with the pointing system has cost scientists valuable star-gazing time, forcing to them to drop some low-priority targets from their list. Columbia's 10-day mission is the first shuttle flight in five years dedicated entirely to scientific research. Columbia's mission was scheduled to fly in 1986 but was postponed because of the Challenger explosion. The flight also was delayed for six months this year because of shuttle hydrogen leaks and other problems. The equipment problems have frustrated scientists who have been anxious to use the observatory to study X-rays and ultraviolet rays that cannot penetrate Earth's atmosphere. Davidsen said he remained optimistic. ``I would be surprised if they could not conquer this problem within the next day or so,'' he said Tuesday night. ``If they can conquer it by (today), and we can do excellent observations until the end of the mission, we can recover very nicely. The instruments are showing us that if we can point at these targets, we're going to get spectacular data.'' Also on Tuesday, the astronauts twice spotted the Soviet Mir space station. Mir was orbiting with five men 32 miles above Columbia, which is carrying seven astronauts in an orbit 218 miles above Earth.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapped Bolivian Entrepreneur Killed by Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: One of Bolivia's most prominent businessmen was shot to death today by his leftist guerrilla kidnappers during a shoot out with police trying to rescue him, authorities said. Jorge Lonsdale - the owner of the country's Coca-Cola distributorship and other properties - was kidnapped in June by members of the Nestor Paz Zamora Commando movement. The leftist group is responsible for a string of recent terror attacks, including the bombing of a U.S. Marine residence. Interior Minister Guillermo Capobianco said negotiations for Lonsdale's release were under way between his family and the captors when fighting broke out early today between the guerrillas and troops surrounding their hideout. He said preliminary reports indicated that Lonsdale was shot in the head by Michael Northtufster, an Italian who is one of the group's leaders. Capobianco said Northtufster was then killed in the shootout with police and soldiers. Two other guerrillas also were killed in the exchange of gunfire, and three were captured, Capobianco said. He said several policemen were injured in the fighting. The Nestor Paz Zamora group takes its name from the late brother of Bolivia's current president, Jaime Paz Zamora. Nestor Paz Zamora launched an unsuccessful guerrilla movement in Bolivia in 1970, the year before his brother founded the Revolutoonary Left Movement, currently the governing party. The Nestor Paz Zamora group claimed responsibility for a bomb attack on Oct. 11 on a U.S. Marine residence in La Paz. A Bolivian policeman guarding the building was killed and a statue of John F. Kennedy was destroyed. Police said several members of the commando group detained in connection with the October bombing were linked to the Lonsdale kidnapping. They said police discovered a small wooden cage used to imprison Lonsdale in one of two safe houses where the kidnapped businessman was held. Lonsdale, one of Bolivia's most affluent entrepreneurs, headed a major Bolivian soccer team and was part owner of a La Paz daily, La Razon. The kidnappers initially demanded $8 million in ransom for Lonsdale's release, but family members said they lowered the demand to $500,000 Tuesday. The family had planned to pay the ransom through a Catholic church leader. Capobianco told reporters the police decided to intervene today and attempt a rescue when they grew concerned the guerrillas intended to kill Lonsdale. He did not elaborate. But a leftist legislator, Gregorio Lanza, who watched the confrontation, disputed Capobianco's account. ``I want to denounce before the country that the government did not keep its promise of a truce (with the kidnappers.) Thirty policemen took part in the operation,'' Lanza said. Authorities said Northtufster, 29, the commando leader who was killed in the shootout, was a native of Bolzano, Italy. They said he arrived in Bolivia in 1982 to work with the poor and became a Jesuit seminarian. They said he broke off his religious studies to study sociology at La Paz University, and it was not known when he joined the guerrilla group.

DOC.HEAD: Fuel Prices Jump by Nearly Half Due to Gulf Crisis
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino's government today raised fuel prices by more than 45 percent, and congressional and labor leaders warned that new strikes and unrest would result. Mrs. Aquino said the government had no choice but to increase prices because of soaring costs for crude oil since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August. Although an increase had been expected, the size of it stunned the public. The price increase was considerably more than requested by the three oil companies. Long lines formed at gasoline stations as motorists sought to beat the 6 p.m. price change. Leaders of the two major labor federations called emergency meetings to consider a general strike. ``God have mercy on those who made this decision,'' said Sen. Ernesto Maceda, a leading critic of other recent fuel price increases. ``This is a most painful, most stinging and baseless decision.'' In an announcement only two hours before the increases took effect, the Energy Regulatory Board raised premium gasoline from 31 cents to 57 cents a liter. The price of liquefied petroleum gas, widely used in cooking, was increased by about 50 percent. Smaller but substantial increases were mandated for all other grades of petroleum, including diesel, aviation fuel, and kerosene. Fuel price increases in 1987 and 1989 were followed quickly by major coup attempts against Mrs. Aquino. The last fuel price rises, in September, led to a nationwide strike by left-wing unions. Consumer prices for fuel are subsidized by the government. The Philippines imports virtually all its petroleum, and increases in crude oil prices have strained the government's hard-currency reserves. In a televised statement, Mrs. Aquino claimed she had no authority to influence decisions of the Energy Regulatory Board, although it is directly subordinate to her office. She urged the board to reduce the increases for kerosene, petroleum gas and diesel and to transfer them to other categories of petroleum ``that will not affect so much our poor countrymen.'' Several Cabinet members appeared to have been caught by surprise by the announcement. Labor Secretary Ruben Torres said he was ``shocked.'' Transport Secretary Oscar Orbos urged reporters to tone down critical reports about the price increase to ``help the president.'' Sources at some newspapers controlled by the government said editors were told by Mrs. Aquino's staff to refrain from critical remarks about the price increase.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Lead Appears To Widen In Latest Poll
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Cheney wishing Walesa victory. TRIMS.
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa has widened his lead over dark-horse challenger Stanislaw Tyminski four days before the final presidential vote, according to an independent poll published today. In another boost for Walesa, U.S. Defense Secretary Richard B. Cheney met with the Solidarity leader today in Gdansk and wished him ``victory and success'' in the runoff election. ``I have certain political experience and I feel that I have talked today with the man who will win,'' Cheney, a former congressman, told Walesa in the presence of reporters at the end of their 40-minute meeting at Solidarity headquarters in Gdansk. ``I wish you victory and success in this difficult task,'' he said. Tyminski had claimed during a rally Tuesday that he was invited to meet with Cheney but turned down the invitation. A U.S. source said Tyminski was on the guest list for an embassy reception for Cheney but that no special meeting was planned. In the poll, 61 percent of those questioned supported Walesa and 20 percent backed Tyminski. The remaining 19 percent were undecided, according to the survey conducted by the private polling service Demoskop and commissioned by the government-owned newspaper Rzeczpospolita. An opinion poll conducted a week ago by state television put Walesa's support at 58 percent and Tyminski's at 30 percent. A Polish emigre businessman who says he made a fortune in Peru and Canada, Tyminski returned to his native land in September and scored a stunning second-place finish in the first round of voting on Nov. 25. His victory forced Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki out of the race. The poll published today was based on a survey of 988 people across the nation and conducted on Tuesday. No margin for error was given. At a news conference on Tuesday, Tyminski said his own soundings showed him trailing Walesa 44 percent to 50 percent, with his support growing by 1.5 percent daily. Today, Tyminski campaign officials denied a claim made in a report on Polish television that he had beaten his wife and refused to give food and medicine to his children in Canada last year. The charge was made in a taped interview broadcast late Tuesday by a woman identified only as Clara Fox. ``The information has nothing in common with the truth,'' said campaign spokeswoman Agnieska Majewska. Tyminksi acknowledged an acquaintance with the Foxes, but said it was only slight. ``Mr. Fox visited us two times and I threw him out because he acted in an uncultured way,'' Tyminski said. ``He behaved in a very un-Catholic way. He insulted my wife and was thrown out.'' Tyminski has promised to quickly improve Poland's economy and has blamed many of its problems on Walesa and Mazowiecki, who heads Poland's first non-Communist government in more than four decades. But Tyminski has also been criticized for his leadership of the fringe Libertarian Party of Canada, his advocacy of nuclear weapons and his long absence from Poland.

DOC.HEAD: State, Local Leaders Face Tough Budget Choices Nationwide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `Massachusetts has ...,' to CORRECT that Maine has proposed postponing, not postponed, contribution to pension plan.
DOC.TEXT: New York state is laying off 10,000 workers. Los Angeles has stopped hiring new police officers even though street crime is getting worse. Maryland halted a program that buys medicine for the poor. Across the nation, state and local officials are making tough choices.
