Squeezed by falling revenue, they are balancing the books the hard way, by cutting back on what government can do. ``I guarantee you we won't be able to care for as many foster children, mentally ill and so forth as we did last year of the year before,'' said Roger Wilson, a state senator from Missouri, which faces a projected $70 million shortfall. At least 26 states face deficits or budget shortfalls this fiscal year. Nearly all have made spending cuts and face more as the economy worsens. ``It becomes a political decision. Do you want to let people out of jail early or do you want to pay a higher sales tax? Do you cut education or cut health care to the old and indigent?'' said Marsha Howard, research director for the National Association of State Budget Directors. Dozens of cities have resorted to layoffs or freezes. Washington, D.C., will cut at least 2,000 workers. Philadelphia, facing bankruptcy by Christmas, has imposed a hiring freeze as a prelude to more severe steps. A $20 million deficit has forced a seven-month hiring freeze in Los Angeles. That will mean fewer new police officers at a time when the homicide rate approaches an all-time record. ``Budgets should not be a roller coaster ride for general managers, city employees or the public,'' complained Police Chief Daryl Gates. Los Angeles and Louisville, Ky., have closed neighborhood health centers. Vermont and Maryland are putting off programs to help the old and poor pay for prescriptions. Maryland health advocates say the cuts will affect 300 people with AIDS, although state officials say help is available through other programs. After several years of belt-tightening, services once considered untouchable now face cuts, including schools, Medicaid and prisons. On average, 25 percent of state budgets go to education, 14 percent to Medicaid and 5 percent to prisons. Options are even more limited for local officials, who rely heavily on federal and state aid. Federal funds have dried up and some states, such as Massachusetts, New York and Minnesota, have cut local aid. ``We're the last government on the end of the rung,'' said Paul Rouis, administrator for Sullivan County, N.Y., which raised property taxes and froze salaries. ``We've been successful at cutting our spending, but the sponge is dry.'' The Northeast has been hardest hit. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo has proposed a $1 billion spending cut that would affect jobs, school aid, Medicaid, help for the homeless and those with AIDS, and other services. An ambitious hospital support plan has been scrapped. There will be less snowplowing and fewer lights on the state's highways this winter. Massachusetts has already laid off 1,711 workers, leaving fewer people to minister to abused children and clean hazardous waste sites. In Maine, despite rosy forecasts by Gov. John McKernan during his re-election campaign, he is proposing the postponement of $73 million in contributions to a teacher retirement fund. McKernan also says layoffs are inevitable. Nationwide, at least seven states have fired or will fire workers. Five more have imposed hiring freezes. Virginia has laid off 700 employees, including mental hospital workers and college faculty and staff. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder has ordered a mental hospital closed. ``We're kind of like a boat in a swift-flowing stream and I am trying to keep that boat right where it is instead of being swept downstream in that current,'' said Gov.-elect Zell Miller of Georgia, where dropping revenues threaten layoffs next year. State college tuition is rising in Massachusetts, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Virginia and New Jersey. New York City faces teacher layoffs. Some New Hampshire schools have eliminated kindergarten. Some officials try to avoid unpleasant choices by shifting funds. Iowa transferred $20 million earmarked for environmental programs to prevent a budget shortfall. Dade County, Fla., borrowed $10 million from a building renovation fund rather than lay off 100 people, a move some opposed. ``Borrowing long term to fund current operating costs starts us down a dangerously slippery slope,'' said County Commissioner Charles Dusseau.

DOC.HEAD: French Radio: Bush to Meet Iraqi Foreign Minister Dec. 17
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, `There was...' with 1 graf to ADD White House comment that meeting will take place week of Dec. 10 but that no date has been set. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `Abed-Rabbo attended...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will meet with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Washington on Dec. 17 to discuss ways to defuse the Persian Gulf crisis, a French radio network reported today. Yasser Abed-Rabbo, a member of the Executive Committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization, made the disclosure to Radio France Internationale. In Washington, Bill Harlow, a White House spokesman, said no date had been set for the Aziz meeting. Bush said it would take place the week of Dec. 10. Abed-Rabbo attended a meeting Tuesday in Baghdad of senior officials from Iraq, the PLO, Jordan and Yemen to discuss Bush's proposal to send Secretary of State James A. Baker III to Baghdad and to invite Aziz to Washington to discuss the 4-month-old crisis, Radio France Internationale said. ``The Baghdad meeting was to study the current situation, as well as to fix a date for the Iraqi-American meeting, which was fixed for Dec. 17.'' Abed-Rabbo said in a telephone interview from Tunis, Tunisia, where the PLO's headquarters is located. He gave no other details about the meeting or how the date was determined.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Agrees to Compensate Iraq; Exit Permits For Soviets Being Issued
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today began processing exit permits for Soviet citizens, and Soviet officials said they were willing to discuss compensation for terminating the work contracts of more than 3,200 Soviet citizens. ``If there are going to be costs, we are prepared to bear those costs because we feel that the security and well-being of our citizens should come first,'' Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin said in Moscow. Iraq demanded the compensation Monday, when it announced the Soviet citizens would be freed. When Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, there were about 8,000 Soviet experts in Iraq, building pipelines, working on construction projects and advising the Iraqi oil industry. A Soviet diplomat in Baghdad, speaking on condition of anonymity, said more than 200 exit visas were issued before the Interior Ministry closed for the day. He said an Illyushin IL-86 jet, which can carry up to 400 passengers, was expected to land in Baghdad on Thursday to pick up the first of the departing Soviets. Thursday's flight will stop in Ankara, Turkey, to be checked for possible contraband in violation of U.N. trade sanctions. Aeroflot, the Soviet Union's national carrier, currently flies smaller planes twice a week to Baghdad. The five-member Command Council, headed by President Saddam Hussein, announced Monday it was allowing the Soviets to leave. The decision came five days after Moscow, once Iraq's chief patron, threatened to send troops to the gulf if Iraq did not release Soviet citizens. Iraq banned foreigners from leaving the country in response to a U.S.-led military buildup that followed the invasion. However, the Soviets in Iraq have not been listed among Saddam's other ``guests'' - the hundreds of Americans, Europeans and Japanese held hostage, or the 600 men held as human shields at strategic locations to deter attack. Churkin, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, said he did not know how much money the Soviet Union might have to pay to Iraq in compensation. ``We have had an extensive economic relationship with Iraq and it will have to be seen what kind of balance there exists in our transactions with that country,'' he said. But Churkin praised the decision to release the Soviet citizens. ``Moscow expresses satisfaction with the Iraqi leadership's decision and proceeds from the fact that our people can now leave Iraq and return home without hindrance.'' Still, Churkin said the Iraqi move did not lessen Moscow's opposition to the invasion and annexation of Kuwait. ``Our attitude will not change at all,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Study Shows Hospitals Tests For AIDS Without Consent
DOC.TEXT: Nearly one in four U.S. hospitals do not require patients' consent before testing for AIDS, and one in four do not require that a patient be told if the results are positive, according to a study published today. The study of 561 hospitals, reported in today's issue of the Journal of he American Medical Association, also concluded that two-thirds of all the nation's hospitals and about 40 percent of its rural hospitals have admitted at least one patient with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. ``AIDS is no longer a disease ... of just 20 cities,'' said Dr. Charles E. Lewis, professor of medicine at the University of California, Los Angeles, and co-author of the study. But despite the disease's spread, a clear, comprehensive policy has not been developed by hospitals to protect the rights of patients, the study concluded. ``From the perspective of a potential patient,'' the study's researchers wrote, ``the current state of policy ... provides no guarantee that their rights will be protected.'' According to the study, 22 percent of the nation's hospitals do not have a policy requiring that they inform patients they will be tested for the AIDS virus. And 25.3 percent of the hospitals do not have a policy requiring that patients be told they have tested positive for the AIDS virus. Fifty-six percent of the hospitals have policies requiring that AIDS test results be included in patients' records; 38 percent require that treatment plans be reviewed when patients test positive and 3 percent require that patients testing positive be discharged or moved to other facilities. Researchers wrote that the discrepancy in policies may be the result of the difficulty in trying to create a policy that protects both patients and hospital employees as well as guards against lawsuits being filed by either group. ``Not only do hospitals face potential risk of litigation from patients for violation of their rights, but hospitals also may be held responsible for placing health care personnel at increased risk by withholding relevant information about infected patients,'' the study said.

DOC.HEAD: Riverboat Gambling Rejected in Two Counties, Approved in a Third
DOC.TEXT: Riverboat gambling was narrowly approved in a referendum in one Gulf Coast county, but voters in two other counties rejected the idea of floating casinos along their docks. Voters in the three Gulf Coast counties went to the polls Tuesday. Hancock voters approved dockside gambling by a vote of 4,246 to 4,004. But voters in Harrison County rejected gambling by a vote of 18,490 to 17,463 and Jackson County voters rejected it 15,351 to 9,508. The state Legislature in June approved a law legalizing riverboat gambling along the Mississippi River and Mississippi's Gulf Coast, but gave voters in individual counties the option of prohibiting it by referendum. Only 38 percent of the eligible voters cast ballots in Hancock County, election officials reported. Officials reported a 52 percent turnout in Harrison County and a 47 percent turnout in Jackson County. ``I think there were two factors,'' Eldon Bolton, chairman of the Harrison County Election Commission, said of the turnout. ``One was the moral issue and the other was the economic issue.'' Supporters and opponents of dockside gambling waged expensive media campaigns. Opponents warned that dockside gambling would increase crime and corruption. Supporters said it would draw tourists and create jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Publishes `Who's Who' of Moscow Crime Gangs
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper today published what it described as a ``Who's Who of Moscow racketeers'' and a map of city neighborhoods controlled by the 10 major criminal groups in the Soviet capital. The weekly Commersant business newspaper said it sent a copy of its map and stories to Moscow's Internal Affairs Department for comment. Two days later, the department replied that ``organized crime does not exist as such in Moscow,'' the newspaper said. Commersant said organized crime controls some or all of Moscow's drug trade, prostitution, slot machines, video arcades and used-car sales. But its main business is extracting protection money, mostly from restaurants and other semi-private enterprises, it said. ``Whenever the supply of a product is forcibly kept below demand - such as narcotics in the West or alcohol during Prohibition - organized crime steps in and thrives,'' the newspaper said. ``But in a country such as the Soviet Union where virtually everything is difficult to obtain, the opportunities for organized crime are endless. Couple that with an overstretched police force and you have an explosive situation.'' The new Soviet interior minister, Boris Pugo, said Tuesday that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ``very concerned with the rise in organized crime.'' ``However, the struggle with this crime hasn't been effective enough so far,'' Pugo told the government newspaper Izvestia. He said ``corruption has penetrated all organizations, all bodies of power, including the highest echelons.'' Commersant said its picture of Moscow's underworld was drawn from anonymous informants and written by journalists who asked not to be identified for fear of gangland retribution. Moscow gangs have grown since 1988, when the two oldest and largest groups held a ``gangster summit'' to divide the city into spheres of influence, the newspaper said. That system soon broke down, and now there are more than 10 major criminal gangs known as teams or brigades, with a combined membership of about 6,000 people, Commersant said. It said the Assyrian Brigade has a monopoly on the illegal drug trade and operates out of the central Krasnaya Presnya district, home to the Moscow Zoo and several embassies. The Dolgoprudnay Brigade controls northern Moscow and leads in racketeering, particularly extracting protection money, Commersant said. Other gangs control warehouses and hard-currency restaurants, black-market leather and fur, counterfeiting and extortion of vodka salesmen, the paper said.

DOC.HEAD: Author Benjamin L. Reid Dead At 72
DOC.TEXT: Author and literary critic Benjamin L. Reid, who won the 1969 Pulitzer Prize for biography, has died at the age of 72. Reid, who died Friday in Holyoke Hospital, taught English at Mount Holyoke College for 26 years prior to his retirement in 1983. He was the author of two biographies, including ``The Man from New York: John Quinn and His Friends,'' which won the 1969 Pulitzer Prize; a volume of memoirs and dozens of essays and poems. His most recent book, ``Necessary Lives,'' published earlier this year, was a collection of nine essays on various authors, including Keats and T.S. Eliot.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Prison Escapee Is Captured After Fleeing Police Building
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with Herrera capture. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A former senior police official who escaped from prison and then seized national police headquarters was captured today by American troops after he fled the building. The former police official, Col. Eduardo Herrera Hassan, walked out of the building ringed by a group of policemen loyal to him and an estimated 80 journalists who were trying to ask him questions. The cluster crossed a roadblock manned by American troops, and Herrera, who was wearing civilian clothes, got away in the confusion. Herrera escaped in a car but was captured a short time later at a condominium building near the police heaquarters. Several shots were fired, and one of Herrera's supporters was wounded. About 50 armed men with Herrera also gave up after trying to flee. Herrera escaped Tuesday afternoon from prison on the Pacific island of Nao aboard a private helicopter, and took over the police headquarters near the Panama Canal early today. U.S. troops and Panamanian police then took up positions 300 yards away from the building. But both sides held their fire. Before fleeing, Herrera met with U.S. and Panamanian officials, but it was not immediately known what they discussed. The U.S. Embassy had issued a statement that said: ``In answer to a request from the government of Panama, the United States has provided military support to the National Police to help in the protection of the area around the National Police headquarters.'' The United States maintains about 12,000 troops in Panama to protect the canal until Panama takes it over at the end of the century. The standoff was the first challenge to the nearly year-old government of President Guillermo Endara. Herrera said he was not trying to overthrow the government but gain more respect for the police. The National Police force was created after U.S. forces invaded last December and toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who is jailed in Miami awaiting trial on drug-trafficking and money-laundering charges. Herrera, a former Noriega associate, was fired as deputy national police chief in August and jailed in October on charges of conspiring against the new government. Before fleeing the headquarters, Herrera claimed to have control of Panama's police force, but it was not known how much support he had among police officers. Officials said he tried to take over a police station on the outskirts of the city Tuesday night but failed. He managed to take over police headquarters early today. Endara said his government had the support of the majority of the country's police and accused Herrera of trying to stage a coup. Herrera allowed reporters into the police headquarters for a news conference this morning and said: ``This is a movement that is not a military coup.'' He said members of the police force ``felt humiliated and wanted me to be their spokesman. I came to cooperate in the reconciliation of this country. No one has been kidnapped. No shot has been fired.'' Herrera did not elaborate on the alleged discontent. There were about 100 men with Herrera at the news conference. Some said they were being held against their will. Herrera said all were free to leave. It was not known if he took any hostages with him when he fled the building. Herrera was a member of Noriega's Panama Defense Forces. But he had been on the outs with Noriega, who forced Herrera to leave the country by naming him ambassador to Israel prior to the U.S. invasion. After ousting Noriega, the U.S. government installed Endara, who had won popular elections that Noriega anulled. Herrera returned to Panama and was named deputy police chief in January. The Defense Forces were dissolved and replaced with the National Police, which number about 12,000 and contain some members of the old force. In describing his escape for reporters, Herrera said, ``A helicopter landed and took me from prison. I didn't know who they were until the men removed their masks and I realized that they were members of the police force.'' Prison guards fired at the departing helicopter, but there were n reports of injuries. A U.S. Army officer met with Herrera early today, but there was no indication of what they discussed. Herrera said he had assured the U.S. officer that he did not want bloodshed. Herrera said he also met with Panamanian officials to present them with complaints of officers. Endara said Tuesday night that Herrera had tried unsuccessfully to seize a police station in the Panama City neighborhood of San Miguelito. ``He called several provinces and we know he failed absolutely. He called over the National Police radio network and he got no response,'' Endara told a news conference. Officials said Herrera apparently visited other police stations before arriving by car at the headquarters in Panama City early today.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Secretary Removes Officers for Failure in Plane Development
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS four grafs for 10th graf pvs, ``Attempts to''; picks up 11th graf pvs, ``A statement.''
DOC.TEXT: The Navy is sacking a senior commander and reassigning two other top officials for failing to inform top Pentagon leaders of serious setbacks in the development of the A-12 attack aircraft program. Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III announced the actions Tuesday as the Pentagon released an internal Navy report that outlined a breakdown in supervision of the 6-year-old aircraft program. The A-12 Avenger ``stealth'' bomber is the Navy's top aircraft priority. The carrier-based plane is scheduled to begin replacing the aging fleet of A-6 Intruder attack planes in 1995 and to serve as a mainstay well into the 21st century. Garrett wrote in a memo to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that the Navy's A-12 program supervisors failed to make clear to top Navy and Pentagon leaders last spring that the project was faring much worse than the contractor claimed. The plane's development is more than a year behind schedule and at least 20 percent over the planned $4.7 billion cost. The controversy heated up last June when the contractors, General Dynamics and McDonnell Douglas, told the Navy they could not produce the first plane on time, that costs were escalating and that certain performance standards for the aircraft could not be met. Just a few weeks before that, Cheney had announced after a high-level Pentagon review of the A-12 program that it was fully on track. Garrett told Cheney he was forcing Vice Adm. Richard C. Gentz, commander of the Naval Air Systems Command, to retire by next Feb. 1. He also said he was reassigning the executive officer for tactical aircraft programs, Rear Adm. John F. Calvert, and the A-12 program manager, Capt. Lawrence G. Elberfeld. Calvert and Elberfeld also received letters of censure from the Navy secretary, although Garrett said he would not stop Elberfeld's scheduled promotion to rear admiral. Gentz's office today released a statement he wrote for his employees in which the three-star admiral said it was ``with sincere regret'' that he leaves the Navy, in which he has served since 1957. ``The NAVAIR team is strong, totally competent, and most of all has the necessary experience and dedication to meet any challenge by continuing to work together,'' he wrote. Dennis Kline, head of the Naval Air Systems Command public affairs office, said today that Gentz would not agree to be interviewed about Garrett's action or the A-12 program. An aide in Elberfeld's office said he was out of town and could not be reached for comment, and an aide to Calvert said the admiral would not comment. A statement issued in Cheney's name Tuesday said he was troubled by the conclusions of a separate A-12 investigation by the Pentagon's inpector general. Cheney ordered Deputy Defense Secretary Donald Atwood to make recommendations for corrective action when Cheney returns from Europe next week. A central theme of both the internal Navy report and the Pentagon inspector general's investigation is that overly optimistic cost and schedule estimates of the contractors were not sufficiently challenged by the government. The reports also said that official secrecy helped mask the project's problems. The Navy report said McDonnell Douglas and General Dynamics contract officials failed to advise the Navy of cost and schedule problems they knew existed. It said the contract officials felt pressured by upper management at their companies to avoid making forecasts of cost or schedule overruns, since such problems would reduce contract payments to the companies. In its report, the inspector general's office cited an instance in which General Dynamics required government inspectors at the company's A-12 plant in Fort Worth, Texas, to turn over their notes to review them for security classification. One set of notes was lost, and it later was determined that they had contained no secret information anyway. ``We question any procedure by which a contractor obtains access to, and control over, the work product of government personnel engaged in oversight duties,'' the report said. The inspector general was highly critical of the role of John A. Betti, the undersecretary of defense for acquisition. It said he put too much credence in assurances by the contractors that the project could be completed on time and within the cost ceiling, and that he dismissed warnings by lower-level Pentagon officials that the project was encountering serious problems. ``We find Mr. Betti's failure especially troublesome in view of a prior warning within the (Office of the Secretary of Defense) of cost growth on the A-12 program,'' Inspector General Susan J. Crawford wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Raises War Option; Iraq Issuing Exit Permits for Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Baker comment, Bush in Argentina, Soviets begin issuing exit permits, Moscow agrees to discuss compensation, Philippines raising fuel prices, U.S. seeking NATO help for troop transport, French radio report that Bush-Aziz talks set Dec. 17. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III told Congress today that Iraq must ``get out of Kuwait now or risk all.'' Israel issued a veiled warning to take matters into its own hands if the United States fails to act. Iraq today began processing exit permits for more than 3,200 Soviet citizens, and Soviet officials said they were willing to discuss compensation for terminating the Soviets' work contracts, as Iraq demanded. The United States, meanwhile, was preparing to seek more help from NATO allies in transporting troops to the Persian Gulf, and the Philippines government increased fuel prices by nearly 50 percent as a result of rising prices brought on by the gulf crisis. Baker's appearance before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee came as lawmakers stepped up demands for a role in any decision to attack Iraqi troops. Many on Capitol Hill have also been pressing the Bush administration to pledge more time for economic sanctions to work. But Baker told lawmakers the U.N.-imposed embargo ``has had little, if any, effect'' on Iraq's ``inclination to withdraw.'' ``Congress and the American people must tell Saddam Hussein in unmistakable actions and words: `Get out of Kuwait now or risk all.''' President Bush, on a visit to South America, said he disagreed with those who believe that sanctions should be given up to 18 months to work. ``I've not been one who's been convinced that sanctions alone will bring him (Saddam) to his senses,'' Bush said Tuesday in Uruguay. Bush was wrapping up the trip in Argentina today. In Buenos Aires, while greeting diplomats at the presidential palace, he was approached by the Iraqi ambassador to Argentina, Sahib-Hussain Tahir. A grim-faced Bush gave Tahir a quick, formal handshake without exchanging a word. In Israel, there was increasing concern about how firmly the United States was prepared to act against Iraq. An Israeli newspaper, Haaretz, said today that Israel has tacitly warned the United States that it will feel free to deal with the Iraqi military threat if the United States doesn't. Israeli officials said the report ``went too far,'' but stressed they were watching Bush's latest diplomatic moves in the gulf ``very carefully.'' Iraq has accepted Bush's offer to send Baker to Baghdad and to receive Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Washington. On the timing of that meeting, a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization's executive committee, Yasser Abed-Rabbo, told Radio France Internationale today that Bush would meet with Aziz on Dec. 17. White House spokesman Bill Harlow said no specific date had been set for the Aziz meeting. Bush had said it would take place the week of Dec. 10. Meanwhile, oil prices fell and stocks rallied on a report that Iraq is willing to withdraw from Kuwait if allowed to keep a disputed section of a border-straddling oil field. Britain's Sky television news said Saddam was proposing to relinquish all of Kuwait but the southern end of the Rumailah oil field. Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohammed al-Mashat, was asked today about the British report. ``I haven't heard that, but all I can say is negotiations involve give and take. I let you conclude what it means,'' he said in an interview on CBS. The Bush administration has been under mounting pressure from Congress not to act unilaterally in the Persian Gulf. House Democrats voted 177-37 in caucus Tuesday for a non-binding resolution telling Bush he must first get permission from Congress before sending troops into battle. The administration is also seeking dismissal of a lawsuit by 54 Democratic members of Congress that seeks an injunction forcing Bush to seek congressional approval before attacking Iraqi forces. The resolution calls for the authorization ``except to protect American lives from imminent endangerment.'' Lawyers for the plaintiffs argued Tuesday the U.S. District court in Washington should tell the president not be ``snubbing his nose'' at Congress. The U.N.-ordered trade embargo has cut off most of Iraq's oil exports and imports of food and weapons. In Moscow, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said Moscow was willing to discuss compensation payments for Iraq for allowing Soviet citizens to leave before their work contracts expired. ``If there are going to be costs, we are prepared to bear those costs because we feel that the security and well-being of our citizens should come first,'' Churkin said. A Soviet diplomat in Baghdad said more than 200 exit visas were issued today, and some freed Soviets were to fly out on Thursday. Economic effects of the gulf crisis are being felt far beyond Iraq. Philippines President Corazon Aquino's government today raised fuel prices by more than 45 percent because of the soaring cost of crude oil. Long gas lines formed in the hours before the price inrease took effect. Word that the United States will seek troop-transport help came from a U.S. official in Brussels, who said today that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney will ask NATO allies for more help during a two-day meeting starting Thursday. The official cited a need for planes and ships to bring more American troops and their gear to the gulf, for help in transporting U.S. troops through European ports, and also for more chemical-warfare protective gear.

DOC.HEAD: Deadline Set for EC Proposal to Cut Agriculture Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: The European Community was given a deadline of noon Thursday to draw up a new proposal for sharper cuts in agriculture subsidies that would rescue deadlocked world trade talks, officials said today. Uruguayan Foreign Minister Hector Gros Espiell imposed the deadline after a series of meetings to try to find a way to move forward the stalled Uruguay Round of trade negotiations. The negotiations, kicked off in 1986 in the Uruguayan resort of Punta del Este, are designed to overhaul world trade in 15 areas, including agriculture, manufactured goods, textiles and services, such as telecommunications, transportation and banking. They are sponsored by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world trade regulatory body. But the European Community's hard-line opposition to cuts in farm subsidies has threatened the 107-nation Uruguay Round, the most wide-ranging attempt ever to reduce trade barriers. In response to the deadline, EC trade negotiators gave differing signals as to how flexible Europe was prepared to be on the farming issue. ``We're ready to move by noon tomorrow,'' said Hugo Paemen, a senior negotiator for the 12-nation trading bloc. ``The EC is discussing new agriculture proposals as well as proposals in other areas.'' But Ray MacSharry, the community's top farm official who has been among the most intransigent negotiators, said: ``Our degree of flexibility is minimal.'' ``A lot of contracting partners need to rethink, not just the European Community. The EC cannot be expected to give in on everything,'' he told reporters. The talks stalled Tuesday amid heavy pressure from the United States and other countries to substantially reduce subsidies for European farmers, who are among the world's most heavily subsidized. In October, the United States proposed cuts in farm subsidies ranging from 75 percent to 90 percent over the next decade. Export subsidies designed to promote sales overseas were targeted for the deepest slashes. The European Community so far has offered to snip only 30 percent from subsidies for major crops over 10 years, beginning in 1986. Some reductions already have been made, prompting U.S. critics to contend that much less than 30 percent would occur in the next five years. France and Germany have been the most resistant to deep cuts in farm supports. The German government had been worried about the farmers' vote in last Sunday's elections. Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke said today he was ``imploring'' German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand ``to inject the political will and the courage which is obviously necessary to prevent a debacle in these negotiations.'' There have been hints of cracks in the community's position opposing any but the most modest reductions. Britain, the Netherlands and, surprisingly, Germany have urged more flexibility. The Uruguay Round is the eighth in a series of negotiating sessions since World War II designed to reduce barriers to world trade. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade was established in 1947 as a forum for promoting free trade.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Narrowly Wins Re-Election, Absentee Ballots Disputed
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Mayor Loni Hancock edged her moderate challenger by 590 votes, but her apparent victory could be reversed if a judge allows some late absentee ballots to be counted. Challenger Fred Weekes, also a Democrat, is asking a judge to allow the counting of mail-in ballots postmarked before the polls closed but not received until after Election Day on Tuesday. ``There are a large number of uncounted ballots out there,'' Weekes said. ``I don't know how large, but it could change the outcome.'' Weekes, 65, a city councilman, trailed Hancock 16,682 to 16,092 in the non-partisan race, but led 2,403 to 1,624 among early absentee ballots. Malcom Bernstein, a spokesman for Hancock, said he was confident she would retain her victory. A hearing was set for Friday to hear arguments on the late absentee ballots. An election code says absentee ballots may be counted only if received by Election Day. The runoff was necessary because Hancock, 50, failed to get more than 50 percent of the vote in a three-way race on Nov. 6. She fell 38 votes short out of 44,339 cast.

DOC.HEAD: Regulator Says Lincoln Was `Probably the Worst'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs
DOC.TEXT: The so-called Keating Five senators applied pressure on regulators in support of ``probably the worst institution in America,'' Charles H. Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings and Loan, a federal regulator said today. William K. Black, testifying before the Senate Ethics Committee's public hearings, asserted that one result of the senators' pressure was to delay enforcement actions against Lincoln - ultimately leading to greater losses for taxpayers. Black described as improper a request that one of the senators, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, made in a disputed April 9, 1987 meeting the senators held with regulators. DeConcini asked the regulators to waive a rule that would limit Lincoln's ability to make direct investments, and would have the effect of exposing the thrift to direct regulatory control. ``This is an institution that is probably the worst institution in America, and instead of people trying to help bring it under control, five U.S. senators were pushing us in the opposite direction,'' Black said. ``It was startlingly the wrong direction.'' Black, a senior deputy counsel with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, generally supported the earlier testimony of two other regulators that DeConcini, an Arizona Democrat, sought to have the regulators waive a rule limiting Lincoln's ability to make risky direct investments, and that he used the word ``we,'' suggesting he was speaking for all the senators. None of the other senators said they differed, he said. But Black went beyond previous testimony to assert that he believed political pressure from the senators led to later actions by the bank board that allowed Lincoln to significantly expand its junk bonds and direct investments. ``This led to greatly increased losses for the (federal) insurance fund initially, and the taxpayers eventually,'' he said. Black's testimony touched off a flurry of objections from defense attorneys for some of the five senators. ``We had found a massive violation of a rule that was vital to safety and soundness (of the institution), and we were being asked not to take any enforcement action and to allow that violation to continue,'' Black said. ``I felt it was intimidating and I felt Charles Keating had clearly set up the meetings to be intimidating,'' Black said. Under questioning by special counsel Robert S. Bennett, Black described a disputed April 9, 1987 meeting he and three other federal regulators held with the five senators under scrutiny. Black said the regulators had found massive problems at Lincoln, including the use of an accounting ``scam'' to produce paper profits and send big dividends to a parent shell company run by Keating, his family and associates. Regulators had also found evidence of ``file-stuffing,'' or the insertion of phony documents in an attempt to support millions of dollars in loans, for the benefit of examiners, after the money had been committed. Keating's institution ultimately collapsed and was seized by the government April 14, 1989. The cost to taxpayers of paying off insured deposits has been put at more than $2 billion. ``We call it a scam,'' Black said. ``I think most people do.'' Black took detailed notes in the meeting he and three San Francisco-based regulators held with the five senators. The five senators are under investigation for allegations they improperly intervened with regulators on behalf of Keating at a time when Keating and his associates were contributing $1.3 million to their campaigns and causes. On Tuesday, M. Danny Wall, former chairman of the old Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said he called Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., to tell him when California-based Lincoln was seized on April 14, 1989. ``He said something to the effect, `I think the board has made a mistake. I hope you are right,''' Wall said. The regulator said he responded, ``We had no choice.'' Bennett has used Black's notes to corroborate regulators' testimony that one of the senators, Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., offered the government a deal in return for concessions for Keating. Wall said he called Cranston after the senator had contacted him four times in three months on Keating's behalf, and several other times over three years. It was an unusual degree of involvement by a senator in the affairs of one institution, Wall said. But he contended it was not improper. Besides Cranston and DeConcini, the senators under scrutiny are Republican John McCain of Arizona and Democrats John Glenn of Ohio and Donald Riegle of Michigan. Wall testified that DeConcini contacted him at least twice ad Cranston four times to urge that regulators permit Keating's thrift to be sold rather than taken over by the government. Two years before the seizure, in the meeting where Black took notes, regulators told the senators that criminal referrals on Lincoln were being forwarded to the Justice Department. Testimony in the hearings has shown that only Cranston and DeConcini contacted the bank board after that. The two senators have said they contacted Wall about a sale because they were trying to save jobs at Lincoln and its parent company, American Continental Corp. Wall said Cranston urged ``prompt consideration and approval of any legitimate proposals'' for the sale of Lincoln, while DeConcini sought prompt consideration but did not urge approval of any proposal. He said he did not recall discussing the details of any of the proposals with the senators. All three proposed buyers were rejected because they were not ``arms-length'' transactions and Keating was involved on both sides of the deal, Wall said. None of the proposed deals would make Lincoln economically viable, he said. Under questioning by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., an ethics panel member, Wall said none of the senators pressured him.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan: Gorbachev Might Resort to Martial Law
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan said today that Sovie President Mikhail S. Gorbachev might resort to martial law to prevent his country's economic crisis from leading to anarchy. Describing Gorbachev as a friend, ``and a friend in need,'' Reagan said Gorbachev is torn between people who want to move faster on reforms and entrenched bureaucrats who are blocking his path. ``With production and the Soviet gross national product declining, will the people be patient long enough for the reforms to work? We must hope so, for the alternatives are not desirable,'' Reagan said. ``It is conceivable that President Gorbachev will feel the need to invoke some of his more drastic powers, using the army and the KGB to impose and maintain martial law,'' Reagan said. ``If he does so, I believe it would not be from some power-mad impulse, but rather from a belief that such an action would be the only way to save his nation from instability.'' Reagan, making the only public address of his five-day visit in England, spoke at the Cambridge Union debating society. He was warmly received by more than 500 students and faculty. ``If the peaceful-transition scenario does not succeed and if the martial law scenario is played out and fails to push the transition forward, the so-called worse case may result. This would involve chaos, civil strife, perhaps anarchy and widespread famine. The spill-over from such an upheaval would become everyone's business. ``There would be millions of starving refuges and there would be uncertainty about the control of the remaining nuclear weapons deployed about the Soviet countryside. ``For all these reasons we in the West must make every effort to understand the current transition. We must understand the tension between and among the various nationalities within the USSR and we must assist the people of that vast land in making the transition to democracy and a market economy as peacefully as possible,'' he said. A few demonstrators were outside the debating chamber, two of them protesting U.S. policy in Guatemala. One student had a grocery shopping cart rigged up with a bicycle wheel strung with tinsel labeled ``Reagan's brain.'' Inside, however, Reagan was greeted with a burst of applause as he slowly walked in, nodding to the main floor and the jammed galleries.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Women Suffer Twice as Much Depression as Men but Reasons Not Clear
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with news conference. Picks up 3rd graf pvs `A three-year ...'
DOC.TEXT: Women are twic as likely as men to experience depression, a major public health problem that costs the United States $16 billion a year, officials said today. The American Psychological Association said patterns of thinking, physical and sexual abuse, poverty and unhappy marriages are all woven into a complex tapestry that puts women at double the risk for depression. Bonnie Strickland, an Amherst professor of psychology and past president of the APA, called depression ``a major public health problem'' that costs the country about $16 billion a year and leads to about 30,000 suicides a year. ``Unfortunately, it's often not recognized and untreated,'' Strickland said at a news conference. The pattern of depression, she said, seems to be occurring more and more often among young adults, shifting away from the middle-aged who were once the major victims. And though depression occurs at some time in the life in one out of every eight men, the disorder strikes 25 percent of all women, Strickland said. A three-year study by a committee of experts organized by the APA found that at least 7 million American women suffer from depression and that most will go untreated, often with ``tragic, unnecessary losses'' such as suicide. ``Women truly are more depressed than men primarily due to their experience of being female in our contemporary culture,'' Ellen McGrath, chairwoman of the National Task Force on Women and Depression, said in a statement prepared for a news conference today. The study said more research is essential to determine why women are so vulnerable to the ailment, how best to treat it and how best to help women protect themselves from the dangers of profound depression. McGrath said the task force found that women of all races, ages and income levels - in Europe,Africa and North America - are all at higher risk than men for most types of depression. And, said McGrath, the reason is not that women are more apt to admit their feelings. ``It is astonishing how often this difference is denied by assuming that women more readily report emotional distress than men,'' she said. ``This argument says women are not really more depressed, they just say and think so.'' The report by the task force said a number of social, economic, biological and emotional factors raise the risk of depression for women. Consequently, the experts said, women and their depression should be studied in a ``biopsychosocial context'' that recognizes the varied effects of gender differences in all these factors. Among the task force findings: -Biology is not as strong an influence in women's depression as previously believed. Menstruation, pregnancy, abortion and menopause are not major factors in significant depression for most women. Infertility is, however, with up to 40 percent of women studied saying the inability to conceive is ``the most upsetting experience of their lives.'' -Depression in women may be related to gender-related personality styles that include passive, dependent patterns and negative thinking, but this requires more research. ``The research suggests women focus too much on discussing depressed feelings instead of developing action and mastery strategies,'' McGrath said. -Abuse early in life may play a large role. The study said that between 37 percent and half of all women have had ``a significant experience of physical or sexual abuse before the age of 21.'' For many women, depression may be the result of post-traumatic stress syndrome or even undiagnosed head trauma from battering. -Unhappy marriages and parenthood are important factors. The study said women are three times more likely than men to be depressed in unhappy marriages, and that having young children around creates a vulnerability to depression. ``The more children in the house, the more depression is reported,'' the study said. -The report called poverty a ``pathway to depression.'' It said that 75 percent of the U.S. poor are women and children. -Some groups of women are particularly susceptible, the report said. These include minority, elderly, chemically dependent, lesbian and professional women. It said these ``need special attention and support.'' Although depression now readily yields to treatment in 80 to 90 percent of all patients, most women with the ailment go untreated, the report said. And for those who are treated, the depression is misdiagnosed ``at least 30 to 50 percent of the time,'' it said. ``Approximately 70 percent of the prescriptions for antidepressants are given to women, often with improper diagnosis and monitoring,'' the study said. It recommended more research on the use of antidepressant drugs for women. The APA task force included 34 women and five men. The group included psychologists, physicians, mental health workers, authors and editors, and Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad. --- Nov. 29 The Westerly (R.I.) Sun on the Persian Gulf: It would be impossible to imagine that the Bush administration did not know what it was doing when it chose or agreed to Jan. 15 as D-Day in the Persian Gulf. Jan. 15 is the day by which Saddam Hussein must remove his patriots from Kuwait or see the Middle East explode into a cauldron of disaster. ... But Jan. 15 is a day with more than passing importance in the United States. In fact, the choice of Jan. 15 as a date of ultimatum for war could hardly have been more ironic. Jan. 15 is Martin Luther King Day. Martin Luther King Jr. was America's Gandhi. More than any other patriot, he represents non-violent confrontation and the peaceful resolution of nearly irreconcilable differences. It was his disarming technique of aggression that ended the timeless supremacy of institutional racism in the South. To supplant this day of peace with a day celebrating the threat of annihilation by fire is an injustice and a terribly sad commentary on the times. It does not bode well for a peaceful solution to the invasion of Kuwait. --- Dec. 2 The Flint (Mich.) Journal on the Persian Gulf: (I)t is our hope that (the) United Nations Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq will result in peace, not war. President Bush has done the right thing in securing the world's approval for the use of force, should that option become necessary. We strongly support the resolution because we believe that if Saddam Hussein understands anything, it is force. ... Still, we remain convinced that force should be used against Iraq only when it is clear all other non-violent options have been exhausted. And so, we applaud President Bush's announcement ... to send Secretary of State James Baker III to Iraq and his invitation to Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to come to Washington for consultations. ... The biggest potential problem we have with the U.N. resolution is its deadline. We understand the need for a deadline. The world cannot go on tolerating Saddam's belligerence forever. He has already defiantly ignored 10 previous U.N. resolutions demanding Iraq's unconditional and immediate withdrawal from Kuwait and release of all hostages. But just because the U.N. resolution allows the use of force after Jan. 15, we hope the Bush administration does not interpret that to mean the United States must or even should initiate war on Jan. 16. --- Nov. 27 The Union Leader, Manchester, N.H., on the Persian Gulf: As we face the stalemate in the Middle East, has the time come to consider use of our ultimate weapon, that is, the nuclear weapon? If it is determined that the sole means of ridding the world of Saddam Hussein's own nuclear threat is through force, then ... it would be foolish not to consider the most effective and life-saving means of that force. ... Nuclear weapons saved thousands of lives that would have been lost in a protracted war against the Japanese. ... Some will think this an ugly solution, but then, war is ugly in itself. A lengthy war, which would spill the blood of American boys across the desert sands, would be the ugliest of all. --- Dec. 2 Wilmington (N.C.) Sunday Star-News on the Persian Gulf: President Bush doesn't have the patience to strangle Saddam Hussein. He is risking war instead. He is risking war even though public support for war is dwindling and some top military experts say it might not be necessary; that given a year or so, the blockade of Iraq could force Saddam out of Kuwait. That was supposed to have been the plan when the president sent our young people to the gulf in late summer. They were sent to keep Sddam from overrunning Saudi Arabia. The refusal of other countries to trade with Iraq was going to bankrupt and starve Saddam into submission. It might have worked. There's reason to think the American people would have had the patience to sit it out. Considering the bloody alternative, a long wait isn't such a bad thing. ... The president got the United Nations Security Council to approve a resolution authorizing Americans to die, possibly by the tens of thousands, for the New World Order. If Congress were willing to play its proper role, it would be stampeding back to Washington to let the president know he has sprinted too far out on the limb that has us all on it. But with the exception of Sen. Sam Nunn and a few others, most lawmakers, Democrats and Republicans alike, lack the nerve to oppose the president. Not that many of them are keen on supporting him, you understand. They'd rather lie low and hope they won't get blamed for whatever happens. --- Dec. 1 Albany (Ore.) Democrat-Herald on the Persian Gulf: The Bush administration ... was wondering whether to call Congress into session on the Persian Gulf situation. It should do so without delay. Congress should be asked to act on a resolution that would authorize the use of force against Iraq unless that country meets certain conditions. One condition would be the release of all American hostages by a deadline. Another would be complete withdrawal from Kuwait. Such a resolution would not be the same as a declaration of war, but it would be close enough. As commander-in-chief, the president has the power to move troops and even to amass units in Saudi Arabia, as he has done. But there's grave doubt whether he can send them into battle without congressional consent when the United States is not under attack and there is no other emergency. Congress often comes across as a collection of craven kooks. Still, it's part of our constitutional government and has a role to play. The Security Council of the United Nations has authorized the use of force if Iraq doesn't leave Kuwait by Jan. 15. This is helpful from the standpoint of diplomacy, but a U.N. resolution means zip when it comes to the American Constitution. If Iraq attacks, our units in Saudi Arabian need no act of Congress to defend themselves. But if it's our side that shoots first, congressional action is required before the bloodshed starts. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Deputy Parliament Chairman Is Likely New Premier
DOC.TEXT: The independent deputy chairman of Parliament is likely to head a new coalition government following the resignation of Premier Andrei Lukanov's Socialist Cabinet, Parliament sources said today. A tentative agreement on Ginyo Ganev was said to have been reached in consultations between the majority Socialists and opposition parties. The talks were aimed at forming a new government and establishing a timetable for future parliamentary work and a new constitution. The accord ``is complete except for a few editorial changes,'' Bulgarian radio quoted an informed source in Parliament as saying. According to the broadcast, the document also specifies the distribution of ministries between the Socialists and opposition parties and the dates of regional and parliamentary elections. According to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity, most of the participants in the ongoing consultations on the government were said to have favored Ganev to head a new ``national government of peaceful transition.'' Other candidates mentioned were two independent university professors, Blagovest Sendov and Petar Dinekov. The new Cabinet is to include three deputy premiers and 11 ministers for a total of 15 government posts, down from 22 in the Lukanov government. Meanwhile, the Union of Democratic Forces, the main opposition alliance, prepared for a crucial weekend meeting in Plovdiv, Bulgaria's second-largest city, that may elect a new chairman. The conference, earlier scheduled for Dec. 15-16, was moved up after Petar Beron, the 16-party Union's chairman, was accused of links with the former hard-line Communist regime under ousted strongman Todor Zhivkov. Beron, speaking from Budapest, acknowledged in a radio interview Tuesday that he had worked as a police informer, informing on foreign visitors to the Museum of Natural History, while heading the museum's international relations department in the 1980s. News analysts in Sofia said the most likely successor to Beron is Dimitar Ludzhev, one of Beron's deputies who is also acting as an adviser to President Zhelyu Zhelev. Zhelev was Beron's predecessor as opposition leader before becoming head of state.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: bloodshed starts.
DOC.TEXT: Nov. 30 Delaware County Daily Times, Chester, Pa., on Middle East hostages: ``A nation that chooses not to pursue freedom for an innocent captive resigns its own freedom. Those who choose not to listen will themselves cry out and never be heard.'' ... This excerpt was taken from a postcard, one of about 450,000 that were mailed to the White House as part of a campaign to show the administration that the American public cares about hostages and hostage-taking should not be tolerated. ... But these cards were not intended to address the current hostage situation. The cards were mailed in 1989 - a year before the average Joe ever heard about Saddam Hussein and what a madman he is. The postcard campaign was intended to rekindle the passions across the land when Americans first became targets of terrorist attacks. The cards were meant to reignite hope for the other hostages. Our country has all but forgotten Terry Anderson, who has been held captive in the Middle East since March 16, 1985. We can only vaguely remember him and the other lost hostages: Joseph James Cicippio, ... who has been held hostage since Sept. 12, 1986; Thomas Sutherland, who was captured June 9, 1985; Edward Austin Tracy, Oct. 21, 1986; Jesse Turner, Jan. 24, 1987; Alann Steen, also Jan. 24, 1987. ... Our fear is that as time goes on, we are likely to get caught up even more in the ebb and flow of our everyday lives. One day, their names may not even draw the faintest of recognitions. And then all hope will be lost. God forbid. --- Dec. 4 The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, Miss., on the ``Keating Five'': ``Sir, I believe what is on trial here is not the five colleagues of mine but the U.S. Senate, and for that matter the Congress of the United States,'' thundered Sen. Daniel Inouye (at) ... the ``Keating Five'' hearings. ... What he said is true, but it should not, as Inouye did, be said in ``defense'' of the so-called Keating Five. Those who defend the five senators say the line between helping a constituent and taking a bribe is very slim. That may be true, too. Like the difference between good and evil, life and death, right and wrong. It's another way in which the words and actions of our elected representatives don't jibe with the common citizen. ... And until the campaign finance laws are reformed to make the average American's voice louder than the fat cat's cash, the language of our politicians will not reflect the voice of the American people. --- Dec. 4 Los Angeles Daily News on taxes and the airline industry: Those new tax increases devised by Congress and President Bush to cut the federal deficit have begun to bite, and now we're waiting for the payoff. ... Businesses and consumers still act as if they expect things to get worse before they get better. ... Taxes on airline tickets ... went up 2 percent. ... By itself, this tax hike is modest; it increases the cost of most tickets by less than $10. ... Several carriers are struggling, and the new tax could well act upon them like a wave of economic influenza, sparing the healthy but killing the infirm. That's the problem with raising taxes even modestly when the economy is sagging. Many enterprises that would absorb the new cost easily when business is good don't have the same cushion when sales are off. ... Even before Saddam (Hussein), Congress and Bush made their economic moves, the airline industry already was in the process of consolidation, in which the weak were getting weaker and the strong were swallowing them up. It would seem that the tax increase can only ... hasten the day when domestic air travel is controlled by just three or four companies. It's not the proper role of government to prop up companies that can't make a profit. But the government should try not to kick companies, through taxation or any other means, when they're down. --- Dec. 1 Sarasota (Fla.) Herald-Tribune on fuel conservation: In the interests of fuel conservation, reduced emissions through more conservation driving habits and better maintenance of our roads and highways, we have urged higher taxes on gasoline. But it still hurts when the price of a fill-up goes up. Though the price rises associated with the tensions in the Persian Gulf have not led to less consumption of gasoline, perhaps the new round of tax increases will prompt drivers to plan their trips more carefully, car pool when possible, break out bicycles and break in new walking shoes. Americans may even take a sharper look at their gas guzzlers, comparing their efficiency to the promised economy of smaller cars. If Americans respond to the tax rises by conserving and using fuel more wisely, we can make progress toward a more responsible energy policy. But even proponents of the gasoline taxes will feel the sting when we fill up our tanks. --- Nov. 30 The Reporter, Fond du Lac, Wis., on Cosby vs. Simpson: The news probably brought out some cheering and sneering, along with sighs and maybe even cries. That bad boy brat, Bart Simpson, edged out a rerun of the Cosby Show by three-tenths of a point. ... Now that the two television shows are on opposite each other Thursday nights ..., the choice is clear. ... Viewers of The Simpsons take delight in the antics of cartoon character Bart Simpson, and both youngsters and young adults see great humor in his ill-mannered actions and insolent attitude. Cos watchers find Bart a disrespectful brat with offensive behavior, as opposed to the clean-cut, wholesome Cosby family which is sure to end its show on the right side of everything. ... Seeing this as a battle between good and evil is really going to an extreme. It's too much to consider it a battle between young iconoclasts and old conservatives. It's simply a matter of good taste. Given the choice of only those two programs, good taste should make the choice easy. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: choice easy.
DOC.TEXT: Nov. 29 Athens (Ohio) Messenger on China: It's one of the paradoxes of totalitarian regimes that they empty language of all objective meaning and yet employ words to send subtle, and often sinister, messages to the people they repress. That's why a recent evening newscast in China carried ominous implications. Since the early days of China's ``liberalization'' in the late 1970s, television news anchors have opened their shows with ``Viewers, hello!'' Earlier (last) month, the program began: ``Comrades, hello!'' The dread ``c''-word, symbol of coerced solidarity and phony totalitarian chumminess, had largely fallen from official usage. Its reappearance is taken by many Chinese as a sign that reigning hard-liners want to reassert their control not only of political institutions but also of social custom. A small matter, perhaps, but looking through the distorting lens of communism one can never be sure of the gauge of things. It's safe to say, however, that despite the comradely (so to speak) efforts of President Bush and his administration, Chinese communism is as entrenched as ever. --- Nov. 30 The Times of India, New Delhi, on Britain's new prime minister: Although Britain's new prime minister, ... John Major, is widely held to be a (Margaret) Thatcher clone, his choice of ... Michael Heseltine, one of his two rivals for the Tory leadership, as environment secretary suggests he has a mind of his own. True, the appointment can be seen as a way of bringing ... Heseltine down a notch or two by filling a relatively minor slot - one, moreover, which would test his commitment to reviewing the controversial community poll tax that Mrs. Thatcher had introduced. On the other hand, by making so fierce and consistent a critic of the tax as ... Heseltine responsible for taking a second look at it, ... Major is indicating that he is prepared, if necessary, to undo one of his putative patron's landmark measures. Hardly the behaviour of a clone! ... Major's retention of ... Douglas Hurd as foreign secretary sends a different signal, one of continuity. This is likely, and may have been meant, to reassure the Americans who valued Mrs. Thatcher's support on the (Persian) Gulf crisis very highly and who were apprehensive that her successor might not be quite as enthusiastically supportive. --- Dec. 3 Straits Times, Singapore, on Britain's new prime minister: What is important is that (John) Major, a man of humble origins whose early youth was marked by economic hardship, has risen to the highest elected office in Britain on his own merits, without the props of wealth or class. He thus exemplifies the social mobility that was accelerated by the policies of his predecessor, ... Margaret Thatcher, whose views on most issues he basically shares. ... In an important decision, he has promised to review the so-called poll tax, a controversial levy to fund local services, whose unpopularity with many Britons could hurt the Conservative Party's chances in the next general election. Notwithstanding this, however, ... Major in effect represents Thatcherism without Mrs. Thatcher. That element of change within continuity should be good for Britain, both domestically and abroad. --- Dec. 3 The Independent, London, on the Persian Gulf: President Bush said ... that the Iraqi leader ``doesn't necessarily believe that I am totally committed to what I have been saying.'' Why should he? President Saddam (Hussein) has been given little reason to believe the United States has the will for war. The behavior of Congress is undermining the credibility of Bush's threat of force and is encouraging the Iraqi leader in his dangerous intransigence. When Bush's firm position is subject to sustained attack ... the effect is to make war more, not less, likely. ... Although talks between the United States and Iraq will almost certainly take place, the situation continues to move closer to war. --- Dec. 3 Al-Ahram, Cairo, Egypt, on the Persian Gulf: (President George Bush's initiative for talks with Iraq) was a happy surprise for the proponents of law, legitimacy and peaceful settlement. ... The great majority of peoples reject war and want a peaceful solution, foremost among them the American people. ... But the condemnation of aggression and the restoration of right and legitimacy are musts that should not be tampered with or compromised on. ---
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Roundup
U.S. Officials See No Terrorist Ties in 1985 Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOP 9 grafs new with testimony about failure by U.S. agency to consult its chief investigator; Pick Up 2nd graf, pvs ``Within hours;'' DELETE 3rd graf, pvs ``The hearing'' to UPDATE
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government endorsed the Canadian findings about a 1985 crash in Gander, Newfoundland, without consulting the chief federal investigator who looked into the disaster, according to congressional testimony today. George Seidlein testified that the Canadian panel was wrong in concluding that ice on the wings caused the disaster that killed a planeload of American servicemen. The cause actually was due to the crew trying to force the DC-8 to climb after takeoff before it had accelerated to a high enough speed, Seidlein told the House Judiciary subcommittee on crime. Seidlein was the National Transportation Safety Board's chief on-site investigator in Gander, but his superiors didn't consult him on his views of the Canadian findings, which the U.S. government endorsed. By the time Canada reached its conclusions, Seidlein had transferred to an agency office in Lansing, Mich., and was about to retire, he testified. Seidlein ``wasn't intentionally excluded'' from consultations, testified Ronald Schleede, the NTSB's investigations chief who was Seidlein's boss. ``Why did you send him up there'' to Gander?'' asked U.S. Rep. William Hughes, D-N.J. ``Is there a reason you didn't bring him in?'' ``No sir,'' replied Schleede. On Tuesday, witnesses told the panel the U.S. government has no reason to suspect a terrorist tie to the crash. Within hours of the tragedy, the U.S. military officials readily accepted Canadian investigators' theory that the chartered DC-8 jetliner went down seconds after takeoff because of ice on its wings, witnesses told a House hearing Tuesday. Several eyewitnesses said Tuesday that they saw a bright light in the sky just before the crash, and a terrorist group aligned with Iran claimed responsibility for destroying the jet. Rep. Robin Tallon, D-S.C., and some families of the victims theorize a terrorist act connected to the Iran-Contra scandal might have caused the crash. How could Canadian investigators so quickly rule out terrorism and the U.S. government readily accept the assertion, disbelieving congressmen asked. ``I can't explain that,'' responded L.T. Filotas, a Canadian aeronautical engineer who dissented from a majority finding of a Canadian panel that ice on the wings caused the crash. The theory of ice on the wings is ``preposterous,'' said Filotas, who attributed the crash to an in-flight fire possibly caused by a bomb. FBI agents who went to Gander cooled their heels in a local motel after offering their help to the Canadians, who declined it, said Rep. Lawrence Smith, D-Fla. The agents went home 36 hours after they arrived when the Canadians informed them terrorism had been ruled out, Smith said. The FBI told the House panel it has no reason to question the accuracy of the Canadian findings. ``No credible evidence has surfaced'' suggesting the plane crash was the result of an act of terrorism, Nicholas O'Hara, deputy assistant director for criminal investigations at the FBI, said in written testimony. Yet the pilot who flew the first leg of the doomed flight, to Cairo, told the FBI he believed the explosion of a bomb may have caused the crash, said Tallon. The pilot said an Egyptian guard assigned to the plane disappeared from his post several times. ``The FBI ... found very serious allegations,'' but there is no record of what the agency did after it received them, said Tallon. Tallon wondered whether the FBI and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police withheld allegations relating to terrorism from the Canadian panel that looked into the crash. The Dec. 12, 1985, tragedy killed 248 members of the Army's 101st Airborne Division coming home from a peacekeeping mission in the Middle East. All eight crew members on the charter flight of Miami-based Arrow Air also died. Arrow Air was one of the subcontractors that hauled weapons to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua for Oliver North's secret resupply network. It operated in 1985 and 1986 during a congressional ban on U.S. military aid to the guerrillas. The Gander crash occurred less than three weeks after the Reagan administration secretly assisted a shipment of Hawk anti-aircraft missiles from Israel to Iran as part of the U.S. effort to free hostages held in Lebanon. The Iranians were outraged and felt they had been duped because the missiles weren't the kind they wanted. Rep. William Hughes, the subcommittee's chairman, asked whether the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency questioned the Canadians about the possibility of a terrorist bomb aboard the plane. ``I don't know of any inquiries made of the Canadians,'' replied William Allard, the DIA's general counsel. Hughes, D-N.J., said he found that ``incomprehensible.'' Allard said the agency gathers strategic and tactical military intelligence, rather than doing investigative work.

DOC.HEAD: British Hostage Dies In Captivity
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with name of hostage and comment from Foreign Office. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A 57-year-old British man held by Iraq at a strategic site has died in captivity, apparently from a heart attack, a British Embassy official said today. A Foreign Office spokesman in London identified the dead man as Donald Major. His hometown was not immediately known. The embassy official said Major died Tuesday at the undisclosed strategic site where he was being held hostage. ``This confirms the underlying need for Iraq to respond to our appeals for the immediate release of all hostages,'' said the Foreign office spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. An unidentified colleague released by Iraq informed the embassy of the death and said the man appeared to die of a heart attack, said the embassy official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity. The official said the man was the first British hostage known to have died in captivity. Three other Britons died of natural causes while in hiding in Kuwait and two were killed in a car accident in October while trying to drive from Kuwait to the Iraq port of Basra.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Drowns in Pool As Father Erects Safety Fence
DOC.TEXT: A man building a safety fence around his swimming pool did not notice his young son fall into the deep end, and the 19-month-old boy drowned, police said. Police Capt. Henriette Bester said the family had lived in the house only three days when the tragedy occurred Monday. It was reported Wednesday in The Citizen newspaper. Bester said Matheus Mulder was putting up the fence around the pool when his wife told him she could not find their son, Jaco. Mulder found the boy in the pool and administered first aid while waiting for an ambulance, but Jaco was pronounced dead on arrival at a hospital. The incident occurred in Witpoort, a town southwest of Johannesburg.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Israel Warns It Will Act Against Iraq If U.S. Doesn't
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Levy's comments to Parliament. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `In this...'
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister David Levy warned Saddam Hussein today that Israel would ``destroy his security'' if he tried to use peace moves in the Persian Gulf as a springboard for an attack on the Jewish state. Levy's remarks to Parliament reflected the apparent unease of Israeli officials at the prospect of a resolution of the gulf crisis that would leave the Iraqi president's army and missiles intact. ``Israel does not use the same instruments and the same deadly weapons as Saddam Hussein used against his people and threatens to use against us,'' Levy said. ``But if anyone thinks that through some maneuver in the name of peace he will be able to continue to threaten with the aim of surprising Israel, he will find Israel ready, always, with its might, to destroy his security, to hurt him until he is sorry and regrets his action,'' Levy said. Earlier, a Tel Aviv newspaper said Israel had tacitly warned the United States that it will feel free to deal with the Iraqi military threat if the United States doesn't. Officials said the report in the daily Haaretz ``went too far,'' but that they were watching President Bush's latest diplomatic moves in the Persian Gulf ``very carefully.'' Haaretz said Levy met Tuesday with U.S. Ambassador William Brown and told him Israel had kept a low profile on the gulf crisis because it was given to understand that the United States would confront Iraq's military might. ``In this lay a hint that if the United States backs out of its undertaking, Israel will no longer feel committed to a low-profile policy, and would react to the Iraqi threat,'' the paper said. Iraq has threatened to attack Israel if war breaks out in the gulf. In the past, it has vowed to use chemical weapons against the Jewish state, and Israel has distributed gas masks to its citizens. Israeli officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Israel expects the United States to abide by all its undertakings, but added that Israel has not received any official assurance that Washington will disarm Iraq. An official said Israel ``believes'' that once the crisis is resolved, Iraq will be unable to carry out its threats against Israel. He then amended ``believes'' to ``hopes.'' Levy summoned Brown after receiving a message from Secretary of State James A. Baker III explaining Bush's offer to send Baker to Baghdad, and receive Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Washington. Haaretz said Levy told visiting European dignitaries Tuesday that Israel would adopt ``the highest profile'' if its existence was threatened. ``These remarks, coupled with the statement to Ambassador Brown, express a new Israeli policy toward the gulf crisis, following the invitation to Iraq to negotiate with the United States,'' Haaretz said. The officials denied Israeli policy had changed. Another newspaper, Davar, said Levy's message to Washington was ``sharp.'' It quoted unidentified sources in Jerusalem as saying this message was ``the most significant'' so far between Washington and Jerusalem on the gulf crisis. Davar said Israel regarded the United States' official goals in the gulf to be Iraq's withdrawal and the restoration of the ousted Kuwaiti rgime, but also believed it had ``unofficial goals - including, in Israel's opinion, the disarming of Iraq, including nuclear facilities.''

DOC.HEAD: Outbreak Kills 46
DOC.TEXT: At least 46 people have died and 412 others have been hospitalized since a cholera outbreak in November, news reports said Wednesday. Ninety-one patients were receiving medical treatment in the Copperbelt districts and northern provinces bordering Zaire, the official Zambian Daily Mail reported. Zambia's Health Ministry, in a statement issued Tuesday, urged people to avoid traveling near the affected areas in seven districts across the country. Earlier this year, cholera killed more than 200 people in the densely populated urban areas of Lusaka, Kafue, and Kabwe.

DOC.HEAD: Coup Attempt Reported in Mauritania
DOC.TEXT: Authorities arrested as many as 300 civilians and military personnel after an alleged coup attempt last week, informed sources said Wednesday. Members of the Mauritanian marines were among those arrested following the Nov. 27 coup attempt by black Mauritanians, the sources said. It would be the second coup attempt in three years organized by black Mauritanians. In 1987 more than 50 black military personnel were jailed and three were executed after an attempt to take over the government. Black Mauritanians make up about 70 percent of the population of this desert country in northwest Africa. The rest of the population is mostly Arab.

DOC.HEAD: 16 Indicted For Alleged Kickbacks in Earthquake Rebuilding
DOC.TEXT: A court investigating alleged kickbacks in reconstruction projects after the 1980 southern Italian earthquake indicted 16 people Wednesday, including a former mayor and his son. The government spent several billion dollars to rebuild a wide area east of Naples struck by the massive quake that claimed 3,000 lives. The probe by the Potenza court is one of a number still under way into allegations of corruption and fraud involving the aid money. Among those indicted were the former Communist mayor of Vietri di Potenza, a town 20 miles from Potenza, and his son, chairman of a local bank.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Warn Against Sniffing Butane and Propane Gas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: The dangerous habit of sniffing butane and propane gas to get high appears to be growing among affluent adolescents and may even approach epidemic levels, two health experts warn. In a letter published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine, they described two cases in Cincinnati in which boys died suddenly while sniffing gas. Both occurred within a six-week period this year in middle-class neighborhoods. Doctors have known about ``sudden sniffing death'' since at least 1970, but such deaths are rarely reported in the United States.
