It said Saddam stressed Iraq's determination to confront ``any attempt to threaten, intimidate and brandish the use of brute force, regardless of the direction from which it comes.'' In Argentina, Bush said Wednesday he is ``not optimistic'' that a peaceful solution can be found. The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin Powell, said in London that America ``is not going to blink on this one.'' Iraq has insisted that any solution must include a settlement of such Mideast problems as the Palestinian homeland. It argues that enforcing U.N. Security Council resolutions against Iraq but not those against Israel represents an unacceptable double standard. Saddam reiterated the link between the gulf crisis and other Mideast problems Tuesday during a meeting in Baghdad with King Hussein of Jordan, Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yassir Arafat and Yemeni Vice President Ali Salem Al-Beidh. The Iraqi news agency said the four leaders welcome dialogue but affirmed their commitment to work toward solving all the problems in the area, particularly over the Palestinians in Israel. The United States and the other countries contributing to the anti-Iraqi multinational force have rejected linking the gulf crisis to other Mideast problems. The Iraqi news agency also said Saddam criticized Bush during the meeting with the Europeans. ``The president of a state that claims to be free and democratic does not have the right to turn into an informing policeman at the U.N. Security Council. He has to seek dialogue. This is what Iraq wants,'' Saddam was quoted as saying. Also Wednesday, the Cable News Network quoted a ranking Iraqi source it did not identify as saying, ``All issues are on the table, everything.'' It said Saddam was feeling enormous pressure to withdraw from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Newspaper Details Organized Crime in Moscow
DOC.TEXT: The business newspaper Commersant on Wednesday published a map of neighborhoods in the Soviet capital that it said are controlled by 10 major criminal organizations and ran a ``Who's Who of Moscow racketeers.'' The weekly said, ``Whenever the supply of a product is forcibly kept below demand - such as narcotics in the West or alcohol during prohibition - organized crime steps in and thrives. ``But in a country such as the Soviet Union where virtually everything is difficult to obtain, the opportunities for organized crime are endless. Couple that with an overstretched police force and you have an explosive situation.'' Commersant said it got its information from anonymous informants. It said journalists who wrote the stories didn't want their names used for fear of gangland retribution. The paper said it sent a copy of its map and stories in advance to Moscow's Internal Affairs Department for comment, and the department replied two days later that ``organized crime does not exist as such in Moscow.'' But Commersant said organized crime controls some or all of Moscow's drug trade, prostitution, slot machines, video salons and used-car sales. Its main business, however, is extorting protection money, the paper reported - mostly from restaurants and other semiprivate enterprises. Boris Pugo, the country's new interior minister, told the government newspaper Izvestia on Tuesday that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ``very concerned with the rise in organized crime. However, the struggle with this crime hasn't been effective enough so far.'' ``Corruption has penetrated all organizations, all bodies of power, including the highest echelons,'' Pugo said. Commersant said the two biggest and most senior gangs in Moscow held a 1988 ``gangster summit'' to divide up the city, spelling out who would operate where. That attempt soon broke down, it said, and now 10 major gangs operate. It said they are known as teams or brigades and involve about 6,000 criminals. The paper gave this breakdown: -The Assyrian Brigade monopolizes illegal drug trade, operating out of the central Krasnaya Presnya district, home to the Moscow Zoo and embassies. -The Dolgoprudnay Brigade specializes in racketeering, especially protection. It controls northern Moscow and parts of the Olympic Village. -The Solntsevo Brigade victimizes used-car sales people and is moving in on extorting protection money from cab drivers. It recently staked a claim on Yuzhny Port on the Moscow River. -The Lyubertsy and Chechen Brigades share prostitution. -Anton's Brigade runs loansharking and controls downtown Moscow, all the video salons and revenues from pop music shows. -One brigade leader controls the income from all slot machines in southwestern Moscow's Gagarinsky district and other parts of the capital. The newspaper said other gangs control warehouses and hard currency restaurants, black market leather and fur, shell games, counterfeiting and shaking down vodka salesmen.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi-Soviet Ties Blossoming Fast Due to Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Relations between Saudi Arabia and the Soviet Union are blossoming due to the Persian Gulf crisis, with both countries eager to open embassies and a multibillion-dollar loan to the Soviets reportedly in the works. The swift rapprochement follows nearly 60 years of diplomatic standoff between Moscow and Riyadh, which had no formal ties since the severing of relations by Josef Stalin in 1932. The two nations now have much at stake in the swift development of relations, reestablished by Saudi Arabia on Sept. 17. The Saudis hope to ensure Soviet support for the multinational coalition arrayed against Iraq, once one of Moscow's closest allies. The Soviets, for their part, are counting on financial help from the oil-rich Arab kingdom to ease their economic crisis. According to official sources, the Soviets plan to send a delegation to Riyadh this month to look for embassy premises and hold talks on a badly needed loan. A Saudi delegation led by the Foreign Ministry's undersecretary for financial and administrative affairs, Mohammed Hussein Abdul-Wali, has been shopping in Moscow for a suitable site for a Saudi embassy, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Saudi foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, an infrequent visitor to Moscow, was in the Soviet capital in the critical days before the U.N. Security Council approved a resolution on Nov. 30 authorizing military force against Iraq. Finance Minister Mohammed Abalkhail was part of that delegation, sparking reports of negotiations for a multibillion-dollar Saudi loan to the Soviet Union, and even heftier assistance from the six oil-rich states forming the Gulf Cooperation Council. The unofficial reports mentioned loans of $1 billion to $4.5 billion from Saudi Arabia alone. Kuwait has had relations with Moscow since shortly after gaining independence from Britain in 1961. For years it tried to influence its conservative Arab neighbors to do likewise. Under pressure of the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war, Oman and the United Arab Emirates established ties with the Soviet Union, as well as with China and the East European bloc nations in the early 1980s. Qatar followed in the late 1980s. Under pressure of the gulf crisis, Saudi Arabia finally dropped its resistance and announced the establishment of ties on Sept. 17, and Bahrain followed on Sept. 28.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Released From Prison, Man Steals More Snow Blowers
DOC.TEXT: A man who spent four years in prison for breaking into a garage and trying to steal a snow blower filched 15 more soon after his release, police said. The 27-year-old man broke into 76 garages in Milwaukee and suburban Wauwatosa between Nov. 7 and Nov. 25 and stole the snow blowers, which he sold in bars and gasoline stations, police Detective Thomas Radomski said. Ronald D. Gatson sold them for about $75 each to support a cocaine habit that cost him about $300 a day, a criminal complaint said. The complaint accuses Gatson of stealing a station wagon to drive to the burglary locations, then removing only items that fit into his car and could be sold quickly. He was charged Nov. 28 with four counts of burglary and one count of operating an auto without owner's consent. He remains in jail in lieu of a $2,500 bond.

DOC.HEAD: Quiet Diplomacy to Restart Aid, Redefine Relations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 4, `Pakistan, one...' to CORRECT to `best friends' sted `few friends.' Picks up 5th pvs, `Teresita Schaffer...'
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Pakistan are trying quiet diplomacy this week to restart a half-billion-dollar aid package and redefine a 40-year-old relationship erected on Cold War foundations. As the vitriolic anti-America slogans of past weeks begin to fade, Washington and Islamabad are searching for ways to break the impasse over Pakistan's nuclear program, the biggest source of friction between the two long-time allies. On Oct. 1, President Bush said he could not guarantee Congress that Pakistan does not possess nor wants to possess nuclear weapons, automatically freezing economic and military assistance. Pakistan, one of Washington's best friends in the Islamic world, reacted strongly to the suspension, partly blamed on the ``pro-American'' policies of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto before her Aug. 6 ouster on corruption charges. Teresita Schaffer, a deputy assistant secretary of state, arrives Thursday for talks with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's month-old government on a wide range of issues, including the impasse on the nuclear program. Henry Rowen, an assistant secretary of defense, is expected next week. U.S. officials say the problems are not insurmountable, but they acknowledge that neither side has much room to maneuver. Few people expect Islamabad to back down on its nuclear program and Congress appears in no mood to make concessions - a stalemate that some Western diplomats fear could reshape alliances in the region by pushing Pakistan closer to its western neighbor, Iran. Many anaylsts and diplomats believe the cutoff of U.S. aid and Washington's ultimatum would leave Pakistan with no option but to accelerate its nuclear program, declare itself a nuclear state and test an atomic device. Neither Pakistani nor American officials are willing to be specific about what Islamabad allegedly did that prompted the aid suspension. But diplomatic sources say President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, Ms. Bhutto and top-ranking military leaders decided last spring to cross the nuclear threshold. With the threat looming of a fourth war with its traditionally antagonistic eastern neighbor India, they agreed to step up Pakistan's secret program to enrich uranium for possible use in nuclear weapons. Islamabad insists its nuclear program is for peaceful purposes and accuses Washington of turning a blind eye to the nuclear programs of other countries, including Israel, South Africa and more importantly India, which tested a nuclear device in 1974. ``A nuclear-capable India breathing down the neck of Pakistan hardly makes an easy equation,'' said retired Brig. Gen. A.R. Siddiqi. ``The resulting strategic imbalance could throw South Asia into a situation where the quest for security takes precedence over the quest for abiding peace and reconciliation.'' Pakistan is the third-largest recipient of U.S. aid after Egypt and Israel, the beneficiary of a six-year, $4 billion package that includes delivery of 50 F-16 jet fighters, the pride and backbone of its air force. When the deal was signed in 1987, Western diplomats said, the United States agreed to provide Pakistan with a sophisticated, conventional defense force. The only hitch - Pakistan would not go nuclear. ``That was the deal. They accepted it then,'' said one diplomat, insisting on anonymity. ``But they are a sovereign state. They can unaccept it now.'' Sharif says he wants to maintain good relations with Washington, but not at the cost of Pakistan's sovereignty and independence. Pakistan, he says, is prepared to live with the consequences. But many Pakistanis say their country has become an addict of foreign aid, receiving an estimated $3 billion annually, and has been living beyond its means for a long time. The suspension of U.S. aid comes at a time when the Persian Gulf crisis is taking its toll on Pakistan's economy, already burdened by a $15.5 billion foreign debt. Oil prices have skyrocketed more than 40 percent, remittances from the gulf have plummeted and export earnings have dropped. Relations between the United States and Pakistan have followed an on-again, off-again course since 1976, when Islamabad first endured Washington's wrath by signing a nuclear reprocessing plant deal with France. The project was canceled in 1977 and aid resumed the following year. Washington again cut assistance in 1979 after disclosures that Pakistan was importing sensitive materials to its nuclear facility outside Islamabad. Aid was restarted later that year after the Soviet Union sent its troops into neighboring Afghanistan and restored U.S.-Pakistan relations to the cozy days of the 1950s containment of the Communist threat. With the end to the Cold War and the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan, Western diplomats say, Pakistan no longer has the strategic importance it enjoyed during the Afghan war. After Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, many Pakistanis believed the Persian Gulf would be their Afghanistan of the 1990s and ease U.S. pressure. Instead, the gulf crisis has heightened the pressure. ``An increasingly assertive Congress feels that the U.S. administration ignored the wrong signals from Iraq to serve short-term strategic goals and nurtured the fiend that devoured Kuwait,'' said one military source, also insisting on anonymity. ``Fear of the `Islamic bomb' still looms large in the American psyche,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Troops Arrive to Give Desert Shield Offensive Punch
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Combat troops once at the front line of the U.S. defense against the Soviets in Europe poured into Saudi Arabia on Wednesday, the vanguard of the U.S. buildup in the gulf. Sixteen hours after leaving snow-covered Germany, soldiers from the 2nd Armored Cavalry Regiment were sweating in temperatures in the high 70s and getting accustomed to walking in ankle-deep sand at an air base in eastern Saudi Arabia. ``This is one of the best trained units in the Army,'' said Lt. Andy Kilgore, 23, of Philadelphia, Miss., from the regiment's 2nd Squadron. ``They've been trained to face 7-to-1 odds against the Soviets. They're ready for the Iraqis or anybody else.'' The arriving soldiers, some looking tense and nervous, said they were well-trained for war, but hoping for peace. Lt. Gene Lanzillo, 25, of Alexandria, Va., said the unit used to patrol the former East German border and had been ``on the cutting edge'' of East-West divisions, never envisioning ending up in Saudi Arabia. There was at least one similarity, he said. The Iraqis use mainly Soviet equipment. ``I think they're a competent army, a battle-tested army after eight years of fighting Iran. We're not leary of them but I think we respect the power they represent,'' Lanzillo said. ``Certainly, we'd like it to be settled peacefully,'' he added. ``I think we have more to lose if it isn't.'' The regiment is one of eight Army units ordered here as part of the 200,000-strong troop buildup that will give the 240,000 U.S. troops already in the gulf the capability to launch a military operation to liberate Kuwait. Advance teams from other U.S. and German-based units have been arriving here the past week, but the 2nd Armored Cavalry, which is part of the Army's VII Corps, is the first major combat force to reinforce Operation Desert Shield. Brig. Gen. Steven L. Arnold, assistant chief of staff of the U.S. Armed Forces Central Command, said combat support units had arrived first, unlike the initial U.S. deployment in early August when combat troops were first on the ground. ``It's not the same situation that it was in August,'' he said in an interview. ``In August, when the 82nd Airborne landed here, they fully expected to fight that day.'' With a lot of combat troops already here, the Army is now returning to its normal practice of bringing in support teams first so that when combat troops arrive there is already someone on the ground to take care of their food, living quarters and transportation, Arnold said. He said the main armored and mechanized units are now on their way. ``We have some afloat coming from Europe, some moving from the States and they'll be arriving soon,'' he said. All reinforcements are expected to be here by Jan. 15, the deadline the United Nations has set for Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait before facing possible military action by the multinational force. It includes about 100,000 ground troops from 15 other countries. Some Air Force reinforcements also flew in on Wednesday. Several F-15 fighter pilots from the 1st Tactical Fighter Wing at Langley Air Force Base, Va., landed at the airbase. A team of civil engineers from Tyndall Air Force Base, Fla., who do rapid runway repairs, were shuttling between two airbases because of a mixup in their final destination. Several truck drivers from the Air Force's 66th Transportation Company at Semback Air Force Base in Germany didn't know where they were heading. Gen. Arnold said ``the ideal'' is to give newly arriving troops at least three weeks to get used to the climate and the environment, to make sure all their equipment has arrived and been checked out, and to travel the several hundred miles to their desert camps.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Announces Recalls for Possible Air Bag Defect
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Wednesday recalled about 110,000 1990- and 1991-model Ford, Mercury and Lincoln cars to see if they were equipped with potentially defective air bags. The company said TRW Vehicle Safety Systems Inc., an air bag supplier, told it that about 3,000 potentially defective air bags had been shipped to Ford assembly plants. Cars involved are 1990 models of the Ford Taurus and Tempo, Mercury Sable and Topaz and Lincoln Continental along with 1990 and 1991 versions of the Ford Crown Victoria and Mercury Grand Marquis cars. Owners will be notified by mail to return their cars to dealerships for inspection. Originally, Ford recalled about 55,000 1990-91 model cars after TRW said 133 air bags were potentially defective. TRW later raised that number to about 3,000, Ford said. Also Wednesday, Ford recalled about 20,000 1988-90-model F-Super Duty light trucks with 7.5-liter engines to install a new electronic engine control processor. Some trucks experienced a loss of power due to the processor. Replacement will be free.

DOC.HEAD: Government Will Substitute Cheese for Peanut Butter in Food Donations
DOC.TEXT: A short crop has forced up the price of peanut butter, so the Agriculture Department instead will donate more cheese to schools and needy people, officials said Wednesday. Betty Jo Nelsen, administrator of the department's Food and Nutrition Service, said process cheese prices have dropped to an average of $1.20 per pound from about $1.65 a year ago. Meanwhile, drought-reduced peanut yields this year boosted peanut butter prices to around $1.70 per pound from less than $1 a year ago, she said. Cheese was in plentiful supply in the early 1980s as result of large dairy surpluses, and was a big item on the USDA's food donation list. But as these surpluses dwindled, prices rose and little cheese was available for donations. ``Cheese is an excellent source of protein and calcium, and we know our clients will be glad to see it back in our programs again,'' Nelsen said. The cheese will be substituted for peanut butter on ``a limited basis'' in the child nutrition programs, including school lunches, and the program for the elderly, beginning in December, she said. In February, about 40 million pounds of cheese will replace peanut butter in the Temporary Emergency Assistance Program, which provides food aid to the needy, including low-income and unemployed people, Nelsen said.

DOC.HEAD: Top Noriega Co-Defendant Agrees to Guilty Plea
DOC.TEXT: A former Panamanian lieutenant colonel prosecutors say can tie Manuel Noriega directly to drug payoffs signed a long-delayed plea bargain Wednesday, his attorney said. Luis del Cid agreed in March to plead guilty to some drug-related charges, but the deal bogged down over guarantees he would not be extradited to Panama for prosecution there after serving his U.S. term. The Department of Justice has now agreed to oppose deporting or extraditing del Cid, said his attorney, Sam Burstyn. ``Fortunately the U.S. government has agreed to all the points now,'' Burstyn said. The agreement was signed late Wednesday and was to be the subject of a hearing Thursday before U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler. Burstyn said recent court battles over Noriega's taped telephone conversations and the freezing of his assets boosted del Cid's bargaining power. ``I figured we had reached a seller's market in light of the government's recent difficulties,'' Burstyn said. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office, said she could not discuss negotiations with defendants' attorneys. Del Cid was a lieutenant colonel in the Panamanian military and a top aide to Noriega when the two were captured during the U.S. invasion. Del Cid ``acted as a liaison and money courier between drug traffickers and Manuel Antonio Noriega,'' the U.S. attorney's office has said. The plea agreement calls for del Cid to provide testimony against Noriega, Burstyn said. Del Cid faced a maximum of 70 years on four drug counts, but agreed to plead guilty to only one, with a maximum recommended sentence of 10 years. Burstyn said he expected del Cid to serve only about 2{ years. Noriega's defense professes iittle concern about del Cid's possible testimony. ``He's just another witness who is getting paid for his testimony,'' said Noriega attorney Jon May. ``Del Cid is just one among many witnesses who are getting the keys to the jailhouse door from a government that's desperate to shore up its case.'' Del Cid's plea bargain will not hurt Noriega ``as long as del Cid tells the truth,'' said a lead Noriega lawyer, Frank Rubino. Del Cid is accused in a February 1988 indictment of accepting $200,000 in cocaine-trafficking profits from drug pilot Floyd Carlton Caceres, now the prosecution's chief witness. Carlton and Noriega had agreed to the price during a December 1983 meeting, the indictment alleges. Later that month, Carlton delivered the money intended for Noriega to del Cid at the headquarters of the Panamanian Defense Forces in Panama City. The pilot continued to deal with Noriega and prosecutors have said that shows the money was indeed passed on to the Panamanian leader. The defense has previously disputed some prosecution claims that del Cid was a key aide to Noriega, forcing the U.S. attorney's office to acknowledge he was not head of Panamanian intelligence, as they first claimed. But prosecutors in turn showed a picture of del Cid and Noriega at a meeting with Cuban leader Fidel Castro, a meeting the indictment says was intended to mediate a dispute between Noriega and the Medellin drug cartel, which allegedly paid Noriega $4.6 million and bribes to ship cocaine through Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Chief US Investigator Says NTSB Never Asked Him About Gander Crash Cause
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Adds 1 graf with Hughes disclosing effort to obtain investigative reports from Canada
DOC.TEXT: The United States embraced Canada's findings about a 1985 air crash in Gander, Newfoundland, without consulting the chief U.S. investigator who looked into the disaster, a congressional panel was told Wednesday. George Seidlein, the National Transportation Safety Board's chief on-site investigator in Gander, testified that Canadian investigators were wrong in concluding that ice on the wings caused the disaster that killed a planeload of American servicemen. Seidlein's superiors at the NTSB endorsed the ice-on-the-wings theory, but didn't ask Seidlein for his opinion, even though they sent him up to Gander to look into the crash which killed 256 Americans. Seidlein said the weather conditions simply weren't right for ice to have formed on the wings in sufficient amounts to cause the crash. He wasn't invited to give his views and didn't volunteer them, he told the House Judiciary subcommittee on crime. Instead, he said, the crash occurred because the crew tried to force the DC-8 to climb after takeoff before it had accelerated to a high enough speed. Seidlein rejects the theory that a terrorist bomb might have downed the plane, a possibility that has been raised by some Canadian investigators, members of Congress and families of the victims. Several eyewitnesses say they saw a bright flame just before the crash. A terrorist group with ties to Iran claimed responsibility for the disaster, which occurred amid the Reagan administration's secret arms sales to Iran. Rep. William Hughes, D-N.J., asked Seidlein's boss, Ronald Schleede, why the chief investigator wasn't questioned. Seidlein ``wasn't intentionally excluded'' from consultations, replied Schleede, the NTSB's investigations chief. By the time Canada reached its conclusions, Seidlein had transferred to an agency office in Lansing, Mich., and was about to retire, Schleede testified. Hughes, the panel chairman, accused Schleede of ``trying to give us a snow job.'' ``Why did you send him up there'' to Gander?'' Hughes asked Schleede. ``Is there a reason you didn't bring him in?'' ``No sir,'' Schleede responded. Rep. William McCollum, R-Fla., suggested that the United States was loathe to question Canada too closely about its probe of the crash. Just because the two countries have close ties, that's no reason ``we ought to have blinders on,'' said McCollum. ``We had access to all the relevant data'' and found ``no problems with'' the Canadians' findings, said Schleede, who still regards the ice-on-the-wings theory as plausible. Seidlein said it was his choice to go to Lansing and that he was under no pressure from the NTSB. But he also said he had been asked for input on other international crashes before the U.S. decided whether to endorse the findings. Hughes disclosed that the subcommittee has been pressing Canada to provide investigative reports by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. The RCMP looked into the possibility of a terrorist link in the Gander crash. Hughes said he will urge the 102nd Congress to pursue the matter and that the FBI and intelligence agencies should review the reports once the U.S. government obtains them.

Washington tackle Jim Lachey said Wednesday that his honor as the NFC offensive player of the week was really an honor for the Redskins whole offensive line. ``One guy can't block for everybody,'' said Lachey, an all-pro last year. ``This is an award for everybody.'' Lachey this week became only the second blocker ever to win the award as the week's top offensive performer. New York Giants tackle Brad Benson was honored in December 1986 after a 24-14 victory over the Redskins. Lachey was cited for leading a Redskins rushing attack that piled up 222 yards on the ground Sunday against the Miami Dolphins, who had been allowing an average of only 85 yards a game rushing. The Dolphins had been first in the AFC in rushing defense, but Washington's Earnest Byner ran 32 times for 157 yards Sunday to become the first back to clear 100 yards against them. The ground game was key in the Redskins' 42-20 rout of Miami. ``It's a nice honor. I don't know what the criteria are, but it's nice to have it. It means a lot as an honor to the total offensive line,'' said Lachey. A sixth-year player, Lachey was obtained from the Los Angeles Raiders in 1987 for quarterback Jay Schroeder, who now starts for the Raiders. Redskins officials, however, consider the deal one of their best in recent years and have long called Lachey the most talented member of their line. ``I think it says a lot for him and the other linemen,'' coach Joe Gibbs said of the award. ``I think it says a lot for our coaches and linemen. They're a tight-knit group. They've bounced back and taken some criticism.'' Gibbs said coaches who grade game films said the Redskins' blocking against Miami was their best of the season. Meanwhile, Gibbs brushed aside comments that were reportedly made by former Redskin quarterback Joe Theismann critical of his coaching methods and assistants. The National sports daily quoted Theismann Wednesday as saying Gibbs had gotten rid of the team's ``characters'' and was becoming so isolated that he was out of touch with his players. ``Joe hasn't been around much lately, so he needs to stop by. I don't know where all that came from,'' Gibbs said. ``From the sounds of it I'm not sure Joe knows what he's talking about,'' he said. The interview with Theismann, who was the Redskins quarterback in their 1982 Super Bowl championship season, was included in the newspaper's first edition to be sold in the Washington area.

DOC.HEAD: Carr Withdraws Proposal to Limi Chairmen's Travel Authority
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Bob Carr suggested yanking the authority of House chairmen to approve overseas junkets for their committees, but that suggestion died before the day was over. ``I offered it only yesterday and didn't have the opportunity to mount the campaign you need to make these kinds of things happen,'' he said Wednesday. ``I didn't want to embarrass anyone by springing a surprise.'' Carr, D-Mich., said he made his point just by floating his proposed House rule, under which recorded committee votes would be required for all committee-sponsored foreign travel. He withdrew the proposal the same day he proposed it. House Democrats discussed the matter at length in a closed-door caucus Tuesday, Carr said. And he said Rules Committee Chairman Joe Moakley, D-Mass., and Rep. Martin Frost, D-Texas, chairman of the caucus panel on organization, promised to study possible changes in travel policy. ``My intention at this point was to put people on notice, to take a shot across the bow on congressional travel,'' Carr said. ``That may be enough to solve the problem. If there's a spate of goofy, thinly-substantiated travel in the future, I'll press this in a most forceful way.'' Carr, elected last month to his ninth term, sought similar reforms in the 1970s without success. He said he decided to renew his effort after seeing a television news report on a trip to Latin America by eight members of the House Ways and Means Committee last April. The group spent the last five days of the 12-day excursion, which cost about $100,000, on the Caribbean island of Barbados. An ABC News crew using hand-held cameras videotaped members of the delegation there. The report, aired in October on the program ``PrimeTime Live,'' said the Barbados segment of the trip consisted largely of leisure activities. Several lawmakers who made the trip said the presentation was inaccurate and that they put in long hours of work. Carr said he couldn't pass judgment on the entire Ways and Means trip, but that the Barbados portion was ``suspect.'' Publicity about such questionable activity threatens to undermine public confidence in all congressional travel, most of which is justified and can save money by giving lawmakers ideas for changing programs, he said. Despite their power, committee chairmen can be overruled by a majority of the members on most matters under House rules, Carr said. But he said there is no provision limiting chairmen's power to authorize travel. Under his proposed rule, all committee-sponsored foreign trips would be authorized by a resolution approved by majority vote. The resolution would include a detailed itinerary, the purpose for each stop, the name of everyone making the trip, the estimated total expense, and the trip's anticipated benefit to taxpayers.

DOC.HEAD: House Chairman Accuses Justice Department of Coverup in Computer Case
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee accused the Justice Department on Wednesday of engaging in a coverup by withholding documents about its dealings with a computer firm. Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, said the committee cannot complete its investigation of the Justice Department's alleged mistreatment of INSLAW, Inc., because the agency refuses to turn over some 200 documents it considers privileged. Brooks indicated the committee would conduct further discussions to determine if it should subpoena the documents. Steven R. Ross, the general counsel for the House, charged that in refusing to turn over the documents Attorney General Dick Thornburgh was trying to exempt his department from congressional investigations of waste, fraud and abuse. The Justice Department has been locked in a lengthy court battle with INSLAW, Inc., a computer software firm that alleges that government officials conspired to steal its product and drive it out of business. The department is appealing a bankruptcy court's finding, confirmed by a federal district judge, that officials used ``trickery, fraud and deceit'' to steal software that INSLAW had devised for U.S. attorneys offices. The company's president, William Hamilton, estimated that the Justice Department's actions cost INSLAW ``several hundred million dollars'' in lost business. The Judiciary Committee is investigating INSLAW's allegations that top Justice Department officials under former Attorney General Edwin Meese III engaged in a criminal conspiracy to drive the company out of business and deliver lucrative government computer contracts to political friends of the Reagan administration. The Justice Department denies those allegations. Brooks said the Justice Department's refusal to turn over 200 documents the agency considers privileged has stalled the investigation. In a Sept. 26 letter to the committee, Thornburgh told the panel he could not turn over the material because of an obligation to ``protect documents compiled by attorneys in connection with pending litigation, which are not in the public domain and could be described as `litigation strategy' or `work product.''' ``That could be described as coverup or hiding or holding out,'' Brooks said at a hearing of the panel's economic and commercial law subcommittee to discuss what steps to take to force production of the documents. Ross noted that in an Aug. 21 letter, Thornburgh urged the committee to review Justice Department documents on the INSLAW matter before launching an investigation into ``unsubstantiated innuendo.'' ``On the one hand, the attorney general invited the committee to review the documents and then when the committee asks to see the very same documents, he has switched positions and now is saying those documents are privileged,'' Ross said. Ross said the Justice Department made a more direct attack on Congress's power to investigate waste and fraud in the government in a Dec. 4 letter to the panel's ranking Republican member, Rep. Hamilton Fish of New York. The letter by W. Lee Rawls, assistant attorney general for legislative affairs, states that ``congressional investigations are justifiable only as a means of facilitating the task of passing legislation.'' Ross said the Justice Department is trying to ``create a new standard for what is acceptable means of committee investigation.'' ``What that proposed standard would do would be to eradicate the time-honored role of Congress of providing oversight which is a means that has been upheld by the Supreme Court ... by which the Congress can assure itself that previously passed laws have been properly implemented.''

DOC.HEAD: Jews, Arabs in Shouting Match at Bail Hearing for Suspect in Kahane Slaying
DOC.TEXT: Scores of Jews and Arabs nearly came to blows Wednesday in a raucous confrontation outside a courtroom where a judge set $300,000 bail for the man charged with the murder of Rabbi Meir Kahane. ``No bail for murderers!'' yelled the Jews, and the Arabs shouted, ``God is great! Thanks be to God!'' as they met in a hallway of the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building. Armed court officers wedged themselves between the groups and forced the Arabs to leave the building by one set of elevators while directing the Jews to another. Outside, both groups marched and chanted. The Jewish group carried an effigy, intended to represent the suspect, with a noose around the neck and a mock-up of an electric chair. The bail hearing was for El Sayyid Nosair, 35, of Cliffside, N.J., who allegedly shot Kahane to death Nov. 5 as the rabbi finished speaking to a Jewish group at a midtown Manhattan hotel. ``We will raise the bail as quickly as we can,'' said Nosair's lawyer, Michael Warren. He was accompanied by an Egyptian lawyer, Dr. Abdel Halim Mandour, who said he was here to help with the case. Nosair came to this country from Egypt in 1981. Nosair is also accused of wounding two other men and threatening a third while fleeing. He was stopped when a U.S. Postal Service police officer shot him in the neck a block from the hotel. Warren asked a judge, Alvin Schlesinger, to set bail at $100,000, saying Nosair had never been arrested before, has a wife and child and other relatives here, and was a responsible city employee. Nosair, a university-trained engineer, worked as a boiler tender. Assistant District Attorney William Greenbaum opposed bail, telling Schlesinger that the prosecution has witnesses, the murderweapon and ballistics evidence to tie Nosair to the crimes. Greenbaum said Nosair did have an arrest record, a rape charge in Pennsylvania in 1985 that was dropped. Schlesinger set bail and said he would issue his rulings on motions March 4. During the hearing, a man who shouted ``God will punish you, Nosair'' was ushered out of the courtroom and a woman who complained that the bail was too low was restrained briefly by court officers.

DOC.HEAD: Transplant Drug Will Be Tested on Diabetes
DOC.TEXT: An experimental anti-rejection drug has reversed the effects of some auto-immune diseases and will be tested on people suffering from the most serious form of diabetes, a transplant surgeon said Wednesday. The Food and Drug Administration approved a University of Pittsburgh study in which the Type I diabetes patients will be given the drug, FK-506, about a week after diagnoses, Dr. Thomas Starzl said. ``We are anxious to get the information out that there is something that could switch off this disease,'' Starzl told reporters. ``Whether you believe it's proper or not, it's only here that teens or adults can be treated - providing we can see them early.'' Several Type I diabetes studies are under way on weaker immune-suppressing drugs, but FK-506 has shown the most potential for curbing the illness, said Gerod Grodsky, a biochemistry professor and diabetes researcher at the University of San Francisco. ``I think this is an experiment that has to be done,'' Grodsky said. ``The potential advantages are enormous.'' Type I diabetes, also known as juvenile diabetes, affects 11 to 12 million Americans of all ages. It can cause blindness and kidney failure, and its symptoms are excessive thirst, frequent urination, rapid weight loss and blurred vision. Only University of Pittsburgh hospitals have been given FDA approval to use FK-506, which Fujisawa Pharmaceutical Co. of Japan derives from a fungus. The drug fights rejection of organ transplants by suppressing white blood cells, which stave off infection and disease. The university already has tested the drug on two auto-immune diseases. In such diseases, the body's white cells mistakenly destroy healthy cells. FK-506 reversed the effects of psoriasis, a skin disease that creates unsightly skin lesions, in all six patients who took the drug, Starzl said. The drug also reversed the effects of pyoderma, a rare skin ulcer, in six of seven patients, he said. ``We're seeing some very dramatic recoveries,'' he said. Also, FK-506 appeared to cure a disease similar to Type I diabetes in laboratory rats, said Dr. Patricia Carroll of Pittburgh's medical school. Starzl said researchers hope to test FK-506 on ``a dizzying list of diseases,'' including multiple sclerosis and a form of hepatitis. Starzl, who in 1963 performed the world's first successful human liver transplant, is credited with making the university a world transplant center. At the news conference, Starzl, 64, also said he would perform fewer surgeries and more research at the university's planned transplant institute. The university has started a nationwide search for 60 Type I diabetes patients ages 18 to 45 for the two-year study. Half will receive insulin and FK-506, half will receive insulin and placebos, Carroll said. Patients with Type I diabetes need insulin shots to survive because the white cells destroy the body's insulin factories in the pancreas. Complicating the study is the Type I diabetes' so-called ``honeymoon period,'' up to a year of remission after diagnosis in about half the patients, Carroll said. It will be difficult to determine if improvements in patients' conditions are due to the remissions or the drug, she said. Grodsky said he was concerned about FK-506's side effects on the diabetes patients. But Carroll said researchers have yet to see the drug's side effects in patients who haven't undergone transplants. In transplant patients, FK-506 has caused dizziness and excessive dreaming, she said. While the Type I study ``is very exciting, whether this drug is the one that works or not, we don't know yet,'' Grodsky said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Representative Put On Probation, Fined On Drug Charge
DOC.TEXT: A former state legislator received three years probation and a $2,500 fine Wednesday on a cocaine possession charge stemming from an FBI investigation of Statehouse corruption. ``I feel there is nothing more I can say except that I am terribly sorry,'' the former House member, Donna Moss, told U.S. District Judge Falcon Hawkins. Mrs. Moss, a Gaffney Democrat and the mother of two, is the third former lawmaker sentenced in the probe. Under sentencing guidelines, Mrs. Moss could have received up to four months in jail. She pleaded guilty Oct. 12 to the single misdemeanor count. As part of a plea bargain, she agreed to cooperate with the government. Mrs. Moss admitted involvement with drugs on or about April 19, 1989. Her attorney, Wade Weatherford, told Hawkins ``Mrs. Moss became associated with people she thought were her friends.'' Weatherford, arguing his client should not go to jail, said after she broke company with those people she never used drugs again. ``She has readily admitted her guilt and cooperated fully,'' Weatherford said. ``She has never received financial gain for anything she has done.'' He said it ``is impossible to express her feelings of having hurt people. She has lost a promising political career but that is probably the least of her loss and hurt.'' Mrs. Moss needs to be home for her two children, ages 10 and 15, Weatherford said. Hawkins said he was confident Mrs. Moss has suffered for ``the pain and suffering'' brought on her family and ``the humiliation you have brought on your fellow-members of the legislature.'' As terms of probation, Mrs. Moss must, if asked, submit to random drug testing. She must cooperate with authorities and pay $96.66 a month for probation costs. In addition, she must pay a $25 special assessment. U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel said Mrs. Moss began cooperating with authorities ``literally within hours'' of being contacted by the FBI. The extent of the cooperation was briefly discussed during a hearing at the judge's bench. The record of the hearing was ordered sealed by Hawkins. Monday, former state Sen. Rick Lee got six months at a halfway house and five years' probation. Former Rep. Luther Taylor got a 6{-year prison term. Lee, R-Boiling Springs, had pleaded guilty to taking cash for supporting a bill allowing betting on horse and dog racing in South Carolina. Taylor contested the government's bribery case. A federal jury in October convicted him on six counts of violating federal bribery laws. Authorities say Mrs. Moss was not connected with vote-buying activities, but information uncovered during the FBI's ``Operation Lost Trust'' led to the drug charge. Three former House members who pleaded guilty to bribery charges await sentencing. Four other House members await trial. Mrs. Moss was elected to the House in 1984 and rose to head of the Medical, Military, Public and Municipal Affairs Committee. She resigned her seat on Sept. 21, the day of her indictment.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Philippine Talks Open on Bases; Both Sides Confident
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Philippine panels began talks Wednesday on the future of U.S. military bases in the Philippines, and a U.S. spokesman said later both sides expected to reach agreement by next month. The Americans maintain the giant Clark Air Base, Subic Bay Naval Base and four smaller facilities under a treaty that expires in September 1991. Stanley Schrager, spokesman for the U.S. side, told a briefing after Wednesday's meeting that both panels are optimistic they can agree by the end of January, their self-imposed deadline. On Tuesday, before talks began, the Philippines spokesma said disagreements had surfaced on operation of the bases. Schrager said Wednesday, ``Obviously, the talks have not broken down. There has not been an impasse.'' Philippine spokesman Rafael Alunan said technical committees of the two negotating teams had ``difficulties'' agreeing how much freedom will be allowed U.S. forces inside Clark after the Philippines assumes ``sovereign control'' over the base. Alunan said Wednesday's talks provided a ``clearer understanding'' of each other's position but no agreements were reached. Talks will resume Thursday. Schrager said any disagreements by the experts will have to be resolved later by Philippine Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus and chief U.S. negotiator Richard Armitage. ``Our hope is by the time Mr. Armitage leaves on Friday, we would come closer to resolving some of the stickier issues ... and mapping out an initial framework for a continued security relationship,'' Schrager said. The third round of bases talks opened in the heavily guarded Central Bank building. Manglapus and Armitage met privately Tuesday. Manglapus has announced the Philippines will take over Clark and the four small bases after 1991, but allow U.S. forces access on a commercial basis. He said Manila was open to extending the U.S. stay at Subic for a 5-to-7-year period. Americans would have access to ``standing structures'' at Clark, but the Philippines will control thoroughfares, runways and air traffic control, Alunan said. He said Filipino officials encountered ``stiff resistance'' from the American side when they insisted on applying Philippine laws on tariffs, income taxes, duties, licenses and registration inside Clark. An official close to the talks, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Philippines demanded total criminal jurisdiction over U.S. service members, takeover of postal service and use of the Philippine peso as currency in the base. ``A lot of this is totally unacceptable (to the Americans),'' the official said. ``This has to be straightened out at a higher level.'' Exact amount of compensation for U.S. use of the bases will be determined later. In 1988, the Reagan administration agreed to seek $960 million in U.S. aid over two years for use of the bases through 1991. Last year, Congress cut the Bush administration's aid request for the Philippines, provoking charges that the United States reneged on its pledge.

DOC.HEAD: Serbian President Urges Calm Ahead of Elections
DOC.TEXT: Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic on Wednesday urged Yugoslavs to learn from their history and avoid fratricidal violence ahead of elections pitting his Socialist Party against nationalist parties. ``There is no time or reason to give our lives again'' in the struggle over the country's fate, said Milosevic, whose party of hard-line Communists recently changed its name to the Socialist Party. The state Tanjug news agency reporting his comments said he spoke to about 70,000 supporters in Novi Sad, 40 miles northwest of Belgrade. Serbia, the largest of six Yugoslav republics, and Montenegro are the last of Yugoslavia's six republics to be ruled by Communists, giving Sunday's elections special significance. With ethnic and political tensions rife, the Central Intelligence Agency has predicted the country may break up in 18 months and civil war could break out. Many of the 1.7 million victims of World War II were Yugoslavs killed by other Yugoslavs, and with the death of Communist founder Josip Broz Tito in 1980, traditional regional rivalries have rekindled. Serbia's differences with ethnic Albanians in its province of Kosovo have resulted in bloodshed several times the past year. Serbia also is feuding with Croatia and Slovenia, the most liberal Yugoslav republics, over the future of the country. Milosevic would prefer a strong federation where Serbia can maintain its dominance. But Croatia's and Slovenia's newly established democratic governments have served notice they could seek independence unless the country was changed into a loose confederation with greater autonomy.

DOC.HEAD: Salman Rushdie Emerges from Hiding for Book Signing
DOC.TEXT: Author Salman Rushdie emerged from two years of hiding Wednesday to sign some books in a north London bookshop. The Indian-born Bitish writer was sentenced to death two years ago by the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini for allegedly blaspheming Islam in his book, ``The Satanic Verses.'' Rushdie was accompanied by bodyguards, but looked relaxed as he signed 100 copies of his new book, ``Haroun and the Sea of Stories.'' The children's fantasy written during his time in hiding is dedicated to his son, Zafar. ``He was wonderful, he was relaxed and chatted with the customers and was glad to sign for them. There were a lot of customers doing double-takes when they came into the shop and saw him,'' said David McRedmond, manager of Waterstone's Books in the wealthy north London neighborhood of Hampstead. ``We were only given brief notice that he was coming and were a bit surprised he was coming out at all,'' McRedmond said, adding that many customers wished Rushdie well during the 20-minute signing. ``One woman said, `It's very nice to see you out and about enjoying some fresh air', which he was very touched by,'' said a spokeswoman for Rushdie's publisher, Viking. Rushdie has appeared on British Television twice in the last few months. In September, he was filmed at a secret ``safe'' house for a special. Last month, he recorded an interview at a British Broadcasting Corp. studio.

DOC.HEAD: Regulator Says Lincoln Savings Was `Perhaps the Worst'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf: ``At the,'' to CORRECT first name of Grogan to James sted Charles
DOC.TEXT: The Keating Five senators pressured thrift regulators on behalf of ``probably the worst institution in America,'' and caused enforcement delays that inflated the cost of the eventual federal bailout, the Senate Ethics Committee was told Wednesday. William K. Black's criticism was the strongest the committee has heard of the senators' intervention with thrift regulators. Black, a senior career regulator, was the first witness in 12 days of hearings to blame the senators for delays in the government's seizing of Charles H. Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings and Loan. At the conclusion of Wednesday's session, Committee Chairman Howell Heflin, D-Ala., announced the panel has voted to compel the testimony of a key aide to Keating, James Grogan. The regulator's testimony had defense lawyers for the senators bitterly objecting that Black should not be permitted to blame the delay on senators because he had no direct knowledge they were responsible. He was permitted to give the testimony. Black said political pressure by all the senators generally played a role in delaying the seizure from 1987 to April 1989. It may now cost taxpayers more than $2 billion to cover the losses of the Irvine, Calif., thrift. The regulator specifically linked pressure from an aide to Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., in May 1988 to delaying decisions by regulators that ``greatly increased losses'' for taxpayers. At an April 9, 1987 meeting between the five senators and four regulators, including himself, Black testified that Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., ``kept coming at us'' on Lincoln's behalf even after the regulators said they were making criminal referrals to the Justice Department. Cranston's lawyer, William Taylor III, called Black's testimony ``the most fundamental smear.'' James Hamilton, representing DeConcini, said Black was ``having people smeared, having innuendo left'' and was ``reckless and irresponsible.'' The other three senators under investigation are John McCain, R-Ariz.; Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., and John Glenn, D-Ohio. Keating and his associates contributed $1.3 million to the five senators' campaigns and causes; the committee is trying to determine whether the money influenced their conduct. Earlier, two former chief thrift regulators, Edwin J. Gray and M. Danny Wall, told the committee the senators were not responsible for delaying the seizure of Keating's Irvine, Calif., thrift until April 14, 1989. That was two years after the San Francisco-based regulators who met with the senators in 1987 had recommended a government takeover. Black provided a vivid account of the April 9, 1987 meeting with the senators, saying he was extremely upset with their hostile tone toward the regulators. ``This is an institution that probably was the worst institution in America, and instead of people trying to help bring it under control, five U.S. senators were pushing us in the opposite direction. It was startlingly the wrong direction,'' Black testified. ``They had made a decision we were wrong, Lincoln was an abused institution and they were coming after us. We were put under considerable pressure immediately. You could see it in our faces. ``Five U.S. senators are a heck of a lot bigger than this boy. I felt Charles Keating had clearly set up'' the session ``to be intimidating.'' Black also said he became aware that Keating was trying to have him fired. Committee counsel Robert Bennett released a July 15, 1987 memo from Keating to his lobbyist in which Keating wrote: ``Highest priority - get Black. Good grief - If you can't get Wright and Congress to get Black - kill him dead - you ought to retire.'' Wright is a reference to former House Speaker Jim Wright, who met on at least one occasion with Keating. But the testimony that most riled defense lawyers came when Bennett asked Black: ``In the two-year period where the bank board did not take action, did the inquiry by the senators have an effect on board decisions?'' ``Yes,'' Black responded, and repeated the answer when the committee chairman, Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., asked whether ``political influence of these senators interfered with or affected the treatment of Lincoln.'' Black testified the Federal Home Loan Bank Board backed off its tough position on Lincoln in May 1988. He testified that after the board approved a hard-line policy on May 5 of that year, a Cranston aide, Carolyn Jordan, ``called two senior officers at the bank board ... and indicated severe displeasure.'' The board revised its policy, Black said, to ``expressly permit Lincoln to make new direct investments they would not otherwise be allowed to make.'' Lincoln also was permitted to significantly expand its sale of junk bonds. ``This led to greatly increased losses for the (federal savings and loan) insurance fund initially and the taxpayers eventually,'' Black said. Under cross-examination from McCain attorney John Dowd, Black was asked whether the Arizona Republican had done ``anything to interfere with your examination of Lincoln.'' ``Not to my knowledge,'' Black replied. And under questioning from Glenn lawyer Carol E. Bruce, Black acknowledged that the senator ``could not have known'' before meeting with regulators ``how bad the problems were.'' Heflin said the committee on Thursday would seek an order in U.S. District Court granting limited immunity from prosecution for Grogan's testimony. Grogan was corporate counsel for Keating's main company, American Continental Corp., and vice president of Lincoln. Grogan, Keating and five other witnesses have refused to testify on the grounds that the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution permits them to decline to testify in a manner that might incriminate them. Heflin said no immunity order would be sought for Keating. In explaining the decision, Heflin said Grogran ``had substantial contacts'' with all five senators and ``the committee believes it cannot fulfill its obligation to these members and the Senate without obtaining his testimony.'' The chairman added that ``giving use immunity to Mr. Grogan does not bar the prosecution of any person, including Mr. Grogan.'' Under a grant of ``use immunity,'' prosecutors may not use testimony of the witness in question in any way, but are not barred from a prosecutionif they can show their evidence was obtained independently. No date for Grogan's appearance has been set but Heflin said he would not testify before Dec. 12.

DOC.HEAD: Miami Police Chief Defends Disturbance Response
DOC.TEXT: Miami's police chief, who has weathered more than 20 riots during 22 years on the force, said Wednesday that criticism over slow police reaction to a melee this week is overblown and unwarranted. Police had no idea violence would escalate in a largely Puerto Rican neighborhood and they had to stay on side streets until reinforcements arrived, said Perry Anderson, who has headed the department of 1,114 officers for 2{ years. Anderson said the Monday incident, in which hundreds of youths swarmed through the city's impoverished Wynwood neighborhood looting stores and setting fires, was minor compared to what he's been through in the past. ``This was not a riot. This was not even an uprising,'' the 46-year-old Anderson said in an interview. ``Everybody's crying foul. You see it all over (the news) and it looks like Miami's burning down. But Miami's not on fire. You have to look at the magnitude of what actually happened here.'' Two large businesses, a vacant crack house and four vehicles were destroyed by fire, causing an estimated $3 million damage. A dozen small businesses were hit by looters. Anderson said there have been 11 arrests stemming from the disturbance so far. ``We're not being given credit that we did not lose any lives,'' said Anderson, who recalled a 1980 riot that left 18 people dead after an all-white jury acquitted five police officers in the beating death of a black motorcyclist. Monday's incident was sparked by the partial acquittal of six officers accused of beating to death a small-time Puerto Rican drug dealer from the neighborhood. The unrest began about 7 p.m and raged unchecked until 150 officers in full riot gear moved in about 9:30 p.m. Until police could get back up help, they did the best they could to keep people from entering the 10-block area, Anderson said. The police also kept close guard on surrounding districts, where thousands of employees work in the city's garment industry. But that didn't make business and community leaders feel better in Wynwood, considered one of the poorest neighborhoods in Miami with an annual median income of $10,900. ``The worst thing was that the cops were there ... and they didn't do anything,'' said Manny Frias, whose television store was cleaned out by looters. ``It was just the most helpless thing I've experienced in my life,'' said Sara Seidler, whose drapery store burned to the ground. ``Why didn't the police go in? How come there were media in here and there were no police?'' Patrick Gerrits, whose 44-year-old construction company was gutted, said he got calls from officers as early as 4 p.m. warning him to clear out. Anderson said he is infuriated that officers made such calls to businesses but didn't notify their superiors of a possible disturbance. ``None of those people informed the chief of police,'' he said. Critics say the police should not have been caught off guard, as Anderson and Mayor Xavier Suarez have admitted, given the city's penchant for unrest after a racially charged trial involving police. Anderson, who said he was criticized this summer for moving in too quickly during a Haitian demonstration, complained, ``Now I'm being criticized because I didn't go in early enough. You're damned if you do, damned if you don't.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Offers Advise On Mikes, Shrugs Off Leftist Shouts
With AM-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush offered some painfully learned advice to Argentine President Carlos Menem: watch out for boom microphones. Bush suggested the warning Wednesday as he posed for pictures with Menem in his private office at Casa Rosada, the president's palace. Reporters, cameramen and photographers crowded into the room, and someone extended a long-poled boom microphone in the presidents' direction. ``I got myself in trouble with an open mike,'' Bush said, motioning at the offending instrument and mentioning an embarrassing incident during his 1984 vice presidential campaign against Geraldine Ferraro. Bush was referring to his comments to longshoremen on the morning after his one debate with Mrs. Ferraro. He was speaking just to the group, but a highly sensitive mike over his head picked what he said. ``We tried to kick a little ass last night,'' Bush said then. The comments haunted him for the remainder of the campaign. If there was any further discussion of the incident between Bush and Menem, it went unrecorded - even on the boom mikes. ---= Bush's annual quail-hunting trip in Beeville, Texas, after Christmas has fallen victim to the Persian Gulf crisis. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the president would spend the holidays at Camp David, instead. ``With everything that's going on, he just thought that was best,'' Fitzwater said. Usually, Bush and his wife, Barbara, spend Christmas at Camp David, and then the president heads out two days later for several days of hunting at Beeville followed by a trout fishing excursion in Alabama on the way home. ----= Words were shouted in anger and pushes and shoves were traded as a leftist legislator demanded the right to speak as Bush waited to address a joint session of Argentina's Congress. Luis Zamora, a member of the Movement Toward Socialism, sought recognition so he could protest Bush's visit. However, Vice President Eduardo Dualde quickly advised Zamora that he was out of order and could not be heard. Amid some scuffling, Zamora was removed from the room by several colleagues and a sergeant at arms. ``I don't want to be part of this farce,'' Zamora said afterwards. A cameraman said the incident escalated outside the chamber, and that the pushing turned into an exchange of blows. Bush took it in stride. ``Lest you be embarrassed by the echo we heard at the opening of this ceremony, don't worry about it,'' the president told the lawmakers. ``Every once in a while you hear an echo from the declining past of Marxism.'' He said it was the price for democracy. ----= With his wife ailing at home from a sinus infection, Bush brought his daughter Dorothy LeBlond to South America as his companion. She also was his tennis partner. They teamed up for a doubles match at Menem's house against the Argentine president and Claudia Casa Bianca, a former Argentine tennis pro. Then, Menem and Bush teamed up against Alberto Kohan, his health minister, and Jorge Dante, Menem's tennis instructor. After trailing, Bush and Menem rallied to win 5-4. It was the second contest for Bush and Menem. The two also had played together last year in Costa Rica amid ceremonies celebrating that country's 100th anniversary of democratic rule. ---= Sports stars from the fields of tennis, basketball, track and golf were tapped by Bush on Wednesday to be members of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. Named to the advisory panel were retired tennis professional Chris Evert, Los Angeles Lakers guard ``Magic'' Johnson, track star Jackie Joyner-Kersee and professional golfer Chi Chi Rodriguez. Bush also tapped Sammy Lee, a diving coach from Huntington Beach, Calif., and James Lorimer, an insurance executive from Columbus, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot in Runway Collision on Rebound After Personal Problems
LaserPhoto planned
With AM-Planes Collide
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines pilot Bill Lovelace had just begun to get his life in order after a divorce and business failure when he found himself on the wrong runway at Detroit's foggy Metro Airport. The pilot in a runway crash that killed eight people was described by friends Wednesday as a professional-caliber magician and woodworker, a man meticulous in everything he did. ``I would never hesitate to fly with him,'' said Barbara Giannini, a neigbor. Investigators say Lovelace was piloting a Northwest DC-9 that collided with one of the carrier's Boeing 727s on Monday killing eight people on the DC-9 and injuring 24 others. No one aboard the 727 was injured. Lovelace, 52, whose own injuries were minor, once was an instructor in flying DC-9s and has flown commercial airliners since 1966, Northwest officials said. After logging 20,000 hours in commercial flight, he took disability leave in February 1985 for kidney stone treatment. Monday's flight would have been his 13th since returning to work Nov. 25 following two weeks of ground training and 13 hours of simulator flying. Five of the dozen flights had been into or out of the Detroit airport, but Monday's was his first without a monitor at his side, Northwest said. Three weeks before returning to active duty, Lovelace had been declared bankrupt under a petition he had filed in mid-July in federal Bankruptcy Court in Phoenix. Court records show he cited debts of about $152,000 against assets of $106,000 and a monthly income of $4,212 in pension and retirement benefits. The airline has described his absence as a medical leave rather than retirement. His bankruptcy laywer, David Engelman, said part ofLovelace's debt stemmed from an unsuccessful gift shop that he sold in 1989. Divorced and with two grown children, Lovelace had remarried in September. He was certified as fit to fly Oct. 10 by the Federal Aviation Administration. ``Flying was his No. 1 love; he talked about it often,'' said Judy Wells, a friend of 3{ years. No one answered the door at Lovelace's Phoenix residence Wednesday, where a neatly trimmed kumquat tree graces the front yard of the beige, stucco one-story house with heavy, brown shutters. Neighbors offered a positive portrait of the man. An accomplished magician, he performed as the Great Orsini, complete with swirling black cape. ``Good enough to be professional,'' said a friend, Jack Wall. ``He's just a good neighbor,'' said Ms. Judy Wells, who took over the gift shop he'd started during his medical leave. ``He'd stop in and see how your day was going.'' Neighbor Dave Giannini, a carpenter, also knows him as ``very fussy, meticulous, very intelligent.'' ``His house, shop - anything he did - had to be just right,'' said Giannini, who lives across the street from Lovelace. ``I don't honestly believe it was his negligence'' that led to the collision, Giannini said. ``That guy was a straight guy. ... Even driving a vehicle he was really cautious.'' Brad Zinn, a friend who patronizes Sun Magic Shop where Great Orsini posters are displayed, said Lovelace is ``a very detailed kind of guy.'' ``Everything was just so with Bill, and I'm sure he took that into the cockpit,'' Zinn said. ``Bill just wouldn't have wandered onto the runway without some good reason. There must have been some miscommunication.'' It was Lovelace's interest in magic that led to his woodworking. He would perform shows for schools and hospitals when he wasn't flying. And because he needed props for such tricks as sawing a woman in half, he said in a 1986 newspaper interview, he decided to make his own. That led to purchase of a table saw and other equipment, and ultimately to the lathe on which he shapes bowls that have sold for $300 to $750. He once said it took 40 to 50 hours to make one of them. He also has produced chess sets and grandfather clocks.

DOC.HEAD: Nurses Say Brain-Damaged Woman Happier With Lover
DOC.TEXT: A woman who was severely brain-damaged in a 1983 traffic accident appears far happier with her lesbian lover than with anyone else, several nurses testified Wednesday during a guardianship hearing. The hearing to determine the guardianship of Sharon Kowalski once pitted her parents against her lover, but Don and Della Kowalski say they no longer have the energy or the money to care for their disabled daughter. That leaves only Ms. Kowalski's lover, Karen Thompson, seeking guardianship. Kowalski relinquished guardianship of his daughter last year and she has been cared for since at a nursing home in suburban Robbinsdakem, pending Ms. Thompson's petition. Maryanne Connell, a licensed practical nurse from Trevilla Nursing Home, testfied that Ms. Thompson has been extremely concerned about Ms. Kowalski's emotional and physical welfare. ``When Karen Thompson isn't around, she is withdrawn. She'll be real quiet,'' Ms. Connell said. ``When Karen is there, she's always smiling. She responds better. She cooperates.'' Other nurses provided similar testimony, which was scheduled to continue through Friday, when Judge Robert Campbell could make a final ruling. Gay rights activists have rallied around Ms. Thompson, saying she is the most capable of caring for Ms. Kowalski, 33, who was paralyzed in an accident blamed on a drunken driver. Ms. Kowalski lost use of her limbs and can't speak, but she can use the fingers on her right hand and communicates by typing, shaking her head and using an alphabet board. She taught physical education before the accident. Ms. Thompson, a professor at St. Cloud State University, has testified that she and Ms. Kowalski lived together four years before the accident and considered themselves secretly married. Kowalski had earlier fought Ms. Thompson's attempts to gain guardianship, saying he thought she only wanted to make money on speeches and a book about his daughter. Neither he nor his wife attended Wednesday's hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Hard Times, Tough Choices for State, Local Budget Officials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT attribution to county budget director.
DOC.TEXT: These are tough times for local and state officials. Confronted by falling revenues and widening budget gaps they are laying off workers, trimming aid to the old and poor and limiting services from garbage collection to snowplowing. ``It takes a lot of courage to be a local elected officials these days,'' said Douglas Peterson, senior policy analyst for the National League of Cities. ``They're going to be making harder and harder choices.'' At least 26 states face deficits or budget shortfalls this fiscal year; several others will next year. The prospects get worse as the economy continues to slide. Local officials are even harder pressed. Federal funds from earlier years have dried up and many states have cut local aid to balance their budgets. ``We're at the bone already and the marrow is just beginning to leak,'' said Dave Fuller, a commissioner in Lewis and Clark County, Mont., where any more bad fiscal news will mean cuts in senior citizen programs, snowplowing and road repair. There are a few exceptions. Oil states such as Alaska and Louisiana see revenues grow along with oil prices. Wyoming is anticipating an unexpected $184 million in increased revenues next year. But the bounty is double-edged. Before his term as governor expired this week, Alaska's Steve Cowper asked for $4.3 million more to pay escalating costs for fueling state cars, trucks and ferries. Elsewhere, officials struggle to maintain the status quo as the situation grows more bleak. ``We're kind of like a boat in a swift-flowing stream and I am trying to keep that boat right where it is, instead of being swept downstream in that current,'' said Gov.-elect Zell Miller of Georgia, where dropping revenues threaten layoffs next year. In most cases spending is being trimmed through across-the-board spending cuts. ``It allows department heads to decide what their priorities are,'' said said Marsha Howard, research director for the National Association of State Budget Directors. ``The problem with across-the-board cuts is that you might end up with a small agency taking such a cut that it can't exist anymore.'' However cuts are imposed, they mean a reduction in what government can do. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo's proposed $1 billion spending cut would reduce state aid to education, Medicaid, the homeless and those with AIDS. ``If you don't like these cuts, then show me what other cuts you have in mind,'' Cuomo said, when his plan was met with criticism. ``I frankly don't believe there are a whole lot of other alternatives.'' Massachusetts has laid off 1,711 workers, leaving fewer social workers for abused children. Virginia has laid off 700 state employees, including college faculty and staff. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder has ordered a mental hospital closed. Los Angeles and Louisville, Ky., have closed health centers. Vermont and Maryland put off programs to pay prescription for the elderly. Delaware postponed a program to fight drug and alcohol abuse among pregnant women. Education also has suffered. State college tuitions are rising in Massachusetts, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Virginia and New Jersey. New York City faces teacher layoffs. Lower per-pupil funding will mean fewer new teachers and larger classroom populations in Kansas. Snow removal is being cut. Concord, N.H., won't bring out the plows until it snows 4 inches. So far, the state capitol has been spared a snowstorm. ``We're kind of operating on a wing and a prayer at this point,'' said Assistant City Manager Julia Griffin. Many places have put off repairs on sewer systems, roads and bridges. ``There might be a road not paved or plowed or a water or sewer system not upgraded,'' said Lash Chaffin of the League of Nebraska Municipalities. ``Those are the kinds of things that come back to haunt you in future years, but they are things the public doesn't see.'' Other cuts are highly visible. A $20 million deficit has forced Los Angeles to impose a seven-month hiring freeze on the police department at a time when the homicide rate approaches a record. The budget ax has fallen on rich and poor communities. Washington, D.C. Mayor-elect Sharon Pratt Dixon promises to cut 2,000 workers in the face of a $100 million revenue shortfall. Officials in Washington's affluent suburbs of Montgomery County, Md., and Fairfax County, Va., say they will be forced to make sharp cuts. Some communities are still looking to taxes to avoid painful cuts. The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors is studying increased taxes on utilities and hotel rooms. New York City is contemplating a similar move on hotel bills. But many have been to the tax trough only to see deficits continue to grow. Arizona faces a $108 million deficit despite a $250 million tax increase last spring. New Jersey, with more than $2.8 billion in new taxes, faces a $600 million deficit. New York has raised taxes $3 billion over the last two years. A survey this spring of National League of Cities' 15,000 members found 76 percent had already increased charges for services like garbage collection. Forty percent had raised property taxes. Yet officials still strive to find places to cut. In Dutchess County, N.Y., which faces the elimination of 75 jobs, County Executive Lucille Pattison found the clerk's office was paying $1,000 a year for canned music. ``You can get rid of people but you can keep Muzak? Come on,'' County Budget Director David Squires said.

DOC.HEAD: Gunshots Wound Three on Bus, Signaling Possibly New Arab Tactic
DOC.TEXT: Gunshots were fired at an Israeli bus and car Wednesday in the occupied West Bank, wounding three Jewish settlers in an attack that may signal rising Arab militancy, government and news reports said. Palestinians protesters have generally thrown stones and firebombs at Israeli vehicles, avoiding guns. But Israel television said Wednesday's attack augurs an increasingly militant mood among Palestinians. Leaflets distributed this week by the uprising leaders, who support the Palestine Liberation Organization, urged Palestinians to attack Israelis ``using all means of struggle available.'' Military sources said several shots were fired at the bus of Egged, the national bus company, as it drove on a main thoroughfare near Jelazoun refugee camp, north of Ramallah in the West Bank. Six to 10 bullets were fired at the bus, smashing some windows and wounding the three settlers, the government news agency Itim said. Soldiers reportedly launched wide searches suspects. The bus was headed to Elon Moreh, Israeli reports said. The settlement is near Nablus and known for its Jewish militancy. The three wounded bus passengers, a married couple and another woman, all from Elon Moreh, were rushed by ambulance to Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem, hospital spokeswoman Ruth Mekel said. Mekel said all three were slightly wounded. Israel radio said shots were also fired at an Israeli-owned automobile traveling behind the bus, apparently from a mosque, but that no one in the car was injured. The worst bus attack of the Arab uprising was in July 1989, when 16 Israelis and foreigners were killed. A Palestinian grabbed the steering wheel of a bus and forced it off a cliff outside Jerusalem. Newspapers, quoting army officials, have said recently that Palestinians are likely to turn to firearms as their uprising nears its third anniversary. Moslem fundamentalist groups have been encouraging activists to mount more attacks, Israel television said. It said black-market sales of guns and pistols to Palestinians in the occupied lands was four times higher than a year ago. The government is also easing regulations for issuing firearms to Israelis, the Maariv daily said, adding that thousands more civilians will soon be able to obtain gun licenses. The measure follows an upsurge in stabbing attacks by Arabs. In other violence Wednesday, a border policeman in the Gaza Strip was shot in the head and seriously wounded during a clash with Palestinians holding a march in advance of this weekend's third anniversary of the anti-Israeli uprising, the army said. It was not immediately clear who fired the shot. In a statement, the army said one protester was also seriously wounded, and 22 were detained. In Jenin in the West Bank, masked Palestinian activists shot to death Harab Hindawi, 43, on suspicion he collaborated with Israeli authorities, Arab reports said. The death raised to 313 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs in the uprising, most as suspected collaborators with Israel. Fifty-three Israelis have been slain by Palestinians, and 776 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Expert: X-ray Machine May Not Have Been Working Before Flight 103
DOC.TEXT: An anti-terrorism expert hired by Pan Am said Wednesday he was told the X-ray machine in Frankfurt, the German city where Flight 103 originated, may not have been working that day. Retired Lt. Col Wilfred Wood told a public inquiry into the Dec. 21, 1988, terrorist bombing of Flight 103 that he had been hired by Pan American World Airways to set up the airline's security subsidiary, known as Alert.
