The Boeing 747, which blew up over Lockerbie, Scotland, left all 259 people on board dead and killed 11 on the ground. After originating in Frankfurt, it stopped at London's Heathrow airport for a transfer to the New York-bound jumbo jet. Wood told the inquiry, now in its 10th week, that security official Ulrich Weber told him the day after the disaster that the X-ray machine at Frankfurt might not have been working the previous day. ``I was shocked rigid and very upset,'' Wood said. ``I was appalled.'' The machine is used to X-ray luggage to ensure it does not carry anything suspicious. Police believe it was in Frankfurt that the bomb, packed in a radiocassette recorder inside a bronze suitcase, was loaded. Testimony during the inquiry has indicated that Pan Am failed to match baggage with passengers or physically search it. The inquiry, expected to last into next year, is looking into possible lapses in security procedures, but it is not assessing criminal responsibility. No one has been arrested in connection with the disaster, but investigators have said they were checking possible involvement by Palestinian radical groups. In his testimony Wednesday, Wood said the Alert security subsidy was set up six months before the disaster. He said that much of the security training he recommended in London was reduced from weeks to days. X-ray operators were trained for an hour or two, he said. On Tuesday, Pan Am security chief Daniel Soneson acknowledged that training of security staff was inadequate.

DOC.HEAD: Transplant Doctor To Focus On Research
With AM-Transplant Drug
DOC.TEXT: The doctor who performed the world's first liver transplant said Wednesday he'll perform fewer surgeries and more research as the University of Pittsburgh creates the world's first transplant institute. ``This is a switch in gears,'' said Dr. Thomas Starzl. ``It's part of a thing that's been going on for a long time.'' Starzl, 64, who underwent surgery in August to clear a clogged artery near his heart, said he only will perform surgeries in cases with unusual problems or experimental procedures. He made his comments on his future at a news conference to discuss an experimental anti-rejection drug that will be tested on people with diabetes. Starzl said he will concentrate on developing Pitt's Transplantation Institute, which was chartered in 1986. It will be modeled after the nation's leading cancer treatment institutes, he said. Centers performing transplants around the world are all part of larger hospitals or clinics, but Pitt's will be the first free-standing facility, he said. Starzl attempted the world's first liver transplant in 1963 at the University of Colorado in Denver. He performed the first successful liver transplant there four years later. Starzl also pioneered techniques in kidney transplants. ``The field has come so far, and failures have become such a rarity. ... In the developmental days when many patients died, the loss was less difficult to see than the few patients who die now,'' Starzl said. ``Now, when you fail, it creates much sharper questions.'' Stormie Jones, 13, of White Settlement, Texas, the world's first and longest-surviving recipient of a heart-liver transplant, died Nov. 10 at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh when she suddenly rejected her transplanted heart. Starzl, who led the team that did the heart-liver transplant in 1984, was reluctant to discuss her case Wednesday, but distributed copies of a statement on his plans and the eulogy he delivered at a recent Pittsburgh memorial service for Stormie and other Children's patients. ``The lot of physicians who care for the desperately ill is to reconcile grief with the determination to make things better,'' the statement said. ``Without the sense of personal loss that goes with a dear name and face, there is little progress and no incentive for striving except for personal or professional ambition.'' Pitt transplant researchers are wrestling with methods of transplanting intestines, which patients reject easily, Starzl told reporters. ``They're the Achilles heel of multiple transplants,'' he said, but doctors were encouraged by four successful intestine transplants that were performed here this year.

DOC.HEAD: World Groups Scamble to Ease Soviet Food Shortages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 15th `On Thursday...' to ADD British food aid; pickup graf 16 pvs, `The Italian...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB1, TLV1; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Israeli fruit, German sausages, Italian cheese and American medical supplies are among the products arriving in the Soviet Union as part of a worldwide private effort to ease winter shortages. While the governments of the United States, Sweden and other countries have no formal plans yet to organize food aid, private groups and individuals are rallying to rush food to the Soviets. Relief organizations have chartered planes, used Aeroflot flights and organized truck convoys to get past the vast country's transportation bottlenecks. Several organizations have sent staff members to ensure that food and medicine reach their destinations. The Soviet government, which blames food problems on the collapse of its central distribution system, has not officially asked for the food. But the chronic shortages have worsened dramaticaly this winter. Consumers must wait in long lines - often for as long as three hours - for basics such as butter. Sometimes, pushing and shoving breaks out over a scarce item. The country doesn't have enough rail cars or refrigerated trucks to transport food from the fields to markets, nor are there sufficient storage facilities. There has been widespread theft and diversion to the black market. The European Community has drafted an aid package, to be adopted next week, providing about $2 billion in food and transportation over two years. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, meanwhile, has made deals involving loans and export credits to buy basic foods and consumer products to fill empty store shelves. But individuals and private organizations have gone ahead on their own to help orphanages, hospitals and pensioners. Tore Waeraass, a Norwegian slaughterhouse owner, is driving a truck carrying three tons of sausages to the Soviet city of Murmansk. ``I'm a bit suspicious of the mafia in Murmansk. But people from the church have promised to help us so that it will be families with children who get the Christmas gift,'' he said. The first aid to reach Moscow - a planeload of food from German charities - arrived on Nov. 29. Trucks met the Aeroflot flight and took 25,000 packages of flour, sugar, sausage and lard to children's hospitals and orphanages. The German Red Cross and the Caritas organization sent convoys of trucks, vans and buses stuffed with food packages last week. More caravans are planned later this month. And Soviet soldiers on Wednesday unloaded an emergency 10-ton shipment of Israeli watermelons, tomatoes and oranges that Israeli leaders said were a gesture of thanks for allowing thousands of Soviet Jews to emigrate. On Thursday, Israel's quasi-governmental Jewish Agency was to send 15 tons of powdered milk to children's hospitals in Moscow, Leningrad and Kiev, said Yehuda Weinraub, an agency spokesman. In London, British children began a campaign Wednesday to collect food for Soviet youngsters. Organizers urged every British school child to donate a can of food and each British school to send at least one parcel. A British management consultant announced a cooperative effort with Moscow officials to improve the delivery of bread and milk in the Soviet capital. Keith Burgess, head of a five-man team from Andersen Consulting that spent three days in Moscow, said: ``In the short run, we will focus on squeezing that extra bit of capacity out of the system to make sure there is enough to eat this winter. ... In the long run, the aim is to rework the food supply system.'' The Italian aid group ``Together for Peace'' flew 14 tons of milk, tuna, cheese, vegetables, syringes and medicine to a children's hospital in Moscow last weekend. The American relief agency CARE, concerned about the effect a sustained shortage could have on Gorbachev's government, this week began an operation to distribute more than 50,000 packages of food to residents in Leningrad and Moscow. The Connecticut-based relief group AmeriCares sent 4,000 tons of powdered protein drink, aspirin, and antibiotics Dec. 1 for orphanages and children's hospitals. The aid, collected from companies and individuals, was the first private American aid flight into the Soviet Union, said spokesman Dwain Schenck. ``Our State Department says they don't see a real famine problem and shortage. But the fact is a lot of people over there are suffering,'' Schenck said. The U.S. and several Western governments say there are shortages, but not widespread hunger. But some governments are taking steps to organize food aid. Japan, which has already promised medical assistance, announced Wednesday it would set up a clearinghouse for private food aid to the Soviet Union. Switzerland plans an emergency airlift this week. ``The impression is that the shop shelves are empty and refrigerators full in the Soviet Union,'' said Norwegian Church Aid spokesman Helge Kjollesdal. ``But even if there is no acute starvation in the real sense, there can easily be difficult situations at children's and old people's homes, and among other underprivileged groups who do not manage to hoard.''

DOC.HEAD: Nasty Fight Over Farm Subsidies Results in Near-Breakdown in Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 21 grafs to UPDATE with Canadian comment, ADDS first name and title to Yeutter, minor editing to conform. Picks up 21st pvs, `The European...'
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators involved in 107-nation free trade talks reported failure Wednesday in their efforts to resolve a nasty fight over farm subsidies with some trade ministers suggesting the discussions are on the verge of breaking down. ``It is a stalemate and it is serious,'' said a grim-faced U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. Officials said there would be another effort at a breakthrough Thursday. ``High noon is tomorrow (Thursday),'' said Canadian Trade Minister John Crobie. ``If there is no change, then it is over.'' The trade ministers emerged just before midnight from a two-hour meeting in which they sought in vain for a compromise position on the expensive subsidies that developed countries pay to their farmers. An Indian official, Commerce Minister Subramanian Swamy, was pessimistic, saying, ``It looks like they are heading for suspension.'' If the talks are broken off, even for a brief time, it would put the entire four-year effort at trade reform in jeopardy because of the tight deadlines negotiators had faced to submit a completed document to the U.S. Congress. The dispute pitted the 12-nation European Community against much of the rest of the world, including large farm exporters such as the United States, Brazil and Argentina. European officials had been expected Wednesday to agree to at least a modest expansion of their offer to reduce internal farm support payments by 30 percent. Instead, the Europeans emerged from their separate meeting saying they had decided to make no further offer on farm subsidies until the United States made compromises on other issues. There had also been hope that the European position might change as a result of a meeting Wednesday night in Paris between German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand. But following that discussion, no new offer was announced. Crosbie described the mood inside the discussions as ``somber'' and said the meeting Thursday would determine whether there was any point in continuing the talks. ``We are going to have to decide whether we are going to give it all up or not,'' he said. The farm subsidy fight evolved as the biggest stumbling block to conclusion of the most ambitious round of trade liberalization talks ever undertaken. The negotiations, known as the Uruguay Round for the country where they began in 1986, had been scheduled to wrap up Friday after five days of marathon bargaining. But after three days the talks remained stalemated and some delegations talked openly about the possibility of giving up and going home. ``The United States has got to recognize that this is a negotiation between equals, not a group of people to be pushed around in this way,'' said British Agriculture Secretary John Gummer. Otto Schlecht, Germany's deputy economics minister, said, ``We have no reason to go to the Americans on our knees.'' Gummer said the Europeans had insisted on American compromise offers in areas including trade in services, textiles nnd investment to be made at the same time that discussions went forward on the farm issue. He said the U.S. side had rejected that proposal. U.S. officials said the Europeans were engaging in a desperate attempt to shift the blame for failure of the negotiations. ``What is holding up the negotiations here is that the European Community has not yet provided a proposal on agriculture,'' U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said. The European Community entered the negotiations offering to trim domestic farm support payments by 30 percent. The United States, supported by major farm exporting countries, was seeking much deeper cuts of 75 percent in domestic supports and import barriers and a 90 percent cut in export subsidies. The trade talks, the eighth in a series of negotiations dating to 1947, offered the promise of lowering prices for consumers while at the same time boosting economic prosperity, especially in Third World countries with farm-based economies. The United States has argued that without sufficient progress in agriculture, developed nations will not be able to win concessions from Third World countries to reform their trade practices including agreement on tough new rules to protect against copyright piracy, something that costs American businesses an estimated $60 billion in lost sales annually. Negotiators spoke pessimistically about a failure of the talks, which many fear could trigger a rise of protectionism and global trade wars, similar to the events of the 1930s that were blamed for making the Great Depression more severe. ``Anyone who does not admit that the round is in deep crisis is just deluding themselves,'' said Australian Trade Minister Neal Blewett.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq to Free 36 Japanese Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Iraq announced Thursday it would release 36 Japanese hostages whose family members are currently in Baghdad, a Foreign Ministry official said. In a meeting with the relatives of the ``human shields,'' Uday Hussein, head of the Iraq Olympic Committee and son of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, told them his father had approved their release, the official said. The date of their departure has not been disclosed. The family members have been in Iraq since Nov. 1 with Antonio Inoki, a professional wrestler turned member of Parliament, to negotiate the release of the hostages. A nationwide television broadcast showed the family members rejoicing over the announcement. The Foreign Ministry has said Inoki's trip is not in line with their policy because he is giving the impression he wants to make concessions to Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone returned from Baghdad with 74 hostages last month in a mission that drew criticism from the U.S. government. More than 200 Japanese remain in Iraq, of which 78 are being held as ``human shields'' against foreign attack in strategic military and industrial locations, the official said.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Affiliate Alerts Network About `Subliminal Messages'
DOC.TEXT: A South Carolina viewer who saw the words ``Adultery!'' and ``Shock Therapy!'' during commercial breaks on CBS' ``Guiding Light'' wasn't seeing subliminal messages, the network said Wednesday. Because of ``a small technical problem'' in New York, the Columbia woman saw the first part of taped promotions for Geraldo Rivera's syndicated talk show that were supposed to appear only on WCBS-TV in New York, the network said. ``It was utterly innocent,'' said a network executive who spoke on condition of anonymity. The brief appearance of the promotional announcements accidentally went out on the network during the pauses it puts in the ``Guiding Light'' daytime soap opera for local commercials aired by affiliates, the executive said. The goof came to light because of the sharp eyes of viewer Julie Moore. She said that while looking at episodes of the soap opera she taped last week, she spotted the word ``Adultery!'' in large type, imposed over the CBS logo, during a commercial break. The words ``Shock Therapy!'' appeared in the same way in the tape of the next day's show. The shows appeared on the CBS affiliate in Columbia, S.C., WLTX-TV. ``I (didn't) know what it was until I ran the tape back,'' said Moore, who said she discovered the words when she advanced the tape slowly. Dick Laughridge, the station's general manager, said he was flabbergasted when shown the videotapes Tuesday. WLTX made copies of them and sent them to CBS officials in New York. Embarrassed CBS officials issued a terse statement. `There was a small technical problem in the way our network computers switch to local stations,'' the network said. Then, alluding to the accidental transmission of the ``Geraldo'' promotions on the network, it said: ``Occasionally, a fraction of a second of another feed will air. In this case, it was a promo for an upcoming show to air on WCBS-TV in New York. We are taking steps to correct this problem.''

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Group Seeks Recall; Chrysler Says Request `Irresponsible'
DOC.TEXT: A consumer advocacy organization Wednesday asked Chrysler Corp. to recall 500,000 cars and minivans equipped with a complex automatic transmission system. The company rejected the request as ``completely without merit.'' The Center for Auto Safety said in a letter to Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca the Ultradrive transmission had performed poorly since its introduction in the 1989 model year and that its durability was questionable. Owners complain that the transmissions stick between gears, causing clutch burnout, computer controller failure and internal transmission damage, said the letter from Clarence Ditlow, executive director of the center. ``Ultradrive's dismal showing in its first two years on the road earns it the dubious distinction of the world's most defective transmission,'' Ditlow wrote. Chrysler spokesman Tony Cervone said Ditlow's description of problems with the transmission were ``grossly exaggerated.'' The recall suggestion ``is completely without merit and his allegations regarding safety hazards in connection with this transmission are totally irresponsible,'' Cervone said. The nation's third-largest automaker introduced the Ultradrive four-speed transmission in late 1988. It was offered on the 1989, 1990 and 1991 Dodge Dynasty, Spirit and Caravan minivan; Plymouth Acclaim and Voyager minivan. It was available as standard or optional equipment on the 1990 and 1991 Chrysler Imperial, LeBarons, New Yorker and Town & Country minivan as well as the Dodge Daytona. Ultradrive-equipped vehicles comprise 2.4 percent of vehicles sold in the United States since the new transmission was introduced. But 23.3 percent of the vehicles that have prompted complaints to the Center for Auto Safety and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration have had Ultradrive, Ditlow said. NHTSA, the safety arm of the Department of Transportation, has received 161 complaints about Chrysler transmissions during the 1989 and 1990 model years, Ditlow said. Ranking second is General Motors Corp., with 91 complaints. GM sold more than 5 million cars and trucks in 1989, while Chrysler sold more than 2 million. ``The letters consumers have written point to an alarming pattern of repeated premature Ultradrive failures,'' Ditlow wrote. Many owners have described ``harrowing experiences'' when transmissions gave out during travel, he said. Cervone said most problems with the transmissions had been identified and fixed early in 1989, and it is ``now fully competitive from reliability standpoints and ahead of the competition in many other areas.''

DOC.HEAD: Most Students Back in Class After Earthquake Projection
DOC.TEXT: Most students and teachers in the New Madrid Fault region were back in classrooms Wednesday after a two-day earthquake break called by officials responding to a scientist's prediction. New Mexico scientist Iben Browning projected a 50 percent chance for a major earthquake this week along the fault, which runs from Cairo, Ill., to Marked Tree, Ark. Earthquake experts scoffed at Browning's projection, which he based on tidal forces, but school officials throughout souteast Missouri and parts of Arkansas, Illinois, Kentucky, Tennessee and Indiana canceled classes. Some school districts that did not cancel classes reported absentee rates as high as 50 percent Monday. Things were pretty much back to normal Wednesday and most students were back in school. But Missouri's Scott County Central School District didn't plan to re-open until Thursday. ``When you're going to have problems with your attendance, you might as well not have school,'' said Superintendent W. Ray Shoaf. Dick Hilburn, assistant superintendent of schools in Kennett, said he didn't notice any lingering earhquake fears Wednesday. ``If there are, I can't tell it,'' he said. ``From what I can tell, things are going about like normal. Attendance is almost normal at the high school, which I think is a pretty good gauge.'' Some school officials blamed the media for exaggerating the earthquake scare. ``I think they got snowed,'' Jim Mauk, business manager for the New Madrid County Schools, said of the media. ``Browning made the projection, but he's not the one who hyped it.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted of Record Speeding Tried to Bribe Cops With Car
DOC.TEXT: A motorist convicted of driving 155 mph on the highway and trying to bribe traffic police with his friend's car was ordered to pay $1,664 in fines, a newspaper reported Wednesday. Police said Salim Ayob set a record for speeding in South Africa when he was spotted zooming toward Durban on March 2 in a friend's BMW sedan. After being stopped, police said Ayob offered an officer the car. The officer refused, and Ayob then offered him $464, prosecutors said. When the officer also refused that bribe attempt, Ayob allegedly approached another policeman, who then arrested him, said the Citizen newspaper, which reported the case. Ayob, 22, was convicted Monday in Heidelberg, southeast of Johannesburg. He was fined $1,200 plus the amount of the second attempted bribe, the paper said.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Stolen Impressionist Masterpieces Found in Corsica
DOC.TEXT: Nine impressionist paintings stolen from a Paris museum in 1985, including a Claude Monet masterpiece that gave impressionism its name, have been found in Corsica, authorities said Wednesday. The works, including Monet's famed ``Impression Sunrise,'' were stolen from the Marmottan Museum in a daring daytime theft witnessed by more than 30 people. Police disclosed few details about the breakthrough in the case, but said seven people had been taken into custody on the Mediterranean island and were expected to be transferred soon to Paris. The nine paintings were found Tuesday in a villa in Porto-Vecchio in southern Corsica. The stolen paintings included five Monets, two by Pierre Auguste Renoir and one by Berthe Morisot, as well as a portrait of Monet. Their total value was estimated at $20 million. Five armed men carried out the theft, getting away easily because the museum's alarm system had been disconnected the previous night. They were in the museum for only about 10 minutes, and drove away after putting the paintings in the trunk of a car.

DOC.HEAD: Judge to Decide Absentee Ballots in Berkeley Election
DOC.TEXT: A judge will decide if last-minute absentee ballots can determine the outcome of a runoff for mayor of Berkeley. Incumbent Mayor Loni Hancock's apparent victory margin over lead challenger Fred Weekes was narrow enough that the outcome could hang on absentee ballots on which the court fight is focusing. Tuesday's runoff was forced when Hancock, a leader of the city's liberal Berkeley Citizens Action party, got 49.9 percent of the vote Nov. 6, just missing the 50-percent-plus-one requirement. BCA's liberal Democratic coalition has dominated city politics for a decade. On Friday, Alameda County Superior Court Judge Howard Schwartz will hear arguments on whether absentee ballots that arrived after the polls closed Tuesday should be counted. The election code says absentee ballots can be counted only if received by Election Day. But Hancock's opponents say as many as 3,000 of 8,000 requested ballots weren't mailed out until last week, reaching voters as late as Monday. ``We won't know the number of ballots involved for a while,'' City Clerk Marie McKetchnie said Wednesday. Hancock led Weekes, a city councilman, by only 590 votes in unofficial results of Tuesday's election. But Weekes, a moderate Democrat who wants to eliminate ``ideological practices'' from City Hall, asked the judge to allow the counting of mail-in ballots postmarked before the polls closed but not received until after Election Day. ``There are a large number of uncounted ballots out there,'' said Weekes. ``I don't know how large, but it could change the outcome.'' With all 116 precincts reporting, Weekes trailed Hancock 16,682 to 16,092 but led 2,403 to 1,624 among early absentee ballots. Depending on the judge's decision, remaining absentee ballots could change the outcome. But a spokesman for Hancock, who during the campaign promised to continue Berkeley's liberal tradition, was confident the mayor would remain in office given her edge. ``If the absentee ballots split in the same ratio as the earlier absentee ballots, there is no way Mr. Weekes can win the election,'' said Malcom Bernstein, treasurer of the Hancock campaign. McKetchnie's office was swamped with requests for absentee ballots after the special election was announced. ``We got applications from all over the world,'' she said. Hancock, 52, is the most prominent member of the Berkeley Citizens Action party, born in the fervor of the 1960s anti-Vietnam War, youth and civil rights movements. The coalition lost control of the council and the rent board in the November election. Hancock's defeat could mean the end of the group's dominance.

DOC.HEAD: Dockworkers Return After Four-Day Strike
DOC.TEXT: Longshoremen returned to work Wednesday after a four-day strike that threatened to disrupt the Philadelphia-area ports' major fruit-importing season. A tentative four-year agreement was reached one day after shipping cargo clerks in Baltimore ended a two-day strike. The Longshoremen's contract provides a $1-an-hour pay raise per year and bolsters pension and welfare funds, said Elwood F. Gunther, business agent for Local 1332, International Longshoremen's Association. Rank-and-file members are tentatively scheduled to vote on the contract Dec. 18, Gunther said. ``I think this is a contract that all the officials can go out and sell to the membership and vote the contract up,'' he said. The deal affects about 2,000 dockworkers at ports in Philadelphia, southern New Jersey and Wilmington, Del. Their 14-month contract extension expired at midnight Friday. Labor agreements had been reached earlier in New York; Hampton Roads, Va.; and in South Atlantic ports from North Carolina to Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion Causes Evacuation of About 1,000 San Francisco Commuters
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and a 1,000-volt electric arc spitting sparks and smoke at a rail station prompted authorities to evacuate about 1,000 San Francisco-bound commuters Wednesday morning. No injuries were reported during the explosion and subsequent arcing that occurred about 9 a.m. at the 19th Street Bay Area Rapid Transit rail station, said Ray Cole, acting manager of system safety. The operator of the 10-car train ordered the station evacuated. ``I was in the front of the train and I heard this loud bump,'' said commuter Clint Danbury, 33. ``There were lots of yellow sparks and smoke and there was about 20 seconds of panic. ``One oman moaned, `Oh my God, oh my God,' but several others said `Let's calm down.' It was pretty scary in a dark tunnel in the ground.'' Technicians were investigating why the rail that carries the electrical current that powers the train began flashing and generating sparks and smoke, Cole said. A heavy electrical current flashed into the metalwork behind the wall panels on one side of the station and melted brackets supporting decorative metal strips at the other end. All traffic to and from the 19th and 12th Street stations in Oakland was shut down for about an hour, until id the group's program ``surprised journalists and even some members of the bloc, who were already disagreeing with some provisions during the press conference.'' Sentiment for a crackdown is widespread in the Communist Party, which holds a majority in most legislative bodies on the national and local level. Many Communists want Gorbachev to call a state of emergency and enforce it through the armed forces and the KGB security police. The National Salvation Committee seemed to have the same goals, although they were not spelled out clearly during the news conference called to announce the group's formation. The Soviet economy is crumbling. The old central system is failing and grocery shelves in major cities are bare. With all but one of the 15 Soviet republics seeking some form of independence or autonomy from central government, many officials fear the collapse of the union. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, warned officers at the Dzerzhinsky Military Academy in Moscow against a military coup. ``If the army enters our boiling society as an active factor, confrontation will increase many times and carry the society to catastrophe,'' he said. ``I am categorically opposed to any possibility of escaping the crisis with force, oprating through the army. ``First of all, the army cannot solve the economic problem, and today the economy is the greatest concern. Just the reverse: such a development will deprive us of the last chance for a positive result, it will deprive us of the chance to escape a civil war.'' Yeltsin said ``any interference by the army in internal political affairs will simply blow up the army from inside. It could split into small groups fighting each other.'' ``The tough political struggle, which today remains peaceful, could grow into an armed conflict,'' he said. ``Taking into account that we are a nuclear power, such a development would immediately create a threat not only to life in our country but in the whole world.'' Yeltsin has led the drive for shifting power from the central government to the republics. As a result, hard-liners feel he has contributed to forces splintering the country.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Remains in Serious Condition After Stroke
DOC.TEXT: Burt Lancaster remained in serious condition Thursday, six days after suffering a stroke, a hospital spokeswoman said. Lancaster, 77, was visiting a friend Friday when he suffered a stroke and was hospitalized at Los Alamitos Medical Center. His condition hasn't changed since the weekend, said hospital spokeswoman Sharon Buaas. ``He's stable. He had a stroke with right side weakness and difficulty in speech,'' she said. Well-wishers worldwide have flooded the hospital with cards and telephone calls, Buaas said, adding: ``He has many, many fans.'' Lancaster won an Oscar in 1960 for ``Elmer Gantry'' and has appeared in more than 70 movies, including ``From Here to Eternity,'' ``The Birdman of Alcatraz,'' ``The Rose Tattoo,'' ``The Swimmer'' and ``Sweet Smell of Success.''

DOC.HEAD: Undercover Mom Returns to Michigan
DOC.TEXT: An undercover drug agent who fled Michigan because of threats against her children has returned despite advice from police to stay away. After leaving Michigan, Wendy Stanek, mother of seven, worked undercover for agents in Arizona. ``It got too touchy. God, if I didn't have the kids, I'd stay out there and do it,'' Stanek said Tuesday by telephone, back in the same Crystal Falls house she moved out of several months ago. Stanek took it upon herself to penetrate the drug trade in her small hometown near the Michigan-Wisconsin line. Her free-lance work for the state police's Upper Peninsula Substance Enforcement Team, or UPSET, led to the December 1989 arrests of 22 people on cocaine and marijuana charges. Authorities heralded the operation's success, but threats against Stanek and her children persuaded her to move her family four months later into hiding near Show Low, Ariz. Stanek, 36 and divorced, said she made slow and uneasy progress in undercover work for the Navajo County (Ariz.) Drug Task Force. ``That's the first time I felt very uncomfortable. ... I was into cut-off-finger times.'' All the while, her kids were homesick for Michigan. ``It was the kids,'' Stanek said. ``They didn't like it.'' Arleigh Richmond, chief deputy of the Navajo County Sheriff's Department, said the task force had great expectations when Stanek volunteered to do undercover work in the mountainous southeastern Arizona county. But after two months, she failed to make any buys. ``We tried to work her as an agent here. We had no success,'' Richmond said. ``I think she had pretty much told everybody what and who she was when she got here. We wasted quite a bit of money before we found that out. ``I think the problem was in our situation,'' he said, referring to Navajo County's close-knit community. ``It's very hard to work narcotics here.'' Richmond said he still has a high opinion of Stanek and, ``I don't want anything negative said about the lady.'' Stanek and her children returned to the Upper Peninsula in mid-November. The Michigan drug agents for whom Stanek worked said her return is a bad idea. ``She's back against our wishes,'' said Lt. Bill Johnson, the Michigan state police detective who leads UPSET. ``We did not encourage her to come back. We're still concerned. It will mean we will have to take some special precautions.'' With Stanek's testimony, Iron County Prosecutor Larry Field has obtained convictions or guilty pleas from 16 of the 22 defendants. Three more are awaiting trial. Stanek said she has had no confrontations since her return to Crystal Falls. And life for her children has resumed peacefully ``just like we never left,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
CNN Gives Up Effort to Keep Tape Transcripts Private
DOC.TEXT: CNN has decided to allow court transcripts of its Manuel Noriega prison tapes to be made public without further legal battles, the network and its attorney said Wednesday. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler ruled Tuesday the transcripts could be released Thursday, unless CNN decided to take the case to a higher court. ``CNN has decided not to appeal,'' network attorney Terry Bienstock said, adding that CNN's primary concern had always been to protect its confidential source. ``We don't think the transcripts in and of themselves will jeopardize the source,'' he said. CNN spokesman Steve Haworth said many of the conversations were in code, and that without supporting documents, they would not be meaningful in any case. Sanford Bohrer, attorney for four media organizations that asked for the transcripts, applauded CNN's decision. ``I think it was the right decision because Judge Hoeveler's was the right decision,'' Bohrer said. ``I could never understand how CNN could claim to own conversations that were taped by the United States government, of an inmate in a federal prison.'' The news organizations seeking the tapes were The Miami Herald, The Associated Press, Post-Newsweek station WPLG-TV of Miami, Gannett Co. Inc. and USA Today, which Gannett owns. They argued the public has a right to examine the content of tapes that set off a free-speech controversy that went to the U.S. Supreme Court. CNN has televised some of the seven tapes at issue and argued that the recordings, and therefore the transcripts, were its property. CNN accused other news organizations of ``professional jealousy,'' and said the transcripts should be burned or returned to the network. But the judge's decision ruled the tape transcripts were public documents because the information was originally compiled by Noriega and the government, not CNN. The tapes controversy began last month when CNN aired a series of telecasts based on Noriega's telephone conversations somehow leaked to the network. The judge ordered the telecasts stopped pending his review of he tapes, a move CNN opposed as unconstitutional prior restraint of the press. The Supreme Court decided not to intervene, and the judge, after reviewing the transcripts, determined there was no threat to Noriega's right to a fair trial and said the tapes could be aired. CNN hasn't said where it got the tapes, but Noriega's attorneys said the tapes were released to the government of Panama by the State Department or the Drug Enforcement Administration, and that Panamanians gave them to CNN. Noriega is awaiting trial on charges of taking $4.6 million in payoffs to protect the cocaine trade passing through Panama from Colombia to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Group Says It Would Support Trade Credits for Soviets
DOC.TEXT: A group that is dedicated to helping Jews leave the Soviet Union said Wednesday that it would not object if the Bush administration agreed to give agriculture credits to the Soviet Union. Surpluses of wheat and corn have beaten down prices, and farm belt lawmakers are urging President Bush to lift the restrictions on the Soviet Union so the bumper crop can be sold. ``We either smell it or we sell it, and this whole situation smells,'' said Rep. Pat Roberts, R-Kan., who slammed his hand a few times at a House Agriculture subcommittee hearing. Shoshana Cardin, chairwoman of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry, said the Soviets had made ``substantial progress'' in allowing Jews to leave or permitting them to study, teach and maintain their religion, language and culture. Another Jewish group, the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews, said Bush should send only emergency food aid. To permit sales on credit, Bush would have to exempt Moscow from a 1974 law that prohibits credit to countries with restrictive emigration laws. In the past U.S. administrations have insisted that the Soviet Union had to embody its emigration liberalization into law, but last week the president said he was considering a waiver. Roberts, Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., and other defenders of wheat and corn farmers say preventing exports to the Soviet Union is similar to a grain embargo. ``The amount of food moving into Soviet cities is so inadequate that last week's newspapers were reporting Soviets literally fighting over food in grocery stores with nearly empty shelves,'' said Glickman, who chaired the hearing of the wheat, soybeans and feed grains subcommittee. ``The time is now to help (Mikhail) Gorbachev and our farmers,'' Glickman said. F. Paul Dickerson, associate administrator of the foreign agricultural service, an arm of the Agriculture Department, told lawmakers that he could not comment directly on the issue. He said, however, that the glut of U.S. wheat is part of a record crop worldwide, and buying countries are not making big purchases because they expect that prices will continue to drop. ``We do not anticipate that shortages will lead to widespread hunger or imminent starvation in the foreseeable future,'' Dickerson said. ``Again, we believe that public reports predicting famine or widespread hunger are overdrawn and premature.''

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Network to Pull in its Belt 108 Million Notches
DOC.TEXT: CBC officials announced Wednesday spending cuts of $108 million, forcing the elimination of 1,100 jobs and the curtailing of local television newscasts, entertainment and children's programs. The shortfall is due to government funding cuts, inflation, declining television advertising, and other costs like new taxes and pension funding, said Gerard Veilleux, president of the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. The cuts represent just under 10 percent of CBC's $1.2 billion annual budget. About $900 million of that comes from government and the rest from ad revenue. The CBC employs about 10,000 people, and the layoffs are its worst ever. Speaking at a news conference, Veilleux said the $108 million in spending cuts means eliminating 1,100 jobs and closing or reducing the operations of 11 CBC television stations. The cuts go into effect April 1, but some effects will be felt immediately. ``These decisions have given me many sleepless nights,'' Veilleux told CBC employees via a closed-circuit televised announcement. ``I can only trust we're doing the right thing.'' With the cuts, each Canadian province will have no more than one English and one French-language station. Closed immediately will be stations in Goose Bay, Newfoundland, and Matane, Quebec. The local news production at CBC Toronto will also cease, although the network will still provide local newscasts. As part of the cuts, the CBC has decided it can no longer afford the $20-million annual cost to run Radio Canada International, the international shortwave radio service, or the $4.5-million cost of the English and French parliamentary channels, which broadcast House of Commons proceedings. CBC will ask the government to pick up the tab for these operations. In addition, English and French radio network budgets will be cut by 1 percent. The following year, 2 percent will be trimmed from their budgets. Newsworld, CBC's all-news cable channel, is not supposed to be affected. However, many of its news items originate at regional stations that will be closed.

DOC.HEAD: School Officials Decide to Keep Twain Books as Required Reading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note Language in grafs 8 and 17.
DOC.TEXT: A black parent who complained that two classics by Mark Train were racially offensive said he was disappointed that school board members decided Wednesday to keep the books as required reading. ``There should have been more consideration given to the problem than take it back to square one,'' David Perry said. Perry said he was pleased with the public review of ``The Adventures of Tom Sawyer'' and ``The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.'' ``I think the process was a good one for the community because I think there was a dialogue ... that was very, very needed,'' he said. Perry said he had high regard for 500 high school students who circulated a petition to retain ``Huckleberry Finn,'' saying they got a chance to hear the black perspective on the book. School board members capped a five-hour meeting by voting unanimously to keep the books on the required reading list. Perry received a standing ovation when he accused the books of portraying blacks in a racist, degrading manner. ``No matter what the depiction of time, I think any writer and any orator who has to use the word `nigger' more than 300 times in a presentation leaves something to be desired,'' Perry said. The hearing stemmed from Perry's complaint about his daughter's discomfort while reading ``Tom Sawyer.'' At his urging, the school board's Materials Review Committee agreed to take the books off the required list and make them optional reading. Both books were written by Samuel Langhorne Clemens, who used the pen name Mark Twain. ``Tom Sawyer,'' written in 1876, is drawn from Twain's boyhood in Hannibal, Mo. ``Huckleberry Finn'' was published in England in 1884 and in the United States in 1885. Plano students first meet Tom in the seventh grade and read about Huck's adventures in the 11th grade. Among the high school students speaking in favor of the book was Joanne Savage. ``To remove the book from the taught reading in the curriculum would be a step in the wrong direction,'' she said. ``The book has the ability to provoke much thoughtful discussion about this problem (racism) instead of ignoring it and pretending that it is solved,'' Joanne said. After receiving complaints last year about ``Huckleberry Finn,'' the Plano Independent School District hired a University of North Texas assistant professor in English to give teachers lessons about how to present Huck with sensitivity. Perry doubted that is working. ``When someone assumes they can teach the word `nigger' in a way that is not offense, I have a problem. It can't be done,'' he said. ``The word has a searing effect that just goes to the soul of a black person.'' Perry said. ``By its very nature and design it is intended to be extremely offensive, take away your identity and destroy your soul.'' He suggested that a better step toward sensitizing students would be for the school district to recognize February as Black History Month and conduct appropriate programs.

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. Senator Takes State Senate Seat
DOC.TEXT: Gordon Humphrey left the U.S. Senate for a seat Wednesday in a state Senate that for the first time in years has a strong Democratic presence. ``Well, it's not what I quite had in mind,'' the Republican said. ``All these years I've been pretty much under a Democrat majority and I figured, `This is really going to be great. I'll go back, there's a big Republican margin, it'll be a piece of cake.' ``And here we are neck and neck.'' A deadlock on the state Senate presidency prompted Humphrey to make a quick move from Washington to Concord. He resigned early Tuesday from Congress and was sworn in Wednesday to his new post. After hours of wrangling Wednesday, the state Senate, with 13 Republicans and 11 Democrats, had yet to elect even a temporary presiding officer to oversee the election of a Senate president. With two Republicans voting with the Democrats and one Democrat voting with Republicans, senators deadlocked 12-12 on two votes. ``Actually, if I wasn't here, the other side would prevail, so it's a good thing I did it,'' Humphrey said of his decision to resign early. Humphrey, 49, honored a campaign promise this year by bypassing almost certain re-election and not seeking a third term. He said moving from the national limelight to relative obscurity in a 24-member chamber has its advantages. ``It has a much more manageable feel to it than Congress,'' he said. ``I think there's diversity here, but we're all from the state of New Hampshire and it's not like trying to rectify the interests of the entire country.'' His first day on the job went well, he said, adding: ``Nobody tripped me. Everyone's very nice.''

DOC.HEAD: Publisher And Cardinal At Odds Over Book Dealing with Catholicism
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal John O'Connor should have read a new book that traces the Roman Catholic Church's historical treatment of women and sexual morality before he criticized it in print, the publisher said Wednesday. O'Connor, spiritual leader of the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese, admitted he had not read ``Eunuchs for the Kingdom of Heaven.'' But he has read the book's dust jacket, which he attacked as ``Catholic-bashing.'' Thomas Cahill, director of religious publishing at Doubleday, said the book by German theologian Uta Ranke-Heinemann is ``a scholarly work that begs to be taken seriously.'' ``There is something almost comical about condemning a jacket rather than a book,'' Cahill said. ``If one wants to challenge it ... one should have read it and wrestled with its arguments.'' The cardinal's spokesman, Joe Zwilling, said Wednesday, ``I think Doubleday is trying to get publicity for themselves in trying to get The New York Times to write about this.'' The Times reported the dispute between the cardinal and the publishing house Wednesday. There is ``far too much tolerance of attacks on the Catholic Church,'' Zwilling said. The book, a bestseller in Germany and Italy, arrived last month in U.S. book stores. Ms. Ranke-Heinemann, a professor of the history of religion at Essen University in Germany, traces 2,000 years of the Roman Catholic Church's attitudes toward women and sexual morality and accuses the church of both degrading women and undermining members' sexuality. ``(Catholic moral theology) is a folly that invokes God and pretends to be religious,'' she wrote in the book. ``It has warped the consciences of many men and women. It has burdened them with hairsplitting nonsense and striven to train them as moral acrobats instead of making them more humane and kinder to their fellow human beings.'' After receiving a copy from Doubleday last month, the cardinal wrote about the dust jacket in a column entitled ``A Seed of Hatred'' in the weekly publication Catholic New York. O'Connor wrote that he was ``not suggesting censorship for a moment.'' He added: ``I am suggesting that it is time we stopped `buying' the line of purveyors of hatred and scandal and malice and libel and calumny. It's time we tell them we are sick of their perversions.'' In particular, O'Connor attacked use of the word ``proves'' instead of ``contends or alleges'' to describe what the author does in the book. Cahill said Peter Heinegg, who translated the book and wrote the dust jacket description, used the word ``proves ... as it is used in academic circles, that (the author) states her thesis and backs it up.'' Cahill, a Roman Catholic, said he was ``really offended'' that the cardinal had dismissed the book in such ``a cavalier manner.'' And he was ``doubly offended by his extremely misguided attempt to accuse Doubleday of being anti-Catholic.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Not Optimistic About Iraqi Withdrawal, Vows No Concessions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 9-11: ``Bush got,'' with speech interrupted, 12th graf edited for transition; INSERTS graf 16: ``Menem presented,'' with gifts
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday ``I am not optimistic'' that Saddam Hussein will withdraw without a fight from Kuwait and vowed that Iraq will not be offered any concessions to end the crisis peacefully ``I have no feeling whatsoever that Saddam Hussein is willing to do now that which he should have done five months ago, four months ago,'' Bush said. Bush's tough approach was echoed by Argentine President Carlos Menem of Argentina, the only Latin American leader to send frigates to the Persian Gulf to enforce the embargo against Iraq. ``We wholeheartedly condemn what Iraq has done, to invade and occupy a territory which does not belong to it,'' Menem said at a joint news conference with Bush. ``The only way is for Iraq to withdraw without any preconditions.'' Midway through a tour of South America, Bush met with Menem at Casa Rosada, the president's palace, within eyesight of the army headquarters seized by rebels in a short-lived military uprising Monday. Bush congratulated Menem for ending the rebellion quickly. ``The Argentine people proved again this week that they will not permit any group to return Argentina to the days of violence and dictatorship in a superb show of strength and commitment,'' Bush said. The president got a red-carpet welcome. A procession of presidential grenadiers on horseback led Bush's motorcade to the Hall of Congress for an address to lawmakers. ``Let those who would attack constitutional democracy understand: in Latin America the day of the dictator is over,'' Bssh declared to the congress. Bush got his greatest applause for his remark when a deputy, Luis Zamora of the Movement to Socialism, tried to interrupt for a speech of his own and was shouted down by his colleagues. ``If that is the price you have to pay for democracy, let's pay it,'' Bush said. ``I feel welcome here.'' Zamora took part in an anti-Bush demonstration of about 2,00 people later, telling reporters he did not want to be part of ``this farce.'' Bush also praised Menem for his tough free-market reforms to cure Argentina's inflation, estimated at upwards of 2,000 percent in 1990. ``We know of the painful, short-term sacrifices you are being called upon to make, in what your own president has called `surgery without anesthesia,''' Bush said. ``For this tremendous undertaking to succeed, it will not take miracles, it will take work.'' Bush was Menem's guest at an evening rodeo and a state dinner. In his toast, the president lauded Menem, saying ``You have helped re-establish Argentina's democratic tradition and I salute your bold reform of the economy.'' Bush also expressed appreciation for Menem's support in the Persian Gulf. ``Together, we will do what is right and good,'' the president said. Menem presented Bush and his daughter, Dorothy LeBlond, with two gift horses, piebald and sorrel mounts used to herd cattle, and, at the dinner, two knives of the kind used by Argentine gauchos - cowboys. The Persian Gulf crisis a half world away continued to loom large on Bush's tour, as well as in Washington. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told Congress the United States will strike ``suddenly, massively and decisively'' if military force is needed to force Iraq to withdraw. In Buenos Aires, Bush's mood turned solemn when he was approached during a diplomatic reception by the Iraqi ambassador to Argentina, Sahib-Hussain Tahir. As required by protocol, Bush quickly shook hands with the diplomat but wore a stern look on his face, in contrast to the warm smile he gave other ambassadors. Later, at the news conference Bush said there are no signs of a deal or any retreat by Saddam despite the U.S. threat of force. ``I'm not optimistic,'' Bush said. ``I see no evidence that Saddam Hussein is ready to comply fully without condition to the U.N. resolutions.'' Bush has authorized Baker to go to Baghdad for talks with Saddam and has invited Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to meet with him in Washington. Iraqi officials have accepted Bush's offer, and say the talks are an opening to negotiations, with give and take by both sides. Bush, however, said the talks would be confined within the limits of U.N. resolutions setting terms for peace in the Persian Gulf. ``That means no concession of territory,'' Bush said. He said Iraq also must release foreign hostages and respect the integrity of embassies. ``And that means the eventual security and stability in the gulf, although that's not specified in the (U.N.) resolution.'' Bush said there are frequent rumors about a deal to end the gulf crisis, but that every time an Iraqi official speaks publicly, he says they will not withdraw from Kuwait. Bush said there must be no attempt to find a face-saving retreat by Saddam. ``When naked aggression takes place, it's not a question of finding (saving) face for the aggressor,'' Bush said heatedly. ``When a country is literally raped and pillaged, should the world go out and try to find a way to save face for he who has raped and pillaged that country?'' Asked by an Argentine journalist how the United States would reward Argentina for sending ships to the gulf, Bush replied, ``I don't believe Argentina is sending frigates to the gulf to help the United States... They believe as we do, that we must stand up against this brutal aggression.'' Menem agreed that Argentina sought nothing in return. ``That would be undignified. ... We don't want any help or aid ... and, in fact, were it offered, we would not accept it.'' On a separate matter, Bush said global trade talks underway in Brussels must tackle agriculture subsidies or the talks will fail. He promised that ``if that round fails, we will work bilaterally with the Argentines to see that their trade with us is not set back.'' The European Community's reluctance to curb protectionist measures for its farmers is jeopardizing the negotiations. Asked if the United States would enact retaliatory subsidies against Europe if the talks failed, Bush said, ``I'm not in the business of talking retaliation while people are still meeting and discussing this.''

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Gets Boost From Polls, U.S. Defense Secretary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new poll findings. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. defense secretary on Wednesday wished Lech Walesa ``victory and success'' in the presidential runoff, and two new polls indicated the Solidarity chairman was opening up a wide lead over his rival. A survey by the state-owned polling service CBOS found Walesa preferred by 58 percent in a sample of adults intending to vote in Sunday's runoff, compared to 23 percent for emigre businessman Stanislaw Tyminski. Nineteen percent were undecided. The survey was conducted between Sunday and Tuesday and had a 5 percent margin of error. It was released Wednesday night by the PAP news agency. The number of people polled was not immediately available. The private Demoskop polling agency had Walesa with a 3-1 edge over the dark-horse challenger in a survey also published Wednesday. Tyminski traveled through the southwestern Silesia region looking for votes among coal miners worried about unemployment. Earlier, his campaign labeled as ``slanders and lies'' a Tuesday night telecast in which a Canadian couple accused Tyminski of abusing his wife and denying food and medicine to his children in recent years. And in an interview published Wednesday in the pro-government newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza, Tyminski said outgoing Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki was ``a Stalinist'' whose governent ``chose a totalitarian road.'' Tyminski also said questions about his past and his qualifications raised by the press were ``rubbish.'' ``The press has discredited itself of its own accord,'' he said. ``They were all working for the government.'' U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, wrapping up a two-day visit to Poland, met for 40 minutes with Walesa at Solidarity headquarters in Gdansk. ``I have certain political experience and I feel that I have talked today with the man who will win,'' said the former Republican congressman. ``I wish you victory and success in this difficult task.'' The remarks in front of reporters appeared to be a calculated attempt to rally voters for Walesa and against Tyminski - who had implied to coal miners on Tuesday night that he had the confidence of U.S. authorities. Tyminski told a rally in the Silesian city of Jastrzebie he was invited to meet with Cheney but preferred to be with them. A U.S. source, however, said Tyminski was only on the guest list for an embassy reception for Cheney and no private meeting was ever contemplated. Tyminski, leader of the fringe Libertarian Party of Canada and an advocate of nuclear weapons for Poland, has sought to portray himself as a business magnate with contacts with government officials worldwide. He traveled to Walbrzych, one of Poland's most-polluted cities near the German and Czechoslovak border, where five unprofitable mines were recently slated for liquidation by the government and addressed a rally of at least 3,000 cheering supporters at an arena. The Demoskop poll indicated a Walesa lead of 61 percent to 20 percent over Tyminski, with 19 percent undecided. The survey, commissioned by the government-owned daily Rzeczpospolita, questioned 988 people nationwide Tuesday. The error margin was 3 percent. A poll by state TV, taken a week earlier, had Walesa leading 58 percent to 30 percent. Tyminski said Tuesday his own surveys indicated he was trailing Walesa 44 percent to 50 percent, with his support growing by 1.5 percent daily. The accusations that Tyminski had abused his wife were made by a woman identified as Clara Fox and her husband in a taped interview on Polish TV Tuesday. The couple presented home photographs of themselves with the Tyminskis in Toronto. Mrs. Fox said she had been Graciela Tyminski's confidante and that Mrs. Tyminski told her of alleged abuse by her husband. Fox said he had urged her to seek police aid, and that a child-protection agency had become involved once. ``The information has nothing in common with the truth,'' said Tyminski campaign spokeswoman Agnieska Majewska. ``We don't know where they got the information from.'' Tyminski acknowledged knowing the Foxes but only slightly. ``Mr. Fox visited us two times and I threw him out because he acted in an uncultured way. He behaved in a very un-Catholic way. He insulted my wife and was thrown out.''

DOC.HEAD: Stranded Whale Kept Alive in Wetsuit
DOC.TEXT: A pygmy sperm whale discovered stranded on a beach in the Florida Keys is warm and alive inside a specially created wetsuit made of the same material worn by scuba divers. Fathom, named for the Orlando wetsuit manufacturer which created and donated its yellow neoprene apparel, was discovered Nov. 26 on Lignumvitae Key and moved to a holding tank at a hotel. Beaching dehydrated the whale's seven-foot, 350-pound body, causing liver and kidney damage. In its weakened condition, the whale stopped eating and began to lose weight, burning up the protective blubbery sheath that keeps it warm. ``Statistically speaking, Fathom isn't doing very good at all,'' said Lynne Calero, medical director at the Dolphin Research Center. ``No stranded whale of her species has survived for more than four months in captivity. ``But the one thing that gives me real hope is that she is alert, in tune with her surroundings and navigating her tank very well,'' she said. ``And she is accepting the wetsuit nicely.'' The whale was transported to a holding tank at a Marathon motel, where it will remain quarantined for more than a month before joining other sea mammals at the nearby research center. Staff from the center, a member of the nationwide Marine Mammal Stranding Network, have kept a 24-hour vigil over the whale, hand-feeding it up to 20 pounds of squid a day. To keep it from becoming dehydrated again, they pump three liters of water into its stomach daily. But the most ingenious way developed to deal with the whale's ills has been the whale wetsuit, designed to maintain the body temperature of the warm-blooded sea creature. The device wraps the whale from six inches below its blow hole to just above its excretory organs. If the whale survives and has not suffered any permanent, disabling physical injury, it will be released back into the wild, Calero said.

DOC.HEAD: Generator Aboard Northwest Jet Catches Fire, No One Injured
DOC.TEXT: An auxiliary generator ignited Wednesday on a Northwest Airlines 727 as it landed at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. The fire was extinguished and no injuries were reported. Flight 582 from Seattle was carrying 69 passengers and six crew members. ``Passengers deplaned through the usual jetway and also down the aft stairs to the tarmac,'' Northwest spokeswoman Christy Clapp said. ``It was an evacuation, but there was no emergency. The fire already was out. They just wanted to get everyone out as quickly as possible,'' she said. Clapp said the fire was spotted on an auxiliary power unit on the right wing. A ground agent put out the fire at the gate, and firefighters doused the plane with chemical foam to prevent another flareup. Northwest was investigating. Monday, two Northwest flights getting ready for takeoff collided on a runway at the airport, killing eight people.

DOC.HEAD: 16 People Killed in Avalanches, Mud Slides
DOC.TEXT: Avalanches and mud slides caused by torrential rains killed at least 16 people Wednesday, the Colombian Red Cross said. In Villavicencio, a small town 55 miles south of Bogota, seven people were killed and nine injured when an avalanche buried several homes, the Red Cross said. In Arcabuco, 60 miles east of Bogota, four members of a family were killed in an avalanche early Wednesday, the report said. A few miles north of Bogota, five people were killed when a small river overflowed and swept local houses away.

DOC.HEAD: State Supreme Court Upholds Klan Anti-Mask Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 20th graf, `For example ...' to UPDATE with comments from attorney general.
DOC.TEXT: The Georgia Supreme Court upheld a law Wednesday that makes it a misdemeanor for Ku Klux Klan members to wear masks in public, ruling the statute does not violate their free speech rights. In a 6-1 ruling, the court said the 1951 law is a legitimate expression of the state's ``compelling interest'' in preventing violence and intimidation. The decision reversed the ruling of a Gwinnett County judge, who dismissed misdemeanor charges against Klan member Shade Miller Jr., after Miller was charged with wearing a mask in public. Miller, attacking the statute as unconstitutional, contended that wearing a mask is symbolic speech protected under the First Amendment. He also contended the law was vague and improperly broad. The lower court agreed, but the Supreme Court rejected his argument. Public disguise is a particularly effective means of committing crimes of violence and intimidation, the court said in an opinion signed by Chief Justice Harold G. Clarke. ``A nameless, faceless figure strikes terror in the human heart,'' Clarke wrote. ``But remove the mask, and the nightmarish form is reduced to its true dimensions. The face betrays not only the identity, but also human frailty.'' The opinion said passage of the anti-mask law was preceded by a period of harassment, intimidation and violence against racial and religious minorities, carried out by mask-wearing Klansmen and other hate organizations. `These groups operated as vigilantes and were responsible for numerous beatings and lynchings,'' Clarke said. ``Because of the masks, victims of Klan violence were unable to assist law enforcement officers in identifying their oppressors. ``They were afraid, perhaps, even to report such incidents in case law enforcement officers might have been involved.'' The lone dissent, on First Amendment grounds, came from Justice George T. Smith. He found the anti-mask law unconstitutional because it is ``a content-based restriction on political speech directed to a dissident group in a public forum, and is not narrowly tailored to serve a compelling state interest.'' The law does not restrict Miller from appearing in public wearing his robe and proclaiming his message, but does prevent him from concealing his identity. The statute makes it a misdemeanor to wear in public - or on private property except with written permission - a mask or device which hides the person's identity. The law exempts the wearing of masks in traditional holiday costumes, safety devices, gas masks in emergencies or drills and in theatrical productions. Michael Hauptman, who represented Miller, claimed a partial victory in the court's declaration that the statute applies ``only to mask-wearing conduct when the mask-wearer knows or reasonably should know that the conduct provokes a reasonable apprehension of intimidation, threats or violence.'' Hauptman said that may have left the door open for Klan members to parade and demonstrate while masked. But the court indicated that any such activity would have to be undertaken in a clearly non-threatening way in order to be deemed legal, adding: ``Persons of common intelligence may readily appreciate mask-wearing conduct that provokes a reasonable apprehension of intimidation ... in a given context. ``For example, a person wearing a ski-mask in mid-winter would not ordinarily warrant alarm, but a person wearing a ski-mask on a warm day while entering a bank certainly would.'' Attorney General Michael Bowers disputed Hauptman's assertion that the ruling may leave room for masked demonstrations or parades. ``If his client wears a mask, it'll make my day,'' said Bowers, who added that the ruling ``may be the biggest decision of the Georgia Supreme Court in 10 years in terms of beneficial impact on the people of this state. ... I'm proud of the court.'' The Rev. C.T. Vivian, chairman of the board of directors of the Atlanta-based Center for Democratic Renewal, a civil rights agency, praised the court for its decision: ``By their actions today, the Supreme Court has helped ensure that Georgians will be free of the threat of anonymous terrorism and violence by the bigotry of the Ku Klux Klan.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Complains About Sanctions, But Won't Seek U.N. Aid
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said Wednesday that it would not seek U.N. humanitarian aid, although it claims food and medicine shortages arising from U.N. economic sanctions have killed 1,400 children. Iraq says the sanctions are illegal and refuses to recognize the legitimacy of the U.N. sanctions committee that could approve such humanitarian aid. Iraq charged earlier this week that 1,416 children under age 5 have died because of shortages. The Baghdad government is the sole importer of medicine Iraq and its only official source of supply. A diplomat on the U.N. sanctions committee, which oversees the embargo imposed on Iraq for its conquest of Kuwait, said Wednesday that Baghdad has filed no formal requests for food and medicine with the world body. ``Iraq has not approached the committee in any way. We've heard and read statements that they've publicized, but they've not approached the committee directly,'' said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Medicine, and food in dire circumstances, are exempted from the global economic embargo against Iraq and occupied Kuwait. But an Iraqi U.N. diplomat, speaking Wednesday on condition of anonymity, said his embassy will not approach the sanctions committee because it does not recognize the legality of Security Council Resolution 661 imposing the embargo and setting up the committee. Iraq has repudiated all 12 Security Council resolutions condemning its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The sanctions committee is the monitor of U.N. member compliance with the economic embargo on Iraq and occupied Kuwait and handles requests for exemptions on banned trade. There was no way to independently confirm how many, if any, Iraqi children have died because of shortages. But Western diplomats generally discount reports of acute food and medicine shortages, saying Iraq in recent weeks received more than 30 tons of medical supplies alone in exchange for the release of foreign hostages. The diplomats contend that Iraq, in an effort to break the embargo, has sought to portray the sanctions as inhumane.

DOC.HEAD: City Puts Together New Crime Package
DOC.TEXT: The mayor and City Council reached agreement Wednesday on a revised crime-fighting package that would be paid for in part by a new lottery game just for the city and tax increases. The six-year, $1.8 billion ``Safe Streets, Safe City'' program called for additional police patrols and funding for education and the criminal justice system. ``We have had enough of crime, enough of bloodshed, enough of the suffering and the tears which flow in the wake of criminal activity,'' said Mayor David Dinkins at a news conference with City Council Speaker Peter Vallone and other city officials. Dinkins had been arguing with Vallone over how many new police the city needs and how to pay for them. State Assembly and Senate leaders, who would have to approve most new city taxes, told both men not to bother coming to Albany unless they could agree on a joint approach. The mayor said the plan would be forwarded immediately to Albany for consideration by the state Legislature, which is currently in a special session. ``The ball is now in their court,'' Dinkins said. Vallone called the package a ``doable plan'' and vowed that efforts to fight crime would no longer be used as a political football. The compromise plan calls for the hiring of 3,462 new police officers - 644 less than proposed by the mayor in his original four-year plan announced in October. Dinkins said the new plan would add 9,744 officers on patrol duty by 1994 through the hiring of new officers, the elimination of some specialized units and the addition of civilians for administrative positions. The City Council leadership offered Friday what it called its last compromise, a six-year, $450 million plan calling for 8,856 extra officers for enforcement duty. Dinkins' four-year plan called for 9,603 officers on patrol. Part of Dinkins package calls for improving the school system by means such as better security and enhanced delinquent programs and job opportunities. Tuesday's proposal also provided additional money for district attorneys, legal aid lawyers, the correction system and drug treatment and several after-school programs. ``If we had had the money in the bank, you can be sure that today's agreement would have allowed for a program broader in scope and more rapid in implementation,'' the mayor said. ``The reduction in scale reflects the economic facts of life.'' The announcement of the new crime package came at a time when the city is attempting to bridge a budget shortfall through cutbacks in other city agencies. Dinkins said funding for the proposed plan would come from three sources: an increase in the property tax rate; an extension of the city's surcharge on personal income tax beyond its current expiration in 1992; and a new lottery game just for the city. Herb Berman, who chairs the council's finance committee, said the effect of the property tax increase would be ``negligible.'' Berman said in the first year, the average homeowner would pay about $10 more, with that figure growing to about $25 in the ensuing years. Officials had no details about the new lottery game except that it would be available only in the city and would yield from $50 million to $120 million each year.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to fix overline.
Liz Taylor Ignores Former Lover in Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with Miss Taylor ignoring Wynberg in court. Pick up 3rd graf, `Lawyers for ...'
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Taylor ignored her ex-boyfriend in court Wednesday as their lawyers began selecting a jury to decide a multimillion-dollar dispute over the rights to her ``Passion'' perfume. Miss Taylor walked across the courtroom surrounded by her lawyers and made no acknowledgement of former beau Henry Wynberg, seated at the opposite end of a table. A panel of 50 prospective jurors sat with their eyes riveted on the actress, dressed in purple, as the judge explained what the trial was all about. Miss Taylor won permission earlier in the day to tell jurors about Wynberg's criminal record after her lawyers said it would explain her decision to keep him out of her perfume business. Lawyers for Henry Wynberg sought to prevent jurors from hearing that Wynberg - who courted Miss Taylor between her two marriages to Richard Burton - once pleaded guilty to statutory rape, providing drugs to underage high school girls in return for sex and taking pornographic photos of young girls. They called the evidence ``irrelevant, inflammatory and prejudicial.'' But Miss Taylor's lawyers argued that those issues were crucial to proving that she was justified in breaking off her business relationship with Wynberg ``because any reputable cosmetics company would refuse to deal with Wynberg.'' Superior Court Judge Coleman Swart declined to bar the evidence. Wynberg claims he conceived the actress' line of ``Passion'' perfume, and he's seeking a hefty share of the profits. He says he created the fragrance under the Elizabeth Taylor Cosmetics Inc. banner. At stake: about $70 million a year in profits. Litigation has produced volumes of depositions and affidavits about Wynberg's claim that he had a contract with Miss Taylor for exclusive rights to her name and likeness for promotion and sale of cosmetics. Wynberg sued in 1986 for 72 percent of ``Passion'' profits. Court documents show Wynberg's two-year romance with the violet-eyed actress ended in August 1975, when Miss Taylor said, ``I'm going back to Richard, Henry. I'll see you later.'' Burton and Miss Taylor remarried in Africa, and Wynberg returned to California. Court records show that a short time later, Miss Taylor and Wynberg signed the cosmetics agreement in Switzerland, with Burton as a witness. Wynberg said he spent years consulting with chemists and manufacturers, smelling perfumes and looking for the perfect bottle. ``I wanted sparkling little lights like stars in there, and I wanted it to look like money, feel like money,'' Wynberg said. According to Wynberg, Hen he presented the actress with the heart-shaped bottle and fragrance in November 1983, Miss Taylor said: ``Let's let bygones be bygones, Henry. Let's split 50-50 on the perfume deal.'' In a deposition, Miss Taylor denies Wynberg's assertion. ``I didn't want to do any business with him,'' she said. Miss Taylor contends that Wynberg's failure to follow through on the project violated the contract and made it invalid. In 1986 she signed with the Chesebrough-Ponds Inc. cosmetics company to market ``Passion'' using her name and likeness. It went on to be a big seller.

DOC.HEAD: Karpov Beats Kasparov in Game 17
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD details of game, Karpov quotes, no pickup. ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: Anatoly Karpov pulled even in the world chess championship with a victory Wednesday after reigning champion Garry Kasparov resigned on the 40th move of Game 17. ``I feel very confident now,'' Karpov said. ``It was quite clear that he was not in good shape.'' The two Soviet grandmasters are now tied 8.5 points each with the next game scheduled for Saturday. Kasparov had gone one point ahead Tuesday when he won the marathon 16th game after 102 moves played over four days. But Karpov, with the white pieces on Wednesday, evened the match. The first player to gain 12.5 points wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. In the event of a tie, Kasparov retains the title. The first 12 games were played in New York. After forcing Kasparov's resignation Wednesday, Karpov said, ``It was a very complicated game, but I felt I always had the advantage.'' The game began with a familiar scenario. As the two previous games in Lyon with Karpov playing white, the opening was a Grunfeld with an exchange variation as Kasparov castled on the eighth move. But Karpov moved his knight into deeper territory on the 10th move. That caused Kasparov almost 30 minutes of reflection before countering with a pawn exchange, then bringing a knight forward. Each player is allowed 2{ hours for his first 40 moves. Karpov wasted his time advantage on the 25th move when he had to decide how to capture a black knight. He finally did so with a bishop. Now both players had less than 30 minutes for 15 moves. But the game turned in Karpov's favor when he advanced a queen and established a rook deep in black territory. Kasparov tried to get out of trouble, but Karpov kept advancing. Karpov even moved a pawn to the seventh rank, blocking the black queen and attacking a rook. Kasparov gave up two moves later.

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. Treasury Secretary Meets Saddam
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein conferred Wednesday with former U.S. Treasury Secretary John Connally, who is hoping to negotiate the release of employees of a Texas oil company. Connally, a member of the board of Coastal Corp., was accompanied by Oscar Wyatt, head of the Houston-based oil and gas company, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said those attending the meeting also included the speaker of the National Assembly, Sadi Mehdi Saleh. The agency gave no details of the talks. But the presence of Saleh indicated hostages were discussed. Previous deals that led to the release of foreigners were cleared first by the National Assembly, or Parliament. Diplomats in Baghdad reported Tuesday that Connally was in Iraq to negotiate on behalf of some Western hostages linked to Coastal Corp. But they did not know how many people are involved.
