DOC.TEXT: The highest judicial body of the United Methodist Church has ruled it is up to the church's governing general conference to decide if a new worship book can substitute the phrase ``Creator, Redeemer and Sustainer'' for ``Father, Son and Holy Spirit.'' The ruling on that and other language alterations by the church's Judicial Council came after the previous 1988 general conference adopted five different, partly inconsistent resolutions about language dealing with the deity. Four of the resolutions supported traditional terminology, and the fifth rejected ``all efforts to legislate specific addresses to God'' in worship and liturgy. The church's Board of Discipleship, which is developing a new worship book, asked the high court to resolve the apparent conflict. The general conference of the 9 million-member denomination meets next in 1992 in Louisville, Ky. --- CHICAGO (AP) - A personnel committee of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America reports that a larger percentage of men than women on its staff have salaries in the higher ranges. While the number of white males making more than $40,000 a year is larger than for women, the percentage of black and Hispanic executives who make more than $40,000 is larger than for either white males or females, the committee says. --- WAYNE, Pa. (AP) - The Catholic News Service has introduced a non-denominational telephone service for reviewing movies. Named the Preview Line, callers to 1-900-773-8439 receive reviews of currently showing movies at a cost of $1.50 for the first minute and 75 cents for each extra minute. Thomas N. Lorsung, director of the news service, said the service was developed in response to parental concerns about values being expressed in motion pictures. --- HILLSDALE, N.J. (AP) - Planners say millions of people are expected to participate in four days of prayer for human rights, beginning Friday in Melbourne, Australia, and circling the globe for three successive days. The observance, promoted by the Freedom, Justice and Peace Society based here and endorsed by leaders of various world religions, culminates the evening of Monday with a gathering of United Nations leaders at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. --- DALLAS (AP) - The pastor of the Wilshire Baptist Church, whose congregation is carrying out environmental-protection measures, says it decided it didn't want such efforts ``to be co-opted by the secular or religious left.'' The Rev. George Mason added, ``Our church is doing what it is doing not because we worship Mother Nature but because we are stewards of God's creation.'' --- RIFTON, N.Y. (AP) - The Hutterian Brethren, a small, communally sharing branch of Christians, urges that all troops be withdrawn from ``explosive confrontation'' in the Middle East. In an appeal sent to national and United Nations leaders, the church said: ``We plead with you, our beloved leaders, to consider the incalculable suffering and loss of life which would result from an armed conflict.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Traditional customs and ceremonies are being revived in Reform Judaism that had once largely abandoned them, a survey found. A commission for the Union of American Hebrew Congregations and its rabbinical organization, the Central Conference of American Rabbis, reported these findings: - Yarmulkes (skullcaps) are provided at 59 percent of the congregations. - Nearly all the reporting congregations kindle the Sabbath candles before Friday evening services. - Blessings are recited before and after reading from the Torah (Biblical books) at Sabbath morning services at 87 percent of the congregations, and more than half report marching with the Torah held aloft. - Like Orthodox and Conservative congregations, two days of Rosh Hashana are observed by 35 percent of the Reform congregations. Rabbi Sanford Seltzer, director of the survey commission, said the trend ``is not a return to Orthodoxy, but rather the expressions of a post-Holocaust generation of Reform Jews seeking new dimensions of spirituality.''

DOC.HEAD: Edna Lewis: Doyenne of High Home Cooking
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Chef Edna Lewis has gained a national reputation simply for cooking the way everybody used to - by tinkering and tasting - before cooking became opening cans, adding water to mixes and tearing open microwave packaging. Sure, chefs everywhere now insist on the freshest local ingredients and many specialize in regional cuisine, but while these culinary academy-trained cooks race from fad to fad (remember baby vegetables? remember quiche?), Lewis has spent most of her 74 years steadily building a repertoire of Southern dishes best described as high home cooking. Readers of Lewis' three cookbooks, ``The Edna Lewis Cookbook,'' ``The Taste of Country Cooking,'' and ``In Pursuit of Flavor,'' know her devotion to seeking out the old varieties of fruits and vegetables, cooking by the seasons and keeping preparations simple. Lewis invoked these themes again and again in a recent interview that began at a farmers' market in Manhattan's Union Square, where she often buys produce for Gage & Tollner, the landmark Brooklyn restaurant where she has worked since 1988. Lewis grew up in Freetown, Va., a small community settled by freed slaves. ``I grew up on the farm. ... Everyone was self-sufficient,'' she said in her slow and soft manner of speaking. ``Each family had a garden. In the spring you planted corn and in the fall you gathered in the crop and during the winter you shelled your corn and took it to the mill and they ground it up and you took it home the same day. ``So when we were shelling the corn, we knew it was going to be made into our cornmeal. When we brought it home from the mill, we would taste it, to see what this corn tasted like that we grew and shucked and shelled ourselves. ... Sometimes we couldn't take it to the water mill and had to take it to the mill that ran by motor, and we would taste it afterwards and say, `Oh, it tastes of the motor.' So we were all involved not so much in the cooking but in the taste of things.'' Such intimate contact with food has given Lewis an exquisitely sensitive palate. She can tell the difference between a chicken stock that has boiled and one that has barely simmered; she can taste a quickbrea and tell if double-acting baking powder was used. The word ``taste'' pops up everywhere in her speech and in her cookbooks. Standing next to a tomato vendor in the market, for example, she explains why she doesn't switch from fresh to canned tomatoes when summer's over, as many cooks do: ``I can taste the can.'' Lewis, who is entirely self-taught as a chef, came to New York before World War II and fell in with a group of friends who took turns cooking for the others. As she tells it, one of them, John Nicholson, said, ``Edna, one day I'm going to open a restaurant and you're going to cook for it.'' He did, and Lewis became chef at Cafe Nicholson in the late '40s. The restaurant attracted Tennessee Williams, Truman Capote and others hankering for real Southern cooking. She later worked at restaurants in North and South Carolina and ran a pheasant farm in New Jersey before returning to New York to cater and do other restaurant work. Her second cookbook, ``The Taste of Country Cooking,'' published in 1976, established her as an authority on the subject. In 1988, restaurateur Peter Aschkenasy bought Gage & Tollner, a fading dowager of a restaurant, renovated it, and brought in Lewis to revitalize the menu. She introduced country ham, pan-fried quail, corn pudding and spareribs at the 111-year-old seafood and chop house, and the crowds started returning. Alice Waters, of Chez Panisse restaurant in Berkeley, Calif., called Lewis ``ageless and tireless'' in her pursuit of the pure flavors from her past - watercress as peppery as the wild cress she used to pick by streams, country ham as mellow as the hams that came from her brother's hogs, buttermilk that hasn't lost its richness from processing. ``I don't think all chefs have her ability, her desire to taste and taste and taste again, to recognize that these peaches don't taste as good as last year's because they were picked too soon, this constant evaluation of everything as it comes,'' Waters said. Lewis is a tall, regal woman who favors African print dresses and tends to answer questions with circuitous stories. She was interrupted at least a half-dozen times by well-wishers who recognized her. ``We're two transplanted Virginians who love your books,'' said one man, accompanied by his wife. ``I just want to tell you we were in Smithfield recently and they told us they don't feed peanuts to the hogs anymore.'' She told the man she would be traveling soon to Smithfield, Va., famous for its country ham. ``I want to talk to Gwaltney (Co.). I think they have the best ham, but they're not as good as they used to be.'' After the interview moved to a McDonald's - the only restaurant in the area found to be open at the early hour - Lewis said she is working on a new cookbook on traditional Southern cooking. People still eat that way at home, she said, but it's increasingly difficult to find that style of cooking in restaurants. ``I guess people want to taste outside cooking - Japanese, Italian, whatever,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: A Depressed Logging Town Rallies Around America's Christmas Tree
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note Wednesday time element
With LaserPhoto
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: When the switch is thrown Wednesday on the Capitol Christmas tree, it won't be just another lighting to the folks of Walden, Colo. For four years, Walden has planned so that one of its trees would be the centerpiece of the holiday season, America's Christmas Tree. ---

Through 28 presidents and half the country's history, it survived. Sprouting from a single seed, it grew as the nation did, from a few scented needles to a 74-foot sentry of the forest. When they cut it down just before Thanksgiving, the evergreen revealed a magnificent trunk girdled by 136 rings. And now, because a handful of people in a depressed logging town believed they could do it, this noble Englemann spruce has emerged from deep woods near Walden, Colo., to make its way, by truck and train, to the front lawn of the U.S. Capitol. America's Christmas tree is ready to light up the season Wednesday. This year's Capitol tree found its way from the Colorado-Wyoming border to the country's front yard because Pat Bunge, proprietress of Pat's Hair Hut, and retired school teacher Mary Rupp, and U.S. Forest Service specialist Carolyn Krupp, and Chris Christofferson, owner of the North Park Cleaners and Laundry, and other civic bosters had an idea four years ago. They wanted to do something special to celebrate Walden's centennial in 1990. Many in the town of 800 people looked around, and what they saw were trees - millions of them. Trees carpeted hillsides, made the air smell good, built their houses, fed their fireplaces and wood stoves through long, frigid winters, and most importantly, kept their faltering economy alive. Like most other Americans, the folks of Walden had watched Christmas tree lighting ceremonies on television. They were confused between the White House Christmas tree and the Capitol tree. So they investigated, and learned that the White House version is a living tree that is redecorated every year. The Capitol tree, however, is always a freshly cut evergreen from a national forest and no public funds ever are used to transport or decorate it, truly making it a ``people's tree.'' So in the late winter of 1987, a few folks in Walden decided they wanted the 1.1 million-acre Routt National Forest that encircles the town to donate the Capitol tree in 1990. Christofferson, then a town councilman, recalled that nobody had thought about celebrating the centennial before a local forest service official noted the 100th anniversary was fast approaching. ``But we got right on it, and sent a letter back to Washington to the head of the forest service, petitioning for the honor,'' said Christofferson. ``We were competing with four other communities, and with the help of our congressional delegation, we got picked. ... Then we went to work.'' Walden's Capitol Christmas Tree Committee met monthly. It commissioned a logo, mailed fliers to every school district in the state soliciting waterproof, fireproof decorations for the tree. The committee brainstormed ways to raise more money in a town that long had been used to making do instead of making new. Its members were a cross section of the community - teachers, businessmen, state officials, foresters, a retired postman, even the school superintendent. It was grassroots, and it was effective. Volunteers eventually raised nearly $10,000. Corporate sponsors were solicited. Union Pacific Railroad agreed to transport the tree to Washington; Louisiana Pacific donated trucks and cranes to get the tree from the forest to the train, and then move it from a rail siding in Washington to the Capitol. Anheuser-Busch even pledged its famous Clydesdales to lead the town's Christmas parade and give the tree a grand send-off. Boosters designed and sold souvenir mugs, hats and T-shirts to pay for cutting and wrapping the tree. More than 100 people, including at least 35 kids, signed up to go to Washington for the ceremony. Bake sales and car washes helped finance their expenses. Before you could say ``Tannenbaum,'' the whole community was united in Christmas tree mania. But despite all the hubbub, Waldenites hung on to the original goal: find their best tree and give it to the country. Parents took their youngsters for weekend walks, scouring the back country for pretty trees. The committee offered a $50 prize. Snowmobilers ventured far back in the wilderness in winter, hoping heavy snow would help them find that one perfect evergreen. Foresters kept a confidential list of candidates and, by last July, nine trees were deemed suitable to show Paul Pinkus, landscape architect of the Capitol, when he arrived in Walden. ``It took us two days to look at all of them because they were spread out all over the county, but he finally picked the next-to-last tree he saw,'' Christofferson said. Pinkus supervises 84 employees who manicure the Capitol grounds, and he knows a good, sturdy Christmas treewhen he sees it. America's Christmas tree must have ``good color, be very full and yet compact, and be at least 50 feet tall and 25 feet in diameter,'' said Pinkus, 63, who has chosen the tree for 27 years. A week before the tree-cutting ceremony kicked off Walden's own Christmas season, the National Association of Counties delivered a morale blow by calling the town one of the 10 most ``endangered communities'' in the West. But that was old news to Walden citizens, who've been going through tough times so long even old-timers can't remember the boom years. They weren't about to let the obvious ruin their party. So, on Nov. 11, a crowd of 500 bundled-up well-wishers applauded with their mittens, sang carols and cheered on 75-year-old tree-cutting expert Casimier Wojakowski of Bark River, Mich., as he choreographed the felling of the chosen tree. With hand signals to loggers and intuitive skill, Wojakowski supervised the ceremony. In just a few minutes a 4-ton behemoth was gently lowered to the snow-sprinkled ground. Christofferson will be in Washington when House Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash., throws the switch and sets Walden's tree aglow. Some 4,000 lights, clear, amber and blue, and 6,000 handmade ornaments from Colorado schoolchildren will set the tree a-twinkling. And Walden will realize its dream. ``It's the biggest thing that's ever happened to us,'' Christofferson said. ``We've really put Walden on the map.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Tad Bartimus is the AP's Mountain States regional reporter, based in Denver.

DOC.HEAD: Revolution Can't Change Geography and Economics
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Europe generally turned its back on the Soviet Union after the region's Communist rulers bowed to popular revolt a year ago, but trade and geography make the huge neighbor impossible to ignore. New governments must balance the lingering emotion of revolution with economic and political reality. They rejoice over the departure of Soviet soldiers and the Warsaw Pact's impending demise, but warily watch the floundering giant that supplies most of their oil and much of the electricity, natural gas and timber, and buys their mediocre consumer goods. Some East Europeans wonder whether they are trading one form of domination for another. ``It is well known that Hungary's energy supplies are largely based on Soviet raw materials,'' Laszlo Lengyel, an economist and political scientist, wrote in the Hungarian labor daily Nepszava. ``There is no need for tanks to maintain their influence in the region.'' Anger and distrust toward the Soviet Union are evident among ordinary people throughout the region. In Bulgaria, once the Kremlin's closest ally in the Soviet bloc, only 30 percent of those polled favored close ties with Moscow and 75 percent were against celebrating Nov. 7, the Soviet Union's Revolution Day. In countries where the study of Russian was required for generations, hardly anyone seems to understand it. People are learning English and German instead. Statues of Lenin have come down and places named for Soviet heroes and their local cohorts have been rechristened. Andras Hegedues of Hungary, the only living signer of the Warsaw Pact, feels Eastern Europeans always must keep their powerful neighbor in mind. Even if the Soviet Union disintegrates, Russia, its largest republic, ``will remain a military power,'' he said. Richard Sumann, director of Czechoslovakia's Foreign Investment Agency, said: ``We must prepare for a situation where the Soviet republics are independent, or more independent.'' Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Romania border the Soviet Union. Bulgaria is tied to the eastern Slavs by language and custom. The Soviet Union says the close ties of four decades were forged by more than Soviet military might. ``Eastern Europe is Eastern Europe, and it will exist as Eastern Europe forever,'' said Oleg A. Grinevsky, the Soviet delegate to talks on reducing conventional weapons in Europe. ``We have historic, economic, and political ties, and it is impossible to exclude them from everyday life.'' In addition to most of its oil, Hungary gets about one-third of its electricity from the Soviet Union. Other Eastern European countries are equally dependent on the Soviets, with little opportunity to change. Cheap and reliable energy supplies are disappearing along with Soviet political domination. Beginning in 1991, the Soviets will demand the market price in dollars for oil delivered to East European countries instead of the much lower prices by complex agreements within the Comecon economic alliance. Several former Soviet bloc nations sought oil supplies from Iraq, then the Persian Gulf crisis tightened supplies and drove prices up. Eastern European countries have pledged to obey the U.N. sanctions on Iraq. Soviet oil supplies to Czechoslovakia this year will be at least 18 million barrels short of the 116 million promised. Poland is expected to get only 70 million barrels, nearly 20 million less than expected. Hungary and Romania have reeived less electricity from the Soviet Union than anticipated. The Soviet economy is in such chaos that Moscow could not even promise supplies of chemicals, coal, timber, cellulose, paper products and consumer goods, said Laszlo Timar, who oversees Hungary's trade with the Soviet Union. ``Their problems and troubles are very big, and we cannot rely on these problems being solved in a short period,'' Timar said. Germany is replacing the Soviet Union as Hungary's main trade partner, but the Soviets are not likely to fall below second or third, he said. That is a matter of geography. According to Timar, when Hungary and the others begin paying the world price for Soviet oil, the Soviets probably will prefer them as customers because pipelines exist to deliver it. When Hungary imposed stiff gasoline price increases in October, taxi drivers and truckers blocked roads for a weekend, virtually shutting down the country. The government struck a deal with the protesters after threatening police or military action. Hegedues, who was premier of Hungary at the time of the 1956 uprising against Stalinism, said he felt ``civil war was in the air'' during the price protests. Gasoline price increases in Czechoslovakia set off two rounds of hoarding this year. Czechoslovak officials used looser rules within the Soviet Union to augment their oil supply. They cut through the Moscow bureaucracy to swap trucks, buses, bulldozers, cranes and consumer goods for 3.5 million barrels of oil from the Tyumen region of Siberia. Timar said Hungary was close to an agreement to trade its Ikarus buses for oil. The Soviet Union is a huge, hungry market for machinery, manufactured items and consumer goods produced in Eastern Europe. Beginning Jan. 1, that trade also will be conducted primarily in hard currency. Many of the products cannot be sold in the West, but East European countries need to earn convertible currency from them. Timar estimated Hungary will lose 20 to 40 percent of its Soviet business next year, including half of its machinery market, because Soviet customers will be freer to buy from the West. He predicted Hungary will remain a major supplier to the Soviet Union because ``our products are well known there. We think that slowly, slowly, our exports will be increased, but they will be tragically cut back for the time being.'' Even though Hungarians look west, business will draw them east, he said: ``There is more personal interest in the West now, but to make money they will travel to Moscow.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Peruvian Babies Available for Adoption
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Phillip Thomas Shaffer, 4 months old, wriggled in his new mother's arms, an appealing grin on his face. He is unaware of the human drama unfolding around him as his mother, Terry, battles court officials and the bureaucracy to adopt him. Foreigners, most of them from the United States, are coming to Peru in growing numbers to adopt infants, despite sometimes nightmarish problems. Light-skinned foreigners with Indian babies are a common sight in Lima. ``Couples wait for years in the United States,'' said an American lawyer who specializes in adoptions in Lima. ``Peru is faster.'' Abortions, family planning and a more organized welfare system in the United States turn adoptions into a five-year process. Most adoptions also involve older children. During an interview in the American lawyer's office, the telephone rang every few minutes with calls from new clients. Peru's appeal has soared since other countries, such as Colombia, made adoptions more difficult. Phillip is one of thousands of babies offered for adoption by poor, single Peruvian mothers who are unable to feed or educate them. This poverty-stricken Andean nation of 22 million, mired in its worst economic crisis, has discovered it has something many people in other countries want: babies. Cuanto, an economics magazine, observed tongue-in-cheek that Peru could pay its $20 billion foreign debt by selling 1.3 million babies for adoption abroad. Newspapers and television stations, noting the growing presence of foreign couples, have begun dedicating more space to baby trafficking scandals. They reported that an unmarried woman in Lima tried to sell her three children to an Italian couple for $10,000, but the father halted the deal. Another woman, who left her 6-month-old daughter with a friend for several weeks, said in a television interview the friend handed the baby over to a European couple. Foreign couples, who begin caring for the babies before they are awarded custody, frequently find themselves caught up in complicated legal proceedings. Critics attribute some lengthy adoption cases to court officials seeking bribes. The American lawyer, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the process is sometimes slowed by ``a sense of national shame that the country can't support its own children.'' Terry Shaffer, 30 and single, left her home in Ellicott City, Md., four months ago to adopt a child in Peru. Since then, she has lost her job as an epidemiologist and is being supported by her parents. Her adopted child, Phillip, is from Ayacucho, a remote mountainous region ravaged by a leftist insurgency. Ms. Shaffer had to face formidable paperwork before the adoption process even began: documents certifying her birth and mental and physical health; copies of her passport and tax returns; letters of reference and employment, even FBI assurance that she had no criminal record. All of it had be translated into Spanish and notarized. ``I gave in everything, but the case took so long we got bogged down, so the judge threw the case out and we started all over again,'' Ms. Shaffer said. Linda Carey of Laurel, Md., had an easier time. Ms. Carey, in her 40s and single, took two months to do the paperwork. She now has her 5-month-old daughter, Johanna Elizabeth, from a poor family in Peru's rural north. Before a child can be taken to the United States, consular officials in Peru examine the papers to make sure the adoption is legal. The American lawyer said a successful adoption in Peru depends on the right combination of judge, lawyer and biological mother. ``Well picked, they can make the adoption a happy, loving experience,'' he said. ``Badly chosen, they can make it the most emotionally distressing experience you've ever had in your life.'' He said lawyers' fees for adoption cases average $6,000-$9,000. ``A lot of that goes on wining and dining the judge and bringing the natural mother to Lima, all medical expenses paid,'' he said. Two years ago, American missionaries Ed and Pam Baumgartner, who have lived in Peru eight years, took in four battered children from a broken home in Pucallpa, a jungle town. When the children, of four different fathers, said they wanted to stay with the Americans, the Baumgartners applied for adoption. That was nine months ago. ``What delayed things is that we refused to bribe a single official,'' Mrs. Baumgartner said. ``Now the fathers are threatening to show up. I'm dreading that. They're going to want money.''

DOC.HEAD: Robert McC. Adams is cq in 4th graf
In a War, Ur Becomes a Target
DOC.TEXT: If war comes to Iraq, it also comes to what's below the surface there: the civilizations of Mesopotamia, the cities of Babylon and Ur, ancient places where humanity learned to write, to raise wheat and barley, domesticate animals and live in cities. But archaeologists are surprisingly sanguine about the safety of artifacts buried under the sands in Iraq's vast desert. Thousands of unexcavated sites and millions of clay tablets whose writings have yet to be interpreted will survive, even if Iraq and Kuwait turn into a battleground, these scientists say. ``Obviously, if war comes, there will be unexpected damage, but I don't think it will be calamitous with regard to archaeological sites'' except those near modern cities or other potential targets, said Robert McC. Adams, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution and an eminent archaeologist known for his years of research in Mesopotamia's ruins. Among the potential targets, however, is the city of Ur, built on the banks of the Euphrates at the dawn of history and said to be the birthplace of Abraham, the biblical patriarch. What sits atop of Ur now is a major Iraqi airfield, almost certain to be targeted in a war. And the fabled city of Babylon, dating back to 3000 B.C., is just north of modern Hilla, an industrial city. A stray bomb intended for Hilla could shatter Babylonian artifacts. Like most sites in Iraq, these two retain their secrets despite 150 years of research. Only a fraction of what is to be found has been uncovered, Adams said. ``We probably have some knowledge, other than having walked over the surface, of less than 1 percent, and it may be one-tenth of 1 percent, of the existing sites,'' he said. ``I myself must have mapped 5,000 mounds or something in that neighborhood. ``So the treasures there to be unearthed over thousands of years to come are enormous.'' The prospect of war - and of Islamic hostility to Westerners - raises doubts about the future of work in Jordan, Syria and elsewhere in the region. The Iran-Iraq war and the Iranian revolution of the Ayatollah Khomeini halted research in Iran. The threat of war raises greater concern about the safety of antiquities stored in such places as the ``spectacular'' museum in Baghdad, according to archaeologist Elizabeth Stone of the State University of New York at Stony Brook. ``A direct hit would be catastrophic,'' she said. Stone is optimistic, however. She noted that on three occasions during the Iran-Iraq war, when it seemed likely that Baghdad would be bombed, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had priceless objects moved out of harm's way. Saddam - who sometimes portrays himself as a latter-day Nebuchadnezzar, the 6th century B.C. Babylonian ruler - is well aware of the value of antiquities in ``fostering a time-depth in the consciousness of the people,'' said Guy Van Beek, a Smithsonian archaeologist who has worked in the Mideast for nearly three decades. Van Beek said Saddam has been ``extraordinarily active'' in encouraging excavations ``even given all his problems with war with Iran.'' ``It is always possible that a pitched battle can take place on a site'' or that a general can decide an excavation would be a good place from which to stage an ambush, he said. But short of those quirky events, he said, most archaeological sites are far from cities or targets and unlikely to be in danger of wartime destruction. The vast majority are 30, 40 or 50 feet below the surface. Peacetime economic development - the flooding of a valley or damming of a river - is generally more destructive to archaeology than war, Van Beek said. And in wartime, he said, random bombing is likely to be less destructive than the loss or looting of equipment and records and the destruction of artifacts that already have been brought to the surface. War, of course, brings the frustration of disrupting work that may have finally begun to pay off after decades of digging. Archaeologists sometimes wait in vain for decades to return to a former worksite rather than starting anew elsewhere, he said. When Saddam seized Kuwait Aug. 2, no Western archaeologists were known to have been stranded. Work had stopped during the hot summer. Before the invasion, Stone was able to put in only three seasons of work at the ``lost city'' of Mashkan-shapir which she and colleagues discovered in Iraq. Some 3,700 years ago, she said, it was ``one of the world's 10 most important cities.'' Now she has no idea when she will be able to resume digging. ``We were just beginning to get a real understanding of the way in which those cities worked,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling at Top, Southern Baptist Fundamentalists Seek States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for 2nd graf pvs to CORRECT verb and break into two sentences.
DOC.TEXT: Having won control of Southern Baptist national operations, fundamentalist forces are concentrating on holding state and local organizations in line, and seem largely to be succeeding. Resistance has come from some quarters, notably denominational colleges. But as the autumn chain of annual state conventions unfolded, potential revolts against the denomination's ``Cooperative Program'' for financing national agencies mostly failed to materialize. State allocations to the national budgets remained generally intact, or increased in some cases, with only three states modifying their pattern of support, two of them only slightly. The 14.9 million-member denomination, the country's largest Protestant body, has churches in all 50 states, some with joint regional conventions. Basic national budgets for the various evangelistic, missionary and educational agencies amount to $137 million, but supplementary revenues push the total to about $400 million. Leaders of moderates, pushed to the sidelines of denominational management through appointive powers of successively elected fundamentalist presidents, met in August and initiated plans for selective giving. Such alternatives also were sanctioned by the big Women's Missionary Union. But just one state convention, Virginia, radically curtailed giving to the central budget, cutting its part by half, and designating the other half to approved causes, mainly missions. Special allocations also went to the Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs, a Washington-based, inter-Baptist agency virtually stripped from denominational support, and also to a newly formed news service. The service, Associated Baptist Press, was set up this fall after national officers fired top journalists of the denominational agency, Baptist Press. The Maryland-Delaware convention also provided direct financing to the Joint Committee on Public Affairs, but otherwise continued its regular giving pattern to the headquarters budget. Similar but unsuccessful efforts to finance the committee were made in New England, Missouri, Tennessee, Kentucky and Hawaii. In North Carolina, an alternative finance plan like Virginia's was narrowly defeated. However, individual congregations still may participate in alternative finance arrangements. How many of the denomination's 37,785 congregations will do so remains uncertain. Several of the state conventions drew unusually large turnouts as the conflict shifted to that level. Strains emerged over relationships with some Baptist colleges. They apparently sought to stave off the kind of new restrictions that already have struck at national levels, including the denomination's main seminary in Louisville, Ky., where exacting views of the Bible were made guidelines for evaluating professors. The guidelines demand various specific beliefs, such as that Adam and Eve were real people and that recounted miracles happened as events in history. Differing from the national supervision of agencies and seminaries, more than 50 Baptist colleges come under oversight of state conventions. Citing fear of a ``fundamentalist takeover,'' the largest Baptist college, Baylor University in Waco, Texas, and Furman University in Greenville, S.C., have made their trustees self-perpetuating. They previously were named by state conventions. Both cases produced convention controversy, study committees and hints of lawsuits. In Florida, Stetson University also moved to distance itself from the state convention through a negotiated arrangement. In Oklahoma, the convention acted to reinforce ties with Oklahoma Baptist University in Shawnee. In the denomination's upper echelons, repercussions of the fundamenalist ascendancy also continued. Disciplinary action was taken against the Rev. Lee Porter of the Nashville, Tenn., headquarters, who was accused of making ``critical interpretations'' about the 12-year controversy in which fundamentalists have gained dominant power. He was removed as design editor of adult Sunday school lesson materials and assigned to a non-editorial position, although he wrote a letter of apology to the administration about his unspecified comments. Porter also reportedly was being pressured to give up his post as convention registration secretary, a post he has held since 1977 and to which he was re-elected last June. A catalyzing center of the fundamentalist upsurge, the denomination's largest church, First Baptist in Dallas, elected a new fundamentalist-backing pastor, the Rev. Joel Gregory, to succeed the Rev. W.A. Criswell. Calling himself a ``defender of the inerrancy of the word of God,'' Gregory told reporters after his selection last week, ``I was country before country was cool.'' Criswell, 81, who has headed the 27,000-member downtown congregation for the past 46 years, will become senior pastor, a largely honorary position, on Jan. 6. Gregory, who for five years has been pastor of Travis Avenue Baptist Church in Fort Worth, also was named speaker on the ``Baptist Hour,'' a nationally distributed Southern Baptist radio program. It marks its 50th anniversary of broadcasting in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Starry, Starry Night: The Popularity of Vincent van Gogh
DOC.TEXT: Vincent van Gogh's creative compulsions brought little financial or emotional solace to the troubled Dutch impressionist during his lifetime. But 100 years later, he is unarguably the world's most popular painter. He enjoyed considerable acclaim among his fellow artists during the late-1800s, and his influence was felt long after his death in 1890. However, experts disagree whether he sold only one work or three or more during his life. Today, though, his works fetch astronomical and record prices at art auctions around the world. A four-month extravaganza earlier this year in The Netherlands commemorated the centennial of the painter's death with about 380 paintings and drawings on show at the Vincent van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam and the Kroeller-Mueller Museum in Otterlo, and a film festival and opera. Now comes Robert Altman's passionate portrait of the artist in Hemdale Film's ``Vincent and Theo.'' It is a thoughtful, inspired explosion of the emotions, fears and genius of the man who once said that ``work distracts me infinitely better than anything else.'' Tim Roth (``A World Apart,'' ``The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover'') gives an intensely intelligent portrayal of the artist. He rides the emotions well without slipping into caricature. Paul Rhys (``Litte Dorrit,'' ``Lion Heart'') co-stars Theo. It is the not the first time the film world has tackled the complex life and personality of van Gogh. Altman's is a psychological vignette, rather than a full-fleshed cinemagraphic biography, focusing on the special relationship the artist had with his brother, Theo, an art dealer who nurtured Vincent all his life. It is quite unlike Vincente Minnelli's sprawling but inaccurate 1956 vision, ``Lust for Life,'' with Kirk Douglas as van Gogh and Anthony Quinn as his one-time lover, colleague and friend, Paul Gauguin. Japanese filmmaker Akira Kurosawa also captures van Gogh in the ``Crows'' segment of his movie ``Akira Kurosawa's Dreams.'' It is a tribute to the artist, who is portrayed by American director Martin Scorsese. ``Dreams'' has eight segments and the central character throughout is called ``I.'' In ``Crows,'' I is a grown man, a young photographer looking at some of van Gogh's work. He eventually finds himself in an open field with the artist, who proclaims, ``all of nature has its own beauty'' as he furiously fills page after page. Van Gogh's most prolific period was 1888-89 when he painted about 200 oils and did 100 drawings. From this passionate frenzy emerged some of the most popular art works ever, van Gogh's vibrantly colored sunflowers, fishing boats and pastoral scenes. During that same period in Provence, he wrote about 200 letters to his brother, his sister, Gauguin and other artists. In a letter to Theo on April 9, 1888, he talks about one of his favorite orchards on the outskirts of Arles, one he ultimately used for a painting: ``I have another orchard, as good as the pink peach trees, apricot trees of a very pale pink. At the moment I am working on some plum trees; yellowish-white, with thousands of black branches. I am using a tremendous lot of colours and canvases, but all the same I hope it isn't a waste of money. ...'' Van Gogh was born on March 30, 1853, in the southern Netherlands village of Zundert. Life was a continual nightmare of poverty, loneliness and periodic bouts of madness until he ended it after firing a rifle into his chest on July 29, 1890. He rode an emotional rollercoaster between and during his prolific outpouring of art. After he mutilated himself by cutting off his right ear, he turned evangelical, saying the Bible had ordered him to remove the ``ofending organ.'' On May 8, 1889, van Gogh went to the asylum of Saint-Paul-de-Mausole in Saint-Remy-de-Provence, a few miles north of Arles. The doctor there wrote in the medical register that van Gogh was suffering from ``acute mania with hallucinations of sight and hearing. ...'' The first canvas van Gogh did at Saint-Remy was ``Irises,'' a dancing field of brilliant, violet flowers and a single white one. ``Irises'' set a record when Sotheby's sold it for $53.90 million on Nov. 11, 1987. The painting subsequently was sold to the Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., after Australian tycoon Alan Bond could not repay a loan Sotheby's had posted for the sale. The most expensive painting ever was van Gogh's ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet,'' which sold this year for $82.5 million. The painting in vivid blues and intense orange, was of the artist's friend, a doctor who practiced homeopathic medicine. But it was ``The Starry Night'' that emerged as a cult favorite, inspiring a song from pop artist Don McLean. ``The sky is blue-green, the water is royal blue, the soil is mauve,'' van Gogh said in a letter to Theo describing the painting. ``On the blue-green field of the sky the Great Bear, sparkling green and pink, a reflection whose modest shine contrasts with the powerful gold of the gas light.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, Dec. 7

DOC.HEAD: With AM-AP Arts: Van Gogh
Tim Roth Paints the Town in `Vincent and Theo'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Film has opened New York and selected cities; will open elsewhere during the month.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Armed with healthy skepticism of the praise being heaped upon him, actor Tim Roth is as rare and refreshing a presence in Southern California as is clean air. The irreverent Roth, who plays a fiery Vincent van Gogh in Robert Altman's ``Vincent and Theo,'' is dressed in a T-shirt that proclaims him ``Well Red.'' He recounts how he was thrown out of a bar at his New York hotel because he was improperly dressed, and how he needed to borrow a suit for an East Coast screening of ``Vincent and Theo.'' ``He's got a rich swagger, doesn't he?'' the 29-year-old British actor says as another movieland power player wanders by the pool at the Sunset Marquis hotel. When a small plane flies overhead, he remarks, ``Oh look. They're bringing the drugs in.'' Although the skinny, sandy-haired Roth doesn't much look like van Gogh, ``he became the character,'' Altman said. ``He's as good a film actor as I've ever worked with,'' said Altman, who has directed Warren Beatty, Robert Duvall, Keith Carradine and Tom Conti, among others. Roth shares top billing, too, in Tom Stoppard's film adaptation of his play ``Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead.'' A grand-prize winner at the Venice Film Festival, ``Rosencrantz'' premieres early next year. While he's not without an ego (Altman says Roth can be difficult on the set) Roth is uncomfortable accepting praise for his work. Although he wants to be a part of the American film scene, he's hardly in awe of the local industry or himself. ``It gets silly,'' the lightly freckled actor said. ``I'm compared to (Al) Pacino and (Dustin) Hoffman. What does it mean? I just think it's safe journalism. ``I treat it all with a large bucket of salt. There's no guarantee of any of this. You come here and people treat you with kid gloves, very nicely. And then they forget about you because the next person is in town. It's a cutthroat business, and has nothing to do with art at all.'' Art, at least, has much to do with ``Vincent and Theo.'' The intense film chronicles the emotional interdependence of the Dutch artist and his younger brother, Theo (Paul Rhys), an art dealer. Roth's Vincent has caked and rotten teeth, filthy hands and a mind that's equally polluted. He jams his pipe into his mouth as though he's burying a fence post, and paints and sketches with similar abandon. Although everybody knows something about Vincent van Gogh - no ear lobe, liked sunflowers, had a beard - Roth says the artist's life is mysterious, and there's not much point doing a lot of research, either. ``I read his letters and looked at the paintings. That's it,'' said Roth, a former art student himself. ``There are thousands of books you could read, but they're all written by academics and intellectuals. It's a tricky one. Everyone wants him to have been mad. And I don't know that he really was. Would you lock him up today? What would be the attitude today? Tell him not to be naughty and put him on welfare? Take away his government funding?'' As an actor, Roth has had his share of rejection, but obviously far less than van Gogh. ``He did believe, and carried on being rejected. And that's the self-abuse thing: eating paint, drinking turpentine and cutting off his ear lobe. That's all part of the rejection. ``The only thing as an actor that you are aware of - and certainly not to the extent that he was - is the rejection. You are aware of being rejected, either when you've done something bad by the audience or by people who, when you think you can do a part, say, `No.''' Roth's film credits include ``The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover,'' in which he plays a sidekick to a thug, and ``A World Apart.'' His next film is ``Backsliding,'' an Australian drama directed by first-timer Simon Target. Roth also starred as the transmogrified son in director Steven Berkoff's London stage production of Franz Kafka's ``Metamorphosis.'' In working with Altman, who often improvises and puts a lot of trust in his actors, Roth was free to fashion much of the film himself. ``If we said, `This is the way we want to do it,' Altman says, `That's how we'll do it,''' Roth said. ``We'd rewrite scenes in the evening with him or on our own, and then go and present them to him. ``The script was the starting point. ... For example, there's a scene where I'm cooking with (Paul) Gauguin (Wladimir Yordanoff), and it was originally a scene where we're sitting around talking about painting. That's not what painters do with their lives. ``That came out when I said, `Let's do a scene where we're all cooking.' And Wladimir, said, `Oh yeah, I got a great recipe from my grandmother for salads.' And that was how it came out.'' Van Gogh, Roth said, was someone who had interested him since he was in art school. ``He was my father's hero. My father used to paint and draw and was also a journalist. He had a rough life, too.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, Dec. 7

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Eden and Larry Hagman Reunited on `Dallas'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Friday in 2nd graf is Dec. 21
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Larry Hagman tells Barbara Eden on CBS' ``Dallas'' that she looks familiar - an inside joke for viewers who saw them 20 years ago on ``I Dream of Jeannie.'' For five weeks beginning Friday night, the prime-time soap opera brings them into a fractious relationship as Miss Eden appears in the role of Leann de la Vega. ``Leann's a very sharp businesswoman who took over running an oil company eight years ago after her husband's death,'' Miss Eden said. ``She knows J.R. because they went to college together. ``I can't say too much about the story. Let's just say that he wasn't very nice to her in college and their paths cross again in a business deal. She decides to extract every drop of blood she can get from him.'' On ``I Dream of Jeannie,'' Hagman played Tony Nelson, an astronaut who lands on a desert island when his mission is aborted. He finds an old bottle. Inside? Jeannie, a genie who'd been in the bottle for 2,000 years. When he set her free, he became her master. The show was on five years, and at the end the characters married. ``That killed the series,'' Miss Eden said. ``I objected to the marriage because I knew it would hurt the show. It was a fantasy. It was all smoke. She wasn't real. To marry her was to turn it into an ordinary sitcom.'' There also was an animated version on CBS on Saturday mornings from 1973 to 1975. CBS and the producers of ``Dallas'' are hoping the Hagman-Eden reunion will renew interest in the show, which has been doing only so-so in the ratings in recent years. On the strength of the ``Who shot J.R.?'' phenomenon a decade ago, ``Dallas'' became a runaway hit and had remained at the top for several years. Of her character of ``Dallas,'' Miss Eden said, ``This woman is deadly serious. She's nothing like Jeannie. She makes a plan and carries it out. J.R. doesn't remember her, which makes it fun. ``I had a great time doing this. We didn't need any inside jokes, but so many of the lines are wonderful. He asks her, `Haven't we met before?' The first day on the stage, everyone was watching us. Larry looked at me and said: `Isn't this the strangest thing? It's like we've never stopped working together.' '' It's not their first time together since ``I Dream of Jeannie,'' however. They played husband and wife in a 1971 murder mystery called ``A Howling in the Woods.'' In 1985, she starred in the movie ``I Dream of Jeannie ... 15 Years Later.'' Wayne Rogers played Tony, but Bill Daly and Hayden Rorke reprised their original roles. If ``Dallas'' returns for another season, Miss Eden might be back for another bout with Hagman. ``Well, at least they didn't kill me,'' she said. Miss Eden starred in the series ``Harper Valley P.T.A.'' in 1981-82, but has spent most of her post-``Jeannie'' time working in TV movies and regional theater. She has her own deal for a series and several movies, and has several series in development, including a comedy and several one-hour dramas. ``Whatever is chosen will be predicated by the needs of the network,'' she said. Miss Eden started work after Thanksgiving on a psychological thriller movie called ``Smithereens,'' based on a book by B.W. Battlin. ``My husband is murdered and I'm accused of killing him,'' she said. ``They can't make the charges stick. It's very suspenseful because the person who killed my husband wants to kill me and my daughter. ``I'm being stalked by Angie Dickinson. The audience knows it, but I don't. She impersonates me, which is why they think I did it.'' Earlier this season, Miss Eden was in the NBC movie ``Running Mates'' and, next year, will be in ``Naked Ambition,'' a CBS movie with a plotline that can be compared to ``All About Eve.'' Miss Eden plays an established anchorwoman who welcomes a younger newswoman, played by Heather Locklear. ``I take this little viper into my heart, and she puts a knife in my back,'' Miss Eden said. ``She's out to get my job - anybody's job.'' Miss Eden also has big news in her personal life: Jan. 5, she said, she will marry real estate developer Jon Eicholtz. ``He took over the remodeling of my house and suddenly everything started getting done,'' she said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Nov. 21-23
