DOC.HEAD: CNN's New Boss: Quiet First Day, But Then ...
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It was such a slow news day when he began as the new president of Cable News Network, Tom Johnson recalls, that ``CNN was televising stories on mules diving into pools of water.'' That was on Aug. 1, when he reported for duty with a number of projects in mind. They included an effort to get Bill Moyers, his White House boss during the Johnson Administration, to move from PBS to CNN. But all that was put on hold the next day, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. CNN and its rivals scrambled to cover the Persian Gulf crisis and a possible war. A month later, CNN had its own crisis. ``We found ourselves no longer simply reporting on budget deficits, but ... experiencing our own as a result of the massive expenses of the Gulf crisis coverage and a softening advertising market,'' Johnson said. And last month, there was another crisis, which began when a federal judge barred CNN from airing tapes of jailhouse phone calls by ousted Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega. Though the Supreme Court refused to hear CNN's argument that the ban was unconstitutional prior restraint of the press, the judge in the Noriega case later lifted it. ``It was a very busy four months,'' said Johnson, understating the case. It surprised many in the industry when CNN's owner, Ted Turner, went outside both the company and broadcast news to hire Johnson, who then was publisher of the Los Angeles Times. ``We really wanted someone that had a lot of management experience and had a good reputation as a strong people-person, as well as strong journalistic credentials,'' Turner said. It was the second time in two years a major network had chosen a newspaperman to run its news division. In 1988, NBC hired Michael G. Gartner, then head of the Des Moines Register and Tribune Co. How great a transition is it from print to television news? ``It totally depends on the person,'' Gartner said. ``I don't think you can generalize.'' ``I don't think there's a great deal of difference in terms of the principles,'' said Moyers, who before working at PBS and CBS was publisher of Newsday on Long Island, N.Y. ``The principles are: Remember you're in the news business, find the best people and give them a chance to do their work in an atmosphere of freedom and creativity.'' But Moyers said his longtime friend ``is really on the front line now in a way that he wasn't at the Times, because as publisher, he had a phalanx of people reporting to him. While that's also true at CNN, he's making, on a daily basis, the kind of decisions an editor makes every day. ... I think he's now in a job more like Patton than Eisenhower.'' ``The intensity of the place surprised me. Perhaps it shouldn't have,'' said Johnson, who for three years was a top executive in Lyndon Johnson's Texas broadcast operations but who has spent the bulk of his career in print journalism. CNN was ridiculed by rivals as ``Chicken Noodle News'' when it began in 1980. No more. It now is an influential, worldwide TV news organization seen in 100 countries, with President Bush and Iraq's Saddam Hussein among its better-known viewers. Plugged into 57 million U.S. homes and offices by cable, it also has 227 TV station affiliates who can excerpt CNN stories for their newscasts. Significantly, 130 of the stations also are affiliates of ABC, CBS or NBC, whose news divisions are caught in the same advertising and money crunch as CNN and have pink-slipped some employees to cut costs. But there have been no layoffs among CNN's worldwide workforce of 1,700, Johnson said, and none are planned. Despite the cost crunch, CNN ``is very healthy economically,'' he said, although ``the slowdown in advertising and costs of the Gulf coverage required that I implement a number of holddowns.'' That included the axing of ``East Meets West,'' a weekly half-hour series on Asian lifestyles and business customs. If the nation's economic slump and the Gulf crisis continues, ``then I probably would need to find other ways to contain costs while doing that which is essential for CNN to do,'' Johnson said. But ``we will provide comprehensive news throughout all of this. ... This is a period of time when I think our audience is more interested in the news than ever before.'' The financial crunch has prompted Johnson to temporarily shelve what he calls ``several initatives,'' or ideas for new programs. One is a series similar to ABC's ``Nightline.'' There has been speculation within CNN that it might evolve from CNN's nightly ``Crisis in the Gulf'' broadcasts, just as ``Nightline'' evolved from ABC's late-night reports on the Iran hostage crisis in 1979. Johnson also would like to start a series about the print and electronic media. And ``I would like to see us expand our international bureaus in Africa, Central and South America, and Asia, three places where I feel more coverage would be useful,'' he said. CNN now has 14 foreign bureaus. Johnson said he still hopes to land Moyers, whom he first met in 1965 while on a White House Fellowship. He initially served as an aide to Moyers, then press secretary for President Johnson. Moyers said there have no serious discussions about a move to CNN. Shortly before taking charge at the network, Johnson ``just said if I ever get ready to come back to the news business, let him know,'' Moyers said. ``I said to Tom that I have commitments here at PBS that I intend to fulfill ... but someday he and I can sit down and talk.'' ``I would like to see Bill do at CNN what he does at public television,'' Johnson said, referring to Moyers' acclaimed specials on various topics. ``I also suggested to him a concept I described as `Around the World With CNN.' '' In that, Moyers would interview major players in world events, among them Saddam Hussein, Soviet president Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush. ``I would love to see him as part of the future of this network,'' Johnson said. ``But he is currently committed to his PBS lineup and there are no immediate plans for him to move over - although I'd be willing to re-open that any day.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Dec. 15-16

DOC.TEXT: Late-November sales of cars and trucks made in North America by the Big Three automakers tumbled 24 percent, reflecting a continued softening in the auto industry, the companies said. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said Tuesday they sold an average of 24,387 cars and light trucks a day during the Nov. 21-30 period this year compared with an average of 32,101 during the same time last year. Car sales were down 20.9 percent and truck sales were off 28.3 percent. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Sales of new homes dropped 3.5 percent in October to the lowest level in eight years, the government reported, but analysts said the free fall may be bottoming out and sales should begin rebounding by spring. Sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 491,000, the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development said Tuesday. That was the lowest since 480,000 new homes were sold in October 1982, a month before the 1981-82 recession ended. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Federal Reserve has relaxed its reserve requirements for banks, an unusual move aimed at stimulating the deteriorating economy by easing a shortage of credit. The central bank said Tuesday's action, the first change in reserve requirements since 1983, was taken in part for technical reasons but also to encourage banks to increase lending. Private economists, however, said the most visible result likely would be a modest boost in bank earnings at a time of increasing strain on the industry, rather than as an economic tonic in general. --- BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - An ambitious effort to overhaul the world trading system appeared on the verge of collapse as pressure built on European countries to compromise in their fight against major farm subsidy cuts. Some European officials indicated Tuesday they were willing to offer more agriculture subsidy cuts, although it was uncertain whether any new offer would be enough to satisfy U.S. negotiators. The 12-nation European Community had staunchly resisted a U.S.-backed proposal to slash export subsidies and reduce internal support payments and market barriers over the next decade. --- ATLANTA (AP) - Soft drink rivals Coca-Cola and Pepsi Cola made almost simultaneous announcements that they plan to sell their products in recycled plastic bottles. The cola makers became the latest companies to join the corporate race to please an increasingly environmentally conscious market. If approved by the Food and Drug Administration, soft drink bottles would become one of the first cases in whic recycled plastic is used in direct contact with food. --- DAYTON, Ohio (AP) - NCR Corp.'s board of directors scheduled a meeting to discuss AT&T's latest offer to buy the computer company. NCR spokesman Mark Feighery said while the board unanimously rejected a previous $85-per-share offer from the American Telephone & Telegraph Co., the latest, $90-a-share proposal has yet to be formally voted. AT&T has said the offer would be on the table until the end of business Wednesday. The NCR board meeting was set for Wednesday. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said it was abandoning the once-lucrative trading of stocks of potential takeover targets, a business hurt sharply by the end of the 1980s mergers boom. Also on Tuesday, First Boston Corp. confirmed it laid off 55 workers in its fixed-income department as part of a companywide restructuring designed to slash 200 jobs in the last two months of the year. The moves were further signs of weakness on during a lengthy recession on Wall Street. --- NEW YORK (AP) - American Telephone & Telegraph Co., emboldened by its highly successful foray into the credit card business, extended the free-for-life membership offer by three months to attract additional customers. The move Tuesday by the telephone giant to increase circulation of its Universal Card was bound to further rankle banks, which view AT&T as an invader chipping away at one of their most profitable areas, credit-card income. AT&T launched the Universal Card, a Visa or Mastercard that doubles as a long-distance calling card, eight months ago. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A federal judge affirmed a U.S. Supreme Court ruling that ordered the LTV Corp. to re-assume liability for nearly $3 billion in employee pension plans it stopped funding in 1987. The Dallas steel, aerospace and energy concern, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, had opposed restoring the plans because it claimed such a move could possibly force the company to liquidate. U.S. District Judge Robert Sweet oin Tuesday rejected the company's and creditors' arguments and granted a request by the federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. to make LTV take back responsibility for the pension plans. ---

A report that Iraq may be ready to withdraw from Kuwait peacefully triggered a powerful rally in the stock market on Tuesday. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 14.11 points to close at 2,579.70. Bonds closed moderately higher. The dollar fell sharply. Gold was mixed. Grain and soybean futures closed lower, oil was up on the futures market and livestock and pork futures were lower.

DOC.HEAD: Extends `Free For Life' Offer on Universal Credit Card
With PM-AT&T-NCR
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. has given potential customers another three months to take advantage of a free-for-life membership in its Universal Card, one of the fastest growing credit cards. The move announced Tuesday by the telephone giant to increase circulation of the card was bound to further rankle banks, which view AT&T as an invader chipping away at one of their most profitable areas, credit-card income. Eight months ago, AT&T launched the card, a Visa or Mastercard that doubles as a long-distance calling card. To attract members, AT&T said those who signed up by Dec. 31 would never pay an annual fee for the rest of their lives - as long as they used the card once a year to buy something. Since then, nearly 7 million cards have been issued, making AT&T one of the biggest forces in the credit-card business. The company issues its cards through Universal Bank of Columbus, Ga., a subsidiary of Synovus Financial Corp. On Tuesday, AT&T extended the signup deadline until March 26, 1991, the anniversary of the card. ``It's a way to allow more people to take advantage of a pretty good deal,'' said Bruce Reid, a spokesman for the AT&T Universal Card Services Corp. subsidiary in Jacksonville, Fla. No decision has been made on what annual fees might be charged after March 26. Industry analysts speculated AT&T prolonged the offer simply because it's been so effective in helping the company muscle in on the domain of big-bank competitors, which generally charge an annual fee for cards. ``The primary reason for AT&T's enormous success in distribution is this free-for-life deal,'' said Bruce Brittain, head of Brittain Associates Inc., a consulting firm in Atlanta that researches credit-card use. ``When you're in the business of getting the card into people's wallets, until you see that growth curve flatten, why not continue it?,'' he said. Kurt Peters, editor of Credit Card News, a industry publication in Chicago, said the free-for-life offer has been so successful that even AT&T has been surprised, and ``they're hesitant to tinker with success.'' The card also offers users a 10 percent discount on long-distance calling card rates as well as the same amenities pitched by other leading cards, ranging from warranty extensions to collision insurance. The Universal Card's interest rate on unpaid balances is 18.9 percent, about the same as other key competitors. The banking industry has fiercely opposed AT&T's credit-card operation and some banks have challenged it on legal grounds, saying the company has flouted federal regulatory requirements. AT&T says it's done nothing improper. Last Friday, Visa U.S.A., the payment organization of Visa card issuers, decreed a six-month moratorium on new non-bank applicants in what was seen as a move to soothe banks unnerved by AT&T's success. MasterCard, the other leading payment organization, tightened rules for issuers, making it more expensive. ``The banks have spent years and millions of dollars building up Mastercard and Visa, and now they see this non-bank company come in and crank up this big credit-card marketing machine,'' Peters said. Others said it was premature to judge the ultimate success of AT&T's effort. If a substantial number of Universal Card users pay off their balances promptly, for example, they will deprive AT&T of interest income. ``The jury's still out on how profitable it will be,'' said Gerri Detweiler, an official at the Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer education group in Herndon, Va.

DOC.HEAD: Sales Remain Sluggish Despite Some Bright Spots
DOC.TEXT: The shopping season is racing toward Christmas, but retailers aren't reporting high-speed sales. The faltering economy, concerns about the Middle East and higher taxes all are being cited as contributing factors to weak - but not disastrous - performances in the first two weeks of the crucial holiday season. ``Thanksgiving weekend was pretty good. Otherwise, it's been somewhat disappointing,'' J.C. Penney Co. spokesman Duncan Muir said Tuesday. Some storeowners were pleased with sales so far, but others found negative predictions proving correct. Analysts called overall sales sluggish, reiterated forecasts for a disappointing Christmas and said the East Coast was hardest hit. Child World Inc., the nation's No. 2 chain of toy stores, said Tuesday it would stop paying old bills for six weeks so it can save cash to buy toys for the Christmas season, according to a published report today. Jeffrey Cole, chairman of CNC Holdings, which controls the 182-store chain of toy supermarkets, said it would begin a $100 million clearance sale and slash prices on Saturday in an effort to increase business, The New York Times reported. Cole said the company wanted to avoid a Chapter 11 bankruptcy court filing. Child World, based in Avon, Mass., concentrates on the Northeast and Cole said Christmas sales were poor throughout the chain. Child World is a distant second in stores and sales to Toys ``R'' Us. The faltering economy is ``creating a difficult time for our retailers,'' said Suzanne McMillan, senior vice president for marketing at upscale Saks Fifth Avenue. ``We've experienced some highs and lows.'' Dayton Hudson Corp. Chairman Kenneth Macke said he was satisfied with his company's peformance so far. ``The Thanksgiving weekend was very good and the next week since then, business has been slower, much like we really anticipated it would be,'' he said. Like many other retailers, Macke said he expected business to pick up in the last 10 days before Christmas. Macke said his company's Target discount chain and Mervyn's moderate-priced apparel stores have fared better than Dayton Hudson's department stores - evidence that budget-conscious consumers were ``trading down'' and buying cheaper gifts. Analysts described the retailers' results so far as choppy at best. ``Sales seem to be running a little bit better than most observers had thought going into the season, (but) it's not a good season,'' said Donald Trott, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. who follows specialty retailers such as apparel stores. Kidder Peabody & Co. analyst Daniel Barry said the Northeast and Middle Atlantic states were faring the worst. The Northwest and oil-producing areas have had the strongest sales. Barry described the Midwest as ``very spotty.'' Many big retailers will announce sales results for November on Thursday, and most of the big chains are expected to report declines from November 1989 levels. The softness so far is n surprise. Retail sales slumped badly in August after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and have not recovered, even though the holiday season is a time when consumers are expected to spend. Many shoppers, facing higher oil prices and taxes and concerned about job security, have said they will do less shopping this season. Retailers are getting no help from the weather, which has been warmer than usual in many parts of the country. Consumers find it hard to get in the mood for Christmas when the temperature is in the 50s. But Douglas Kline, a vice president of General Growth Center Cos., which manages 67 shopping centers in 26 states and Washington D.C., said ``sales are basically humming'' at his firm's malls. ``We're seeing increases at most markets across the nation ... especially mid-size markets in the Midwest,'' while business at two shopping centers in the Northeast is slower, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Heating Oil Users Squeezed By Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: People who use home heating oil have been hit hard by prices pushed up by war fears, but the warmer-than-usual fall has provided something of a break. But cold weather has to set in at some point, and consumer advocates fear energy bills could jump again. Uncertainties in the Middle East desert give heating oil the potential to move sharply in either direction. ``If we begin to get into cold weather and supplies start to be drawn down, we're very concerned prices could go even higher and bust people's energy budget,'' said Richard Kessel, executive director of the New York State Consumer Protection Board. Heating oil dealers in the Northeast agree a cold snap could push prices up. But they see war or peace in the Middle East as having a potentially greater impact, because supplies are running well ahead of last year's levels. Dealers blame the prices, which in some cases have gone up about four times as much as they might during most cold seasons, on war fears that have mesmerized the market for months. But they say a diplomatic solution for getting Iraq out of Kuwait could send prices falling as sharply as they rose. If peace breaks out, ``the price of this stuff is going to fall through the floor,'' said Eugene Guilford, of the Maine Oil Dealers Association. Recent industry statistics showed the nation's stockpile of heating oil to be about 15 million barrels higher than it was going into December of 1989, largely because many in the industry stocked up ahead of time to avoid a repeat of the run on supplies during last December's extreme cold snap. The ample supply and the lack of cold weather has Kessel and others thinking that consumers are unfairly being charged too much, but it's not easy to pinpoint a culprit. ``Whether it's purposeful or whether it's a product of the system, I think the market is anti-competitive,'' Kessel said. Consumer advocates say an average family that uses heating oil can expect to pay $300 to $500 more to keep warm this cold season, assuming prices stay about the same. The higher prices are also bad news for retail heating oil dealers, who say they are getting squeezed by the Gulf crisis. ``We kind of got hit with a double whammy,'' said Vera Haskins, executive vice president of Mauger & Co., in Malvern, Pa. ``We got hit with this warm weather, and on top of this we lost about 20 to 25 percent of our margin coming.'' Mauger, which supplies fuel in the Philadelphia area, was forced to lay off five people from its payroll of about 145, she said. ``We kept saying it's going to get cold, it's going to get cold, but it didn't,'' Haskins said. Dealers are still hoping for cold weather, although Haskins emphasizes most of them would prefer normal, seasonal cold instead of record cold. Heating oil dealers would rather make their money on lower-priced oil, both because they would have less cash invested in their inventories and also because fewer people will look to alternatives, such as natural gas, when heating oil is cheap. ``The fact that we're no longer as competitive is a killer in our industry,'' Haskins said. Each $10 rise in the price of crude oil pushes heating oil up by about 25 cents, said Bob Greenes, of the New York Oil Heat Association. In some Northeast markets, the price has gone up as much as 39 cents a gallon this season to more than $1.40 a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Pru-Bache Axes Risk Arbitrage; First Boston Fires 55 in Bonds
DOC.TEXT: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. is abandoning the once-lucrative trading of stocks of potential takeover targets, a business hurt sharply by the end of the 1980s mergers boom. Also, First Boston Corp. confirmed Tuesday it laid off 55 workers in its fixed-income department as part of a companywide restructuring designed to slash 200 jobs in the last two months of the year. The moves were further signs of weakness on Wall Street. Top firms are cutting jobs and axing key business areas to cope with a three-year industry recession being made worse by the ailing economy and Middle East crisis. Prudential-Bache said in a statement it is ceasing proprietary risk arbitrage trading, that is, securities trading for the firm's own account in stocks of companies believed to be targeted for takeovers. The move was the second major business reduction by Prudential-Bache in the last month. The firm laid off 120 of its 180 investment bankers because of a downturn in financing mergers and acquisitions. Several other firms also have reduced their investment banking forces. Most recently, PaineWebber Inc. this week began dismissing a reported 18 percent of its 160 investment bankers. A Prudential-Bache spokeswoman said that Guy Wyser-Pratte, a top arbitrager with 25 years at the firm, would help wind down the risk arbitrage department's operations. Wyser-Pratte, 50, was said by Wall Street sources to be seeking to move his 12-person department to another firm. Risk arbitrage was one of Wall Street's most lucrative trading areas in the booming 1980s. But a sharp decline in mergers and acquisitions - more than 16 percent in the first 10 months of 1990, according to IDD Information Services - has limited opportunities for the risky trading activity. In a memo last month to employees, Prudential-Bache Chairman George L. Ball said the risk arbitrage department lost money in 1989 and so far in 1990. ``Risk arb is a business which ails in a bear market, and we are in a bear market,'' Ball said. The First Boston bond department layoffs include low-level support staff and veteran professionals with as much as 20 years at the firm, First Boston employees said. The cuts are part of a restructuring at First Boston announced last month that features an overhaul of senior management and a $725 million cash and equity injection by the Swiss owner of CS First Boston Inc. First Boston Corp. is the main U.S. subsidiary of CS First Boston. First Boston employees said the 55 layoffs included personnel who reported to departed vice chairman William Voute and managing directors E. Craig Coats and Ronald Stuart, who came toFirst Boston from Salomon Inc. The three were touted highly by the firm but clashed repeatedly with management. They and two other former Salomon executives were ousted from First Boston last month.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Bank, Top U.S. Strategist Form Partnership
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese bank has agreed to provide up to $30 million to back a partnership with a top Wall Street mergers and acquisitions specialist in a new investment banking firm. The alliance between Sanwa Bank Ltd. and former First Boston Corp. executive Michael Duval, announced Tuesday, is the latest between major banks and emerging investment firms. Eric Gleacher, a former Morgan Stanley & Co., executive, last summer formed a partnership with Morgan Grenfell PLC, the merchant banking company owned by Deutsche Bank Group. The latest new firm, to be known as Sanwa Duval, will be owned by Duval, the bank and other partners, Duval said in an interview. Sanwa, the world's fifth-largest bank, has agreed to provide $30 million to back the partnership, Duval said. Sanwa Duval will take over the operations currently carried out by the Merchant Banking Group of Sanwa's offices in New York and Los Angeles. The new firm will be managed by Duval and Shuhei Sato, senior vice president of Sanwa's merchant banking arm. Duval left First Boston as a managing director last summer and formed his own firm, The Duval Group. He had helped arrange First Boston's merger with its London-based affiliate, Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston. Before joining First Boston in 1984, Duval spent seven years at Mead Corp., and before that served in the Nixon and Ford administrations. Sanwa Duval will be an investment banker, advising clients on proposed transactions, but will not create its own fund to participate in deals of its own, Duval said. That decision places Sanwa Duval in a different league from Wasserstein Perella & Co., the investment firm formed by two other First Boston alumni. Although Bruce Wasserstein and Joseph Perella have advised clients on deals including the $24.5 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc., they also have entered into transactions themselves. Duval said he was more interested in advising long-term clients rather than picking up business on a deal-by-deal basis with clients who are potential rivals in transactions. Duval said he expects his new firm mostly to advise U.S. companies seeking strategic acquisitions, joint ventures or divestitures. But he said he also expects to handle cross-border transactions, in which one party is American and the other foreign. While most cross-border deals are likely to involve European parties, Duval predicted the firm will be handling an increasing amount of transactions with Japanese firms. Although Japanese markets have generally been closed to American buyers and investors, ``I think it's opening up,'' Duval said. Sanwa Duval expects to be operating in early 1991, after it has received government approval, Duval said.

DOC.HEAD: Coke, Pepsi Announce Recycled Plastic Bottles
DOC.TEXT: In the latest corporate attempt to meet environmental concerns, Coca-Cola and Pepsi Cola plan to market products in recycled plastic bottles. The rival soft drink makers said Tuesday they were seeking government approval for separate proposals to use recycled plastic. The Food and Drug Administration to date has approved just one case - submitted by an egg company - in which recycled plastic can be used in direct contact with food. The FDA regards recycled plastic as ``an indirect additive'' to food, said agency spokesman Chris Lecos. Plastic bottles are widely recycled now, but the finished material is used for such products as carpeting, piping and non-food containers - not for food packaging. The environmental group Greenpeace said it was unimpressed with the cola makers' plans. Greenpeace spokeswoman Julie Brenegar said the beverage companies would do better by eliminating plastic packaging altogether. ``Plastics recycling is yet another way the plastics industry is trying to justify the use of plastics,'' she said, adding that new ``virgin'' plastic is needed even for recycled packages. Therefore, she said, plastic recycling makes only a small dent in the amount of raw material introduced to the environment. Jackie Prince, a staff scientist at the Washington-based Environmental Defense Fund, said the Coke and Pepsi plans mark a step in the right direction by expanding the uses for recycled plastic. ``The reality is there is a lot of plastic out there now, and we'd like to see what's there recycled,'' she said. ``This brings plastics recycling further along the learning curve.'' Coke spokesman Randy Donaldson said the recycling proposal was submitted to the FDA in June, and officials at the Atlanta-based company hope to test market the new bottles sometime in 1991 before launching a full-scale rollout. Pepsi also said it plans to have the recycled bottles in stores next year. FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbitt said the agency has been talking to Pepsi's partner in the project, Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co., about their planned recycling process and plans to review the data shortly. The FDA review of the bottles will include analysis of product quality, consumer safety and environmental impact. ``I think recycling is one thing the cola warriors agree on totally,'' said Andrew Giangola, a spokesman at the Pepsi Cola Co.'s headquarters in Somers, N.Y. ``They are both working with the mutual goal of creating the most environmentally correct packaging.'' ``Producing new plastic beverage bottles with a blend of recycled plastic is a significant step ahead in plastics recycling,'' said M. Douglas Ivester, senior vice president at The Coca-Cola Co. Several companies have taken steps to reduce the amount of solid waste disposed of in landfills. McDonald's, in a highly publicized move, recently announced it will stop using plastic foam containers at its fast food restaurants. Coke and Pepsi already use recycled steel, aluminum and glass for packaging. Pepsi officials estimated that about one-third of soft drinks are in plastic bottles, though cans are the most widely used. Coke said its process, developed with Hoechst Celanese Corp., involves breaking down the bottle polymer into original molecules, then reconstructing the purified resin for use in making new bottles. Pepsi's bottles, to be made by Sewell Plastics Inc. of Atlanta, use Repete, a recycled resin based on ground soft drink bottles and produced by Goodyear. The material is put back together with raw materials to make the recycled bottles. Jesse Meyers, publisher of the industry newsletter Beverage Digest, said recycled bottles give the soft drink business a way to defend continued use of plastic amid fighting between the glass and plastics industries. Despite the pronouncements of concern for the environment, it's also a way to stimulate soft drink consumption by attracting publicity to the products, Meyers said. ``The cola wars, whether its rock singers, taste tests or packaging - it creates business for the industry,'' e said. ``The cola wars is the only war where there are no losers.''

DOC.HEAD: Sales Slide in Late November
With PM-Auto Sales-Tables
DOC.TEXT: Sales of North American-made vehicles tumbled 20.4 percent in late November compared with last year, mainly because of a sharp slump in truck sales. The decline reported Tuesday and recent announcements of production cuts for the rest of the year reflect a slumping auto industry as the U.S. economy softens. Among the Big Three automakers, Ford Motor Co. suffered the most, but General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp. didn't fare much better. Late November sales of Ford vehicles dropped 30.1 percent, GM's sales fell 22.5 percent and Chrysler's were down 17.4 percent. Combined, the Big Three and the seven Japanese companies making cars and trucks in the United States reported they sold an average of 29,510 vehicles during the Nov. 21-30 period this year, compared with a daily rate of 37,062 during the same time last year. The Big Three automakers held 68.3 percent of the market for the month. Light truck sales fell 28.5 percent and car sales dropped 15.2 percent. ``Sales have been fairly good this summer and fall,'' said auto analyst David Healy of the investment firm Barclays de Zoete Wedd in New York. ``That thump you heard was car sales falling out of bed.'' The late-November car sales rate was among the lowest of recent history, he said. ``You have to go back to early October 1982 to find a (sales) rate lower than that in the last 10 days (of November),'' Healy said. At that time, the U.S. economy was in the midst of a deep recession. For the month of November, with major overseas automakers included, combined car and truck sales were 4.3 percent behind last year's pace. Car sales fell 1.5 percent and truck sales were off 9.6 percent. The auto industry, indicating agreement with a softening economy, has cut production schedules for the rest of the year. GM Chairman Robert Stempel last week said he expects the giant automaker's fourth-quarter earnings will decline significantly from the third quarter, when the company earned $109 million, not including a $2.1 billion one-time loss it took for plant closing costs. Through the first 11 months of this year, total car and truck sales in the United States stood at 13.15 million, down 4.9 percent from the same time last year. The industry's slump began in the third quarter of last year and generally, sales rates for 10-day periods have been lower than year-ago periods. Ford suffered the most of the Big Three in this year's late-November reporting period for North American-made cars and light trucks. Automakers report sales of imported vehicles only on a monthly basis. Ford's combined sales of North American-made cars and trucks for late November were down 30.1 percent compared with last year. Company sales analyst Joel Pitcoff said part of the downturn stemmed from fewer fleet orders, including those from rental car companies, law enforcement agencies, taxi companies and big corporations. Through November of this year, Ford's cars and trucks were selling at a pace 7.7 percent slower than last year. GM said its combined car and truck sales for late November fell 22.5 percent. Through the first 11 months of the year, sales of GM's North American-made cars and light trucks were down 4.1 percent. Chrysler, which has suffered the most in this year's sales downturn, said its late-November car and truck sales were off 17.4 percent through November of this year, the company's combined car and truck sales were down 13.6 percent from last year.

DOC.HEAD: NCR Board To Meet on AT&T Buyout Offer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Board meeting scheduled to begin 9 a.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: With PM-AT&T, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NCR Corp. Chairman Charles Exley Jr. has told employees the computer maker isn't interested in a $6 billion buyout offer from AT&T but the company's directors will have its own chance to reject it. While the board unanimously rejected a previous offer of $85 per share from AT&T, it has yet to formally vote on a $90-per-share proposal. A board meeting was scheduled to be conducted by telephone today. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. announced its stock-swap offer to buy the NCR, the nation's fifth-largest computer maker, on Sunday. Exley said the deal made no business sense and that NCR had no interest in merging operations with AT&T. The telephone giant has said it may make a tender offer directly to shareholders if NCR's board doesn't act on the proposal by this evening. NCR stock, which soared nearly $25 a share on Monday, rose another $2 to $83.50 Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange. AT&T, which had fallen $2 a share, recovered slightly to close at $30.37{ a share, up 25 cets. In a speech to NCR employees Tuesday, Exley urged workers to have confidence in the ability of management to make decisions that are in the best interests of all who have a stake in the company. ``We have made it perfectly clear to AT&T and anyone else who cares to listen that we have no interest in being acquired, and we must face the fact that we may face a lengthy takeover battle,'' Exley told the workers. A union representing 110,000 AT&T employees encouraged NCR to oppose the buyout, saying the takeover could lead to layoffs at both companies if AT&T is forced to make cuts because of a high purchase price. ``I do not believe that AT&T's offer for NCR is in the best interest of your employee stakeholders nor those shareholders committed to the long-term business efforts of NCR,'' James Irvine, vice president of the Communications Workers of America, said in a letter to Exley. In another development, an NCR shareholder filed a lawsuit against the NCR board, alleging that the directors have breached their duty by depriving shareholders of the chance to increase the value of their stock. Sidney Kaufman of Cincinnati asked a local court to issue an injunction forcing the board to fully cooperate in any proposed transaction that would maximize shareholder value. Meanwhile, U.S. Senate officials said NCR officials have sought a meeting on Capitol Hill to detail their fears about the proposed buyout. Nancy Coffey, spokeswoman for Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said the senator's staff members have agreed to meet with NCR officials this week. Metzenbaum is chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on monopolies and business rights.

DOC.HEAD: Bondholders Top List of Continental Creditors
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of bondholders who financed the expansion of Continental Airlines over the past seven years top a 600-page list of creditors in a bankruptcy petition filed by the carrier. The Chapter 11 filing lists $620.5 million of Continental's $2.2 billion debt owed to bondholders. About $1.7 billion of Continental's debt is secured by collateral. Continental, the remnants of Frank Lorenzo's Texas Air Corp. empire, said it filed for the reorganization Monday in federal court in Wilmington, Del., because it was overwhelmed by its debts and surging fuel prices. Banks in California, Texas, New Jersey, New York and Switzerland are acting as trustees for the bonds, which are due between 1991 and 2005. Bank officials, who declined to be identified, said they had not yet seen a copy of the bankruptcy petition and declined comment. A creditors' committee is being formed to work with the bankruptcy court to restructure Continental's debt. The bonds issued by Continental make up the lion's share of the largest unsecured creditors listed in the petition. Others include Pratt-Whitney Canada Inc.; Dobbs International Services Inc., an airline food service vendor; American Express Co.; General Electric Corp.; and Boeing Co. The filing was the second time in seven years Continental has sought to reorganize. An analyst with Price Waterhouse said there was no limit to the number of times a company can file for protection from creditors, but a court must approve the move. In 1983, as Lorenzo was building Texas Air into what once was the nation's largest airline operator, Continental filed for protection from creditors amid a bitter labor dispute with its union. The firing allowed Continental to scrap union contracts and hire low-cost replacements for strikers. It also led to a change in federal bankruptcy law to make such a move more difficult. As of Sept. 30, Continental had $4.77 billion in assets and $5.85 billion in total liabilities, with $138 million cash on hand.

DOC.HEAD: Popularity Not Enough to Pull Catfish Industry Out of Slide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report and on general news wires; note Dec. 12 time element in 26th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Once considered river trash, the whiskered catfish is turning up in avant-garde restaurants and on fast-food menus from coast to coast. ``I eat in a lot of places around this country. ... Many of them now have catfish on the menu,'' says Craig Claiborne, cookbook author and retired New York Times food editor. Last year, sales of farm-raised catfish ranked the variety as one of the nation's top five seafoods, behind only tuna, shrimp, cod and Alaska pollock. But despite its rising popularity, the boon predicted for the aquaculture industry in the 1960s hasn't fully come to pass. ``The pie is getting larger, but the pieces are getting smaller,'' said Roger Barlow, catfish marketing director for the Mississippi Department of Agriculture. Nutritional value and the consistent taste brought by high-protein feed allowed the catfish industry to grow dramatically, but that growth also brought more competition, especially in processing, Barlow said. Catfish farmers also are facing rising costs, labor demands and softening sales. Catfish farming started in Mississippi in 1966 with 40 acres. Now, the industry is the state's fourth leading agricultural crop, contributing more than $300 million to the state economy in 1989. Many farmers in the Mississippi Delta region switched to catfish in the early 1980s because the traditional agriculture industry was slumping. Aquaculture allowed them to use their land and skills and brought new economic strength to the state. The new industry also provided thousands of new jobs for unskilled and semiskilled workers idled when machinery replaced many jobs throughout the Delta region. The state's catfish industry now employs more than 6,000 people, with an annual payroll of more than $76 million, according to The Catfish Institute in Belzoni, which is located in Humphreys County, ``The Catfish Capital of the World.'' This year, catfish operations in the state will raise, harvest and process more than 380 million pounds of fresh catfish. The fish is processed by 25 to 30 companies, most of which are in the state, including the nation's largest two. But a glut in processing forced four processing plants to close in 1989-90, and many processors say they are pinched by higher prices they pay to farmers. About 85 percent of the catfish supplied to processors in Mississippi is produced by members of the Catfish Bargaining Association, which fixes selling prices for processors. Processors are paying farmers 80 cents a pound this year, compared to 71 or 72 cents last year. Some processors say this year's price is about 10 cents too high. The nation's second-largest processor, Isola-based Country Skillet Catfish Co., has even threatened to expand into farming unless it can secure lower prices from farmers. ``If we're faced with no option, we'll start farming,'' said Dick Stevens, Country Skillet's president. ``We can't afford to buy fish at what prices are today. We have to buy raw materials relevant to market prices.'' Country Skillet's retail sales and sales of live fish are slowing because of the higher prices, Stevens said. ``I guess the farmers wanted to make a sackful of money,'' he said. ``Instead of creating a good situation, farmers have created a nightmare.'' Country Skillet, which is owned by food processing giant ConAgra Inc. of Omaha, Neb., is among the major catfish processors in the Delta region rebelling against efforts by farmers to control the price of whole fish. But many processors are cooperatives of catfish growers, who benefit from higher base prices. Delta Pride Catfish Inc. of Indianola - the nation's largest catfish processor - is owned by a 180-member farmer cooperative, and it supports fixed prices. That hasn't stopped workers from the United Food and Commercial Workers unions from going on strike at two Delta Pride plants. The workers walked out Sept. 12 after turning down a contract proposal offering a 4.8 percent average wage increase in the first year and pay increases averaging 35 to 90 cents per hour over the remaining two years of the pact. The workers, many of whom are unskilled or semiskilled black women, say the raises are not enough. Negotiations are to resume Dec. 12. The increased demand for catfish, due no doubt to its more refined taste and image, is one of the best safeguards that the industry will survive, Barlow said. In years past, the fishy-tasting river variety of catfish were caught with a cane pole with worm bait. They were cleaned, rolled in cornmeal and deep-fried, and usually served with hush puppies - small fried balls of cornmeal dough. Now consumers can buy pond-fed catfish in grocery stores as whole dressed fish, steaks, filets, strips and nuggets. Recipes offer ways to poach, barbecue, broil, smoke, stir-fry, fry, bake, steam, braise, stew, blacken, saute or grill dishes. ``French chefs I've talked with are fond of both the flavor and texture of pond-raised catfish,'' Claiborne said.

DOC.HEAD: Steelmaker To Idle 900 Workers at Cleveland Plant
DOC.TEXT: LTV Steel Corp. said it is closing three production units at its Cleveland plant and laying off about 900 employees because of weak economic conditions. The units include a blast furnace that will close Friday, and a steel production department and a direct rolling complex that will close by Sunday, the steelmaker said Tuesday. LTV Steel said the units would remain closed until market conditions improve. The company said about 90 percent of the affected workers had more than two years' experience and would continue to receive company benefits, including hospitalization and life insurance. LTV Steel, a subsidiary of Dallas-based LTV Corp., employs about 6,500 people at its Cleveland Works, the largest flat-rolled steel producing plant in North America.

DOC.HEAD: Defense in Commodities Trial Concedes Rule Violations But Denies Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Defense attorneys tried to impress upon jurors the distinction between rule violations and fraud as the 11-week trial of 10 soybean traders and brokers winds to a close. ``Violating a rule is not inconsistent with good faith,'' attorney Matthias Lydon told U.S. District Court jurors in closing arguments Tuesday. His client, Edward A. Cox, and the nine others are charged with racketeering conspiracy and fraud in their dealings at the Chicago Board of Trade. They were among 48 people arrested in a federal undercover investigation at the board and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The government has presented witnesses who testified that they participated in improper trading with the defendants or witnessed it. In their closing arguments, prosecutors scoffed at the concept of traders breaking the rules to benefit customers. ``These men intended to get money from customers under false pretenses,'' said Mark Rotert, an assistant U.S. attorney. ``They think things like ethics, fairness and the law are a matter of context.'' Defense attorney Jim Epstein conceded his client, Martin J. Dempsey, broke trading rules, but denied any intent to defraud, and instead insisted these violations often benefited customers at no one's expense. ``Did he violate the rules?'' Epstein asked rhetorically, referring to Dempsey. ``Absolutely. ``Did he attempt to commit fraud? Absolutely not.'' Epstein reminded jurors that testimony indicated many of the rule violations were an everyday practice on the trading floor. One such violation is curb trading, which occurs in the trading pit in the seconds or minutes after the closing bel. ``Sure, he did curb trading,'' Epstein said of his client. ``Is he proud of it? No. Did he try to conceal it? Of course, he did. ``But not because he was committing ... fraud, but because he was breaking the rules.'' The defense contends the prosecution tried to confuse the two issues, to trick the jury into believing that concealing what they were doing was a sign they were trying to cheat the customers. ``Curb trading has been going on for who knows how long. It goes on every day; it's no secret,'' Epstein told the jury. He said customers sometimes file orders just seconds before the close. And there's no way, he said, for a broker to comply without trading beyond the bell. At other times, Epstein said, a customer specifies his buy-or-sell order should be made at the closing price, which sometimes makes trading go beyond beyond the closing. ``So, people get the fill on the close,'' he said. ``Other than breaking the rule, you're not cheating anyone.'' On trial before Judge George Marovich, in addition to Dempsey and Cox, are Charles W. Bergstrom, Bradley Ashman, William A. Barcal III, Thomas P. Kenney, John Ryan, Joel J. Fetchenhier, Sheldon Schneider and John A. Vercillo.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Signed on Undersea Optical-Fiber Cable
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollars are U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Australia's government-owned overseas telecommunications carrier, OTC Ltd., signed a construction and maintenance agreement Wednesday with 35 other carriers to build the world's longest undersea optical-fiber cable system. The $620 million cable network will be built over the next four years and stretch more than 10,000 miles from Sydney to Hawaii through Auckland, New Zealand, and from Sydney to Guam. The South Pacific network cable will be able to handle more than 30,000 simultaneous telephone conversations, OTC said. OTC will be the biggest shareholder in the South Pacific network, which will join an optical-fiber network in the North Pacific forming a loop connecting the Pacific rim nations. Other companies taking part include TNI of New Zealand, KDD of Japan and American Telephone & Telegraph Co. of the United States. Officiating at the signing ceremony, Prime Minister Bob Hawke said the telecommunications loop would be of enormous economic significance to the region and its interaction with the rest of the world. Hawke also said the link would provide a conduit for the new privately owned telecommunications company which will compete with OTC and Telecom, the government-owned domestic carrier.

DOC.HEAD: Toy Store Plans To Delay Payments
DOC.TEXT: Child World Inc., trying to get through a cash squeeze, said it would delay paying for merchandise ordered before today until Jan. 15 and suspend payments on the principal on a $122 million credit line. However, the toy retailer said Tuesday it would make interest payments on its debt and pay cash for all merchandise ordered from now until Jan. 15. Child World also announced steep markdowns on its merchandise for the remainder of the Christmas season to raise cash. The move will result in the firm reporting a substantial loss for the year, the company said. Toy retailers are expected to pay for merchandise shipped as early as July by Dec. 10, but Child World is short of cash and has a $19 million bank payment due Jan. 1. Although it was delaying payment for merchandise already shipped, ``cash on hand, together with cash generated from operations, will be enough to assure vendors of prompt payment for new shipments,'' the company said in a statement. The retailer said it was negotiating for an extension of its working capital credit line until 1992. Company President Peter J. Hayes said discussions were being held with potential buyers of the company, including Trefoil Capital Partners LP of Los Angeles, the group that last month backed out of a deal to buy Child World for about $180 million. The retailer, with 182 stores in 32 states, is the second largest toy merchant in the country after Toys R Us Inc. It has annual sales of about $900 million. Child World reported a third quarter loss this year of $14.4 million on sales of $185.6 million, compared with a loss of $4.1 million on sales of $157.3 for the third quarter of 1989. The company's nine-month loss was reported as $30.3 million on sales of $466.5 million. It earned $5.8 million in 1989. The company owes Hasbro Inc. $40 million, Mattel Inc. $25 million and Tyco Toys Inc. about $20 million, The Boston Globe said today. Hayes said rumors that Child World may be close to filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection are false. ``We have value in excess of $200 million and no long-term debt,'' he said. ``After we get through Christmas, we will be in a much better position with cash.'' CNC Holding Inc., a private Cleveland company, owns 82 percent of Child World stock.

The stock market was mixed today, hesitating after its advance of the past three sessions. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 60.89 points from last Thursday through Tuesday's close, slipped back 4.45 to 2,575.25 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 10 to 9 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 490 up, 446 down and 553 unchanged. Big Board volume came to 24.35 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Stocks have been staging a yearend rally in recent weeks, encouraged by falling interest rates and steps by the Federal Reserve toward an easier credit policy. But analysts say investors have still been proceeding cautiously as they wait for more evidence about the prospective severity of the economic slump. Unsettling news is expected on Friday when the Labor Department issues its monthly report on the employment situation. If advance estimates are accurate, the figures will show a drop of as much as 100,000 in payroll employment and an increase in the civilian unemployment rate from 5.7 percent in October to 5.8 percent or 5.9 percent in November. NCR rose 2] to 85~ and American Telephone & Telegraph dropped [ to 30\. NCR has resisted takeover overtures made by AT&T earlier this week. On Tuesday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.11 points to 2,579.70. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of NYSE-listed stocks, with 907 up, 639 down and 457 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 185.82 million shares, up from 177.07 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Wal-Mart Planning First New England Stores
DOC.TEXT: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. is making its first foray into New England with five discount stores planned in New Hampshire and a wholesale club scheduled to open in Maine. Patrick Peery, Wal-Mart's real estate manager, said Tuesday the retailer chose New Hampshire as the site for the discount stores because the state has no sales tax. The new Wal-Marts will be located near the borders of Massachusetts and Maine to take advantage of shoppers from those states who come to New Hampshire to avoid their states' sales taxes, Peery said. The stores will be in Somersworth, Amherst, Derry, Seabrook and Hooksett. Wal-Mart also said it would open a Sam's Wholesale Club in Scarborough, Maine. Sam's Clubs are cash-and-carry warehouses open to managers and owners of other stores and to groups such as retirees. Wal-Mart, based largely in the Sunbelt and the Midwest, operates 1,527 discount stores in 35 states, including 146 Sam's Wholesale Clubs and four Hypermart-USA stores. The company is the nation's third-largest retailer, behind Sears, Roebuck and Co. and Kmart Corp.

DOC.HEAD: EC Given Deadline in Trade Talks
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Updates with new information, quotes, editing, no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The European Community was given a deadline of noon Thursday to draw up a new proposal for sharper cuts in agriculture subsidies and rescue deadlocked world trade talks, officials said today. Uruguayan Foreign Minister Hector Gros Espiell imposed the deadline after a series of meetings to try to find a way to move the stalled Uruguay Round negotiations. ``We're ready to move by noon tomorrow,'' said Hugo Paemen, a senior negotiator for the 12-nation trading bloc. ``The EC is discussing new agriculture proposals as well as proposals in other areas.'' But Ray MacSharry, the community's top farm official who has been a hard-liner in the negotiations, said, ``Our degree of flexibility is minimal.'' ``A lot of contracting partners need to rethink, not just the European Community. The EC cannot be expected to give in on everything,'' he told reporters. David Woods, spokesman for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which is sponsoring the talks, confirmed the action by Gros Espiell, who is presiding over the bargaining. ``He basically wants to see some new approach from the community by midday tomorrow in order to restart the negotiations,'' said Woods. The talks stalled Tuesday amid heavy pressure from the United States and other countries on the European Community to make deep cuts in farm supports. The talks also cover trade in services, textiles and other major areas. Woods said Gros Espiell disclosed his deadline in a series of meetings with trade negotiators to try to solve the crisis. U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Gros Espiell ``has informed folks that unless several of these major areas are essentially brought to a conclusion, or close to a conclusion, by tomorrow (Thursday) noon, we're never going to get finished.'' ``So in essence he's given the conferees until tomorrow noon to get on top of these major issues,'' Yeutter told reporters. Gros Espiell said Tuesday the talks were in a ``very serious impasse'' and started meeting with individual delegations to explore prospects for a breakthrough. Australia and Canada appealed to the European Community to back off its hard-line position opposing deep cuts in farm supports and save the 107-nation Uruguay Round, the most wide-ranging trade bargaining ever. Work continued behind-the-scenes to try to strike deals in some of the other 15 areas under negotiation, but officials conceded that little progress could be made until a solution was found to the agriculture dispute. ``I don't think anybody is going to commit themselves to anything while the negotiation is in this stage,'' said the GATT spokesman Woods. ``We are trying to see if there is any chance for movement in the areas that are blocked.'' The negotiations, kicked off in 1986 in the Uruguayan resort of Punta del Este, are designed to overhaul world trade in 15 areas, including agriculture, manufactured goods, textiles and services, such as telecommunications, transportation and banking. The latest week of bargaining, which opened on Monday, has been stalled by the European Community's refusal to go along with deep cuts in its extensive farm support program - as demanded by the United States and others. Attention focused on an evening meeting between German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand for any sign of a breakthrough on the agriculture problem. Leading up to the talks, France and Germany were the most resistant to deep cuts in farm supports. The German government had been worried about the farm vote in last Sunday's elections. Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke said he was ``imploring'' Kohl and Mitterrand ``to inject the political will and the courage which is obviously necessary to prevent a debacle in these negotiations.'' John Crosbie, Canada's trade minister, said, ``We would like to have Mr. Kohl and Mr. Mitterrand instruct (their negotiators) ... that their offer now has to be changed in accordance with what the rest of the world is wanting.'' There have been hints of cracks in the community's position opposing any but the most modest reductions in farm subsidies. Britain, the Netherlands and, surprisingly, Germany have urged more flexibility. Trade ministers of the 12-nation community were scheduled to meet in early evening to take a fresh look at the situation. U.S. President George Bush seemed to signal a willingness to give some on the American side. Bush, traveling Tuesday in Uruguay, said, ``We are not locked on a specific figure'' on how deeply farm subsidies should be cut. ``We are locked on the fact that there has to be inclusion of all categories (of products). In an October offer, the Bush administration proposed cuts in farm subsidies ranging from 75 percent to 90 percent over the next decade. Export subsidies, payments to promote sales of a country's products overseas, were targeted for the deepest slashes. The European Community so far has offered to snip only 30 percent from subsidies for major crops over 10 years, beginning in 1986. Some reductions already have been made, prompting U.S. critics to contend that much less than 30 percent would occur in the next five years. The Uruguay Round is the eighth in a series of negotiating sessions since World War II designed to reduce barriers to world trade. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade was established in 1947 as a forum and an agreement for promoting free trade.

DOC.HEAD: Government Approves Temporary Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: The Italian government on Wednesday authorized Olivetti to temporarily lay off 2,800 workers next month following a drop in international sales for the office automation equipment giant. But the government rejected an Olivetti request for a special early retirement program for 5,000 Italian-based workers. The group is trying to reduce its worldwide workforce by 7,000 to 47,000 in 1991. Budget minister Cirino Pomicino stressed that the retirement plan, calling for men to retire at 50 instead of 55 and women to leave at 47 instead of 50, would be an unbearable burden for the state pension fund. Olivetti, which is owned and managed by Italian financier Carlo De Benedetti, said that the layoffs, to begin in January, will be a temporary measure. But it did not disclose its duration. The 2,800 workers to be laid off will receive compensation of up to 80 percent of their original salary from a state fund. The powerful metalworkers unions called a five-hour strike in the Olivetti factories to protest what they called the company's one-sided decision on layoffs. Unions are also opposed to Olivetti's early retirement proposal. The company's managing director, Vittorio Cassoni, said the plan is not an option but is necessary to help Olivetti face the crisis in the computer industry. Analysts said that Olivetti's crisis is due to the growing competition of U.S. and Japanese manufacturers and to weak demand worldwide, which is severely affecting the major European makers of information technology. Office automation is not the only sector faced with a severe recession in Italy. Fiat, Italy's auto giant, has laid off about 70,000 workers this month to cut its production.

DOC.HEAD: USX Chairman: Company Faces Strike, Proxy Battle
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. Chairman Charles A. Corry said the company hopes to resum talks soon with the United Steelworkers union, but said the likelihood of a strike has increased. Speaking to financial writers Tuesday in New York, Corry said USX hoped to reach an early agreement with 18,000 union workers. Negotiators for the company and the union met this fall to try to work out a new pact. The current contract expires Jan. 31, and talks were recessed on Nov. 10. ``We had some negotiations. We made an offer. I don't think that offer was ever countered,'' Corry said. ``The early effort failed.'' Corry said one stumbling block is a union demand for a more lucrative contract than agreements reached with other steel companies. After his remarks, Corry told the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette he was unable to say if USX is willing to continue operating under a contract extension if the deadline is not met. ``You have a different situation than last time. It was concessionary bargaining then, so if you worked under the existing contract, you paid more,'' Corry said. ``This time it's really a question of if the steelworkers are willing to work under the existing contract.'' Corry also said he believes a proxy battle with financier Carl C. Icahn is inevitable. Icahn, the company's largest shareholder with a 13 percent stake, asked USX to restructure its steel and energy units before the annual meeting in May. Icahn has said he will seek to place five people on the board of directors to force the issue. ``I have to take him at his word,'' Corry said.

DOC.HEAD: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Board Elects Chairman, CEO
DOC.TEXT: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. has selected D. Leonard Wise, who has spent 33 years in the steel business, as its new chairman and chief executive, the company said. Wise, 56, of Pittsburgh, was named to the job Tuesday. He had been vice chairman of the board since April 23 and a board member since January 1988. He succeeds William J. Scharffenberger, who resigned Tuesday but will remain aboard to help accomplish the transition at the nation's eighth-largest steelmaker. Scharffenberger will continue as the ``responsible officer'' in leading the company from Chapter 11 status in compliance with a June 1987 federal bankruptcy court order, the company said. The company and the United Steelworkers union reached settlement in mid-August on a contract that expires March 1, 1994. The agreement was seen as a key to allowing the company to emerge from Chapter 11 status after five years. The Wheeling-based company employs 5,500 union workers and 1,600 non-union workers in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia.

DOC.NOTE: For release 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: Job Advertising Weakens Nationwide, Survey Shows
DOC.TEXT: Labor market conditions worsened in October with no sign of a quick turnaround, a leading business research group reported Wednesday in a monthly survey of help-wanted advertising. The Conference Board's Help-Wanted Advertising Index fell to 116 in October, six points below the September level and 34 points below the year-earlier level. The index's decline substantiated other assessments of growing trouble in the U.S. labor market, which has been beset by layoffs and reduced hiring plans because of an underlying economic decline that some are calling a recession. On Monday, for example, Manpower Inc., the world's largest temporary help firm, reported in a quarterly survey that hiring plans of U.S. companies will plunge to ``recession depths'' in the first quarter of 1991. ``The decline in the economy in the fourth quarter affords very little opportunity to develop new jobs,'' Conference Board economist Kenneth Goldstein said. ``Layoffs continue to climb, as does the national unemployment rate.'' The national unemployment level, which moved from 5.2 percent in June to 5.7 percent as of October, will likely climb to 6.5 percent in the second half of 1991, Goldstein asserted. The Labor Department is scheduled to release its figures on November unemployment this Friday. The Conference Board survey showed advertising volume in newspapers fell almost everywhere in the country, particularly in the Southeast with a 12.8 percent decline and New England with a 9.2 percent decline. The least affected was the Pacific region, but help-wanted ad volume there still fell 4.2 percent. More disturbing, the Conference Board survey suggested, was a 5.2 percent drop in help-wanted advertising in the Midwest, which has enjoyed relative prosperity in recent months because of a manufacturing resurgence and foreign demand for U.S. goods. ``There has been a significant deterioration in the labor markets of the Pacific and the South Atlantic,'' Goldstein said. ``Even more telling - job advertising declines are now firmly set in America's heartland.'' The survey assesses help-wanted advertising volume in 51 major newspapers across the country every month and is considered a sensitive barometer to changes in the supply of jobs. The Conference Board is a business-funded research organization based in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Propose Shakeup of Airport `Slot' Allocation
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's executive commission on Wednesday outlined a proposal toredistribute takeoff and landing ``slots'' at airports in the economic bloc. The proposal, intended to help smaller airlines compete in the increasingly congested EC market, has attracted widespread criticism from airlines. Sir Leon Brittan, EC commissioner for competition policy, said smaller airlines would be given priority for half of slots - landing and take-off spaces in the air-traffic pattern - that became available. He said that the ``sting in the tail'' of the proposal was that the commission could intervene in cases where it thought that slots weren't distributed fairly. The plan represented a ``concerted attempt by us to provide opportunities to smaller airlines who up to now have not had them,'' Brittan told reporters. Under the complicated proposal, slots allocated to but unused by bigger airlines at a particular airport would be distributed to smaller airlines, defined as those holding no more than 30 percent of slots there. Any airline not using more than 65 percent of its allocated slots would have to relinquish excess slots for redistribution, Brittan said. A problem with the proposal is that small airlines themselves are not sure it will work. Many say the existing system for allocating slots through traffic-scheduling committees run by the airlines works reasonably well. Another problem is that even if they gain more slots at busy airports, small airlines do not have large enough fleets to compete. EC Transport Commissioner Karel Van Miert said he did not know how many slots the major airlines would have to give up. ``It's very difficult because of the reciprocity between airports,'' he said. Under the proposal, if a new airline were granted a takeoff slot at one airport, it would have to be given a landing slot at another. The Commission would limit the number of new slots for new airlines to four each day.

DOC.HEAD: Propose Worker Councils For Europe-Wide Companies
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's executive commission Wednesday proposed requiring large firms operating in more than one member country to establish councils for consulting workers in decision-making. At the least, the councils would be forums where employes would be ``informed of, and consulted on, any management proposal likely to have serious consequences for the interest of the workers,'' the commission said in a statement. Individual EC nations have laws requiring companies to consult workers, ut there are no rules for companies operating in more than one EC nation. The Commission termed its proposal, which requires the approval of the 12 EC states before it can become law, an ``important moment'' in the 12-nation trade bloc's progress toward the 1992 internal market. Only companies operating in at least two EC states and employing at least 1,000 workers would be required to set up the ``Works Councils'' under the legislation proposed by the Commission.

DOC.HEAD: Saatchi Posts Annual Loss of 98.2 Million Pounds, Omits Dividend
DOC.TEXT: Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC, the world's second-largest advertising agency group, said Wednesday it lost 98.2 million pounds, or $166 million, in fiscal 1990, the biggest yearly loss ever for such a company. It was the second consecutive annual loss for the company that grew rapidly through acquisitions in the 1980s to become one of the biggest advertising and marketing services companies in the world. But the company stumbled when it branched out into the consulting business and has spent more than a year arranging sales of those operations. In announcing its huge loss, Saatchi also said it wouldn't pay a dividend to its shareholders this year. It paid a dividend of 9 pence, or 15 cents, a share a year ago. The company blamed the loss for the year ended Sept. 30 on its efforts to focus on its communications operations and to withdraw from consulting. ``Our withdrawal from consulting reduces our downside risk,'' the company said in a statement. Saatchi said it plans to concentrate on advertising, media buying, direct marketing and public relations. But Saatchi's operating results from communications businesses like these declined in the latest year. Results were strong in the United States and continental Europe, but sank in Britain and the rest of the world. The overall loss was the second annual loss in a row for Saatchi, which had previously bought ads of its own to tout its string of earnings gains. Saatchi lost 72.7 million pounds in fiscal 1989. Chairman Maurice Saatchi said in a statement ``1991 will be a difficult year for the group but when market conditions do improve I believe the group will be well positioned to benefit from the upturn.'' Advertising agencies generally have been hurt by the worldwide economic downturn. WPP Group PLC, the world's largest advertising group, last month announced that its pre-tax profit wouldn't match analysts' expectations of 110 million pounds, or $213 million, and the news sent the company's share price diving. Neil Blackley, an advertising analyst with the London investment firm James Capel and Co,. said, ``The outlook is very poor indeed with the U.S. economy weakening and the economies going down in mainland Europe and the impact on margins will be felt.'' Saatchi's ``financial position is not good. In order to survive the company is going to have to restructure'' debt of 176.5 million pounds, or $342 million, he said. The loss for fiscal 1990 reflected an extraordinary loss of 76.9 million pounds, or $130 million, on asset disposals, property provisions, and other expenses, compared with a loss of 58.5 million pounds on such items a year earlier. Pre-tax profit rose 63 percent to 35.6 million pounds, or $60 million, from 21.8 million pounds a year earlier. But the latest results were helped by substantially reduced restructuring costs compared with a year ago. The 1989 results included reorganization and streamlining of the group's communications division plus costs from its consulting business. Sales dropped 17 percent to 808.1 million pounds, or $1.37 billion, from 973.5 million pounds in fiscal 1989. Operating profit for its communications division fell 10 percent to 63 million pounds, or $106 million. Its U.S. communications activities had a 12 percent rise in operating profit while continental European operations posted a 25 percent gain. But the operating profit from British communications activities fell 48 percent and in the rest of the world, it fell 72 percent. Saatchi said that its two remaining consulting businesses will be sold when market conditions improve. They are Litigation Sciences Inc. of Los Angeles and MSL International, a London-based executive recruitment business. It completed the $70 million sale of Gartner Group Inc., a Stamford, Conn.-based market information company, earlier this year. The price was below Saatchi's original expectations. Saatchi's results were converted at an averaged exchange rate for the fiscal year of $1.69 to the pound.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's NTT Announces What It Calls World's Smallest Cellular Phone
DOC.TEXT: Japanese telecommunications giant Nippon Telegraph and Telephone said Wednesday it has developed a palm-size portable telephone that is the lightest and smallest in the world. The 8.1-ounce cellular phone, to be made by four Japanese electronics companies, can carry a continuous conversation for 45 minutes, NTT said. New miniaturized low-power circuitry is used to cut its size to 9.2 cubic inches, compared with 13.5 cubic inches for Motorola Inc.'s MicroTac telephone, it said. The MicroTac, which the U.S. company says is the world's smallest cellular phone, weighs 10.7 ounces and can transmit for up to 30 minutes with its slim-sized battery, and up to 100 minutes with a slightly thicker battery, Motorola spokesman David Pinsky said. Motorola introduced MicroTac two years ago. Pinsky, speaking from his company's Schaumburg, Ill., headquarters, said Motorola would have no comment on the NTT phone until it receives more information on it. ``The new phone comes out on top in all three areas - size, weight and battery life,'' said NTT's Kazuyoshi Terada. ``After feeling melancholy for two years, we now can feel proud about having the best portable phone.'' The phone is about one-third the size and weight of the smallest model currently marketed by NTT, Japan's main telephone company. It will be available in four designs containing the same NTT-developed circuitry, each manufactured by a different Japanese electronics firm. The four companies are NEC Corp., Matsushita Electric, Mitsubishi Electric and Fujitsu, NTT said. The phone features automatic dialing, message notification by either audio or light signals, and a selection of three different message notification tones. It also has a built-in electronic memory for storing up to 100 names and telephone numbers. NTT said it plans to begin marketing the telephone in Japan in April. Although it will not sell the phone overseas, the companies that participated in its development may market similar products outside Japan in the future, Terada said. NTT said it was able to reduce the volume of radio parts in the phone by about one-half by developing new high-density integrated circuits and reducing the size of other components. However, the phone contains two separate receivers and antennas, including one inside the case, and can automatically pick the stronger of the two signals to improve reception, it said. The phone saves battery power by automatically limiting transmission strength to the minimum amount needed. Transmission power is a maximum 0.6 watts, the same as in the MicroTac, NTT said. The new NTT phone, like most existing cellular phones, uses analog technology, while digital technology, which allows many more callers to use te service at once, is considered the wave of the future. Motorola's digital voice-coder technology was selected last summer as the future Japanese national standard, a move that helped defuse trade tensions over Japan's cellular telephone market. Those tensions also were eased when the Japanese government agreed in June to allow Motorola's analog cellular technology to be used on frequencies in the Tokyo area, which had been limited to NTT technology. Previously, Motorola supplied analog cellular equipment to NTT and other Japanese companies only outside Tokyo.
