DOC.HEAD: Lack of Progress in GATT Talks Weigh on Market
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed lower Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as concern over the lack of progress in the trade and tariff talks depressed the market. The lack of export business to the Soviet Union also weighed on the market, said Dan Cekander, an analyst with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. in Chicago. ``The market had been pumped up over all the talk of extending credits to the Russians,'' he said. ``(The market) remains optimistic it will happen. But it has settled back to wait.'' The extension of a U.S. credit package would allow the Soviet Union to buy badly needed grain. Cekander said there also was concern the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations, under way in Brussels, could collapse. The main obstacle is the demand by the United States and other countries that the European Community reduce farm subsidies. Analysts say a breakdown of the talks, scheduled to end this week, could result in a world trade war, which would hurt U.S. farm exports. At the close, wheat was a { cent to 2 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.43{ a bushel; corn was a \ cent to 1\ cents lower with December at $2.27 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2\ cent lower with December at $1.10{ a bushel; soybeans were 2{ cents to 9} cents lower with January at $5.93 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Holiday Inns Acquisition Helps Bass Profit, But Outlook Cloudy
DOC.TEXT: The acquisition of Holiday Inns has helped Bass PLC post a 23 percent jump in annual profits, but the U.S. hotel industry's downturn now is clouding the outlook for the world's largest hotel operator. Bass Chairman Ian Prosser told a news conference Wednesday, ``Overall, we are finding trading conditions difficult.'' In a statement, Prosser warned that ``unless there is a swift change in economic conditions leading to improved business confidence and an increase in consumer spending, we expect those conditions to prevail for most of 1991.'' Bryan Langton, chief executive of the company's Holiday Inn division, told reporters that U.S. hotels have been pressured by a slowdown in demand from both business travelers and vacationers. Langton cited the U.S. recession, but declined to quantify the effect on the company. Bass acquired the North American assets of Holiday Corp. for $1.98 billion in February after paying $475 million for its international hotels in 1988. The second purchase was clinched as the U.S. economy slowed. A glut of hotel rooms in the United States - whose 40,000 hotels make it the world's largest hotel market - now is forcing operators to cut rates to attract business. Langton maintained that Holiday Inns could weather a slowdown, citing Bass' strategy of segmenting the Holiday Inn product. It has been developing Holiday Inn Express, targeting the upper level of the economy class, for example. As many as 1,450 of Bass' hotels are located in North America rather than faster growing areas elsewhere in the world, making Bass vulnerable. But Langton said that fact that 1,365 of its 1,605 hotels are franchised rather than owned or operated will help insulate the company. Bass also has better financing and is not as indebted as some of its competitors, and Holiday Inns is a strong brand name, he said. ``Our relative strength gives us the opportunity to outperform the market,'' Langton said. Bass said its net profit for the year ended Sept. 30 came to 470 million pounds, or $808 million, compared with 382 million pounds, or $657 million, in the same period a year earlier. Earnings per share came to 109.6 pence, or $1.89, compared with 92.7 pence, or $1.59. Pre-tax profit rose 15 percent to 535 million pounds, or $920 million, from 465 million pounds, or $800 million. Revenue climbed 10.5 percent to 4.46 billion pounds, or $7.67 billion, from 4.04 billion pounds, or $6.95 billion dollars. The group's hotel operations saw operating profit jump 69 percent to 127 million pounds, or $218 million, from 75 million pounds, or $129 million. Holiday Inns accounted for 103 million pounds, or $177 million, of that 1990 profit. Bass didn't provide the year-ago figure. Langton said Holiday Inns' profit had met the company's expectations, and he said Holiday Inns' performance improved over the year. Holiday Inns occupancy rate increased 0.9 percent over the previous year, and outperformed its competitors in the middle of the market, he said. Bass' brewing operations also experienced strong growth, rising 21 percent to 177 million pounds, or $304 million, from 146 million pounds, $251 million. Its brands include Carling Black Label, Lamot Pils, and Tennents. The company said it had 108 million pounds, or $186 million, of one-time costs because of the British government's decision to force brewers to focus either on brewing or pub operations. The decision, aimed at fostering more competition in brewer-owned pubs that sell their own beers, means Bass will have to sell or free up 2,680 pubs by November 1992. Bass' 6,886 pubs make the company Britain's largest pub owner. The company also has smaller interests in betting and soft drinks. Bass didn't break out results for the latest quarter or second half of the year. It isn't required to under British law. The figures were converted at company-provided exchange rate of $1.72 to the pound.

DOC.HEAD: Falls to Lowest Level in More than Three Months
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEDES with five new grafs to show oil sharply lower, picks up 2nd graf, Cable News...,minor editing changes thereafter to conform
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell more than $3 per barrel today to the lowest level in more than three months on news that Iraq would discuss a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. With just minutes left to trade on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude, the key grade of oil, was down $3.31 at $27.35 per barrel on contracts for delivery in January. The exchange said crude had last traded below $28 per barrel for next-month delivery on Aug. 31. Oil came crashing down in the afternoon when the U.S. government said Iraq had accepted its offer for high-level diplomatic talks on the desert standoff that began when Iraq seized neighboring Kuwait Aug. 2. ``That's what pushed it through,'' said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. ``There was some good selling at that point.'' Earlier, oil prices were down more than $2 per barrel today on a television report indicating negotiations might bring a peaceful end to the Persian Gulf crisis. Cable News Network reported this morning that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was feeling enormous pressure to withdraw from Kuwait and quoted a ranking Iraqi source it did not identify as saying, ``All issues are on the table, everything.'' After opening lower following Tuesday's British television report indicating Iraq might have a plan for pulling out of Kuwait, crude started moving up when Secretary of State James A. Baker III warned Congress that delaying war with Iraq could be harmful, should war become necessary. The CNN report then prompted crude to reverse direction, said Christian Gohler, a broker at Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. Contracts for oil delivery in later months were all moving down, though not as dramatically as the January crude. Futures for refined petroluem products were also tumbling this afternoon. Home heating oil dropped 3.25 cents to 83.65 cents a gallon on contracts for delivery in January. Unleaded gasoline fell 4.32 cents to 71.60 cents a gallon on contracts for delivery in January. Oil's drop in New York followed a fall in London that came in reaction to an unconfirmed report that Saddam may be willing to leave most of Kuwait in exchange for a disputed oil field on their border and a guarantee that Western forces would not attack Iraq. U.S. and British officials said they had heard nothing of the proposal reported by Sky Television News, which quoted unnamed sources close to what it called negotiations between Iraq and senior international mediators. Brent crude oil, the British benchmark grade, opened about $1 lower then drifted slightly higher on January contracts as traders refused to respond strongly to the report. ``They've reacted in a very placid sort of way,'' said Geoff Pyne, an oil trader at UBS Phillips and Drew. ``If the Sky News report was believed by the markets it would have dropped three or four dollars.'' ``The thing that was interesting about the Sky report - there seemed to be so much detail ... that it was too good to be true,'' Pyne said. ``It could be some sort of a smoke screen to make the West think he (Saddam) is going to pull out and it buys him time.'' The Sky News report jolted traders in New York shortly after the market closed on Tuesday, but it had apparently been discounted this morning, at least until the CNN report was aired and the oil pit turned bearish.

The stock market gained more ground today, extending its advance of the past three sessions as the price of oil tumbled. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 60.89 points from last Thursday through Tuesday's close, rose another 15.10 to 2,594.80 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 947 up, 538 down and 499 unchanged. Oil prices dropped and stocks picked up new forward momentum after word came from the State Department that Iraq had agreed to hold talks with President Bush on the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Crude oil for January delivery fell more than $3 a barrel, to the neighborhood of $27.50 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Stocks have also benefited of late from falling interest rates and steps by the Federal Reserve toward an easier credit policy. But analysts say investors were still proceeding cautiously as they wait for more evidence about the prospective severity of the economic slump. Unsettling news is expected on Friday when the Labor Department issues its monthly report on the employment situation. If advance estimates are accurate, the figures will show a drop of as much as 100,000 in payroll employment and an increase in the civilian unemployment rate from 5.7 percent in October to 5.8 percent or 5.9 percent in November. Bank stocks were strong for the second straight session following the Fed's announcement Tuesday of a reduction in reserve requirements on some commercial deposits. Citicorp gained 1] to 15}; Chase Manhattan 1[ to 12|; BankAmerica 1{ to 26, and Chemical Banking ~ to 13]. NCR rose 2] to 85~ and American Telephone & Telegraph dropped ] to 30. NCR has resisted takeover overtures made by AT&T earlier this week. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 1.22 to 179.41. DOC.HEAD: Beverage Company Posts 11.2 Percent Earnings Rise in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The Seagram Co. Ltd. said Wednesday its profit rose 11.2 percent in the third quarter, helped by strong international beverage sales growth, lower orange juice costs and a bigger dividend from the DuPont Co. The Montreal-based producer of liquor, wine, coolers, fruit juices and soft drinks said it earned $189 million, or $2.01 a share, in the three months ended Oct. 31 compared with $170 million, or $1.77 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 9.2 percent to $1.5 billion from $1.4 billion a year earlier. Edgar Bronfman Jr., president and chief operating officer, said the company had strong sales growth in its Seagram International operation, aided by currency translations. Operating income from the company's Tropicana division benfited from lower orange juice costs, he said. The company had $66 million in dividend income from its 24.5 percent stake in the DuPont Co., up 15.8 percent from $57 million a year earlier. Seagram's equity in unremitted earnings from DuPont fell 11.6 percent to $61 million from $69 million a year earlier. For the first nine months of the year, Seagram earned $581 million, or $6.16 a share, up 2.8 percent from $565 million, or $5.84 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the first nine months rose 7.8 percent to $4.2 billion from $3.9 billion a year earlier. Among Seagram's brands are Chivas Regal and The Glenlivet Scotch whiskeys, Crown Royal and Seagram's V.O. Canadian whiskeys, Martell Cognacs, Sterling Vineyards Wines, Seagram's Coolers and Tropicana Pure Premium Orange Juice.

DOC.HEAD: Court-Appointed Trustee Uses Personal Approach
DOC.TEXT: Eight months after arriving at Eastern Airlines with the cold title of court-appointed trustee, Martin R. Shugrue has come to personify the company while taking a place in its tradition of colorful and controversial bosses. Shugrue enjoys obvious support, and even admiration, from employees at a carrier known for labor-management strife. He's also making new friends for Eastern among travel agents and other key industry players and, he admits, has become something of a celebrity. ``I'm no shrinking violet (but) I don't like being recognized on the street. I can't go anywhere. I can't have a private dinner in a restaurant,'' Shugrue said. ``But it's worked for us.'' Along the way, though, he's antagonized the Eastern creditors by fighting off their push to liquidate the carrier. And he's made few friends among union leaders, who say he broke his promise to settle the disputes leading to the March 4, 1989, strike that nearly paralyzed Eastern and pushed it into Chapter 11 bankruptcy five days later. While Eastern's future remains very much in doubt, Shugrue at least has bought time for last-ditch marketing efforts to take effect. Last month, he persuaded the bankruptcy judge to release another $135 million from the company's escrow account, which Eastern says will pay operating costs through March. An innovative ``100 Days'' advertising campaign and subsequent ads, based on footage of Shugrue talking with workers, passengers and reporters, has portrayed Shugrue as a straight-talking magnetic leader. Some Shugrue backers say he's succeeded in giving Eastern a scrappy, positive image. ``Americans always like an underdog,'' said Philip Davidoff, president of the American Society of Travel Agents. ``When you see an underdog really fighting for so long, you say let's give them a chance.'' ``His presence is probably the only thing that's kept the airline in business,'' said Helane Becker, airline analyst for Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``He's brought to the employees a sense of stability ... a sense of ability, and clever insight.'' Shugrue's personalized effort to save Eastern has brought inevitable comparisons to the Chrysler Corp. chairman. ``He's out Lee Iacoccaing-Lee Iacocca,'' Davidoff said. Several employees mentioned the comparison in a recent mass meeting inside an Eastern hangar. ``If I could get $2 billion worth of federal loan guarantees, I'd show you a turnaround,'' Shugrue replied, referring to the government loans to the automaker in the early 1980s. The employee meeting was a virtual lovefest, with many of the workers' ``questions'' just expressions of gratitude to Shugrue. ``We really feel he's out to save the company,'' said reservations agent Mario Gomez. James Ashlock, a vice president and 25-year veteran of the airline, said Shugrue has for the first time given Eastern a proud, enthusiastic workforce that believes its management wants the same thing it does. Ashlock's past bosses at Eastern included World War I flying ace Eddie Rickenbacker, Apollo astronaut Frank Borman and airline entrepreneur Frank Lorenzo, who was replaced at the Eastern helm by Shugrue. Shugrue, whose tenure also has seen the departure of some of Eastern's most unpopular executives, claims he used a simple approach, telling his managers to ``get out on the ramp and tell the people what you expect of them.'' ``And I did it by example, I went out and talked to employees,'' he said. ``I think (when) CEO's get into a crisis situation, the more visible they become in taking command of the crisis, the more successful they're going to be getting out of it. ``There's no secrets, no magic to it. It may be Leadership 101 - getting in front and leading.'' However, Shugrue agreed his feelings about Eastern are stronger than he would have ever expected the Sunday last April when he came out of the shower in his Houston home to take a telephone call from bankruptcy court examiner David Shapiro. At age 50, Shugrue was heading a successful independent consulting group. Nonetheless, Shugrue was well-versed about Eastern's woes. He was a pilot and long-time executive at Pan American World Airways and then president of Continental Airlines, Eastern's parent which this past week sought federal bankruptcy protection. Taking over as trustee the same week as Shapiro's phone call, Shugrue said he quickly found Eastern's financial situation was even worse than he thought. ``We were staggered by what we found - a company bleeding to death; horrible media, liquidation stories, advance bookings were zero; long-range planning at Eastern was Tuesday.'' But Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland in New York told Shugrue he wanted Eastern saved. ``And a funny thing happened. In a very short amount of time, I fell in love with 18,000 people,'' Shugrue said, saying he was moved by the employees' dedication and willingness to sacrifice. Whether Shugrue would enjoy the same rapport with those who have been on strike 21 months seems doubtful, but he said he'd like to settle the labor disputes and insisted: ``We can convert anybody.'' Shugrue, from working-class roots in Providence, R.I., says he has no anti-union bias. The flight attendants and pilots unions ended their sympathy strikes more than a year ago. Most flight attendants are back at work, but only 125 union pilots have been returned and the pilots union is battling Shugrue in federal court to get more jobs back. Machinists union leader Charles E. Bryan said Shugrue, who cited ``labor peace'' as a top priority when he was appointed, has only gone through the motions of negotiating and really doesn't want to settle. The Machinists say they will continue picketing, urging a boycott of Eastern and challenging Shugrue. Graffiti painted on an Interstate 75 overpass north of Miami, complains: ``Shugrue makes $35,000 a month. Eastern loses $2 million a day. Is this anyway to run an airline?'' Meanwhile, many airline analysts praise Shugrue and his ``corporate rate'' strategy that lures business travelers with expanded first-class service at discount fares. However, most are skeptical about whether Eastern can survive during what appears to be an industry shakeout. Creditors' attorney Joel Zweibel said they believe liquidation is inevitable. Shugrue plays down employee pleas for him to stay past his trusteeship. He won't answer directly on whether he would stay on if asked by Eastern's new ownership, when that comes. Although rarely in short supply of self-confidence, Shugrue does at times seem surprised at how far he's come. He chuckled when one listener at a Fort Lauderdale civic and business club asked whether he was interested in a screen career. ``I'm just an unemployed pilot trying to sell some airplane tickets,'' he replied.

DOC.HEAD: Mickey Greets Public as Euro-Disneyland Looks to 1992 Opening
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: MARNE-LA-VALLEE, France (AP) - Mickey Muuse made his official bow to the French public Wednesday, inaugurating a welcome center for Euro-Disneyland's theme park and resort complex opening in 1992. Fireworks exploded above the wintery noon sky as Mickey and the band of Disney characters greeted guests at the colorful complex known as ``Espace Euro-Disney'' - Euro-Disney Space - an information center to familiarize the public with the park. ``Espace Euro-Disney is our first real opportunity to bring the message of this exciting project directly to our audience,'' said Euro-Disneyland President Robert Fitzpatrick. Espace Euro-Disney, a fantasy-like building topped with a blue magician's hat, sits on the edge of the construction site, 20 miles east of Paris. It provides a glimpse of the theme park through attraction mock-ups, a scale model of the complex, a ``Fantasia'' boutique and a preview film of the park's attractions in a viewing room. Mickey is to make daily appearances there. Euro-Disneyland will be the second overseas home after Tokyo for Mickey and the Disney clan, including Goofy, Donald Duck, and Huey, Dewey and Louie. It is expected to draw visitors from all over Europe with up to 11 million visitors projected for the first year. Scheduled to open in the spring of 1992, Euro-Disneyland is the core of a complex that includes a second theme park, Disney MGM Studios-Europe, more than 18,000 hotel rooms and other facilities that will spread into the rural hinterlands by the year 2017. The more than $3 billion complex, crowned by Sleeping Beauty's Castle, will have six hotels, an entertainment center, a camping ground and an 18-hole golf course. Much of the park will be covered to protect visitors from the often inclement weather of the Paris region. ``We learned a lot having operated in Japan,'' said Executive Vice President Jim Cora, who noted that the Tokyo theme park was lacking in weather protection. What would an American visiting Euro-Disneyland think? ``I think they'd think we've reached a new level of sophistication,'' Cora said.

The stock market forged ahead today, extending its advance of the past three sessions as the price of oil tumbled. Oil prices dropped and stocks picked up new forward momentum after word came from the State Department that Iraq had agreed to hold talks with President Bush on the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Crude oil for January delivery fell more than $3 a barrel, to the neighborhood of $27.50 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Stocks have also benefited of late from falling interest rates and steps by the Federal Reserve toward an easier credit policy. But analysts say investors were still proceeding cautiously as they wait for more evidence about the prospective severity of the economic slump. Unsettling news is expected on Friday when the Labor Department issues its monthly report on the employment situation. If advance estimates are accurate, the figures will show a drop of as much as 100,000 in payroll employment and an increase in the civilian unemployment rate from 5.7 percent in October to 5.8 percent or 5.9 percent in November.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Moves Communications Division Headquarters to Britain
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. said Wednesday it would move the headquarters of its worldwide communications division to Britain from suburban New York. The division will be the first of IBM's business lines to be based outside the United States, spokesman Peter Thonis said. He said it is part of IBM's drive to become more international, and also is a recognition of the major growth potential in European communications equipment sales. The division provides hardware and software products used to link computers in networks and to manage these networks. It also provides products that mix voice with computer applications. IBM said the move from Somers to suburban London will enable the world's largest computer company ``to better serve its customers in the global telecommunications marketplace.'' The move, which will involve about 120 people, is expected to be completed by the third quarter of 1991. The division, called Communications Systems, is headed by IBM Vice President Ellen M. Hancock.

DOC.HEAD: Iowans Press Ahead with Pan Am Buyout Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 10th graf with official no-comment from Pan Am
DOC.TEXT: Airline analysts were skeptical Wednesday about plans by an Iowa group to raise $1.5 billion to buy Pan American World Airways and move its headquarters to northeast Iowa. ``I'd give this a long shot at occurring,'' said Robert Decker, an analyst for Duff & Phelps in Chicago. He said it would be nearly impossible to raise the money needed for the buyout, especially in light of Pan Am's tottering finances. A Waterloo-based investment group proposes to sell at least 300,000 bonds in $5,000 denominations to buy Pan Am, according to Pan Am airline Capt. Neil Sapp, 51, of Miami. That would be equivalent to borrowing half the annual state budget for Iowa. Speaking Tuesday in Waterloo at a luncheon attended by 175 northeast Iowa business and government officials, Sapp said the effort should not be taken lightly. ``We would like to make a solid offer in January,'' he said. ``We're not crazy; we're just innovative.'' Sapp and Samual Nodarse of Cedar Falls, a retired University of Northern Iowa professor, formed the Iowa Acquisition Group and said they would buy the company on condition that its headquarters move from New York to Waterloo. ``We're the white hats, the good guys,'' Sapp said. ``We're not just someone who wants to buy it for its assets, then run away from it with the profits from that.'' He said money raised through the sale of bonds would be invested with Iowa banks, primarily in certificates of deposit, with the interest used to pay off loans from investment bankers. Investors would get interest when bonds mature in nine years. Sapp predicted a ``very high probability of success.'' Spokeswoman Pam Hanlon at Pan Am's headquarters in New York said company policy is to decline comment on reports of mergers and acquisitions. Industry analysts disagreed with Sapp's prediction. ``In today's market, it would be difficult to raise that kind of money for an airline like Pan Am,'' Decker. ``We're in a period where debt markets are cautious and conservative. ``There's not a lot of funds available nd Pan Am would certainly be a high risk company to do a buyout on at this stage.'' he said. Thomas Canning, who follows airlines for Standard & Poors Corp. in New York, said, ``Selling the bonds might be difficult. And I don't know what Pan Am might say about it. They've been looking for a buyer for two years and have not been able to make a deal. ``I don't want to say there's no chance, but it's a little wild,'' Canning said. ``It's been difficult finding somebody interested in buying the whole company.'' Pan Am has been losing money for years. It recently agreed to sell key London routes and some other assets to Chicago-based UAL Corp., parent of United Airlines, for $400 million.

DOC.HEAD: Crayola Has Another Surprise: Top Crayon Maker Colorblind
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBs 4th graf to include Moser's title and add that the company name is Binney & Smith Co.
DOC.TEXT: Crayola company officials might be turning a little red, make that fuchsia, with news that its top crayon maker is colorblind. Emerson Moser, who is retiring next week after 35 years, isn't colorblind in the sense that he can't see color at all. It's just that some colors are confusing to him. That means trying to spot the difference between a cadet blue and a blue green can make him feel, well, like a shrinking violet. ``If you have a serious case of it, you could foul up a lot of materials,'' said Moser, 63, who has made a record 1.4 billion crayons. His title at Binney & Smith Co., the official name of the company that makes Crayolas, is a crayon molder. As far as Moser and the company can tell, there's been no threat of children coloring the sky green and the grass blue - unless they were doing their Andy Warhol imitations. ``He's blue-green colorblind, but despite his handicap, he's gone to the top of his trade,'' said Brad Drexler, spokesman for the Easton-based company. Moser has made seas of salmon, pecks of plums and is a king crayon craftsman, Drexler said. Tuesday, Moser made yards of yellow and Wednesday, it was oodles of orange - colors that give Moser no trouble. ``When you have shades of one color, you get a little doubt about it. Before you go do anything, you double-check yourself,'' said Moser. It's the second technicolor shock to come out of the Crayola plant this year. In August, it retired eight traditional colors into the Crayola Hall of Fame. The company is asking Moser to donate his final pair of ankle-high boots, splashed with the waxy colorful remains of his time on the job, for inclusion in the hall. ``The colors splash a little bit when it comes out of the kettle into the bucket,'' said Moser. ``People daily clean their shoes, but I don't. I have a multicolored pair of shoes. It's probably made them waterproof. ``This pair I have now ... there's yellow on them, because I worked yellow today, and some orange and some red,'' Moser said in a telephone interview Tuesday. A company doctor detected Moser's slight vision problem during a physical conducted when he was hired Oct. 12, 1953, as a floor boy in the packing department. ``It's so slight that if the doctor wouldn't have tested me, I probably would have never noticed it,'' Moser said. Less than two years later, Moser graduated to the most colorful job in the world, pouring molten wax into 2,400-crayon molds nearly 100 times a day. Once the wax is set, crayons are flicked out of the racks and stacked in a bin for a conveyor belt to carry them to a labeling machine. At Crayola, there are subtle shades of everything. But can anyone over age 12 really tell the difference between violet and blue violet, cornflower and navy blue, blue green and cadet blue, sepia and brown, orchid and thistle, or mulberry and red violet? Other colors to worry about are the new shades of cerulean (a type of blue), dandelion, fuchsia, jungle green, royal purple, teal blue, vivid tangerine and wild strawberry. They replaced blue gray, green blue, lemon yellow, maize, orange red, orange yellow, raw umber and violet blue last summer. For less than obvious reasons, Moser likes the eight basic Crayola colors: black, white, red, yellow, green, blue, brown and orange. He even liked the eight retired colors, which now are remembered only in 5-foot-tall models at the hall of fame. But Moser says there is no reason to wax nostalgic about retiring the crayon colors. ``The new ones are nice. They really stand out when you color with them,'' Moser said. ``The other colors were nice, too. You grew up with them and got used to them, but you can't survive on sentiment. Sentiment doesn't keep a company moving forward.''

DOC.HEAD: Factory Orders Jump in October
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 5 grafs additional details
DOC.TEXT: Factory orders for manufactured goods bounced up 2.8 percent in October, the government reported Wednesday, but analysts said the jump mostly was due to the transportation sector and the higher cost of oil. ``The October numbers are about as good as the factory orders are going to look for awhile,'' said economist Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co. International in New York. Like many analysts, he believes the economy is in a recession. ``The strength was mostly in aircraft and in non-durable price increases,'' added Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI-McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass. ``I don't see any reason to become particularly hopeful on the basis of this report.'' The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and non-durable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $250.7 billion after a revised 0.2 percent decline the previous month. The revision showed September orders even weaker than the 0.1 percent gain initially reported. Transportation orders jumped 14.8 percent to $37.9 billion, reflecting gains in both the aircraft and automobile industries. But aircraft orders tend to be volatile and analysts pointed to reports that car production was falling at the end of November. ``Discounting transportation, orders rose just a modest 0.9 percent,'' noted economist Thomas Runiewicz of the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. Factory orders are a key economic barometer of the manufacturing industry. A decrease may forecast a slump in that sector and future job layoffs. Durable goods - products like autos that are expected to last more than three years - were up 3.9 percent to $129.8 billion after dropping 1.6 percent in September and 0.9 percent in August. But Brusca said October total still was below the $131.7 billion level reached last December and added: ``The orders situation is really pretty bleak.'' Indeed, a survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management on Monday said its index of new manufacturing orders dropped to 39.4 percent in November - the lowest level since it stood at 38.1 percent in May 1982 during the last recession. Forty-three percent of the purchasing managers surveyed said their firms had fewer new orders in November. Only 18 percent said their orders increased and 39 percent said they were unchanged from October. Non-durable goods orders rose 1.6 percent to $120.9 billion, with the largest increase in petroleum refining, the department said. The price of oil bounced above $40 a barrel at one point during October but since has fallen back. One possible bright spot was in the key category of non-military capital goods, often a barometer of business investment plans. Orders there gained 8.7 percent to $41.6 billion following a 6.8 percent advance in September. The often-volatile defense orders fell for the second straight month, down 9.4 percent to $7.1 billion following a 6.1 percent decline a month earlier. Excluding the defense component, orders were up 3.2 percent. Orders for other durable goods included primary metals, up 5.5 percent to $12.0 billion, and electrical machinery, up 3.1 percent to $19.8 billion. But non-electrical machinery orders were down 1.5 percent to $22.2 billion, Inventories inched up 0.1 percent to $377.3 billion. Shipments gained 1.7 percent to $247.5 billion and unfilled orders were up 0.6 percent to $522.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar turned in a mixed performance Wednesday as foreign exchange traders anxiously watched the Middle East situation and the U.S. economy. Gold prices declined. ``The markets are still very nervous about peace, war, peace, war'' and the dollar has fluctuated accordingly, said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager with Bank of New York Co. The dollar advanced against most major currrencies in Europe after Secretary of State James Baker reiterated demands for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee the United States would strike ``suddenly, massively and decisively'' if military force is needed to remove Iraqi troops from Kuwait. The dollar has gained in recent weeks amid signs that Middle East tensions were increasing. But it has also fallen as those tensions seemed to dissipate or as the markets had second thoughts about how serious the situation really is. The dollar generally advances during times of international turmoil because some investors view it as a safe-haven currency. But the dollar was held down Wednesday by the faltering U.S. economy and the belief that interest rates in this country will fall. A Federal Reserve survey released Wednesday showed the economy in all regions of the country was either declining or growing sluggishly at the end of last month. Traders believe the Fed will be forced to lower interest rates. That would be a negative for the dollar, which like all currencies is supported by higher rates. In New York trading, the dollar advanced against the British pound and the Japanese yen. Sterling fell to $1.9260 in New York from $1.92925 late Tuesday. In earlier London trading, the pound fell to $1.9225 from $1.9350. The pound is also facing the prospects of lower interest rates. The dollar rose to 133.625 yen in New York from 133.30 late Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell 0.93 yen to 133.42 yen, and it was quoted later in London at a higher rate of 133.95 yen. The Japanese economy is seen as particularly vulnerable should war break out in the Midle East and disrupt oil supplies. Japan imports nearly all its oil. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.49925 German marks, down from 1.5030; 1.2795 Swiss francs, down from 1.2825; 5.0770 French francs, down from 5.0825; 1,127.685 Italian lire, down from 1,129.25; and 1.16295 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16325. Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late rates Tuesday included: 1.5025 West German marks, up from 1.4942; 1.2835 Swiss francs, up from 1.2750; 5.0898 French francs, up from 5.0570; 1.6955 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6933; 1,130.75 Italian lire, up from 1,124.00, and 1.1623 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1632. In New York, gold fell $4.70 to $374.20 on the Commodity Exchange, and Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $372.75, down $3.50. Gold fell earlier in London to a late bid of $372.65 a troy ounce from $378.20 late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $374.50 an ounce from $377.40 late Tuesday. In Hong Kong, gold rose 95 cents an ounce to $377.04. Silver fell 0.3 cent in New York to $4.148 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange. The metal fell in London to a late bid of $4.16 a troy ounce, down from $4.18 late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Kodak Seeking Joint Venture for Sterling Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. is talking with several companies about forming a joint venture with its Sterling Drug subsidiary, officials said Wednesday. Kodak spokesman Paul Allen confirmed that French pharmaceutical giant Sanofi S.A. is among the companies with which Kodak is negotiating. ``Sterling has been talking to several companies about an alliance, and Sanofi is a company that Sterling is talking to,'' But Allen said no agreement had been reached ``and there's no assurance that any will.'' He would not comment on other companies with which Sterling is talking or what kind of joint venture is being sought. Sterling makes Bayer aspirin, Phillips' milk of magnesia, Midol pain relievers and other over-the-counter products. Its best-selling prescription drug is Omnipaque, which highlights body organs during X-rays and CAT scans. Kodak acquired Sterling for $5.1 billion in 1988, hoping the drug company would help offset sluggish growth in the photography business. Analysts have expressed dissatisfaction with Sterling's failure to produce new drugs or the kind of profits Kodak had expected. But Allen said the negotiations do not reflect unhappiness with Sterling's performance. ``They're right on target. Their performance is right on plan,'' he said. ``We said they would be contributing to the cash flow by the end of 1989 and they are.'' Kodak President Kay Whitmore has said the company won't sell Sterling or buy another pharmaceutical company, but would look for other ways to improve Sterling's performance. The Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday that sources close to the talks said an agreement between Sanofi and Sterling could be reached by the end of the year. Allen would not comment on a timetable for the talks. The newspaper said a number of other pharmaceutical companies may be considering a joint venture with Sterling, including F. Hoffmann-La Roche & Co., Ciba-Geigy AG and Sandoz AG, all based in Switzerland; Bayer AG of Germany; and Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France. If Sterling and Sanofi create a joint venture, Sterling probably would market a number of Sanofi drugs in the United States, and at the same time get a larger share of overseas markets, the Journal said. The newspaper said Sanofi, which is 60 percent owned by France's state-controlled Elf Aquitaine oil company, has been looking for a U.S. distribution network to launch several drugs in the mid-1990s.

DOC.HEAD: IEA: OPEC's November Oil Output Down 1.2 Pct from Pre-Invasion
DOC.TEXT: OPEC's crude oil production was down 1.2 percent in November from levels before Iraq invaded Kuwait, the International Energy Agency reported Wednesday. The 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries produced 22.9 million barrels a day in November, despite the U.N. embargo against oil produced by Iraq and Kuwait, both OPEC members, the agency said in a report released in London. The November figure was 300,000 barrels per day less than in July, just before the Iraqi invasion, and up 600,000 barrels a day from October, the report said. The IEA said that among OPEC producers, Saudi Arabia's output was 7.9 millions of barrels a day, an increase of about 300,000 barrels a day over October. Iran boosted production to 3.3 million barrels a day, up 400,000 barrels a day from October, the report said. Iraq produced 400,000 barrels a day and Kuwait prodced 100,000 barrels a day, despite the worldwide ban on importing oil from the two countries. The Paris-based organization said increases in production came from greater output in heavier, high-sulphur grades. World oil supplies outside countries with centrally planned economies totaled 53.8 million barrels a day in November, up from the revised October total of 53.2 million barrels a day, the IEA said. That was the second monthly rise since levels were depressed in August and September, following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Production in Western countries that are members of the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development rose slightly to 16.1 million barrels a day, mostly from increases in North Sea and Australian output. Oil producers within the OECD include the United States, Britain and Norway. Soviet oil exports suffered a larger-than-expected seasonal drop. After averaging about 1.7 million barrels a day during the first nine months of the year, Soviet crude exports to the OECD countries have dropped to about 1.4 million barrels a day since September, the agency reported. The IEA said the normal seasonal drop of Soviet exports to the OECD in the fourth quarter of the year to meet rising winter domestic demand was this year reinforced by falling output and a drop in deliveries to eastern Europe, caught in a hard currency crunch. ``Soviet deliveries to all destinations from the Black Sea ports in October were at the lowest level since January and early indications suggest a further fall to less than 0.9 million barrels a day in November,'' the agency said. Outside the OECD, the IEA expects oil consumption to average 15.3 million barrels a day, up from 1989's level of 14.7 million barrels a day. It projects oil consumption for the world outside the centrally planned economy countries to average 53.1 million barrels a day, an increase of 800,000 barrels a day from its 1989 level.

That marked the highest close for the average since it stood at 2,625.74 on Sept. 12. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,087 up, 485 down and 446 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board reached 205.82 million shares, up from 185.82 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 252.68 million shares. Oil prices dropped, and stocks picked up fresh forward momentum, after word came from the State Department that Iraq had agreed to hold talks with President Bush on the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Crude oil for January delivery fell more than $3 a barrel, to the neighborhood of $27.50 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Stocks have also benefited of late from falling interest rates and steps by the Federal Reserve toward an easier credit policy. But analysts said investors were still proceeding cautiously as they wait for more evidence about the prospective severity of the economic slump. Unsettling news is expected on Friday when the Labor Department issues its monthly report on the employment situation. If advance estimates are accurate, the figures will show a drop of as much as 100,000 in payroll employment and an increase in the civilian unemployment rate from 5.7 percent in October to 5.8 percent or 5.9 percent in November. DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Plunge on Increased Prospects Mideast Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices plunged Wednesday on New York's Commodity Exchange on perceptions that developments favor a negotiated settlement of the crisis caused by Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. Also helping to push gold lower was the steep plunge in crude oil prices, with the January contract down $3.37 a barrel. On other markets, grains and soybeans fell and livestock and pork futures climbed. Gold prices began their plunge on reports from Paris that French Foreign Minister Randolph Dumas said the permanent members of the U.N. Security Council would meet soon to discuss a Mideast peace plan. An announcement by the State Department that Iraq accepted President Bush's offer to hold talks on the Persian Gulf crisis reinforced peace sentiments. ``Perception that developments in Middle East favor negotiation rather than otherwise, sent gold prices down sharply,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, an analyst with Prudential Bache Securities Inc. in New York. Ms. Raptopoulos said the possibility of a peaceful solution to the crisis sent crude oil prices plunging, adding to the selloff in gold. Investors usually buy gold during periods of uncertainty because its value is universally accepted. Ms. Raptopoulos noted that platinum and silver suffered minor losses. ``The end of a war situation will be good for platinum and silver because those are industrial metal,'' she said. Gold settled $4.60 to $4.80 lower with the contract for delivery in February at $375.80 a troy ounce; silver was 3 cents to 6 cents lower with March at $4.238 a troy ounce. Crude oil prices plunged on New York's Mercantile Exchange on word of the various diplomatic moves. Analysts said oil prices also were influenced by reports from energy experts of ample supply of oil in coming months. And they say a report expected from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Counties indicating demand for oil will decline in coming months added to the bearish tone of the market. Light sweet crude was 84 cents to $3.37 lower with January at $27.29 a barrel; heating oil was 4 cents to 5.76 cents lower with January at 81.14 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 4.55 cents to 7.08 cents lower with January at 68.84 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures prices closed lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as concern over the lack of progress in the trade and tariff talks depressed the market. The lack of export business to the Soviet Union also weighed on the market, said Dan Cekander, an analyst with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. in Chicago. ``The market had been pumped up over all the talk of extending credits to the Russians,'' he said. ``(The market) remains optimistic it will happen. But it has settled back to wait.'' The extension of a U.S. credit package would allow the Soviet Union to buy badly needed grain. Paul Dickerson, the Agriculture Department's general sales manager, said Wednesday the decision on whether to grant export credit guarantees to the Soviets is still under review. Cekander said there also was concern the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations, under way in Brussels, could collapse. The main obstacle is the demand by the United States and other countries that the European Community reduce farm subsidies. Analysts say a breakdown of the talks, scheduled to end this week, could result in a world trade war, which would hurt U.S. farm exports. Wheat was a { cent to 1} cents lower with December at $2.43{ a bushel; corn was 1\ cent lower to a\ cents higher with December at $2.27 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2{ cents lower with December at $1.10 a bushel; soybeans were 2{ cents to 9{ cents lower with January at $5.92{ a bushel. Livestock futures climbed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as cash prices held firm, while pork futures were higher on the perception that Tuesday's sharp selloff was overdone. Live cattle were unchanged to .47 cents higher with December at 79.07 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .40 cent higher with January at 87.72 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .75 cent higher with December at 49.62 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .17 cent to .45 cent higher with February at 64.10 cent a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Steinberg Concerns Holds 2 Percent Stake in UAL
DOC.TEXT: New York investor Saul Steinberg, once a major holder of the stock of UAL Corp., has again bought into the parent company of United Airlines, according to documents disclosed Wednesday. A subsidiary of a Steinberg family-controlled concern, Reliance Group Holdings Inc., disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has purchased 451,000 shares of UAL common stock. The filing, covering the quarter ending Sept. 30, disclosed that the subsidiary - Reliance Financial Services Corp. - paid more than $43.9 million for the shares. But the document is not required disclose exactly where or when the purchases were made. ``As a policy, we don't comment on our investment,'' said Brian Martin, a spokesman for New York-based Reliance. In Chicago, UAL spokesman Joe Hopkins also declined comment. Steinberg was a big investor in UAL stock before an employee buyout plan fell through in October 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Paul Pursues Appeal as Regulators Set New Bond Deadline
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys prepared an emergency appeal Wednesday to keep thrift regulators from seeking a $30.8 million bond from ousted CenTrust Chairman David Paul, a symbol of wasteful opulence in the savings & loan crisis. Paul, whose lavish ways propelled him into the public eye, has been a target of regulators since they took over Florida's one-time largest thrift in February at an estimated loss of $1.8 billion. The Office of Thrift Supervision, which charged that Paul surrounded himself with luxury ``to satisfy his insatiable greed and vanity,'' sought the huge bond to prevent him from squandering money from the failed CenTrust. The government initially set a Nov. 1 deadline for payment of the bond, but Paul won some time by challenging the administrative order in U.S. District Court. His arguments were rejected Tuesday, and OTS set a new deadline of noon Thursday. But Steve Davis, a Paul attorney, said Wednesday that an appeal was being prepared for the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. Paul's attorneys charged the government was forcing him to pay restitution without a way to defend himself against claims he used bank funds for his personal use, but U.S. District Judge Edward Davis rejected those arguments. The judge upheld the application of the 1989 S&L bailout law against Paul, rejected arguments that OTS was improperly pursuing enforcement actions without benefit of due process or trial, and cited an ``important governmental interest'' in protecting depositors' interests. ``The ruling is clear. The constitutional arguments were completely without merit,'' OTS attorney Faith Hochberg said in a telephone interview from Jersey City, N.J. ``We believe it was a proper order from the beginning and have followed proper judicial proceedings throughout.'' OTS wants Paul to post the $30.8 million bond, file an accounting of his assets and seek OTS approval of any change of personal assets involving $5,000 or more. Among questionable CenTrust spending cited by OTS are a $15 million legal defense fund for thrift officers and directors, CenTrust's sumptuously appointed 47-story office tower in downtown Miami, Old Masters paintings and a private dinner cooked by European chefs flown in for the occasion.

DOC.HEAD: Report: US Must Get Serious About Computer Security Before It's Too Late
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 14-15: ``A ``virus,'' to explain computer terms
DOC.TEXT: So far, the country has been lucky. There have been viruses, worms, logic bombs, Trojan Horses and other computer scams but no successful, systematic attempt to subvert the systems that are so essential to modern society. However, says an expert on computer security, ``there is reason to believe our luck may soon run out unless we take action now.'' A committee of the National Research Council spent 1{ years looking into the state of computer security and found systems and information in danger, and society, in turn, at risk. It issued a 300-page report Wednesday, titled ``Computers at Risk.'' ``We have in many cases left computer systems unprotected from a wide variety of current and future threats to their integrity,'' committee chairman David D. Clark told a news conference. ``National computing and communications systems are vulnerable to potentially catastrophic ecurity breaches and accidental failures,'' he said. Contending that the nation has been lucky, he said, ``The committee concludes that tomorrow will not be like yesterday.'' Horrible examples abound: -For 10 months in the mid-1980s, a West German nicknamed ``Wily Hacker'' attacked 450 computers operated by the U.S. military and its contractors, successfully gaining access to 30. He allegedly had ties to the Soviet KGB, the NRC report says, and it was assumed he was looking for sensitive data. -In 1988 a ``worm'' paralyzed thousands of computers in the Internet, a network that links 60,000 computer systems used in university and other research. Robert Morris of Arnold, Md., is appealing his conviction in federal court for unleashing the program. -A software design error froze much of American Telephone & Telegraph's long distance network. -The German Chaos Computer Club broke into the NASA Space Physics Analysis Network. -An error in computer software controlling a radiation therapy machine, a Therac 25 linear accelerator, resulted in at least three patient deaths. -More than 26,000 diskettes that featured AIDS prevention information but were infected with a hidden computer virus were mailed to hospitals, businesses and government agencies worldwide. There have been thousands of reported virus attacks and hundreds of different viruses identified, such as Stoned, Devil's Dance, 1260, Jerusalem, Yankee Doodle, Pakistani Brain, Icelandic-2, Ping Pong and December 24, the committee said. A ``virus'' is a computer program, usually hidden, that attaches itself to other programs and has the ability to reproduce itself. Viruses generally are ``Trojan Horse'' programs which, when executed, result in undesired side effects unexpected by the user. ``Logic bombs'' are Trojan horses activated by a particular event in the computer, perhaps even the occurrence of a particular date. A ``worm'' is a program that distributes itself in multiple copies within a system or into connected systems. A worm attack might exploit security vulnerabilities in a system or cause denial of service to the computer user. Clark said the committee, which had 16 members from universities, industry, computer manufacturers and security firms, is concerned about a blase attitude among most in the U.S. business community. ``Many people still use easy-to-guess passwords such as their first name, or they use common English words that can be `guessed' by a determined hacker with a computerized dictionary,'' he said. ``Attacks based on these weaknesses are commonplace today.'' The committee recommended six key actions, a major one being creation of a private, non-profit organization to develop system security principles, supporting research, maintain a tracking system of threats and foster training of computer security agents. ``The modern thief can steal more with a computer than with a gun,'' the NRC report says. ``Tomorrow's terrorist may be able to do more damage with a keyboard than with a bomb. ``Thus far we have relied on the absence of malicious people who are both capable and motivated. We can no longer do so. We must instead attempt to build computer systems that are secure and trustworthy.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Takes Dixon Bank Fraud Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury began deliberations Wednesday but reached no verdict in the bank fraud trial of Don R. Dixon, who owned the Texas savings and loan that was one of the first costly failures of the thrift crisis. Vernon Savings Association collapsed in 1987 at a cost to taxpayers of more than $1.2 billion. Dixon, who owned Vernon from 1981 to 1986, was charged in 38 counts with misusing thousands f dollars of the thrift's money for political contributions, a California beach home and prostitutes. The combined charges carried a maximum penalty of up to 190 years in prison and fines of up to $9.5 million. In closing arguments, attorneys on both sides urged jurors to focus on legal questions presented in the case, not on the savings and loan crisis. U.S. District Judge A. Joe Fish then read more than 40 pages of instructions before the eight-woman, four-man jury began considering more than five weeks of testimony. The jury was out part of the afternoon before quitting deliberations for the day. Government attorneys portrayed Dixon as a ``master manipulator'' of Vernon and its employees. Assistant U.S. Attorney David Jarvis told jurors the case was a ``classic story of power and wealth that caused Don Dixon to lose his moral bearings.'' Dixon schemed and used sham documents to render the disputed dealings unaccountable to regulators and its board of directors, Jarvis said. ``If these are legitimate deals, why wouldn't (Dixon) put them on the table?'' he asked. Defense attorney Billy Ravkind said prosecutors, through their choice of witnesses, had ``embraced people even a child would know are lying.'' He called the government's investigation of Dixon ``sloppy'' and said it focused on ``a few minor transactions in a multibillion-dollar business.'' The 38-count indictment was a ``script'' that prosecutors had to act out, Ravkind said. Jarvis said Dixon's defense focused on which ``drawers from the cash register'' the thrift owner got his money. ``What's he doing in the register? What is Don Dixon doing tapping Vernon's till?'' the prosecutor asked. Government attorneys brought more than 20 witnesses to the stand and introduced hundreds of documents over four weeks. Dixon and a handful of others testified in his defense during the last week. Dixon testified that Vernon employees were responsible for the crimes for which he is accused. He said he had no knowledge of illegal activity at the thrift. Dixon said the beach house near San Diego was used as a hotel by the thrift's owners. He said he knew escorts were hired for parties attended by Vernon officers and borrowers at the house, but said he did not know who paid for them. In testimony about trips on which thrift officers took Linton Bowman, former commissioner of the Texas Savings and Loan Department, Dixon said he helped arrange for a female Vernon employee to be a date for Bowman. Providing the date was ``probably inappropriate, but at the time I did not think so,'' Dixon testified.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Seek Beer-Making Jobs
DOC.TEXT: the discussions are on the verge of breaking down. ``It is a stalemate and it is serious,'' said a grim-faced U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. Officials said there would be another effort at a breakthrough Thursday. ``High noon is tomorrow (Thursday),'' said Canadian Trade Minister John Crobie. ``If there is no change, then it is over.'' The trade ministers emerged just before midnight from a two-hour meeting in which they sought in vain for a compromise position on the expensive subsidies that developed countries pay to their farmers. An Indian official, Commerce Minister Subramanian Swamy, was pessimistic, saying, ``It looks like they are heading for suspension.'' If the talks are broken off, even for a brief time, it would put the entire four-year effort at trade reform in jeopardy because of the tight deadlines negotiators had faced to submit a completed document to the U.S. Congress. The dispute pitted the 12-nation European Community against much of the rest of the world, including large farm exporters such as the United States, Brazil and Argentina. European officials had been expected Wednesday to agree to at least a modest expansion of their offer to reduce internal farm support payments by 30 percent. Instead, the Europeans emerged from their separate meeting saying they had decided to make no further offer on farm subsidies until the United States made compromises on other issues. There had also been hope that the European position might change as a result of a meeting Wednesday night in Paris between German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand. But following that discussion, no new offer was announced. Crosbie described the mood inside the discussions as ``somber'' and said the meeting Thursday would determine whether there was any point in continuing the talks. ``We are going to have to decide whether we are going to give it all up or not,'' he said. The farm subsidy fight evolved as the biggest stumbling block to conclusion of the most ambitious round of trade liberalization talks ever undertaken. The negotiations, known as the Uruguay Round for the country where they began in 1986, had been scheduled to wrap up Friday after five days of marathon bargaining. But after three days the talks remained stalemated and some delegations talked openly about the possibility of giving up and going home. ``The United States has got to recognize that this is a negotiation between equals, not a group of people to be pushed around in this way,'' said British Agriculture Secretary John Gummer. Otto Schlecht, Germany's deputy economics minister, said, ``We have no reason to go to the Americans on our knees.'' Gummer said the Europeans had insisted on American compromise offers in areas including trade in services, textiles and investment to be made at the same time that discussions went forward on the farm issue. He said the U.S. side had rejected that proposal. U.S. officials said the Europeans were engaging in a desperate attempt to shift the blame for failure of the negotiations. ``What is holding up the negotiations here is that the European Community has not yet provided a proposal on agriculture,'' U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said. The European Community entered the negotiations offering to trim domestic farm support payments by 30 percent. The United States, supported by major farm exporting countries, was seeking much deeper cuts of 75 percent in domestic supports and import barriers and a 90 percent cut in export subsidies. The trade talks, the eighth in a series of negotiations dating to 1947, offered the promise of lowering prices for consumers while at the same time boosting economic prosperity, especially in Third World countries with farm-based economies. The United States has argued that without sufficient progress in agriculture, developed nations will not be able to win concessions from Third World countries to reform their trade practices including agreement on tough new rules to protect against copyright piracy, something that costs American businesses an estimated $60 billion in lost sales annually. Negotiators spoke pessimistically about a failure of the talks, which many fear could trigger a rise of protectionism and global trade wars, similar to the events of the 1930s that were blamed for making the Great Depression more severe. ``Anyone who does not admit that the round is in deep crisis is just deluding themselves,'' said Australian Trade Minister Neal Blewett.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Broadcasting Corp. Takes Big Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Government-run Canadian Broadcasting Corp. announced a major reduction in operations Wednesday, including the reduction of 1,100 jobs. The radio and television broadcasting company said a budget shortfall of 108 million Canadian dollars, or about $93 million, for the fiscal year starting April 1 forced it to take the austere steps. Besides the job cutbacks, CBC said it would close three stations, in Toronto; Goose Bay, Labrador; and Matane, Quebec. In addition, CBC said it will reduce the operations of eight other stations and could not longer finance the cost of operating Radio Canada international, a short-wave service. The Canadian government said it would seek alternate ways of maintaining the international radio service. CBC said no layoffs of regular employees were contemplated before April 1.

DOC.HEAD: HMO Emerges From Chapter 11 Reorganization
DOC.TEXT: Maxicare Health Plans Inc. said Wednesday it had emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization profitable and at half its old size. The health maintenance organization said it made money in quarter ending Sept. 30, its first profitable quarter in four years. ``Our company is viable because we focused on the basics of arranging for accessible quality health care at a reasonable costs,'' Maxicare Chairman Peter J. Ratican said in statement. Maxicare's recovery includes signing up such firms as Bank of America Corp., Price Waterhouse, Sears, Roebuck & Co., and Stanford University, the firm said. Maxicare operates in California, Indiana, Illinois, Louisiana, North Carolina, South Carolina and Wisconsin. It filed Chapter 11 reorganization plans 21 months ago. Within a year after the filing, it sold or closed plans with more than half its original membership. The U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Santa Ana, Calif., confirmed the reorganization plan on Aug. 31. The plan calls for creditors and shareholders to receive about $130 million in cash, 10-year notes at 13.5 percent interest with a face value of about $67 million, and common stock and options. More than half of the HMO's creditors and shareholders approved the proposal. Forty-nine percent of the restructured company will be owned by medical facilities and doctors.

DOC.HEAD: Bankrupt Developer Convicted on Corruption Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Thursday in lede is cq
DOC.TEXT: George Herscu, one of Australia's richest men until his Hooker Corp. fell on hard times, was convicted Thursday on corruption charges. The 62-year-old Romania native was found guilty of paying $77,000 in 1983 to a Queensland state cabinet minister to try to ease access restrictions to a failing shopping center. Herscu had pleaded not guilty to two charges of official corruption. He claimed he made the two $28,500 payments to Russ Hinze, who at the time was a state minister for roads, to buy him two racehorses. The now-bankrupt Herscu appeared unmoved as the Brisbane District Court jury delivered its verdict at the end of a four-week trial. Sentencing was scheduled for Friday. A Romanian Jew, Herscu worked in Nazi labor camps during World War II until being liberated by the Soviet Army in 1944. He moved to Australia in 1950. As a 25-year-old in 1953, Herscu bought one small grocery store then others, including one at the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. In 1959, he went into property development. In 1986, Herscu took over Hooker Corp., Australia's premier property developer with substantial U.S. interests. He took out loans and spent $1 billion, in part on up-market American retailers, including Bonwit Teller. The U.S. subsidiary, L.J. Hooker Corp., has disposed of the bulk of its retail holdings acquired since 1986, including Bonwit Teller and other department store chains. After being steered into shopping-center developments in the United States, Hooker grounded on a $1.5 billion debt in July 1989. Both Hooker and Herscu's personal company, Hersfield Developments Corp., went into liquidation. In July, Herscu and his wife, Sheila, declared themselves bankrupt. The move came two days before a bankruptcy claim made against them was to be heard in a Melbourne court. Documents filed with the court showed Herscu had total debts of more than $382 million and assets of only $1.5 million. Once among the social elite of Melbourne, Herscu was forced to move out of his Toorak mansion, an extravagant home that was based on ``Tara'' from the movie ``Gone With The Wind.''

DOC.HEAD: Higher Fuel Costs, Weak Dollar Blamed for Hike on RCA, GE TVs
DOC.TEXT: Thomson Consumer Electronics said Wednesday it was raising factory prices on RCA nd GE brand color television sets, big-screen TVs and camcorders because of increased fuel costs and a weak dollar. The company said the 3 percent price hike would take effect in February. It blamed on rising oil and gasoline costs from the Persian Gulf crisis and the decline in the value of the dollar against foreign currencies for the increase. Thomson said the cost of materials purchased in Japan and Europe have risen sharply because of the weak dollar, which makes it more costly to buy foreign-made materials. Thomson is suffering ``tens of millions of dollars in annual costs that are not reflected in today's pricing structure,'' said Martin J. Holleran, chief executive of Thomson's Sales and Marketing Co.-Americas. Rising energy costs have adversely affected the costs of transportation and raw materials such as glass, plastics and chips, he said. Holleran said unit sales of color television models are declining and the prospects for future growth in the smaller screen sizes are limited. Industry growth is focused on larger screen models as consumers seek a theater environment in the home, he said. While manufacturing costs have climbed, color TV prices in the last 10 years have declined more than 27 percent, Holleran said. Thomson manufactures RCA and GE brand consumer electronics.

DOC.HEAD: Company Announces Tentative $460 Million Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 15th graf pvs, `A spokesman... to UPDATE with comment from supporting lawyer; PICKS UP 16th graf, `The company...
DOC.TEXT: Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. announced a tentative agreement Wednesday to pay $460 million over 20 years to victims of asbestos disease, but plaintiffs' lawyers rejected the plan as too small. Eagle-Picher faces 65,000 claims by workers made ill inhaling asbestos fibers in a key case in the attempt to clear a nationwide court backlog stemming from liability over the cancer-causing mineral. Cincinnati-based Eagle-Picher said it reached agreement with two of four lawyers appointed by U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein in New York to negotiate a settlement with the company. Last month, some plaintiffs' lawyers rejected a proposal that offered a reported $500 million to victims over the same time period, and the same attorneys said they would oppose the new proposal. Under the plan, Eagle-Picher would create an independent trust to resolve asbestos claims. The company would contribute $30 million in the first year, $20 million per year for the next nine years and $25 million per year in the following 10 years. The plan would take effect in November 1993. In addition, the trust would receive preferred stock that could be converted after five years into 25 percent of Eagle-Picher common stock if the company's meets the payment plan, and 50 percent if it does not. Eagle-Picher also would set aside 6.75 percent of its net sales each year to provide for basic operations. A hearing was scheduled for Friday on Eagle-Picher's request that Weinstein declare a class-action to resolve the claims on grounds the company cannot meet its asbestos liabilities. A similar request has been made by the Manville trust fund, the nation's largest asbestos resolution facility, which faces about 130,000 claims but has run out of money to settle new cases. A proposal to restructure the trust is pending. Dozens of other former asbestos users are watching the cases closely. Peter Angelos, one of the four plaintiffs' lawyers appointed by Weinstein to negotiate with Eagle-Picher, said the latest proposal ``wasn't even worthy of consideration.'' ``The obligations of the company are minimal in relation to the number of persons who have sustained serious injury by way of occupational exposure to its products,'' the Baltimore attorney said. The plan was backed by attorneys David Shapiro of New York, who is representing future claimants, and Stanley Chesley of Cincinnati, who was added to the negotiating group only last month. Angelos said he and the fourth attorney, Henry G. Miller of New York, were not consulted about the plan announced by Eagle-Picher. ``This proposal is millions of dollars less and has millions less in value than one rejected last month,'' Angelos said. He placed the present value of the proposal at under $200 million and the company's potential total potential liabilities at more than $1 billion. A spokesman for Eagle-Picher could not be reached for comment. Chesley defended the plan, saying that the $460 million fund, combined with $45 million to pay previously negotiated claims and and estimated $178 million from the company's net sales make it worth well over $600 million. He said the tentative Eagle-Picher settlement will protect plaintiffs if the company has to seek bankruptcy court protection. ``This ... is a combination of cash, money, guaranteed income and equity,'' he said. ``That's a plus.'' The company has been inundated with lawsuits from people who say they suffered cancer and respiratory problems from exposure to an asbestos-based pipe sealant the company made primarily for ships from 1934 to 1971. Eagle-Picher has said it faces insolvency if it does not settle the claims, and said in a statement Wednesday that ``liquidity will continue to be a serious concern for the next several months.'' The company also said it would seek to sell some assets and receive accommdations from lenders for a period. Eagle-Picher has said it has paid more than $500 million in settlements and legal fees. Asbestos defendants want claims be made class actions to reduce legal fees they say are exhausting assets that otherwise could be used to compensate victims.
